text: This is a good quality, fine-to-medium grained file.  I've used it on wood and metal, and it works great on both.  The handle is comfy and seems durable enough.  For the price, it's a steal.
Nice sticker - good size, nice, thick plastic, looks great on my car.  No issues.

We have a 13 lb. Havanese, and he figured this thing out after using it a couple of times.  Now we feed him his meals from it, and he gets super excited when he sees anyone pick it up.  We generally keep the holes wide open, because his kibble can get stuck, otherwise.  It now takes him around 10 minutes to eat, instead of maybe a minute (if that).This is made of hard, durable plastic.  It WILL make a lot of noise on a hard floor, but I don't find it that bad - usually he's eating while I'm cooking supper, or he's eating breakfast while everyone is getting ready in the morning.  We also feed him in the next room so that the cats can eat without being bothered.My only issue is that I wish it was easier to fill.  Putting a few snacks or a small amount of kibble is fine, but trying to load the full small scoop for his dinner is a little time consuming.  But it's not so bad that I will remove a star, because this thing's a hit.

It's such a simple thing, but it works beautifully for what it does.  In the past I've washed my rice right in the pot from the rice cooker.  This uses a lot more water and seems to take forever.  This bowl allows the water to drain slowly, and the results so far (3-4 batches of rice made) seem to be superior.  No starch scorching on the bottom of the cooker, rice is less "gloopy".  Overall, a noticeable improvement.Plus, it's well made and I see no reason why it won't last forever.  I just rinse it after using, and don't put it in the dishwasher.
It's a battery, and it works.  The battery died on my wife's LG phone.  This replacement shipped fast and works fine.

I'm not usually interested in these "match 3" games, but I was in a mood one day and gave this one a try.  Well, it's awesome.  It's different enough that it feels like its own thing, and there's enough strategy to keep me coming back.  My wife got addicted, too, and within a couple of weeks she'd already completed the whole game.  I'm still moving slowly through the medium puzzles, but I maybe play a puzzle a day.

This is very good, fresh-tasting curry powder.  It is very mild (no one else in my family likes spicy food so that's all I can get) and has what I would consider the "typical" curry flavor that is common in the US.  I've used this for meats, vegetable dishes and soups, and it's worked very well in every dish I've tried.

From looking at some of the negative or mixed reviews, I think people have unrealistic expectations for this little guy.We've been using this for about 2 months in our bathroom (about 8 x 10).  The bathroom has a small window that opens and a (pretty much useless) ventilation fan, but we still get mildew on the ceiling over time.  The bathroom gets strong afternoon direct sunlight, but it still has trouble drying out, for whatever reason.First, this small unit does not work as quickly as a large compressor-based unit.  The reservoir will fill in about 2 days, if left running constantly.  There is a small amount of noise - and I mean it's very minor.  I don't see how anyone could complain that this is noisy.  It has to have a fan to circulate the air, and it produces a low-level hum in the background.  When it's running we can still have conversations with the kids when we're brushing teeth before bed, etc.  It's a very minimal amount of noise.The unit has a smallish, fairly narrow wall-wart, which isn't too obtrusive, but it does take up more space than a standard plug.  Not a huge deal.Removing and draining the reservoir is very easy.The pattern we've followed this summer is that we open up and air out the bathroom after a shower, then the window is left open just a crack, and the door is mostly closed while the dehumidifier runs.  Within a few hours there is a noticeable difference in the feeling of the room.  We generally leave it running all night, and during the day when we're home.  We generally get half a reservoir of moisture every day, and while it takes awhile to notice the difference, there is a big difference in the room now.If you're not getting good results you may have it in a room that's too large, or the humidity level may not be high enough for this unit to make a noticeable difference.  For us, it works.

I love cast iron pans, but this is my first griddle.  So far, so good.  I've cooked eggs, veggies, pancakes, pizza crust, fish and a bunch of other things on this so far.  Works without fail, the pre-seasoning was excellent.  We took it camping and it performed great over an open fire.Learn to care for your cast iron, and you will love it.  It's not too hard, really, and I find cast iron in general to be very forgiving if/when you make a mistake with handling it.

I found this book very enjoyable, and I'm a fan of the HBO series.  There are some who seem to feel that the author is somehow denigrating the USMC, First Recon, or the US Military in general in this book, but I don't find that to be the case at all.There is always going to be some subjectivity in reporting like this.  So much of it is based on Wright's memory, etc.  What I think this captures very well is the devastating nature of modern warfare and the logistical impossibilities of major military operations, especially when multiple branches are involved.It is truly amazing that there weren't more friendly fire deaths during this operation, considering the many close calls First Recon seemed to have.  This book does not glamorize war, nor does it place an unfair moral burden on the young men tasked with the invasion of Iraq.  It's so difficult to generalize about a book like this.  The enlisted marines come across as very brave, sometimes foolish, often conflicted, and very human.  Officers get less coverage, and though the decisions of the higher-ups at times seem to border on the absurd, I feel that this book gives the reader the very real sense that the person giving the order is usually just the messenger, and that messenger may be at odds with what they're expected to do.Also, and perhaps most importantly, this book really gives a sense of how random and tragic modern warfare is.  Civilians get killed constantly.  I don't see this as a reflection on the marines portrayed in the book - they are put in an impossible situation with regards to how to execute their orders while keeping themselves and their comrades safe, while accurately identifying military threats - but rather the nature of the modern war machine.Politically, it doesn't matter where you sit.  Regardless of the Rolling Stone byline, I don't think Evan Wright brought any particular agenda to the table with this book.  It is not intended as 100% accurate history, but rather his perceptions of things as they happened.  I found that I was in the position of rooting for the marines and for the safety of the innocents caught up in brutality, as well.

I prefer cargo shorts and needed some new ones and saw these.  I liked the idea of the stretch fabric.  If you're unsure, a 13" inseam is long.  They probably hang 2-3" below my knee (I'm 6' 3").  The fabric is slightly stretchy, they are not like sweat pants or some other super stretchy material.  They feel just like any other Dickies work pants or shorts, if you've ever had them.  The fabric feels almost like denim.  I wore them for the first time today and they're very comfortable.  It was a warm, humid day and they breathe nicely.No issues, and I would definitely buy them again.

I have a little Sandisk mp3 player with a wide spring-loaded clip built into the back side of the unit.  I've had it for a few years now and the clip has held up just fine, but I noticed a couple of weeks ago that the unit was not sitting flat, but was at a slight angle when resting on the clip.  It turns out that one of the plastic mounts for the hinge of the clip was starting to break.  There was a crack, and opposite the crack on the other side of the mount, the plastic was turning white.I tried some cheapie dollar store super glue, which lasted about an hour before coming undone - and that was after letting it set overnignt.  The place I needed to fix is in a cramped place, so my options were pretty limited.  I decided to see if there was better super glue out there, saw the ratings for this stuff, and gave it a shot.I glued the crack and taped the clip to relieve pressure on the joint while it dried, and let it set overnight.  It's been about a month now and the bond is still holding, and I use this thing every single day.Needless to say, I'm impressed, and I now know that all super glues are not the same.

I've been using this for about a month now.  I've been snoring for a long, long time and my wife has gotten used to it.  A friend told me about good results with an infomercial product that was similar to this - and much more expensive.  I liked the fact that you mold this mouthguard to your teeth.  That process is very easy - I just poured boiling water into a large coffee mug and followed the instructions.  If you've ever molded a mouthguard for sports, it's basically the same process.So, yes, this thing initially feels large, but it's not uncomfortable.  The breathing holes are large enough that I never feel claustrophobic while wearing it.  Initially my teeth were a little bit sore, but that went away after a few days.  Now I wear it without issue.The other night I forgot to put it in and my wife said she couldn't sleep because of my snoring - so it actually works.  And that's the thing - I don't hear myself snoring, so I can only go by what my wife says, and she is very happy with this thing.  Also, I absolutely and in all seriousness feel more refreshed in the morning.  That was something that I noticed right away.  I really feel better, and I no longer get groggy and sleepy in the afternoons at work like I used to.I couldn't be happier with this thing.  I hesitated to buy something like this for many years because all these things seem like gimmicks or scams.  This one works for me.

I tried a different style of bean from Third Alarm before this one (Nicaraguan, I think) and I wasn't really happy with it.  Nothing bad about it, just was a little one dimensional.  This Ethiopian Sidamo - the first time I've tried this kind of bean - is much better.  Good complexity, smooth, not overly acidic.  No issues, really, it's just not my favorite coffee bean ever.  However, it's good enough that for now I'm keeping my subscription going until I feel like trying something else.

I'm not a tennis expert by any means, but when I was younger I played casually quite a bit and I have a (very) basic grasp of fundamental strategy.I got this a week or so ago as the FAOTD and so far I'm very pleased.  I play this on a Samsung Galaxy 2 7.0 tablet.  The graphics are very good and the game is fun.  The touchscreen controls, which use finger swipes to indicate the type of shot, are generally responsive.  I've not tried to use the virtial control pad options because the idea doesn't appeal to me - I want my tablet games to be simple, and simulated gamepads never work well for me.  I don't have the patience to master something where I can't feel the buttons.My only gripe with the game is that the game sometimes confuses a shot command with a movement command.  To position your player you simply touch where you'd like him to go.  The instructions tell you that the quicker you give your shot command after the other player hits the ball, the more power you'll have.  Well, if you, say, reposition your player to the center of the court, and then give a shot command while he's in motion, the game will often read that second input as another movement command, so your player will run to another part of the court.  This happens more than I would like.  I've tried to be very deliberate with my finger swipes, but it still happens.Overall, this is a great game, especially for a FAOTD.  Fun and challenging, and worth the time I've spent with it.

I have a large and medium.  Works great.  I use it for small to medium watercolors, pen and wash and water soluble graphite.  The brush is sturdy and is capable of large or relatively fine lines.  I haven't felt the need for a small size yet.These have not leaked at all and are very easy to use and refill.  What a great gadget.

I prefer to use masking tape to tape up my watercolor paper onto one of my drawing boards, rather than gum tape.  I can't recall the last brand I had, but this is much better.  It's much easier to get it off the roll and it sticks until I don't need it to anymore.  The other stuff was too sticky on the roll and would release from the board after a few hours.So, no issues with this stuff.
This pack was well priced and they work as well as any tortillions I've ever used.  A good variety of sizes, too.

I'd gotten the idea of sketching with flat pencils from a book on drawing I'd read a few years ago.  I've tried to use some carpenter's pencils before, and they certainly work, but the "medium" lead is more in the 2H range, and I prefer darker tones if I'm using a large drawing medium. (although, now that I think about it, I can probably use both together very successfully, which I haven't tried yet).These pencils are more of a flatish oval than an actual carpenter's pencil, but the lead is roughly the same - wide and flat - and these are longer than a carpenter's pencil by an inch or so.I just carve away the wood and leave the lead square so that I can get broad strokes with the wide side, thinner with the thin side, and relatively fine lines with the corners or edges.  These are a lot of fun - it's like painting with a pencil.  I like the 4B lead - it allows me to easily get at least 4 or 5 tonal values for my sketches.Obviously these work best with larger sketches or drawings, but I enjoy the results, and it's easy to rough in a thumbnail with these, as well.One last note - I did not purchase these through Amazon.  As large a vendor as General is, you'd think Amazon would carry more of their stuff themselves, but I guess this is a niche item.  The price and shipping asked by the current 3rd party vendor is a bit absurd and I wouldn't pay it.  Look around and you can find much better deals.

I've been exploring some old PS2 racing games lately and this was one I picked up a few weeks ago.If you don't follow rally racing, then you need to understand that this is purely racing against the clock on linear courses.  You don't see other cars and you're just trying to go as fast as possible and get the best time.  Each rally is several stages (4-5 in this game, many more in real life) and the driver with the lowest overall time wins that rally.The Ps2 certainly has its limits, and this is a 10 year old game, but it's still extremely fun. The cars have a good feel, the sound design is excellent and there's a good variety to the stages.  There's a lot of content here, and because there are so many courses, replayability is very high.  The controls work very well (I just use a dual shock, I've never made the investment in a good wheel setup) and the game has a good sense of speed.  Also, there is a good cockpit view that's fun to race with, though it feels a little bit more cramped than it should (it feels like the driver - i.e. your view - has his head resting against the window.  The left door post shouldn't obstruct your view to the extent that it does), but it's still fun, and makes the game challenging.My gripes?  I'd like to be able to create my own driver.  There is damage modeling, but it's very forgiving.  There should be more of a time penalty for rolling your car or driving off a cliff.  For example in TOCA 3, you can hit a wall and you're simply done if your car is damaged too much.  That kind of realism as an option would be nice.  It also would've been nice if car setup had more options - you get three choices for things like tires, suspension and brakes.Overall, though, a fun game with decent graphics that is still a blast many years after it was released.

Obviously the meaning of "How to Read a Painting" can be interpreted in different ways.  This book, as other reviews mention, focuses on the history and some of the symbolism, and not on the artistic, aesthetic point of view.For example, the author mentions that a Van Eyck has the husband near the window because he is connected to the outside world while the wife is more connected to the inner workings of the home.  Composition is otherwise not mentioned from an aesthetic sense.I love this book.  I'm very far removed from my college art history classes, so delving into this area with a fresh mind has been a lot of fun.  Yes, the information provided is selective and limited.  But I'd rather learn a little about a bunch of masterpieces than read a textbook, which can get old very fast.This, to me, seems like a perfect starter book.  It is an easy read because the text is limited - but it still provides a wealth of information.  Also, though the pictures are small, the printing is of high quality, so details can be viewed with a magnifying glass, if need be.I've learned a lot from this book and I'm very glad to have it around.  It is a starting point, not the only book on art history you'll ever need.  I think it does what it sets out to do very well.Another reviewer suggested Mary Acton's books, and I may move on to them next.

First, I really want to support this company.  It's nice to think about ordering a product that I need as well as giving money to firefighters and their families.This coffee is not bad by any means, but it's also not great.  It's a medium roast that comes across as a bit "one-note" to me.  I've tried brewing it a little stronger and a little weaker, which sometimes works with some beans.  It's hard to put my finger on it, but it just lacks complexity and really just doesn't get me excited in any way.I'm going to try another blend from this company and hopefully I'll find something more to my liking.

I got this paper for my 7 year old daughter for her birthday so that she could have all the drawing paper she wants and doesn't have to use the better quality paper from my art supplies.The paper is nice and heavy with a semi-rough texture, as is expected from manila paper.  So far she's used pencil, colored pencil, crayon and markers - all have worked great.This paper was the bargain of the century, and it will keep my daughter happy for a very long time.

This is your basic, no-frills Bic pen that you've seen a thousand times.  I hadn't realized that they now made it in 1.6mm, so I ordered some.These write beautifully, the ball rolls smoothly and the ink flow seems just right so far.  I haven't had issues with splotchy writing yet, as others have reported.I've also found these to be good for sketching, and I plan to order a box of black for my art supplies.  It's good to have a reliable, cheap pen that won't break my heart if it's lost.

I have a few of the Lyra water soluble graphite crayons, which I love.  I bought some of these, thinking I was getting more water soluble graphite (I was unaware at the time that Lyra made both kinds of graphite crayons) but decided to keep them.So, think of this as a big graphite stick.  I don't know what the filler content is, it doesn't seem waxy at all like a crayon.  So far the only difference between this and my regular drawing pencils is that these don't seem to blend quite as smoothly.  In other words, if you block in some shapes and/or tones, and try to blend them together with a stump, some of the lines may remain visible - but softened - within the area of tone.  With a regular pencil or charcoal it's very easy to make the lines completely disappear.  Of course this can be mitigated by applying the lines more evenly or smoothly or lightly, or using the broad side of the crayon to put down areas that will be blended.To me this isn't a huge deal.  I don't always blend my sketches, and a little texture never hurt anybody.  As I've been using these I've been trying to maintain the "pencil point" shape by using the side of the sharpened area for shading, which keeps a bit of a point for smaller lines.Again, these are fun and it was a happy accident to have them, so I have no complaints and I find myself returning to them because I'm enjoying them so much.

My favorite ballpoint for drawing is the Uniball Gel Impact 1.0mm, which has a great flow of ink and a nice bold line.As far as felt tips go, the Pentel Sign Pen is now my number one.  I actually had a weird deja vu moment after I ordered these.  I remember that I somehow acquired a blue one many years ago and which is now long lost, but I recall at the time loving the pen and not being able to find more of them.Anyway, this pen is a bit unique in that the nib is pretty long and has a nice taper to it.  It's almost like a short, stiff brush pen.  Don't misunderstand, there is no flex to the nib, but the length allows you to get fine lines with the tip and broad strokes with the side.  Having that range is very nice.  Also, the nibs are pretty substantial so they hold their shape well.I also like that this is a very compact pen, and very economical.  It will fit in any pen case, or your pocket, so it travels easily.The ink flows well, so you don't get ragged lines, and they seem to last a good long time.This is one of those pens that is inspiring to use.  It's such a simple design, nothing flashy at all, but it's so satisfying and functional in a unique way.  This is a true "classic".Oh, and by the way, I don't know what it is, but I'm glad that I'm not the only "pen freak" in the world - which I've discovered from reading pen reviews on Amazon.  I think it's the way that different pens feel and react with the page, so discovering a new pen is always a fun experience.  (And is the reason why we have a drawer full of pens)

Yes - 3x love.  Having a nice, chunky piece of graphite is great.  But the fact that it's water-soluble is the big seller for me.  I also have some (very nice, useable) water soluble graphite pencils, but the big difference with these crayons is that you can lay down tones without imprinting the paper, which sometimes happens with a pencil (I never said I was a great artist).These crayons allow you to fill large spaces with color (tone), and then soften it with a wet brush.  Works great and looks beautiful.  I like softening pencil sketches with stumps, etc, but being able to use a brush and get watercolor-like B&W images is magical to me.  Endless fun.Oh, and FYI:  I have 2B and 6B versions and I find both to be very useful.  I don't know that I need anything darker than the 6B, and so far I find that I can get whatever variation in tones I need from these two, as well as my various other water soluble graphites.

I got these for my daughter for her 7th birthday, and both she and her 10 year old brother didn't want to stop drawing with them.  As others have noted, these are far from the best colored pencils in the world, but my kids don't care and they're very good for the price.

I bought a cheap clutch pencil for my daughter for her birthday with the idea of getting her this kind of colored lead assortment.She loves the clutch pencil and the lead works great.  The colors are nice and bright, but the lead isn't overly soft so they'll last quite awhile, I'm sure.  No issues - great stuff.

I'm not a seasoned or experience artist, though I've been drawing and playing with watercolors for several years.  I wanted to get a good volume of paper because I want to get more serious about practicing my art, and this seemed like an excellent value.So far I'm very pleased.  For 500 sheets of 80 lb paper, this is an absolute steal.  The paper has a small amount of texture and has been a pleasure to work with.  I've done pencil sketches, colored pencils, pastels (which I don't use very much but I wanted to give them a try for a simple value study exercise) and I even did a bit of light wet work with water soluble graphite.Excellent results so far, and I've got quite a bit of paper to keep me busy.  The paper of course buckled just a bit with the use of the wash for the graphite, but not too bad - I purposely kept it light.  (this was not a background wash, but I used a damp brush to fill out the details of a tree I'd drawn - I primarily wanted to see how the paper worked with a bit of moisture).Anyway, if you are a more experienced artist you will likely be more picky than I am, but this is a tremendous value and it gives me a huge stack of quality paper to practice my skills - which is a great feeling.I think Sax's drawing paper goes up to 90 lb, and I might try that next time, which was only a few dollars more.  But regardless, I think this is excellent paper.EDIT:  I just wanted to add that over the weekend I was experimenting with some water soluble graphite sticks I purchased, and did some drawings with background washes.  These were not as heavy as a watercolor wash, but still, a good portion of the paper was wet at one time or another.  Yes, the paper will curl, but after it dried for a few minutes I put a drawing pad on the picture and weighed it down a bit.  The result is not completely flat, but acceptable.  So, in my opinion, this paper can take a reasonable amount of wet media, but you then need to flatten it out either as it dries or afterward.

I have been using Resolve stain remover for years and absolutely love it.  I have a great homemade stain remover recipe that works well, but sometimes it just doesn't cut through whatever I'm trying to get out.  Nine times out of ten, Resolve gets that "impossible" stain out.I often pre-soak a wee bit longer than recommended, and have never had an issue with that.  But, of course, that's not recommended because it could potentially damage some materials.  Just saying that I have done that without issues.I absolutely love this.  I pay FULL price for this and highly recommend it!

My daughter loves Hershey's syrup.  Not too long ago, I introduced her to the strawberry flavor of it and her eyes absolutely lit up.  She likes strawberry milk better than chocolate milk now!!!  I'm sure this would taste amazing over ice cream and other desserts too, but we primarily use syrups to flavor milk as a special occasional treat.I paid full price for this and highly recommend it!

We have been using Quilted Northern toilet paper for a little while now and I decided that I wanted to try another top name brand to compare, so I ordered this Charmin to see what we thought.This is absolutely a very good quality toilet paper.  It is very strong and doesn't pull apart when you are using it.  However, I find that it does leave some pilling behind, which I don't care for.  So our families personal preference is going to remain as Quilted Northern.  However, if the store doesn't have that in stock, Charmin is absolutely our backup choice.  It may not be my top brand, but it is my second favorite.I paid FULL price for this and am glad that I tried it!

My friend introduced me to Quilted Northern this summer and I haven't looked back!!!I started out as a Scott's girl, graduated to Cottonelle and occasionally other brands. But wow....I haven't found anything quite so soft and strong as this brand. We are absolutely loving it. When you tear the sheets off, there is no cloud of dust. These absorb and liquids soak up without going through and getting your fingers messy.The paper itself is extremely soft. It doesn't pill up or leave any residue behind. We love this change and are NOT going back to our old brands.I paid full price for this item and am thrilled with it!!!

I have loved Huggies wipes ever since I discovered them when my daughter was a baby.  They were our almost exclusive choice of baby wipes because they work so well and never caused sensitivity issues for my daughter.  She is six years old now, so we obviously don't need them for changing diapers anymore.  But when she was little, I discovered that these work miracles for cleaning things around the house.  They're inexpensive and don't shred easily.Amazon recently offered an instant clip coupon promotion for these and I decided that it was too good to pass up.  I'm so happy that I've rediscovered these.  They're just as great as I remember them and I highly recommend them!!!

I have been struggling to find a good way to clean my cooking griddle.  We typically do not have napkins or paper towels in the house, and only use items that can be washed and reused.  However, the greasy mess that my griddle left behind, and the amount of washcloths that would end up in the washer every time I use it was getting ridiculous.  So I decided to order some paper towels specifically for griddle cleaning - it's the best decision I could have ever made!!!These paper towels soak up the grease - whether it's a little or a lot, and I don't have to use many at all.  Then I can simply toss them in the garbage with no laundry load of greasy washcloths.  It's a win-win situation and takes a lot less time and effort.I love that these are not full sheet towels.  I can use however many I want to.  they tear easily and work great without scratching my griddle.  I'm really happy with them.I paid FULL price for these and I will be ordering them again!

I am quite pleased with this expandable hose.  I have had several shorter ones, but they are not long enough to reach around to the full front yard.  After putting sod down this year, and not being able to reach all of it with my spray hoses, I realized that I needed to get one that was at least 75-feet.  This one is perfect.  I can reach all of the edges of my yard now and don't have to drag any heavy hoses across my new grass.The spray head fits nicely in my hand and is not overly heavy.  That's a big deal for me - not only because I have wrist issues but because yard work and watering - whether it's a lawn or a garden or cleaning an automobile - involves long term standing.  The weight of many spray heads is just too heavy and feels heavier the longer you go.  This one, being relatively lightweight, makes the work a lot easier.The hose itself has no leaks and is really easy to hook up.  Just remember that you can't turn the water on full blast when you first start to fill it.  I love that this doesn't tangle up or kink and that there is no heavy dragging of a hose because this is so light.  I love it.  It's absolutely excellent!!!  I'm really happy that I ordered this!!!Full Disclosure: I was blessed to receive a free sample of this item for free in exchange for my testing, inspecting and reviewing it.  I received no compensation for my review and always give my honest and unbiased opinion of each product. My words and the rating I provided are my own and are based on my own personal experience with this item.

0:28 Mins ***Video Slideshow Attached***This mini fan is excellent!!!I am absolutely shocked and stunned by the power and the amount of wind / fresh air that this little guy can make.  I never imagined that it would work as well as it does!!!  This is extremely quiet - not silent but by no means is it loud either.  To use it, you simply plug it into the charging port of your Apple device (I have it in an iPhone 5S in the photos in the video slideshow).  It begins working instantly!  And to turn it off, simply remove it from your device just as if you were removing a charging cord.If you put your fingers onto the fan when it is running, you will get a little sting from it.  Noticeable, yes.  But it will not cause permanent damage.  It will just (hopefully) make you wise enough to not touch it again when it is running.  This is easy to unplug without having to touch the fan portion of it.I'm really happy that I ordered this and highly recommend it!!!Full Disclosure: I was blessed to receive a free sample of this item for free in exchange for my testing, inspecting and reviewing it.  I received no compensation for my review and always give my honest and unbiased opinion of each product. My words and the rating I provided are my own and are based on my own personal experience with this item.

We switched over to Pink Himalayan Sea Salt about two or three years ago.  And since switching to it, we have not looked back - we love the flavor of this.  It doesn't have the same sharp bitterness that you get from normal table salt.  This also has many minerals that are excellent for your health - minerals that regular table salt does not have.The packaging for this salt is excellent.  The plastic that it is in does not allow for any salt to come through.  It is good and thick to protect the salt from moisture.  It also is resealable, so you can remove the salt that you need to fill up your grinder or shakers, or to measure out what you need and then you can seal it back up to protect the quality.I am very pleased with this and am very happy that I purchased it.  I highly recommend this brand!!!Full Disclosure: I was blessed to receive a sample of this item at a discounted price (it was not free) in exchange for my testing, inspecting and reviewing it.  I received no compensation for my review and always give my honest and unbiased opinion of each product. My words and the rating I provided are my own and are based on my own personal experience with this item.

We have been using Glad ForceFlex bags for a long time now - since shortly after they were introduced to the market.  I love the fact that they stretch out and typically don't puncture, even when you over-fill them or put sharp objects inside. I ordered this scalp brush with one thought in mind - I need something strong to relieve the ever-increasing itchy scalp issues that I have.  I have tried everything.  I use Tea Tree essential oil in my shampoo which does help quite a bit, but lately I've been plagued with hair that becomes extremely oily even shortly after shampooing it.  Nothing was helping - I even did an oatmeal and brown sugar scrub.  My scalp felt so dirty, as if the shampoo wasn't even actually getting through to the skin.  So I would come out of the shower still feeling dirty and oily.  And oh-so-itchy!!!The first time I used this, I was a little disappointed.  I remember thinking that it was just too stiff for me and that it could potentially actually scratch my head.  I almost gave up on using it.  But I didn't.  And I'm so happy for that!!!  Because now I have learned just what pressure I need to use when I am using this.Through trial and error, I have learned that I need to put the shampoo on my head, rather than on the brush.  Sometimes I get my hair all suds up with my hands first.  And sometimes I pour it on my head and brush it through.  I definitely have better results when I use this at different angles instead of just running it down my hair like I would with a hairbrush.What have I discovered in the week that I have been using this?  My head, in general, itches a lot less.  My scalp absolutely, without a doubt, feels significantly cleaner.  And my hair is a different texture - it's no longer weighted down by the oil.  It is lighter and fuller looking and looks healthier in general.  I wasn't expecting all of that - but the ONLY thing I changed was when I added this brush to the routine.  Now whether I'm using it the way I'm supposed to, I'm really not sure.  I haven't read up on how these are supposed to be used.  I just did what felt right to me and it's working great.I ordered this at FULL price and absolutely do recommend this and would order it again!!!

I originally fell in love with Chai Tea when I worked near a Dunkin Donuts store.  Once I found discovered it, I would go there every single morning to get a cup. I had almost given up when I discovered this Oregon Chia tea while shopping in a store in New York during our summer trip.I brought the box back home and found that none of our local stores - even the big name ones - carried it. 1:59 Mins *** Video Slideshow Attached***I am a big fan of TENS units.  As someone who is in pain 100% of the time, I do have a high pain tolerance - but sometimes I simply cannot bear it.  I was injured in a bad car accident when I was thirteen and also suffer from Fibromyalgia.  To top that off, I have liver issues that prevent me from taking most pain medications and I refuse narcotics because my family struggles with addiction and I don't want to take the chance of ever having to deal with that.  So TENS units are such a blessing to me.I've tried several, from a small unit that simply sticks to your body to units that have snap-on electrodes to a prescription-strength $600 Theratech unit.I'm pleased with this unit.  It works quite well and has quite a few options / settings so that you can adjust it to the sensation that you personally need.  If you're anything like me, the settings can be vastly different depending on the day and the location of the pain.  I love that this unit allows you to use four pads at the same time, as sometimes I really need that.The pads themselves are the quality I would expect.  They adhere well.  I personally extend the life of my pads when the adhesive starts to run out by using TENS unit adhesive.  And then I use the pads until they literally stop working.  A side hint that my physical therapist told me is to store the pads in the fridge to help them last longer.I'm really happy with this unit and am glad that I ordered it!!!Full Disclosure: I was blessed to receive a free sample of this item for free in exchange for my testing, inspecting and reviewing it. I have been a Harmony remote user for many years.  They really dominated the high end universal remote market for over a decade.  In particular, their library of devices is huge and they are usually quick to add new devices to their list of compatible devices.  Lately though, home automation systems have grown to control not only smart switches and devices but home entertainment as well.  Meanwhile Harmony is looking to control those home automation devices with systems like the Elite.The Elite is a device that aims to be a complete home system both controlling your entertainment system and your home devices.  The centerpiece, unlike previous standalone Harmony remotes, is the Hub.  Setup is pretty easy.  I simply plugged everything in and used the remote to start the setup process.  Unfortunately the transfer of my "Activities" from the previous remote only worked for 2 out of 3.  I had to download the desktop software (recommended regardless) to configure the 3rd Activity.  With the desktop software you have way more control over what you want the buttons to do and also you remote LCD screen functions.  The desktop software is the best I have used from Logitech.  It is pretty easy to select what device and function is assigned to the buttons on the remote.  The functions of the device are pretty complete and come from Logitech's list of compatible devices.  If there happens to be a function not listed, you can have te Harmony remote learn the function with the use of the device's remote.  I have to say that everything works perfectly.  The system, with it's included IR blasters, never fails to turn off or on a device--a problem that used to aggravate me with all previous Harmony remotes.  Also, the PS3 can be controlled and turn on/off by pairing with the Harmony Elite via bluetooth--works perfectly and no need of the previous Harmony PS3 adapter!  I have not yet tested the home control option but look forward to adding a Samsung SmartHub with room light switches.  After reading the documents and online info, I still was not completely sure which home automation systems were compatible though.  Wish there were more info for people who want to build a system around the Harmony Elite.  I think people with existing home control systems would have no issues.  Overall, this is hands down the best Harmony remote I have used.  Highly recommended!PROS:Easy SetupDesktop software improvedHighly customizable remoteLarge list of compatible devicesSmartphone control (iOS and android)More reliable device communication (with hub and 2 IR blasters)Home automation control capableExcellent remote (battery life, sharp/bright screen, vibration, motion wakeup, layout)CONS:Expensive

Awesome Awesome Awesome.  That's all I have to say.  I bought this not knowing if it would work with my Kitchen Aid refridgerator that is probably 13-14 years old now.  The door on the fridge would not close right because the cams were worn and broken.  I first looked at Parts stores online but they only had one lower cam that turned up when I input my refridgerator model #.  This kit looked like the cams on mine and Whirlpool makes KitchenAid refridgerators so I thought it was worth the try.  Well the parts do fit perfectly and saved me some dough.  Installation took all of 10 minutes.I noticed after the repair the inside temperatures are now much lower!!!  ...must have not sealed right with the broken/worn cams.  It's like I have a new refridgerator!!!

I am using this speaker on my desktop in lieu of my normal NHT SuperZeroes, powered by the M-Audio Super DAC II and Dayton Audio Class T integrated amp.  Although the sound is very good and unfatiguing, I find that there is a disturbing resonance in the upper midbass.  Otherwise the highs are very clear and smooth.  It has way more bass than my SuperZeroes.  You do get a lot for you money in this inexpensive bookshelf speaker.  Overall the sound is very good but the resonance that I referred to earlier being the main failing.  I hear it bass guitar, lower registers of vocals, etc. so it is not inconsequential.  Perhaps the thin MDF used to make the enclosure is to blame.  The knock test showcases a very lively box.  So at least B5 vs. SuperZeroes, I will have to give the nod to the NHTs.  The B5 does have a fuller sound that plays louder but loses points for ultimate neutrality.

Really cute, well made ornament.  Lenox printed on the back in gold for collector's.  The battery compartment is on the bottom with an on-off switch.  The star holes on the penguin belly glows multicolors and flashes in seemingly random fashion.  This ornament is sooooo cute for lover's of Lenox and Christmas ornaments alike.

Made the mistake of buying a Metz flash many years ago.  While powerful, it was not fully compatible with Canon's ETTL.  This time around, I wanted the venerable 430EX II for it's compact size.  I actually waited some thinking a new model would come out but none did.  Great flash for the photo enthusiast like myself.
Great product.  The material is fantastic.  Feels very comfortable, quick to dry, fitment is great.  Sized right as is.

Differs from other bike locks in it's versatility.  It has a loop around one end and the locking end you loop round to a metal hub on the cable.  What that means is you don't have to make one big loop with your 8' cable--you can secure one end to one area and the other end to a totally different area.  This is a good product and does not command a price premium.  Recommended.The work matchkey system is kind of neat in that you can buy other locks with the same word on the key and use multiple cable locks without having to have mulitple keys.

Good alarm clocks are not easy to find.  Not sure why many don't have the snooze bar front and center and easy to hit without accidently hitting other buttons.  This Timex is great for several reasons.  Has a classic LED display that is not the kind that illuminates the entire rectangular display.  The snooze bar is very wide and up front.  The clock is easy to program and use.  The snooze is programmable!!!  Wow.  Acutally love the USB charging--one less thing to have around my night stand.  I use a shorty lightening cable for my IphoneAmazonBasics Apple Certified Lightning to USB Cable - 4 Inches (10 Centimeters) - Black

I keep this in my kitchen junk drawer and use it often.  Great for cutting paper, slicing tape off boxes, etc.  Just about everything I would use an exacto knife for but love the fact that this knife has a retractable blade like a box cutter.  Small "pen" style means it is easy to wield and use.  Love it.  I do know ceramic stays sharp but can be broken off if dropped on the blade, so I am very careful with it.

Love the Platform type bike racks.  No banging of bikes like the hanging type.  There is some assembly required and I did encounter a problem with the parts--thankfully the Thule group which owns SportRack took care of the problem.  Have to give kudos to their customer support.The Deluxe version of the Crest 2 is nice in that the top holders have key locks.  I still use a cable lock around the bikes if I plan to leave the bikes on the rack for any prolonged period though.PRO:-platform style-easy to assemble and use-quality contruction and powdercoated paint-inexpensive-great customer service (Thule group)CONS:-heavy-anti-wobble hitch pin bolt requires wrench (ie. not tool-less)

I would say fit is very slightly larger than the norm.  Usually for Columbia Sportswear, I would size down but not this Silver Ridge.  One size down is snug and you will only be able to wear a thin t-shirt underneath.  I am 6', 190lb.  Large is a slightly large on me. I would like to wear a t-shirt and long-sleeve shirt--maybe even a sweatshirt--so I will accept the sizing.  Love the nylon vest.  Very few comparable vests with full zip up collars.  Love the numerous pockets.  Perfect travel and hiking vest.  Love this vest.  Highly recommended!  I even bought my GF a Medium which is slightly long for her but still OK.  Too bad no women's version of this excellent vest.
Cable has a nice flexible jacket.  I love the short size--just makes sense when I don't need the cable length for my desk charger.

I have been a spiralizer believer the past 6 months or so but mainly using zucchini and yellow squash.  This book opened my eyes in terms of the possibility.  I didn't even think outside the box in terms of other vegetables you could use and the recipes you can try.  I do wish there were pictures for every recipe but know that it really isn't needed.
Put these on a hybrid.  They are nicely shaped and easy to grip.  Live the front flat spot to place your thumb.  These are also not too gawdy with the graphics.  Would recommend!

I know this is recommended for use without a case.  That said, I would say even the thinnest of cases would not work.  It's too bad too because this armband holder is low cost and you seem to get a good deal for your money.  Because I would need to remove the case, I just cannot recommend it.  I personally don't know anyone who keeps their 6 Plus without a case so the market for this is small.

This mug is very similar to the Nissan Thermos mug that has been around a while.  There is a button up top to open and close the sippy opening.  For the most part, it is water tight and won't spill when knocked down.  The amount of liquid that is allowed to come out when opened is not a lot which is bad for people who like bigger gulps.  The lid is also not easy to clean.  The mug is vacuum insulated which means it has excellent insulation properties for warm and cold.  To be honest, most of the vacuum insulated mugs I have do about the same job unless you get one in the thermos form factor which provides better insulation.I find that this mug is pretty decent but wish it were easier to clean the lid and wish the lid let out more coffee.Edit:  after further use, I cannot recommend this mug because of the lid.  There is a cavity inside the lid from the button that retains water after cleaning.  It never fully dries out.  Also, the buttom of the mug is recessed and traps water in the dishwater.

I would have loved to see this work but unfortunately the Perky Fure Removing broom does not pick up my cat's hair as much as I'd like.  On my microfiber sofa, it doesn't do a good job at all.  It works best on hard surfaces but even then, cleaning the hair off the rubber bristles is a chore.  I have even needed to take out my vacuum cleaner to clean the rubber bristles--makes me think I should have just used the vacuum in the first place.
My dogs love these.  They eagerly do tricks to get one of these as a reward.  Nice to know they are from a trusted brand.

The price pretty much means that this product is aimed at commercial use.  It offers a beefy 2.4A charge rate for each port.  Not shared or divided like some multi-port chargers.  The unit is physically quite large but poses no problem.  If you really have an array of tablets or smartphones that can use the charging capability of this charger, then this is for you.  The build quality is great--seems very sturdy.  The power brick is quite a bit larger than standard laptop power bricks and has a proprietary plug.  There is what appears to be a mounting bracket but you will have to drill holes in it because it has none (???) for unknown reasons.
Unlike other wine aerators, this one doesn't have vent holes that leak wine from time to time.  You simply hold over your glass and pour the wine in.  Works like a charm.

The rake is very nice and sturdy but the basket is not very sturdy and doesn't hold poop very well.  I use the rake with the Four Paws Grass Wire RAke Dog ScooperFour Paws Grass Wire Rake Dog Scooper instead.
This water bottle may not be super lightweight but the adjustability for various bottle widths is great.  I've damaged countless bottles on other holders that jarred loose with bumps.

The size is rather small but more importantly, the main drawback of this feeder is the chute clogs with even small size dog food.  I simply cannot use it and will throw it out for recycling.  Maybe you will have better luck as I obviously cannot test it out with anything but the dog food I use.

I have used Food Saver vacuum sealers and a couple of other sealers for the past 20 years.  Food Savers are definitely more expensive but are also better performing.  The Gamesaver serves a niche:  if you need repetitive seals in a row non-stop and/or need to seal large size bags.  You will be hard-pressed to find a non-commercial sealer other than the Gamesaver that will do that.  That said, the size is imposing.  I personally cannot fathom leaving this unit on the kitchen counter permanently--it is just too large.  It stays in the pantry when not in use.

This is a large thermos that is perfect for trips and camping.  It keeps my coffee hot for hours!  It has a pretty simple and easy-to-clean screw top and lid that serves as a cup.  Build quality is pretty rugged.  You really cannot go wrong with this thermos.

I had an HP Chromebook 11 which I think was the precursor to this model.  there are some good and bad to this newer model.  For one thing, the size is significantly bulkier and heavier.  Although the battery life is better, that is a huge penalty.  The old Chromebook 11 used to charge with a high amp ac adapter via micro USB port.  This one uses a cludgy laptop-style power brick.  Otherwise the performance in daily use is similar.  I think it still represents a great buy for someone who just wants something to browse with.  I love Google's Chrome browser so this laptop is perfect for me when browsing in front of the TV or for guests to use while staying at my place.  I also don't worry about it (because of it's low cost) when bringing it on trips.

Maybe my golden doodles are finicky but they sniff the Wellbars and one of them will eat it, the other one noses it some more and then eventually will eat it.  It's good knowing the bars are healthy for them though but I find it hard to use this treat as a reward when they are not enthusiastic about eating them.  They are a nice reward size though.
wow.  This was super easy to install on my 6 Plus.  looks and feels great.  the surface is polished and slick unlike some plastic screen protectors.  highly recommended

These are the best fenders I've ever used on a hybrid.  Very clean look.  Fitment is great and not hard to install.  The mounting rods were a little long and needed to be cut--make sure you don't do what I did and cut them a little too short!  Otherwise a great set of fenders.

I bought this after accidentally breaking my 2nd BonaVita dripper.  This one is nice because it is simpler and cheaper.  I like that it is plastic although I do realize it may not last as long.  The shutoff seals also give me pause.  It seems to work very well right now though.  Unlike the BonaVita, the pour into a small-mouthed mug is no problem.  Love that it will take a full 16oz that I let sit for a couple of minutes before I empty it into a mug.

Really love this pry bar.  It is heavy duty and heavy in weight.  The actual pry end is sturdy and relatively wide, unlike a lot of pry bars.  This provides a nice stable surface to work with.  The price is fitting of a tool of this caliber.  I also have a cheap adjustable pry bar from Harbor Freight.  There is no comparison!

This Thule is a high quality GoPro Sling bag that is comfortable to wear over the shoulder with a waist strap for extra security and holds up to two GoPro's in its custom foam bag insert, along with accessories.  It offers enough storage with two small zippered pockets inside, 2 smartphone  pockets (one of which fits my Note 4 perfectly!), and a larger outer pocket.  The back of the bag is padded--really with the padded back and foam insert, your GoPro's are very well protected. Materials are high quality.  The only thing I would like to see are two straps on the bottom of the bag to tie my selfie stick to--similar to what my camera bag has for securing my travel tripod.

These two wrenches appear very well made which is typically what Crescent is known for.  The two are pretty heavy given how solid they are.  The real kicker with the wrenches is that the tooth design fit a variety of fastener shapes and also allows some play in size.  Basically the wrenches should fit a variety of shapes and sizes with just 4 different ends!  While this may not be ideal for really stuck on bolts, it is perfect for more compact travel tool boxes.  So far, I have had no problem using the wrenches on a variety of fasteners.

We have been sleeping on this bed for the past week on our platform bed frame.  Previously, I have had a 7" memory foam mattress and a Comfortaire air mattress with memory foam insert.  I like the Brentwood Home S-Bed the best.  Unlike other mattresses that use memory foam and allow you to initially sink and then meet a much harder layer, the S-bed feels more supportive without being hard--more like a traditional mattress.  Knowing that it won't go lumpy like a coil spring mattress is reassuring.  I won't claim that back pains are a thing of the past because that is asking too much of any bed.  That said, we get a well rested sleep in the S-Bed and it doesn't call attention to itself--which is a good thing.Setup was easy.  We simply moved the bed to our sleep area and unboxed/unsealed it.  It looked pretty good within minutes but we let it fully expand for 24 hrs (instructions say 48hrs).  There were no strong odors of any kind.  The outer covering is a pretty durable cloth unlike some memory foam mattress covers.  The bed is pretty uniform throughout except for the edges which seem less firm than the rest--if you lay at the very edge of the mattress, you feel the tendency to fall out.  Not an issue during normal use.

This fan is not a personal fan despite it's diminuitive size.  It's not quite powerful enough as a whole room fan either.  It is large enough to provide a nice breeze while operating 6-8 ft from a sofa which is where I use it.  It has a quiet oscillating feature and you can tilt the unit to point up at you.  The noise is definitely quieter than a tranditional fan and only become obtrusive when the setting is near high.  Otherwise it is impressively quiet.  Heat mode is warm, not hot, but is definitely functional.  The device looks elegant, but in an industrial sort of way.For those who won't balk at it's price, the Dyson is a great fan/heater.  You pay the premium for unique design, quality of materials, and aesthetics.

This style of ear bud is a category all it's own.  It lets in ambient noises so that you are in tune to your surroundings whether it be biking, hiking, walking, running, etc. as long as you don't play the music too loud.  The trade off for this is usually lack of bass.  this Actionfit ear bud is no different.  The sound quality is not bad but certainly not in the same league as in-the-canal earphones.  The highs are not as clean and refined as the Bose Soundsport.  Why am I giving this product 5 stars then?  For one thing, the cost is affordable.  The set is a quality one with 4 different ear pieces to fit a wide range of ears.  For my big ears, this is the best fitting sport ear buds I have ever owned.  There is no way to shake these out and yet they are very comfortable and light at the same time!  The sound quality is probably as good as the Monster iSport Strive.  Sound and fitment are much better than Yurbuds or Philips SHQ1200/28 ActionFit (old model).PROS:-allows you to hear ambient noises-awesome fitment for sports-sound quality is decent-long cord with shirt clip-affordable priceCONS-lack of bass (as with ALL similar style ear buds)-not the highest sound qualityHighly recommended!  These are my new favorite ear buds for sports!

Very tasty bar with low added sugar.  It is a little chewier than I'd like (prefer drier, less tacky bars) but otherwise this bar is great.  I like that this product has peanuts, almonds and sunflower seeds, combined with something to keep it together and does add anything fillers that I don't want.Recommended!

First hand experience here.  They will use any excuse to deny you coverage.  Your accident will be labelled "user error".  LOL.  Will definitely be contacting my state's attorney general.  Amazon should be ashamed to offer this "protection" plan.
Great battery for use with Invisible Fence dog collars!  Not much else to say--fitment is great and last a long time.

Nicely sized Qi charging pad.  It goes without saying that your phone must be Qi Wireless capable or you must have a Qi charging pad or case to enable your phone to have be Qi charging capable.  With that said, this pad is a good size and my phone does not slip on it's top surface.  It is easy to position my Note4 smartphone with it's Qi charging pad underneath the cover.  Charging is on par with what I would expect--nowhere near as fast as the Samsung RapidCharge feature but it is plenty fast for overnight charging.  One problem that I've found is that if you placed the phone in a marginal position, it my cycle continuously between no charging and charging and delivering an annoying beep from the phone.  Make sure you know your phone and where the sweetspot for charging is to prevent this from happening.  I find wireless charging is a "must have" feature and hope all future smartphones include this feature.  With the Belkin Qi wireless charging pad, I will be set.

This wireless fence differs from the buried wire fence systems by sending out an adjustable width system that is detected by the collar and gives a warning sound then corrective shock once the width is breached.  I personally like the buried wire system but it is a lot of expense and effort to install that sort of system.  If you do it yourself, you can save money.The Motorola is a very good product.  There is some interference by objects/structures but in general, it is pretty reliable.  The main negative that I see is battery life.  I find I recharge the collar every third day.  On buried wire systems, a battery in the collar probably would be good for 3 months!  That takes getting used to.  My dog is used to collars and shock so it was easy to train him to the motorola.  I put out flags once I determined the boundary and when he approaches them, a sound goes off.  Not sure he has been shocked yet but he sure obeys the flags.  This system is nice because you can take it on the go as well.  When my brother dog sits while I'm on vacation, I just take my dog to his house and set it up with the flags.  Good to go!  If you have more than one dog, just be aware that an extra collar costs about $120.  That's about the going price for a collar that does not say Invisible Fence on it.

This lever is great.  It is easy to set up and the shifting is just what I had hoped for.  The hood is nice and beefy--just what my hands need.  I have no complaints with this brifter so far--love it and would recommend it.

I used this for a drop bar conversion on my hybrid bike.  It is a solid lever that is intended to be used for linear pull breaks and works with my v-brakes just fine and dandy.  I do find that the top of the lever is a little too pointy and thin for my hand and wish it were wider and bulkier.  Still, I was glad to have an option that uses the long pull of linear brakes that also wasn't too expensive.

I too saw this band open up for Matt & Kim.  To my surprise, I loved their performance and music more than the headliner.  The songs are upbeat and leave me tapping my toes.  really enjoyed this album and look forward to listening to their previous one as well as future work.  Recommended!
This is a great album.  I thought it might be a one hit (Cool Kids) album but most of the songs are great.  Like the positive vibe.  Recommended!

I made the mistake of using the long brake cable from the full kit for the front.  Glad the rear cable is available separately here although the price is pretty high compared to the full housing/cable set.  Ah well, live and learn.  This is my first time using the teflon Jagwire.  Seems good so far although the teflon seems to come off easily with just a scratch
Worked great for the Schulte closet built-ins on my 18 year old home.  The caps were too small but the clips worked just like the one that broke.

Great product.  PetSafe has a variety of wireless fence products which may or may not be compatible with this indoor barrier so I would recommend you check to make sure you collar is compatible.  I have the Yardmax invisible fence system and the collars work with this.  I was happy to see the cost is very inexpensive and that it is battery operated.  I feel that once you train the dog to avoid areas with this, the barrier may not be needed again.  It is very convenient to just turn it on, set the diameter, and place it where you want.  Right now I am wanting to train my dog to avoid 2 couches.  I got tired of having pet covers and removing them when I want to sit.  This seems to be doing the trick.

Although these shoes do not breath, they are great to have around when going out on the deck, working in the yard, etc.  Love that they are inexpensive and the pattern is quite eye-pleasing.  Recommended!

These are quality pedals and look great.  You can always trust Shimano to produce quality gear and this one is no different.  In the end, it's better to pay a little more for these than to buy lesser quality and end up upgrading in a year or two.

I love this rain gauge.  I have it installed on the railing of my deck.  The red float makes it easy to read, although I do have to be careful not to pour out the float when emptying the water.  I have tried a number of rain gauges including electronic and this is the best one I've ever owned!

I am a been fan of Keen.  The toe area are always nice and wide and they all seem to be great walking shoes whether it be their sandals, their shoes, or their boots.  I love the look of the Keens.  They just look like a million bucks and are comfortable to wear.  They are not as cushiony as running shoes but the soles are more rugged and durable as a hiking shoe should be.  I would say though that these shoes fit like wide shoes.  For me, that's great.  For someone with narrow feet, that may be a problem.

This is a really great monitor at an attractive price.Per TFT Central, used color calibrated settings of:Brightness 20Contrast 50Preset Mode: Custom ColorRGB 100, 93, 99I like this monitor so much, I may just get another one for dual monitor.  The bezel on the top and sides are so small that it would work well in this capacity.  I did have to get my own HDMI cable as well as a DVI (male) to HDMI(female) adapter for my DVI port on my video card.  In my opinion, the screen makes such a huge difference to your computing that it's worth it to spend a little to get quality.  This UltraSharp is clearly the best monitor I've ever used and blows away the Viewsonic IPS monitor I was using before.

This commercial fan is physically large.  It moves a tremendous amount of air and does so without any bells or whistles.  It does not have an oscillating feature.  It has height adjustment and you can tilt the head upwards but not so much downward.  Even fully extended, this fan is very stable owing to the large metal base that is weighted.  You turn it on by pulling a draw cord and also change speeds (3) with the same cord.  My wish list:  rubber feet, oscillating head, speed switch.  For what it is, this fan does the job and seems like it would be durable.

This racket was designed for table tennis enthusiasts like me.  Comparied to your less-expensive brick and mortar sports store offerings, this paddle is light yet solid.  The rubber is great for players who like to spin the ball--be it topspin or chops.  I am not a competitive player so can't speak to it's failings for the elite, but for me, it is a great paddle that I would pay a premium to buy and appreciate the difference.

Back when Nakamichi was a high-end brand these would have sold for a fortune. Now they are a bargain as they offer affordable great sound with Bluetooth convenience.To me the sound is all there without being contrived. So far I haven't been annoyed and at the same time don't think I am missing anything. I listen to all forms of music, some kinds for longer periods of time...The only problem is that Bluetooth is still nerdy. There is all that silly pairing nonsense to deal with, listening to tones, discovery modes and messing around with things to get connected. The directions are written by the only person they could find who does not speak English and is taking a remedial writing course besides. I got this to hook up with my iPad, but it got confused, or I did, trying to connect with a Mac Mini. How about "on" and "off"?Once connected though, it is very good. I can walk 30 feet away and still listen to music and the connection is reliable.I really wanted those beautiful Harman Kardan sort of retro square phones, but this the more practical choice.

Lots of discussion about what is or is not the official Zeiss lens cleaner. This seems to be it, cop-out made in China, but distributed by Zeiss and shipped from their facility. It does not smell like Windex, which is like the quite good generic product the glasses lady sold me. If you ever saw the My Fat Greek Wedding movie, as you should, you would not be Windex-adverse, but in any case it works just fine and the four big bottles should last for years unless you clean windows with it.

Inserts don't last forever, especially if you cut rough stuff like logs. This fits the Grizzly GO570. Some people might not like that the slot is wide and so dust falls through to the lower guide, but my experience is that it does anyway so what the heck.The price is high for a plastic disk, but then again I could never find anything else that I was sure would fit. And I was tired of making ones out of wood.

I am a beginning golfer and so far have refrained from trying to buy my way into a decent game, but these made sense and after installing them I would never go back. My glove size is big. There are smaller sizes available so it makes sense to buy one grip and experiment, then buy a set if they work for you.I see, and feel, no need for a glove now. These are of course bigger than standard grips and are softer and have a tacky feel. Not icky sticky tacky, just right. A good idea for many golfers.

Got so tired of matches. The boxes are scientifically designed to fall apart and the sandpaper striking surface is only good for 1/3 the supply of matches. The Hotshot works great, that torch effect really gets the flame where you need it, even in the wind as promised.. The matches go tomorrow when the garbage gets picked up..Very good for the fireplace and the grill, especially a chimney briquette starter.It ignites reliably, so far for me, but the safety switch is very stiff and the unit is non- refillable so it must be thrown away. Don't know how many cycles this is good for. When it runs out I will try to take it apart and see if it can have a longer, better life.

This actually works for me, a 6.2, 215 lb person who rides a mountain bike on the road and maintained trails for the most part and who was tired of being beat up. Yeah, I shoulda bought a comfort bike, or one with both front and rear suspension, but here I am with what I have. Sort of a cheap way of getting rear suspension. Takes off some of the jolting. Can be adjusted for your weight, trial and error but a good feature.I combined this with a bigger foam seat and some hybrid type tires and this has made riding much better for me.It wiggles a bit from side to side, the anti-twist mechanism a bit more loose than desirable. This can be a little annoying, or ignored which isn't to hard to do.I think the price is very reasonable.

I haven't gotten sunburned, something easily done, and I am outside a lot. It is thick and not a real joy to apply, have to rub it in so the white stuff doesn't make you look weird. The nozzle swivels around and if you are not careful it won't go where you want. Have no background in the chemistry of sun lotions, so can't make an authoritative scientific breakdown. That doesn't stop others, so read such opinions with some care.It works, no odd irritations. I tend to believe in the mineral thing, although not 100%. I think this will be my go-to sun lotion unless there is something very compelling in the future.
These work, fit my Dremel and were the best deal I came across. They last as long as anything and I am glad I bought them. All sandpaper products are too expensive IMO, but what can you do...

It is always good to read of others worse off than you, especially in golf. For this reason and because it is funny and well written it is recommended for all golfers. It also serves as a warning to those contemplating the golfing life. You will have to go through this stage, and might not emerge from it.

Good specs for the price, as you would expect. One went dead, as did one from a previous order of a different type of AmazonBasics battery, and maybe that is coincidence or they are cheaper for a reason...I don't know and I am not going to return one battery. Overall a good deal and I will buy more. I would like to see 9volts offered some day, and D cells too.

This is a universal fit blade and comes with two adaptors. Without them it fits natively to my Dremel. I tested it by cutting a chunk out of a 2 x 4, including a knot, and a framing nail. No drama, no noticeable damage.Its bimetal construction is like a quality hacksaw blade and it does tout titanium coating that they say does extend the life of the tool. I know my original blades died almost immediately upon contacting a nail, so while I suggest to always try to avoid nails with these tools it should survive a number of encounters.Blades are better these day, thank goodness. This is a good tool worthy of purchase.Made in USA.

I suggest practicing on garbage bits first, experimenting with the angles both when you set the depth and then when you set the angle on the final, vertical step. Start with light pressure. You have to be mindful of the cam action when you do the sharpening and keep the chuck in contact with the pin on the body of the device. This will only make sense when you read the directions, watch the video and then get to sharpening.My first project was a cobalt 1/2" bit that was blue from overheating caused by dullness. Now it works fine.This is a touchy feely device. You can't just stick a bit into it and have it come out perfect, but as you work with it you build a rapport and all is good if you pay attention and work with a deliberate pace.The body is plastic, but mounted to a metal substructure. It seems like it will last, except of course you have to replace the diamond wheel now and then, but that is easy.This is a clever and useful device for those of us who have boxes of dull old drill bits. Nobody else would buy such a thing! And we all know a sharp bit is just so much better than the smoke and drama of dull ones.Hecho en USA.

Stores a lot of wire away nicely, prevents knotting, is cheap and just sturdy enough to do the job. Obviously if it was a nice  metal unit it would cost a lot more.As for how to wind the wire:The doubling of the wire method was a pain for me. Hard to unwind, hard to wind up. I thought it would be best and tried that first, but...nah...Todd Pravata's method was best, doing it as he suggests with the male end protruding. The alternative, with the female end hanging out seemed like a good idea, but that leaves you with the reel and a couple of feet or wire where you are working. My leaf blower and electric chain saw both have stubby little power cords which means I would be dragging the reel behind me, up ladders, etc. If all of your tools have long power cords it might be ok doing it like that.So, the prize goes to Todd even though you have to walk back to plug it it. I attached it to the wall, hanging on a hook so it can be unwound by simply walking away with the female end (snort). Remember: people pay to exercise.Made in the US, which was surprising.

One otherwise very nice sink was really disgusting with a corroded drain. This is a quality replacement with nice bright chrome and it made a huge difference. Note that the tailpiece, the bottom section of pipe, is quite short, maybe only four or five inches long. My old one was about eight and so I bought a long tailpiece, cut it to length with a hacksaw and screwed it in. You can also buy an extension that slides on. That works fine, but makes your plumbing look a bit hacked (if you care).The plunger part is made of proper metal, not the cheaper plastic variation.

It must have been really important for Kohler to have drains that look identical but where some take a 1/16 smaller stopper. Must be to keep people busy, designing stuff that is just fine and doesn't require an update. And some of these have a metal lower part and some plastic, and that can be two different sizes as well. I loathe this sort of thing cuz it cost me money as the packaging is in atom bomb proof ultra strong and thick plastic that even a high-end knife is more likely to bounce off and slit your wrist than to cut through and then of course it is not returnable. What a waste. Hope people who specify these changes spend considerable time in the afterlife dealing with their bad ideas, over and over again as the hot sulphur flows waist high.The quality seems good just in case you got lucky and this is the right size for your installation. The top part is nice actual chromed metal and is a step up from the hideous chromed plastic units you find in hardware departments these days, those being more suitable for a 1-hour motel than your house.

Nice cloths so you don't have to keep using that nasty old one that you are too lazy to wash. Yes, I see all and know you do this. Now you can finally clean those glasses and your complete collection of Leica lenses.

These are surprisingly big. Make sure you have enough room amongst the pipes and such under the counter. Use flexible braided supply lines, 1/2 ip at the tank end and normally 3/8 compression at the shut off and faucet end. Be careful at the hardware dept as other types of lines are often improperly displayed.Lines are normally found in twenty and thirty inch lengths. Attaching the line from the red outlet on the tank to the line hanging down from the faucet will require using a 3/8 compression union. Take off the nuts and washers and the ends of the line will screw right on. Be careful to buy compression fittings as pipe fittings will not work.When you run water through it for the first time you will hear air hissing out. When that stops, plug it in and turn it on. Don't turn it on before then as you will burn out the element.I was surprised how fast the water heats up. Do know that the first gallon or so will be hot, but as cold water comes in the temp will go down as the element cannot heat water coming in instantly. But there is enough to wash your hands and after awhile the hot water from your main tank gets there. It is all good.The plastic pipes on the heater are scary. You have to be really sure you are not cross threading on the outlet lines and it is hard to know how tight you are getting them, a trait of plastic connections. Just be careful and attach the lines where you have good access and check for leaks. Mine turned out fine.I found a baking pan that works perfectly for a drip pan and I found a down pipe with a branch outlet on it and hooked up a line from the TP valve (included) to a down pipe with a branch on it.I was put off by the warranty that pretty much says you are out of luck unless a professional plumber installs it. The directions are not detailed and assume the installer has skills, tools, etc. And the plastic pipes are something that requires some care and touch.Made in Japan. I noted that Chinese made heaters seem to be more unreliable than they should be. There is no new technology here and they all should be totally reliable unless cost cutting is excessive. Also, these are not cheap, the WaiWela being on the expensive side. Hope that works out.

This is a work of art, made in the US. I saw a TV show on how they make them, so cool. I have wanted one for a long time even though my cheapo rubber handled 16 oz is ok. I also am not seeing them in stores anymore and I worried they might cease production. I felt flush and bought it happily.

My Kohler Fairfax single-level faucet was feeling stiff and funky. It had to be this cartridge, and it was. Now it is silky smooth and I feel much better about things sink-wise as I replaced the side spray as well (another review).You can watch a certain video channel, You know it, and get instructions. Of course it isn't that easy taking apart an old faucet. This is how to do it:1. Pry out the hot/cold cap on top.2. Remove the screw (some may have allen screws, mine was Phillips). Careful as they can be stuck.3. Remove the lever assembly. It too can be stuck. Lift and kind of push back on it. If it is still stuck get a piece of wood, around 3/4 thick, push the lever down at the front and put the wood between the back of the lever dome thing and the ridge on the part below it. Lift up on the handle and the lever assembly will lever off.4. There is now a dome looking thing with the hole in the middle being where the top of the valve sticks out. Unscrew it. Mine was fairly easy, but some may stick. The IMPORTANT thing to do is to not let the body of the faucet turn as that will ruin the little hoses that screw into the faucet. You can buy them, but they are expensive and usually only available on-line. You can try penetrating oil or perhaps a hair dryer, some sort of clever way to get ahold of things and unscrew it.5. Now there is a retainer that holds the valve in. It too can be stuck.
