I was hooked from the first page and read it in one sitting. A really good read in my book! I'm giving this one 4.5 AMAZEBALLS stars!!Review by Tabitha

When I picked up this story to read, I wasn't sure what it was about.  When I found out it was transgender story, I was a little worried whether I would like it or not.  This story is an amazing story of a journey of discovering ones self.  Kellie never felt right in her body.  She's not Kellie but Kaleb.  Kaleb's journey to becoming who he was suppose to be is not easy.  He has people who are accepting of him and other who are not.  There are a few twists that I didn't expect.  This is definitely is must read!!A copy was received for a review.

Uncovering Peace is book two in the Military Love series.  It can be read as a standalone.  This is Seth and Faith's story.Seth is in a marriage that he's not happy with.  He's in the process of getting a divorce from Krystal.  He likes Faith and is determined to fight for her.  Faith has had an awful childhood and is pretty closed off.  Not many people know of her past.  Reading about her pass is heart wrenching.  Seth is a great guy and stands by hr through everything.  Seth has things to deal with too but their love is a strong one.Uncovering Peace touches on some sensitive subjects but it's done it a great way where you are filled with  emotions but not are totally discussed.A copy was received for a review.

Scandal is part one in a three part series.  This one is a short quick read that ends in a cliffhanger.  I knew there would be a cliffhanger because it's part one but I didn't expect it to but such a big cliffhanger.  I immediately wanted to read part two but I thought I would write my review for part one first.Ella works for The Daily Scandal.  She's not a sleazy paparazzi.  She is caring and kind hearted.  Her former step sister, Madison, is a Hollywood star and is killed.  Ella ends up investigating the story for The Daily Scandal.  During the investigating she meets super sexy Jaxson Cole.  Jaxson is Madison's ex.  There are some many things wrong with Ella starting a relationship with Jaxson.  Some things about Jaxson seem off.  The cliffhanger at the end is crazy and I'm off to read part two to see what happens next.

I love reading reading about real life prison breaks and one of my favorite shows to watch is I Almost Got Away With It.  So, when I read this blurb, I had to read this book.Tessa has fallen in love with the paper version of Max.  She has read his file and seen his picture and she likes him.  When her boss can't make it to Max's parole hearing, she goes in his place.  Tessa is having a bad day and it gets worse when she become parts of a prison break.Max is as sexy in person as he is in his file picture but at first he's not as nice as Tessa excepted.  I wasn't really sure about Max.  He has times where he seems super nice then there are times where we see a completely different side of him.  Tessa goes through a lot of different things and emotions throughout her ordeal.  I really liked Max and Tessa together and I was hoping that when everything came to head that their relationship would last.Unlawful Seizure is a great read.  It keep me hooked from beginning to end.A copy was received for a review.

Pretty In Ink is book two in the Bodies Ink and Steel series.  It can be read as a standalone.  The first book is Blurred Lines and that one is Riley and Blake's story.  If you read that one you already meet Stevie.  This one is Stevie and Wilson's story.I love Stevie.  She's a great down to earth girl.  She speaks her mind and you always know where you stand with her.  She's not like a typical girl, there is nothing fake about her.  Stevie thinks she wants a bad boy biker but that hasn't panned out for her.Wilson is anything but the type of guy that Stevie wants.  He's rich, caring, and sweet.  Sometimes what we think we think we want is not always what works best.  I was glad Stevie gave Wilson a chance and Wilson didn't change to fit the mold of a guy that Stevie thought she wanted.Wilson character has a lot going on.  He had kind of a sheltered up bringing and some of the things his parents instilled in him effect the way he is now.  Wilson's mom is a little crazy and causes trouble for Stevie and Wilson.  I was definitely surprised at some of things that Wilson's mom did.Wilson and Stevie  are great characters that have an amazing story.  Pretty In Ink is definitely one you should one click.

Wow, just wow.  This book was great.  Tegan is a herion addict and the author doesn't hold anything back.  We get the raw and gritty view of Tegan's journey through getting hooked on heroin and getting clean.  We go back and forth between the past and present.  I really liked that and the transitions between past and present were flawless, there was no confusion with switching between the two.Tegan has had a trouble past, drugs became her way to forget the memories.  At rehab she meets Asher.  Asher isn't a patient.  He's a counselor.  Asher has been through a lot too, he's a recovering addict who has turned his life around.  He and Tegan bound pretty quickly.  He not judgmental and he's a very likable character.  They work closely together and feeling get involved.  Their relationship is kind of taboo because it a counselor patient relationship that is frowned upon.I really enjoyed reading this one.  I was rooting for the characters relationship to make it and be something serious between them.  There's no cliffhanger but I really would love to read more about Tegan and Asher.A copy was received for a review.

You know those series that have you so hooked you never want it to end? Yeah, that is this series for me. I fall in love with each book and each time I think, it isn't possible for it to be as good as the last, and each time I am proven wrong. I must say I really have been looking forward to Olivia and Dylan's book from the beginning. Liv has been such a strong character from book one. I knew there would be some major things she has had to deal with in her past and the only one who could help her with it would be Dylan. Boy was I right!! He is the perfect match for Liv and he is willing to do anything to prove that to her. I am truly in love with the Dare family!! I am so excited to read what comes next! Another 5 AMAZEBALLS stars for me!! A copy was gifted in exchange for an honest review.Review by Tabitha

This is the first book I have read by this author and I am hooked!!! This is such a great start to what promises to be a great series. I must say I fell in love with all the McKinnon Sisters immediately. They are such a close knit family and I love that. I, myself, have 3 younger sisters and found that I can totally relate to each one of the McKinnon sisters and how they protect each other. Now onto this book, Faith and Cain are two lovers who have really been through the ringer. Cain went off in the military and had some horrible things happen to him and in the process of that he basically sent a "dear john" letter breaking off their engagement to Faith. He firmly believes that he is not good enough for her until a certain McKinnon sister goes and pays Cain and visit and basically knocks him up side the head and tells him to get his crap together and get Faith back. And things are not smooth sailing for sure, but I love that. Love isn't always easy, but it proves to always be worth it. I love Cain and Faith so much!!! This book was a 5 AMAZEBALLS stars for me! A copy was gifted in exchange for an honest review.Review by Tabitha

Loch is book three in the The Powers That Be series. It can be read as a standalone. Each book follows a different super hot Power's brother.Simone grew up with Loch and she had a major crush on him. Loch was awful in middle school and embarrassed her and her friend. She moved away and life went on but because of how Loch treated her she has nightmares and insecurities.They are both older now and in college. Simone's looks have changed a lot since middle school and Loch has gotten a lot hotter. When there paths cross Loch doesn't recognize her. Simone wants renege for the hell he put her through. But Loch is not the same guy she remembers. Loch has changed a lot and just not in the looks department. He's not that same jerk from middle school. Loch seems to genuinely like Simone but she's has secrets that you know are going to cause major problems when they come out.I loved Simone. She a great character. She's a little geeky and definitely a funny girl. Loch is great too. He super hot but doesn't have that whole cocky thing going on. They both made this an enjoyable story to read.A copy was received for a review.

Fatal Knockout is a crazy emotional roller coaster of a read.  We get Madisyn and Blaze's story.  We get a little past (so we can see how they meet) then it bring us up to the present.  Knowing a little about their past really helps to connect with them.  They have a great love for each other.  I love how Blaze instantly knew that Madisyn was the one for him.  The ending was absolutely crazy.  I can't wait to read the next one.

I really liked reading this book.  It started off a lot different then I excepted.  In the beginning, We get to know Ronnie.  She young and we go along with her as she grows up.  That really helps us to see how she got to where she is today.  She has a always had a huge crush on Jagger.  I thought the story was going to jump right into the con part but instead I really got to know Ronnie and Jagger first.Jagger is a hustler and a con man.  He always thought that Ronnie deserved better then him.  He has one major job that he need Ronnie to help him with.  Things don't always go as plan but it gives Jagger and Ronnie a change to reconnect and act out on there feelings for each.This is a great read, that doesn't have a dull moment.A copy was received for a review.

Episode Six is the last one in Season One.  It can not be read as a standalone, you must read the first five episode first.  In this one we get the POVs of Erin, Skyler, Jess, Adam, Bear, Cassie, and Ashlie.  In this one we get the most of different POVs.  I loved being able to read everyone POV.I was surprised by some of this things that happened.  I don't want to say to much because I don't want to give anything away.  This one is great and it definitely left me wanting more.  I fell like we are left with a lot of the characters having unresolved issues and I can't wait for Season Two to see what happens next.A copy was received for a review.

After reading It's A Date, I was left wanting more of Noah and Heather's story.  I couldn't wait to get my hands one A Winter's Date.  A Winter's Date is not a standalone, you must read It's A Date first.In the beginning Noah is with Heather in London.  Crazy Alexis is there too.  OMG Alexis really showed how crazy she is in this one.I was hoping for some more happiness before we got sadness.  At about 9% we are hit was some tragedy and then it get worse before it gets better.  I loved how strong Noah is even when you know he has to be falling apart inside.I loved reading the sad and happy parts of their story.  The ending took me by surprise.  I didn't expected the heartbreak at the end.  It's very crazy heartbreaking ending.  I can't wait to read the next one and see the characters do next.A copy was received for a review.

When I saw this book on my schedule to read, I wasn't overjoyed.  I couldn't remember why I wanted to read it.  I went into reading this one thinking it wasn't going to be great and I was just like let me read and it get it done.  Asylum Harbor was definitely one book that I underestimated.  I was very surprised on how much I liked this book.  It hooked me in right from the beginning and I read it in one siting because I didn't want to put it down.Devon is escaping a difficult family situation and she ends up on Shell Island.  She doesn't like water so it's a little weird that she picked an island for her shelter.  She meets some great characters on the Island.  Devon meets the harbormaster, Kerr.  Kerr is a little stand offish but he melts little for Devon.  Her boss at the Salty Dog, Diane, seems nice but she has a lot of stuff going on.  Danny is Kerr brother and he rents the room across from Devon.  Where Kerr is cold and not very friendly, Danny is friendly and nice.  There is a lot of mystery about the characters.  I kept trying to figure out what their past was.  There is definitely some heavy past stuff going on between Kerr, Danny, and Diane.Asylum Harbor is a good read.  I feel like there are still some unanswered questions so I will definitely be reading the next one.A copy was received for a review.

I have read all the books in this series so far and while you can read them as standalones, I really believe you should read them in order because they all have intertwined characters and well honestly because they are really dang good. When Decklan was first introduced in Gabe's book (Dare to Surrender) I have to be honest and tell you that I knew his book was going to be freaking awesome. Decklan just had this "thing" about him that drew me in and made me really want to know him. I have to say it did not disappoint in the least. I was hooked from page one and did not get anything done until it was over. And then I decided I had to start the next one because I just could not wait. This series is not one to be missed. I really think you will fall in love with every single character I promise. This was another 5 AMAZEBALLS stars for me!! A copy was gifted in exchange for an honest review.Review by Tabitha

Another 5 star read for me!! This author really knows how to make you want to never get up and do anything other than read. I keep thinking there is no way this series could be any better and every time I am proven wrong. I really can't decide who is my favorite Dare man so far. Gabe is the cousin to Ian and Alex from books 1 and 2 and boy does he heat things up!! I love the whole Invitation to Eden element too. Isabelle and Gabe are another awesome couple in this family. And might I just add that whole scene with Decklan and Isabelle in the beginning is hilarious!! Love every single thing about this book and can't wait to read Decklan's book. A copy was given a copy in exchange for an honest review.Review by Tabitha

This is book two of this series and I must say just as great as the first!! I totally fell in love with Alex in Dare to Love and honestly couldn't wait to read his book and was super excited to know that his was next. Alex goes through something traumatic in the beginning and really doesn't handle it well. And while Madison wants so badly to be there for him, he won't let her. Then fast forward a few months and he knows he screwed up and is going to do anything possible to get her back. I also want to say that Madison is a really great heroine and is the perfect partner for the elusive Alex Dare. I am really in love with this series and can not wait to read more. This is an easy 5 AMAZEBALLS stars rating for me!! A copy was gifted in exchange for an honest review.Review by Tabitha

HOLY HOTNESS BATMAN!!! I seriously didn't think Ms. Bliss could even come close to making this one as awesome as the first in this series, Sinful Intent, but boy she did. I am in love with the ALFA PI series!!! Morgan blew my mind and made me pant. Frisco, well he made my head spin and heart skip many beats along with melting my panties. I LOVE Frisco is supposed to be a bad boy and does everything he can to prove he is for lack of a better word, a manwhore. Doesn't stick around for more than one night and definitely has no relationship with anyone since he caught his cheating ex fiancee. Georgia is the coolest dang heroine. She is a sassy, spitfire that doesn't back down. She sees who Frisco really is and not who he wants everyone to think he is. These two together are explosive!! I can not wait to read the rest of this series! These are MUST READS!!! A copy was given in exchange for an honest review. I rate this one 5++ AMAZEBALLS stars!!Review by Tabitha

When I first heard about this book I thought it was a young adult book but it is definitely not a young adult book.  We meet Shaylee on her twenty first birthday.  Her birthday is not the typical bar hopping twenty first birthday.  She finds out she is only half human and the other half is faery.  Aden is the one to tell Shaylee that she isn't fully human.  He is a super sexy faery who has know Sahylee most of her life.Shaylee is thrown into a world that she never believed existed.  As Aden explains this to her, we also get to learn about Rien, the Fae Realm.  I really liked that we got to learn about the Fae Realm and it wasn't done in a way that made me feel bogged down with information.There is a lot of sexual tension between Shaylee and Aden.  Aden is a patient guy but he can only take so much waiting before the tension explodes into some steamy scenes.  While Aden and Shaylee are getting reacquainted, there is danger lurking around too.I really enjoyed reading this story and I can't wait Laila and Ean story.A copy was received for a review.

I absolutely loved the beginning of this story.  It had me laughing.  Lara is starting her new job but her first day doesn't go as she expected.  She ends end falling in front of a car during a rain storm.  That's how is meets Reed.  Reed was driving the car.  Reed is a very sexy and wealthy man.  He is also very confident and cocky.  I was not a big Reed fan at first, he was just a little to cocky for me.  Lara has an amazing best friend Kade.  Kade is a huge part of Lara's life.  There also some parts were Lara thinks Reed is a prefect match for Kade.  Reed knows he has to win over Kade and become friends with him in order to move on with Lara.  I loved reading how Reed changes throughout the book.  In the beginning we get cocky Reed but as we read on we get a loving Reed.A copy was received for a review.

Season One continues with Episode Five.  In this one we get the POVs of Jess, Ashlei, Adam, and Bear.  This is my favorite serial to read.  Each Episode we get a fresh view on event with different POVs.  I never know who's POVs we are going to get until I start reading.  I was glad to get more Bear in this one.  I thinks Bear may just be my favorite.  I love the tension between Jess and Jarrett.  Ashlie is a very interesting character and has gotten herself into a little bit of trouble.  I can't wait to read the next one.

Blurred Lines is a great read.  It's book one in a new series called Bodies Ink & Steel but there' no cliffhanger.  If you read the Selected Sinners MC series, you'll notice a few characters from there pop up in this one.Riley got caught up in an unhealthy relationship.  She is now free from it and wants a tattoo.  Blake is a tattoo artist who owns his own shop.  Riley goes to his shop for her tattoo.  She is expecting an overweight former sailor to be doing her tattoo  but instead she gets Blake.  Blake is very attractive and has amazing eyes.Blake has issues and a rough past.  He has some major surprising issues.  He had me guessing what was actually going on with him.This a was a very interesting read.  The prologue hooked me and the story keep me hooked the whole time.

I honestly don't even know where to begin with this review. Ok, now onto this book....Shawn and Taralynn have known each other practically their whole lives. Their brothers are best friends so in turn they are friends. Taralynn wants much more than just friends with Shawn, but he just won't give in and making her feel like he doesn't want her as anything more than a friend. However, Shawn does want Taralynn he just doesn't think he is good enough for her. STOP RIGHT THERE....this is where I wanted to strangle him. Like reach into the book and strangle him. I really loved Shawn from the get go although there were many points I wanted to not just strangle him, but throttle him as well. This book had me hot one minute, mad the next, and bawling my eyes out next. Ms. Henderson has a way of pulling you in and holding on so tight. I truly felt like I didn't breathe until the very end. It was a rollercoaster of emotions. I recommend this book and any book this author publishes. She is one of my MUST READS!!! A copy was gifted in exchange for an honest review. I rate this book 5++ AMAZEBALLS stars!!!Review by Tabitha

I loved reading Nerd Girl. It got romance but also comedy in to it.Amy is a shy girl and a book nerd. At a book signing she bumps into cover model, Derrick. They way they meet is super funny. Derrick find her attractive but Layla doesn't know what he would see in her. After the signing, Amy's best friend, Layla, helps get them together again. Amy is a very funny character. Derrick's best friend, Riven, is very funny too.Not only do they have overcome Amy's insecurities but they also have problems with Derrick's manager, Mitzi.Nerd Girl is a must read.

Love Burns is book two in the  Caged Love series.  It can not be read as a standalone, you must read Love Hurts first.  Love Burns picks up where Love Hurts left off.I was pulled right into this book and it kept me glued to it the whole time.  The beginning starts off with a bang.Andrew is back and things about him are not actually what I thought they were.  It seems like Frankie didn't know everything that was going on with Andrew either.  Deacon is a fighter and a fierce protector.  When Frankie is faced with danger he goes into protector mode.There is a lot more action and suspense in this one. Of course there are some great steamy scenes with Deacon and Frankie.  Love Burns is a great read.A copy was received for a review.

Saw "The Martian" a week ago - loved it.  Received the soundtrack today, played the Score on Disc 2 by Harry Gregson-Williams on my 5.1 system. Totally immersive.  It sounds awesome and takes me mentally back to the sense of awe when I saw the movie.  My favorite track is #3 "Making Water" but each song of the score is shines in it's own way.  A mix or organic and electronic sounds:  orchestra  combined at times with sequenced / arpeggiated analog synths with delay.  Digital synths.  Obscure instruments.  Sometimes I think I  hear Tibetan prayer bowl on some of the ethereal scenes.  This is in the same realm to me as "Valley In The Clouds" by David Arkenstone as far it's ability to evoke space and mystery.  As for Disc #1, the one that has all the pop Abba, Donna Summers, disco, etc.?  I'll probably play it occasionally for grins and giggles.  It was funny in the movie theater to see Matt Damon rocking out to Hot Stuff in the middle of nowhere.  I already own the Bowie track ("Starman" from Ziggy Stardust) but I'm glad a new generation gets to hear it.TECHNO INFO FOR THE GEEKS (Skip if you want):  Audio quality is excellent for a conventional 16bit 44.1 "Red Book" audio CD.  Good dynamic range.  Smooth, un-harsh.  The audio peaks are not clipped or compressed.  It can give you stereo a really good workout.  You'll want to turn it up.SUMMARY:  I love it.  This will tide me over and put me inside the movie until the Blu-Ray is released in (supposedly) Jan 2016.  Maybe by then I'll be living inside the score!  I think the score disc will be something that holds my interest over time.
Great pasta bowl.  Cleans easily, looks good.  Just the right size for a hearty sized meal.  Reasonably priced - I bought two at $6.99 each.

Miracle product for ingrown hairs, wood slivers, and the occasional deep zit that hurts and puffs up but wont surface or subside. (No, people with acne should NOT apply to entire face,  if you have acne that is a bit different).  I had a sliver in my toe and put some of this on a bandaid, went to bed.  After 2 nights of treatment, the sliver had surfaced and was easily removable.  By the way, I had success using this product when it was past the expiration date.  No problem.  I think this stuff pretty much lasts forever as long as you keep the lid on.  I'm glad to have this in my medicine cabinet.P.S. this is not for open wounds and yes it does smell like an oil field with camphor.

It's BIG.  I wanted a dress watch and bought this from Amazon online.  I'm not tiny by any means.  5ft 11, a fair amount of pounds on me.  My shirts are XL to XXL, broad shoulders, large hands, etc.  The dial diameter on this watch is still ** almost ** too big for my wrist.  I'm keeping it, it works, but I would caution those who have medium to smaller builds/ wrists that this watch may look out of proportion on you.  I'm going to have 1 link taken out of the band.  It would be nice if they had something(s) next to the watch to give a sense of scale.  All that being said, it's eye catching and seems to be well made.  It came packed in a nice case with a micro size padded "pillow" to wrap the watch around.  For 60 bucks I will keep it.  So far, I can't speak to it's accuracy.  HISTORY WITH PREVIOUS ARMITRON DRESS WATCH:  My last Armitron Men's dress watch ( a sort of Rolex Oyster blue dial knock off) did and (even now)  still does keep good time.  However, the band clasp failed after 2 years use and the * correct * band that goes with that model costs 2/3 of a new watch ($39.95).  My previous Armitron to that (divers watch with all stainless case, blue dial) lasted 3 or so years.  My opinion:  Armitrons are a compromise, you get a decent looking watch that will probably cost you 1/2 to a 1/3 of a Seiko and last you about 3 years of constant use.  In the case of this watch, if your usage pattern is:  occasional use, night on the town, "bling" watch, that spends most of it's time in a drawer except for every other friday... it might last you 10 years (with the required battery changes of course.)  Most definitely this is NOT the watch to wear for everyday rough trade / carpentry, work.

This is my boot / OS System C drive for my new PC build. It's very fast, I have a very short boot time to Windows 10 login screen. Rock Solid performance. No waiting, no freezes, no blue screens. Other components for reference: MSI Gaming 7 motherboard, 32GB DDR3 RAM, Core i7-4790 CPU.P.S. After a week of using this "as is" (which was damn good by itself), I downloaded a trialware copy of a RAM drive software (there are a lot of these on the Net, mine has perfect in the name) and created a 2 GB RAM drive. This slowed down the boot up a bit IF you are doing a true, full reboot. In exchange though, it made my PC even faster overall and I believe it reduces some of the wear leveling stress on the drive (i.e. improves reliability a bit). PC is now ridiculously fast. I've never had it so good. P.S. except for completing patching or certain new program installs, rarely (in my case) is a full reboot needed. So... I just put the PC into "Sleep" mode and when I need to use it, reactivation takes maybe 3 to 4 seconds to reach login screen.SUMMARY:  *** HIGHLY RECOMMENDED ***

I installed WD Black 3TB as my data drive on a new PC build (modern MSI mobo [Gaming 7] with fast Intel CPU).  This WD 3TB drive is not my boot drive.  I formatted this drive into 4 different volumes, all NTFS partitions using Windows Disk Management.  I then imported (transferred) around 1TB total data from an external Mediasonic USB 3.0 enclosure that had a 7200 rpm Toshiba drive in it.  The data transfer using USB 3.0  was a smooth process, probably took 3, maybe 4 hours max.  So far so good.  Drive is very fast and quiet.  Runs cool.  Currently cruising at 26 degrees celsius (79 degrees Fahrenheit) after PC being on for 4 hours.  Tons of room.  For what I paid ($151.00 in Aug 2015) I am very pleased with price/performance ratio.  For my purposes it's the right balance between future proofing and affordability.P.S.  Owners manual mentioned it is possible to use this series of Black drives in RAID 0, RAID 1 or 0+1 but, Western Digital will not provide technical support for those usage scenarios.

Worked flawlessly a connector for a Samsung blu-ray player SPDIF output that sends PCM data to an Orei (brand) DAC converter that generates stereo analog output as a final result.  No crackle, balking, glitches, etc.  Not one iota of hassle.  No worries. Very happy.

This worked GREAT.  I am so pleased.  I was doing a brand new PC build, my Thermaltake Chasar A41 ATX case has toolless drive bay "inserts" or "slideout" units.STEPS:1.  I first attached my Samsung 2.5" SSD drive onto the connector of this Sabrent template/frame device. (You slide the drive a half inch onto the Sabrent card connector, slight pressure needed, no drama).2.  I snapped the Sabrent template/frame into my Thermaltake drive bay slideout unit and then...3.  I snapped the drive bay slideout unit that now contains the Sabrent template/frame & SSD drive into my ATX case.4.  VOILA!I was ready to cable up in less than 2 minutes start to finish and some of that was just briefly looking things over.  I've never had a drive install this easy in the 19 or so years I've been building computers.CAVEAT:  Now, half of that ease-of-use depended on the engineering of my particular case design.  If you had an older school case, you will probably have to get out the screw driver and deal with screws.  Those will tool-less cases will be in heaven.I do like that this Sabrent template/frame presents an interface right to the edge of of a 3.5" format.  Cables went on very easy._________________________________________________________________________________________*** HIGHLY RECOMMENDED *** if you have a case that supports spaces for 3.5 inch hard drive units and you want to get a 2.5 inch drive installed in that 3.5 inch space quickly and painlessly.

I found these to be high quality stereo audio cables.  The connectors have a snug but workable fit.  The 1.5 ft length IN REALITY (when it arrives and you are actually going to use it) is shorter than you'd actually think, a bit restrictive.  For my purposes it was "just enough" to work with.  If you are trying to eliminate clutter (and yeah I was) and your audio components are right on top of each other, this length will work.  I found myself wishing for 2ft length for a little more patching / setup flexibility / breathing room.  Anyway, I got this to work and am satisfied with the outcome and quality of these cables.

I bought the 5 meter version of this cord.  I use it to provide a Line Out audio level connection to a powered stereo fill speaker that I put out when I have outdoor deck parties.  The cable is well built and FLEXIBLE YET STURDY.  It looks classy and the connectors are well made mate up well with a Sony boombox 3.5mm line input.  So far no crackle, no hassle, just good sound.  I am happy, would buy this again.
Very flexible, priced right.  These have worked great for me, no hassles.

I bought this specifically for Moonlight Drive which was not included on my 2 Disc Doors Greatest Hits compilation (a crime!)  While I can appreciate Horse Latitudes (Song #5) as intense method acting of poetry, I can't listen to it for pleasure.  The Doors did have a lot of guts though and they believed in what they were doing.  As far as the technical audio quality on this Elektra/Rhino/DMC release with 2007 copyright, its quite good!  i.e. especially for what looks at first glance to be a "plain jane" commercial Red-book audio CD release costing $7.99.  Very clear sound, yet the upper midrange has none of that digital harshness I normally associate with CDs.  Lots of air, soundstage and ambience.  No "Loudness Wars" here.  (i.e. this disc is very well mastered, it does NOT have it's dynamic range severely compressed). Quite refreshing in that regard. I believe that "People Are Strange" and "Love Me Two Times"  from this disc sound way clearer than the same songs from my 2 CD Doors compilation (purchased probably 15 years earlier).THE BONUS STUFF:  As a bonus you get Take 3 of People Are Strange and also Love Me Two Times.  The People bonus track has a long studio banter and a bunch of false starts, not a complete song.  It's interesting to hear the creative process but most won't want to hear that repeatedly.  On the other hand the Take 3 of Love Me Two Times is a full song.  It's pretty darn close to the final cut we all know and love.  I prefer the final version of LMTT though, I think the vocals are recorded better but the bonus take is no slouch.BOOKLET, PACKAGING & OVERALL QUALITY EXPERIENCE:  The 20 pages (back to back) booklet is very well done. It contains cool/interesting photos, lyrics to all songs, and background on the album recording sessions.  Some good stories in there.  There's a cool sepia toned photo of the band underneath where the disc is seated.  You can tell that that a lot of loving care was lavished on this CD release.  Comments on page 2 of the CD booklet from Ray Manzarek imply this audio is taken from the original master tape.  I believe it, it sounds so good.  I love the sound of the snare on this album, the overall ambience.  The original engineer (Bruce Botnick) did this "40th Anniversary Mix".  It's not just a cash cow or an afterthought. It's a labor of love.  I admire the heck out of Ray and Co. for seeing to it that the band's legacy is preserved this way.In short  --->  You are getting a lot for $8.00, this is a good deal.  A quality experience.  I can recommend it.The disc I purchased has a UPC of 081227999841.P.S.  For those who remember the Doors "13" vinyl LP back in the day, that was my first wider exposure to their catalog.  I loved the sequencing of the songs on that compilation.

Initial review.  Just received these today, 9 days after I placed my order. The discs literally shipped from the city of Hamamatsu in Shizuoka prefecture, Japan.  Arrived in perfect physical condition, undamaged.  They have both Kanji and English text on the case.  Note:  Nothing on the package specifically states in English "Made In Japan".You are not getting a manufactured by Sony product.I ran DVD Identifier, it's a Ritek.  If you Google for Ritek Blu-Ray reliability, the reviews are not good.  There are reports of discs deteriorating after 1, to 1.5 years.  Note:  It's very hard to find perfect, long term archival Blu-Ray discs.  I am going to look at Blu-Rays as one part of my backup strategy, alongside pen drives and magnetic spinning hard drives.  These are OK for shipping a video to relatives or for a short term holding tank for files.  I wouldn't look at this or any consumer burned Blu-Ray disc as a true archival storage medium.I will burn some videos, file archives soon and update this review later.  I just bought a Pioneer D-209 burner (2209) but have yet to obtain burner software (leaning towards LeaWo Blu-ray Creator).----------------------------------------------------------------------------Unique Disc Identifier : [BD-R-SL:RITEK-BR3-000]----------------------------------------------------------------------------Disc Type :  [BD-R SL : Class 0 - Version 1]Manufacturer Name :  [Ritek Corp.]Manufacturer ID :  [RITEK]Media Type ID :  [BR3]Product Revision :  [000]Stamper Date :  [October 2010]Layer Info :  [1 Layer (L0) : 25.03 GB (23.31 GiB) Per Layer]Blank Disc Capacity :  [12,219,392 Sectors = 25.03 GB (23.31 GiB)]Recording Speeds :  [1x , 2x , 4x , 6x]----------------------------------------------------------------------------[ DVD Identifier V5.2.0 - http://DVD.Identifier.CDfreaks.com ]----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Rough ride on initial install.  I have purchased many video cards (AMD & nVidia) for many system builds over the years.  I bought this card to add to my new Windows 10 PC build (Intel i7-4790, MSI Gaming 7 motherboard, 32GB RAM, brand new, totally current hardware).  I had an older AMD card that worked fine but I wanted to have any performance edge that could be obtained without generating extra noise.  I can say that this card is - so far - totally silent.  I'm not a gamer by the way, primary purpose of PC is general surfing, some hi-def movies, and work from home (business).After disinstalling AMD drivers and Catalyst, setting restore point, rebooting,I find out I had to find very specific Win10 drivers that were only 2 weeks old  355.80-desktop-win10-64bit-international.hf.  I install them and find that, right after the desktop loads, there's this hesitation and settle down period where my mouse wont respond, screens don't totally respond.  This is subtle in some ways, you don't usually see an hourglass (or circle going around in this case).I have had to replug my mouse, etc.  I have the latest nVidia driver for Win10 64bit.The everyday display quality / contrast, sharpness, etc seems a bit lackluster.  Don't know why.  Quite honestly my older AMD 6670 card or my nVidia GT430 card - either one of them seemed to have more snap or clarity than this card.  I could swear that general latency (from mouse click to screen or video delivered) is lacking compared to my old video card.I find the Strix will run 1080p YouTube videos no problem.  No dropped frames.  The video quality seems a bit ....subdued.This may be an interrupt issue or an initial driver release issue.  It works, it's just not the improvement I thought I was going to get.Maybe if I get some sleep and come back to this it wont seem so bad.  I may move card to one of my other PCI 3.0 slots this weekend to see if (again just speculating) if it's a card slot/ interrupts, resources issue.  I was somehow expecting less hassles and a sharper snappier picture for $170 over my old videocard.  The jury is out on this.  I will check back later with more info.UPDATE:  9/05/2015  Things are a bit better.  1.  I have 3 PCI express 3.0 slots, moved card from the top slot to the middle slot.  Peformance seems snappier, less "settling" when changing screens, etc.  2.  I upgraded from my older 500Watt Seasonic power supply to a Cyonic 650 watt modular PSU (Seasonic sourced/rebadged PSU).  Probably overkill but that was part of this last change I just made.  I still feel/experience on a body intuition/egonomic level the text readability / legibility / ease-on-the-eyes of my older AMD 5970 card was sharper than this nVidia card.  Obviously that older AMD card would not have a prayer of matching the video/multimedia/gaming rendering performance of this card but a lot of my usage scenario is looking at text.  I will run through the clear text settings - again - to see if I get any improvement.  At this point: yeah it works...now after putting me through some changes, I am keeping it.  Will report back later with longer term usage report.  P.S.  My monitor on this box is a Viewsonic VA2431wm which I have had for a couple years and have loved.  Set to 1080p using DVI connector.UPDATE 9/19:  Working good, this videocard is silent for the purposes I use it for.  I suppose if I did gaming the fans would spin up enough to be noticable but for now dead quiet.UPDATE 9/27:  It works fine now, no hassles, just a rough start due Win 10 being newly released for general retail sale at the time I purchased this card.  Once I found the correct drivers, my problems went away.

3 PCI 3.0 slots, USB 3.1, High quality, dream BIOS..what's not to love here?  I paired this with a Samsung 850 Pro SSD (OS / boot drive), WD Black 3TB 7200 rpm hard drive, Intel Core i7-4790 running stock,  Noctua cooler Noctua Premium Quality Quiet CPU Cooler for Intel 1150 Socket NH-U9S,32 GB of GSkill ARES DDR3 2400 RAM, 550 Watt Seasonic power supply. It's screaming fast.  I am spoiled. I can have many multimedia windows open and nothing stutters or breaks a sweat (CPU hovers at 50 degrees C , 122 degrees F)  My rig is near silent.  The BIOS is very posh... the graphics, navigation, etc.  I have never had so much information, setting choices (and decent EXPLANATIONS regarding setting choices) BUT!  --> You are ** not **  forced to use all that info it you don't want it.  Just set the time, take the defaults.  It's all good.For Overclockers and those who want to fuss with settings:  You ** could ** spend most of your adult life manually tweaking the plethora of RAM and CPU parameters here.  I can't be bothered with that, but it's certainly there for those who want it.OTHER COOL THINGS:  The slot spacings are wide enough you are unlikely to have component spacing conflicts.  There are dual LED hexadecimal readouts that give you codes you can look up to see why something might not be working.  Aside from the excellent functionality, did I mention that it looks flat out great?MSI gives you two USB 2.0, six USB 3.0 and 2 (two) USB 3.1 jacks, so..those who can't afford a USB hub to begin with have a generous supply of USB ports to work with .  The 3.1 jacks were a deciding factor to me - future proofing without taking up a card slot.It has an M2 socket but I passed on that.  If you use the MD2 socket, it will eat up Sata connectors 7 and 8.There is a single PS2 connector that supposedly can be used for either Keyboard or mouse.  (Yes PS2 is ancient but some people have beautiful PS2 input hardware they don't want to part with just yet.).I didn't bother with the onboard video but you are given a lot of connectors for that.  For audio, I'm using an external DAC but, if I wasn't, the Realtek sound chips have gotten so good that it wouldnt be a bad solution.The built in Ethernet networking (NIC) is the "Killer" (brand) licensed hardware.  I don't game anymore really so I can't speak to if it's any faster than an Intel NIC but it certainly delivers solid, zippy performance.I declare this board a winner.  I didn't buy it here at Amazon but I can certainly recommend it.ADDENDUM:  I got some RAM DISK software and created a 2GB RAM BOOT DISK.  You have to wait a bit for the boot to happen but Gads!  the surfing is blazing fast now.  Very please with how things turned out.

It works!  We recently bought a Samsung Blu-Ray player as a gift for my son-in-law and his sweetie.  Their flat screen had so-so built-in speakers and their old skool receiver had no HDMI inputs, just stereo RCA analog audio inputs.  I purchased this unit and ALSO purchased this cable C2G / Cables To Go 29115 Velocity S/PDIF Digital Audio Coax Cable (6 Feet) .  When we hooked it up it immediately worked.  Audio content from movies sounds good, clear.  Sound is in sync with the picture.  Now their setup has some real bass and oomph.  This will be a solution for them until they can afford a modern 7.1 surround receiver/speaker setup.Note:  We went into the Blu-Ray player's audio settings and confirmed that PCM was set as the default.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -CAVEATS, TECHNICAL ADVICE:Caveat 1:  This only produces stereo output (Left and Right analog audio jacks).  In the setting of your Blu-Ray player:  You ** have ** to use PCM (Pulse Code Modulation) output setting if you want this to work right  -- it specifies that right on the box.  Now, some people may have an older receiver that would have a feature to synthesize surround for a 5.1 system but usually, if you have that feature available to you, then one would "tend to" also have HDMI inputs on their receiver.  If you have HDMI inputs on your audio receiver... why bother?  This is a work around for those who don't.  IF your receiver has HDMI inputs, the high likelihood is that you don't need this.  IF your receiver has HDMI inputs and you aren't getting audio output 1. Check your settings and the sequence in which you turn components on  (I find that turning on my plasma TV before turning on my receiver works better).  2.  You might need to find an HDMI cable that specifies it has "audio return".All that being said, if you need this kind of workaround solution to deliver an analog feed an older sound system, then  ---> running your Blu-Ray player's sound output through a decent stereo's analog inputs using this interface conversion box beats the pants off using the the wimpy speakers in most TVs.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -Caveat 2:  OREI DOES ** NOT ** GIVE YOU A NON-OPTICAL (i.e. copper wire) CABLE ...which I believe will be the solution most people actually want.  YOU HAVE TO PURCHASE ONE SEPARATELY.  I strongly recommend buying a speficially "Digital" cable, labeled as being meant for SPDIF (Sony/Panasonic Digital Interface) like in the link I mentioned above - they run 5 - 10 dollars.  If you try using a conventional RCA analog audio cable the digital signal may corrupt or the sound could stutter, especially over longer cable lengths.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -Caveat 3:  I suppose there may be some Blu-Ray players out there that, for cost cutting purposes, have omitted the SPDIF connector that looks like a single RCA jack.  In which case this product would not be a solution you could use.Final note:  This unit also comes with an optical connector interface and a probably 3 ft optical cable.  I did not use that feature or test it so cannot speak to how well it works.  You * could * run the blu-ray player's HDMI cable to your flat screen and then, IF it had an optical out, use the supplied optical cable to this OREI box and then run RCA analog cables to your stereo.  The big unknown is:  Will the audio output "lag" or stay in sync with your TV?  Sometimes you can set video / sound delay in your TV.  You'd just have to test.  Again, if your receiver has HDMI built in, there is usually no need to use this kind of product.

Clean Win 10 Pro install on a blazing fast PC, runs smoothly, quickly, I'm coming to like it more and more.It was time to completely rebuild one of my PCs that had very old hardware and Win 7.  I had choices.  Did not want to cling to Win 7.  I wanted the known performance improvements to the network stack, WDDM, etc that came along with Win 8.X without it's known UI aggravations.  I made a conscious decision to purchase Win 10 Pro.At first I hated the tiles until I learned how to customize them and also create my own.  Runs very smooth and fast on Intel i7-4790K 16Gig RAM , Samsung 850 Pro SSD setup.  No real complaints here.  I have yet to get a blue screen, no OS crashes.  I did choose "Custom" install option and opted out of all the nosy nelly information sharing settings with Microsoft.  I have no doubt that some remain.  C'est L'vie.  I have read that people doing an upgrade install instead of a "clean" (fresh) install can supposedly have slow boot issues.  I guess I'll find out when I take the free upgrade offered on my other two older PCs.One review I just read said it about right:  "Look at it as Windows 7.5 and you wont be disappointed."P.S. Note: Some perpective:  I avoided Windows 8.X like the plague as I hated the interface.  The interface for Win 10 I can work with.Trouble in Paradise?  I noticed tonight that while Windows Media Player 12 that comes with Windows 10 allows for ripping files to FLAC,etc., I cannot seem to RIP the songs of my legally purchased Doors "Strange Days" album to my hard drive for my music server.  This is a bummer and inconvenience.

My downstairs PC was a very old 2.6Ghz 4GB Core2 Duo circa 2008 that I upgraded piecemeal at times (Win7, more drives, etc).  I realized it's performance was holding me back and I had done the frugal "get your value out of an older device" thing long enough.  I looked at all the current options, including Skylake and X99 40 lane mothboard / chip combos.  I finally settled on this, MSI extreme 7, Samsung EVO 850 Pro SSD, 16gig Gskill RAM and Noctua CPU fan Noctua Premium Quality Quiet CPU Cooler for Intel LGA 2011,1156,1155,1150 and AMD AM2/AM2+/AM3/3+,FM1/2 Sockets NH-U9S.  Boy am I glad I did!  It's just NIGHT and DAY faster than my old system.  Nothing crashes anymore, I have simply thrown a battleship's worth of resources at the problem and hey IT WORKS.  Surfing, telecommuting no longer has any lag.  The thing resumes from sleep in less than 2 seconds.P.S.  it's running just fine with an older Seasonic 550 watt power supply.  I am using a modest, older AMD video card (6670)  as gaming is not my focus.  My CPU temperature hovers at 50 degrees Celsius (122 degrees Fahrenheit) when just surfing but multiple windows open.  Surfing performance would probably get even better with a GTX 950 Strix videocard which I may purchase in near future.

Upon initial purchase, I was not impressed.  Reason:  I have large hands and found myself wishing this keyboard was inflated in overall size (except height) by 1 or maybe 2 percent.  I don't like the gritty feel of the tops of the keys.  It's like fingernails on the blackboard to me.  Mind you most will say the "grit" is a subtle texturing but it instinctively irritates me.Understand that I LOVED my older Microsoft ergonomic keyboard.  I thought it was ergonomically perfect.  Smooth key tops, everything instinctively in the right place - no mistyping as far as reach and finger placement goes.  It's only failing was that it had a PS2 connector.This Perixx, it's hard to put into words but I don't have a solidity / confidence / certainty when I type.  I'm making adjustments, the tips of my fingers at rest "notice" that they are touching the sides of the next row of keys.I may send this back.  I also ordered a Microsoft 4000 ergonomic keyboard - it's on it's way.  I'm told the MS keyboards have kind of devolved into mediocrity.  We will see.  If the MS 4000 beats this in any way, this is going back or being relegated to a backup.Maybe people with smaller hands who like the gritty feel of the keys will like this.  I can't fault the overall feature count, just the feel.  It "looks" good.  I simply can't recommend it.P.S.  Point of reference regarding my hand size:  I wear a size 11.5 - 12 ring on my ring finger and can, with a slight stretch, reach a 10th interval on a real Yamaha or Steinway piano.UPDATE 8/28/2015:  BIZARRE BUT TRUE:  Ergonomics on this keyboard got much better for me once I put a 3/4" thick piece of wood that is 3 inches wide under the front part of the keyboard.  This piece of wood is probably 16 - 18 inches long.  Long enough to have an inch of extra wood showing on either side of the keyboard.  It makes sense in a way - there have been other ergonomic keyboards with detachable front spacer/elevator components.UPDATE 9-01-2015  I'm raising this from 2 stars 4 stars since my "fix" works - put something (a small board?, piece of plastic, etc. ) that is of size:  3/4" thick X 18" long X 3" wide under the front edge of this.  It's may be a funky fix but it transformed the ergonomics for me.  Your mileage may drastically vary.  I just know it changed this keyboard from a loser to a winner for me.  The one star taken off is for me having to come up with this fix.

I did double takes when first starting up my i7-4790K /MSI Gaming 7/Samsung 850 Pro build as I couldn't believe the fan was actually running it's so quiet.  (Note I'm only running one fan as I'm not overclocking.  It's capable of accepting a 2nd fan.)Does not interfere with my RAM sticks or other cards.Highly recommended.

I was looking for ATX cases that still have front 5.25" bays --- that still had some kind of styling.  They are getting hard to find.  With bluetooth, MP3s, etc, there is less demand for optical drives.  Me, I want those front bays to put in a Blu-Ray/DVD burner (yes I still burn discs), possibly a fan controller, or multi-slot card reader, etc.I order this, it shows up and it's very easy to look at, well styled.THE GOOD:*  This case has GREAT CABLE MANAGEMENT as it gives you a section partitioned off behind the motherboard with multiple pass-through grommets to feed cables in such a way that they don't interfere with airflow or look unsightly.*  The TOOL-LESS SLIDE OUT BRACKETS FOR HARD DRIVES - WORK GREAT.  Very smart idea to position them 90 degrees perpendicular to the case itself.  VERY easy to work with.* Ditto the tool-less slide out brackets for the front 5.25 bays.*  I like that they have made it so you cannot lose the 4 back-of-case screws as they have retainers.*  It has a TON of top ventilation.  Big surface area.*  It has 3 built-in fans.  I will probably never use all of them.  Gamers or people in hot climates with no AC might care though.  The fans all use 3 pin connectors.  If your particular motherboard only supports PWM type 4 pin connectors, you'll need to purchase Molex-to-3 pin adapters or buy a fan controller / adapter cable or, if it really means that much to you, physically swap out the fans.  Again, Joe Average business user, occasional light gamer wont care.  For serious gamers the factory parts are just a starting point.  I'm not in that world.  I just needed a zippy, good looking, easy to maintain business / surfing PC case and this totally fits my needs.You know how you have some cases you dread opening?  This is not one of those.*  The metal the case is constructed of is medium thickness, decent, sufficient.  The paint job is good.  The switches and connectors seem to work fine. I have had previous cases that were beefy tanks (and weighed like tanks) and I've also had the elCheapo 25 dollar project cases that I could almost bend with 2 fingers and cut myself on.  This case is neither.  It strikes the right note of quality and heft.  I have not cut myself on anything with this case.*  It looks damn good.  I didn't purchase the case because of the side window feature but I do think it's pleasing to look at just the same.TIP:  For installing my 2.5" Samsung Evo 850 Pro boot drive, I used this Sabrent adapter (purchased separately) http://www.amazon.com/Sabrent-Desktop-Converter-Mounting-BK-PCBS/dp/B00UN550AC/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1440552776&sr=8-1-fkmr0&keywords=sabrent+2.5+to+3.5+inches+internal+hard+disk+drive+mounting+kit+bk-hddh  and it was effortless.The BAD:  If you want extreme sound deadening to muffle 5 screaming noisy drives and a zillion fans and dual high end video cards, well.. I don't see this case as any kind of heavy sound suppression enclosure.  If you buy SSD drives or non-Enterprise regular HDDs and keep your hardware count low, this should not be a big deal.  Right now I have a Noctua fan on a Core i7-4790 4.0 CPU and the PC is completely inaudible.  When I eventually add in the TWO (2) Western Digital 3TB Black drives I bought to run Raid 0 + 1, then yeah, I expect to hear sound from this case.  I don't think it's going to be that bad though.  Note:  I just use an older, low power consumption AMD card at this time (6670) - I don't even think it has a fan -- so that figures into my review and usage scenario regarding noise.*  I have read that the built-in top / front panel USB ports are "only" USB 2.0  This is not a big deal to me.  I'm going to buy a USB 3.0 /3.1 front bay or hub anyway...but this might be a big deal to you.  YMMV.SUMMARY:  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.  It's a winner!P.S.  I also own the Snow (white with black and blue trim) version of this Chaser A41 case from another outfit.  It looks really cool.  It functions exactly the same as the black one.

My original Qwest Zyxel 1000 (?) VDSL2 router was starting to cut out every few days.  I work from home and things ** HAVE **  to work. The Zyxel modem died in the middle of my weekday telecommute / work from-home day.MY UNIT PURCHASED MID-AUGUST 2015:  I bought this Actiontec at a local big box store that has those initials: BB.----->  SETUP WAS EXTREMELY LOW HASSLE!!! and IMMEDIATE. It was glorious!!  <-----After swapping out the old router hardware for the Actiontec, the minute I pulled up my Firefox browser, it immediately brought up the Century Link install wizard!  I don't even recall entering in the numeric IP address.  I was then prompted with maybe 7 screens asking me very short, intelligent questions.  All it really needed from me was my email and account number (or phone number)---->  I ZOOMED through to having good connectivity again in less than 3 - 4 minutes!!!  <-----At no point was I prompted to put a disk into my computer or download anything.In this day and age of overcomplication this is astounding to me!  The total and I mean TOTAL, lack of hassle was an unexpected Godsend.I never had to call Century Link.  The router's built-in software did offer a chat line, phone number, etc. but I didn't need it.SO...I * admit *  I know nothing about the longevity of this device and yeah I'm on the smitten "honeymoon" with it.CAVEAT:  I CAN'T SPEAK TO WI-FI CAPABILITIES EITHER WAY ON THIS UNIT:One caveat regarding my review:  I cannot speak to Wi-Fi quality and range as frankly I don't really use it.  I just need solid, functioning, work-from-home desktop Ethernet bandwidth with NO hassles and so far I'm impressed.Even if these boxes were to only last a year, for business purposes it's worth it to keep me on hand if it saves me an hour or two in phone calls, troubleshooting, cussing,  tweaking etc.  Your needs and expectations may differ from mine in that regard.  I've learned that I'm not above throwing money at a solution (within reason) as I place a value on my time and aggravation.  Ask me down the road when I'm retired and this mindset will reverse of course.SUMMARY:  If you have Century Link and you hate hassles and need your DSL modem replaced BUY THIS THING!  You don't need to dread the swap-out process, they make it extremely easy to get running again.P.S. The unit includes 4 Ethernet ports and a foldout quick start guide with a numbered-in-sequence pictograph (storyboard) of steps.  It really is idiot proof.

I have an older 6 burner Brinkmann.  Like 10 years old.  It started acting funny, not lighting even with full propane tank and clean grill components and igniter.  Ordered this, swapped out the old regulator/hoses - voila, burners start up immediately.  I can recommend this.

This is a great product!  We live in a neighborhood where occasionally yahoos throw things in the street, break bottles, etc.  It happens.  This oversized dustpan is just the ticket.  It's easily double the size of a regular dustpan.  The handle is comfortable and the lip on the edge is accurate, maintains a good connection with the ground or desk surface when sweeping.  I would buy one again in a heartbeat if mine got lost or damaged.  HIGHLY recommended.

Spartan elegance and high value in a small package!MY JOURNEY:  I have a sound system for my back deck (hot tub / barbeque area) that is kept in a weather proof outdoor enclosure under the eave...like this:  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000E9DPDQ?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage*  That sound system had a DIFFERENT BRAND of amp (which shall remain nameless), an awful amplifier designed for marine use. That "other" amp sucked, no high frequencies, flabby bass, etc.  I was determined to get rid of it.*  For my needs, I have primarily analog inputs (high quality separate FM tuner and a blu-ray / CD player.  I was set on finding a 50 Watt per channel RMS into 8ohms high quality mini amp and a mini 4 channel mixer (occasionally relatives come over with their iPOD for parties).  After going through 2 defective mini-mixers and trying a mini-PA amp, I started re thinking my needs.  I only really needed 3 inputs.  Much as I didn't want to give up tone controls and wanted more power, I took a chance on this amp.THE GOOD:>  It's well built, looks cool.>  Gold plated NICE, STURDY speaker posts that I believe accept banana plug aside from regular wire.  The two inputs are "always on" (i.e. ready for input).>  STEREO PRE-AMP OUTPUT that tracks the gain knob (for future expansion).>  USB input that goes to internal Burr-Brown DAC (which I've yet to test).>  22 Watt AB class amp (8 ohms) that sounds great>  Headphone output which mutes the speakers (for if I want to read on our back deck at night using headphones without disturbing neighbors.THE "sorta" BAD>  No tone controls>  Only 22 watts per channel (8 ohms)>  I have to run the volume at 80 - 90% to rock out, but it's fine for moderate/background levels at 1 o'clock position - WITH INEFFICIENT SPEAKERS!>  Not recommended for people wanting CONTINUOUS UBER HIGH Sound Pressure Levels with visceral deep bass,  i.e. certain metalheads and rap / electronica lovers.  If you want it loud enough to feel in your gut all the time you'll probably want to look elsewhere.  I'm guessing you would either be frustrated with this amp or you might roast it trying to drive large (12" or over) heavy magnet speakers that could drop into low impedance ranges.  Now, with smart planning (and additional expense), you COULD use this as the front end for a beefier system using the speakers from this as your "fill" - just make sure that the downstream "Mack truck" system has it's own, separately manageable, gain controls and EQ so you can balance what takes the beating in your system.WELL GUESS WHAT?>  This 22 watt per ch. amp produces ample volume for my purposes with inefficient 6.5" two-way (outdoor, made to look a "rock" cabinet) speakers (Sensitivity 86db).  [Test music examples:  Crowded House - "Farewell TTW" Live, Pink Floyd "Dark Side", ABWH - 1st album]>  The amp has a "mellow", rounded audiophile sound with good soundstage - the highs are certainly there, every so slightly recessed but IT DOES NOT CUT MY EARS TO PIECES.>  No hiss that I can find. I feel it will improve with "burn in" (most solid state electronics improve or settle into a final sound after 40 - 100 hours of use.  I have repeatedly found this to be true over the years).OTHER GOOD NEWS:>  My other worry was about quality control.  AudioEngine must have seen the older forum complaints from various about the volume knob feeling unsmooth, scratchy/cheap because the unit I received DOES NOT have that problem.  The travel of my volume knob rotation is very smooth and it's * NOT * "cockeyed" in any way.>  For large get-togethers, I augment my system by sending the Line Out to a large boombox I have which doubles my bass radiating area - the sum total of the two systems is provides very satisfying coverage on an 18 X 22 foot deck.>  The smoothness of this system is less likely to offend my neighbors.  (Some of perceived annoyance is distortion - aside from unawareness and bad manners, which I do not practice.  It amazes me how many people brag online about being able to offend their neighbors with their stereo.  For the 3 or 4 parties a year I have, they are made aware of in advance and I encourage them to contact me - good relations).>  TIP:  YOU COULD INCREASE "OOMPH" (VOLUME OUTPUT) BY CHOOSING SPEAKERS with 92 db or higher sensitivity.>  With my Sony dynamic headphones, it blasts my ears off.  No problems there.WHY I CHOSE THIS:SIMPLICITY:>  It seems odd, but you'd be surprised at how the simplicity of the "one knob" (and no input switch choice decision to make) is appreciated on a visceral level.  It's like my old Corolla:  I JUST TURN THE DAMN THING ON AND IT WORKS!  No Decisions.  High Quality sound.  In this complicated world, I love it.I have 3 other stereos that all involve choosing settings (Dolby or DTS, surround ambience, crossover cutoff, input choices.)  None of that here.  Whew.  What an oddly freeing experience!  Especially for my back deck chill-out system.BUYING A NAME WITH A REAL SUPPORT NETWORK:I seriously considered buying one of the TriPath 80 watt per ch. amplifiers for $200.00.  I think they are probably great in most cases.  What swayed my decision:  After problems with 3 different previous attempted hardware solutions, (new Rolls or used eBay purchase Furman mixer, used mini-PA amp), support became a crucial issue for me rather than an afterthought.I CAN ACTUALLY -->  FIND <--  THIS VENDOR AND GET SUPPORT IF THERE'S A PROBLEM.  I don't have to ship this to China or try and hunt down a support network.  And yes this is probably made in China like everything else these days.  Once you experience aggravation, the idea of a support network and customer service moves up to become 30% of one’s purchase decision.Now, down the road, I may buy 2 more speakers and take a chance and try purchasing a Lepai type amp to drive a 2nd set of speakers off the Line Out.  For now, this is the "anchor" of my future system and I am quite happy with what I have.-->  THE MORAL HERE:  >  Once I let go of my obsession with wanting a tone controls and high wattage, I found this exactly fills the bill for this purpose:  high quality casual listening system.  >  The amp itself sounds so good YOU DON'T NEED TONE CONTROLS if your source is high quality.  iPod users can use their internal software EQ to tweak things as a workaround.-->  SUMMARY:  VERY PLEASED!  Sage advice:  Just accept the simplicity my son!  Accept that you can simply turn something on without fiddling and it will fulfill your needs!  ahahaha.  I will report back on how it sounds after full burn-in later.**************************************************************************************************************ADDENDUM - HIGH QUALITY (Name Brand) ALTERNATIVES TO CONSIDER:Emotiva Mini-X - nearly same price, 1 less inputNAD D 3020  Rave reviews, over 2X as much money, 1 less inputPS Audio "Sprout"  Rave reviews, 4X as much money 4 inputs_____________________________________________________________________________GENERIC SAFETY NOTE RE ** ANY ** OUTDOOR SYSTEM:  When in the hot tub, I manage my input devices (i.e. make radio station or CD track number choices) with their own, respective wireless remote controls.  It should be obvious:  Don't manage this or ANY powered audio system DIRECTLY from a hot tub or while you are wet.  That would be unsafe.  Just sayin'.  Also, give your components adequate ventilation.  I bring my audio components in for the winter come late October as my component case is unheated and I don't want capacitors and circuit board solder connections to freeze, but that's just me.UPDATE 10/18/2015:  My external power supply for my N22 unit died after only 2 months.  I contacted Audioengine support and explained symptoms and all the various ways I had tested it.  They sent me out a new power supply at no cost.  Sent it regular shipping speed (took like 6 days).  I plugged it in and the blue power light went came on in the main unit.  I will have to fully test it later, haven't had time to hook it all back up.  I love this unit enough that I am going to chaulk it up to one bad part.  Audioengine sells the power supply on their site for (if memory serves like $19.00 + shipping).  I am pleased that they made things right at no cost to me (except doing without it for a week).  I'm also pleased that they make the replacement power available on their website at a reasonable cost.

Very good rainshow emulation, good patterns, ergonomics, I'm pleased.OK I got three pack assortment of sprayers at a local Grocery Outlet on a super deal: $9.99.  The star of the show here is the Wand type nozzle which has IN USAGE very precise patterns that work better than other garden nozzles.  The "shower" is the closest yet to emulating a real rain shower.  The Jet throws water at least 25 feet.  All fo the patters are good on this.  I LOVE IT.  My wand has one minor, defect annoyance that I can live with  - the label does not match the actual spray patterns.  At the price I got it for, I'm not complaining.  The middle nozzle (ray gun looking one) like most of these, is sort of a forgettable freebie - OK for a car wash, not really for watering plants.  Finally, the short handled multisprayer is very good, just a stubby version of the wand sprayer.  HOWEVER, the wand sprayer, aside from being very comfortable in the hand and more aim-able has this COOL ROCKER SWITCH on it turn the water on and off and - if you are careful can even be a variable flow switch.  Knowing what I know now, I would have paid even the full $19.00 bucks that is being asked on Amazon.  I can recommend this kit, just forget the middle "ray gun" for anything precise and/or kind for garden watering.  Over and out.

BACKGROUND:  I know Skechers is capable of making good shoes.  My significant other absolutely loves her Skechers Go-Walks.  I used to buy Skechers for my son growing up.  Skechers is supposed to be Nike's latest main competition.  My beloved New Balance 475 shoes were wearing out.  The replacement New Balance did not have the color or price that I wanted.  I tried finding an equivalent, ordered these.They run larger and half-step sizes are not offered at the top of the size range (normally a 13 works for me, these are oversized even for that) and I couldn't get a half-size in my size. ( Ideally what I needed from them, if they offered it, was Size 12.5.)  Worse is they seem to have no arch support.  Me adding inserts to take up slack and add additional support do not seem to help.  These shoes are extremely well padded on the heel but so much that it almost pushes my whole body posture into a lean forward type position - even if I'm just walking or standing still.  I have to compensate, it's awkward, not comfortable.SUMMARY:  I hate to say this but for my purposes, these are sloppy shoes, lacking support and agility.  Cosmetically they look "OK" but don't seem to have the quality of construction I have gotten used to with the New Balance shoes.  I will probably grudgingly wear these or obtain some better fitting / looking /construction shoes from another brand.  These Skechers will probably be relegated to gardening / dump run / painting type shoes.  I certainly wanted to like them.SAVING GRACE?  I could say that the only saving grace for these shoes is, IF you are a "heel striker" with wide feet and you have an extreme sensitivity to impact, these ** might ** be your ticket?  But as far as "steering" your feet and agility - forget it.  They are sloppy boats in that regard.  They are not mega expensive compared to what's out there in Nike, New Balance, etc.  I notice that lately the New Balance shoes that I would be interested in are around $80 - $85.00.  As usual, you get what you pay for.  It's possible there are other models of Skechers in a higher class of shoe design but this purchase has left me ambivalent about trying anything else from this manufacturer.

Defective EQ out of the box, not impressed, sending back.THE GOOD:*  It has a gutsy gain structure, capable of decent output, did not hear any noise or hum.*  It's got a lot of features for this price point.*  The case is sturdy, all metal.*  The knobs and general hardware quality seem good.*  The input / output jacks on the backplane do not buckle when you attach plugs to them.*  The size and small footprint of this is attractive for certain set it and forget it audio type installs.THE BAD:CON1:*  My EQ circuit was broken - out of the box - for the Line 1 & 2 inputs.  It's a global EQ - i.e. it affects (or should affect) the 1st two Line inputs.  -  Treble EQ did absolutely nothing.  Zilch.  -  Bass EQ changes were so subtle as to be almost imaginary.  Something is wrong with a solder joint or tracing, etc somewhere.  In short:  There was certainly ***  NO ***  + or -  12DB of bass or treble happening with the particular unit I received.  (Yes, I double-checked the dip configuration switch for system setup)CON2:  While audio is I would say "clean" it is also kind of clinical / nondescript / perfunctory / forgettable.  There I said it.  One input on my Mackie VLZ1202 compared to this blows the doors off it.  I get spoiled by that.  Yes the Mackie costs almost 4X as much but they have the cheaper models now too.  I was looking for this form though as I didn't want an entire conventional mixer "footprint".BACKGROUND:  I own (and have owned) many many stereos, boomboxes, audio devices - more than probably the average person in their lifetime.  I currently have 3 stereos including a Mackie / Yamaha Professional power amp component type setup.  I used to do DJing and some live sound reinforcement/recording.  Have run ARP2600, hand soldered a knockoff of a Sequential Pro 1 (400 piece kit) long ago.  I'm unafraid of mixers, patchbays, DACs, impedence, EQ, etc.SUMMARY:  I probably got a bad one.  It happens.  I just know I'm not impressed with my time being wasted like this.  It's going back.  This may be fine for some.  Others report success with this.  If the EQ worked I probably would have kept it but still longed for something better sounding.  Will keep looking.P.S.  Shure makes a mixer very similar to this one except is costs 2X as much ($260.00).  The Shure unit has an internal power supply and probably works better (known Shure's reputation).  I myself have never heard it though.P.P.S.  Radio Design Labs and Furman are other manufacturers that make equipment somewhat in this design scope..

I am using this on the older Windows 7 PC in my basement, circa 2006 motherboard, strictly USB and 16/44.1 WAV audio content at this point.  This DAC works fine, and to my ears is a cut above the ASROCK motherboard's built-in Realtek audio I had and some of the $30.00 basic soundcards I have owned.  It has good clarity and separation of instruments, bass is not bad for the price.  This is not a DAC that seems to emphasize bass.  It's enough, decent.  I wouldn't call it "fat", it's neutral.  Is this DAC a cut above the basic audio?  For my purposes yes.  Internal soundchips have come a long way since my ancient motherboard but this external DAC does get you away from noise and crackle issues.  I have ZERO noise and crackle issues, that some others here mention in their Topping reviews.  Why they have these issues , I can't say.  My USB cable is nothing fancy.  I've used headphones (open back, large diaphraghm dynamic headphones) with this, it drives them fine, sounds fine.  I have a good time, enjoy the music.POSSIBLE SHORTCOMINGS:  Design decisions get made for a price point.  I would say if you turn this up screaming loud with certain material for LONG periods of time, it might occasionally fail in the sense that you'd want it sweeter /warmer sounding.  But on most of my material , at moderate to lower volumes, its on the crystaline side of nice.  Or the nice side of crystaline/ detailed.  Mind you this is --> hair splitting <--- for the price, don't take this impression too far,  this is still quite a bargain for what it is.SIDE STUFF:  The actual fit and finish of the case and hardware parts are very good.  The action of the switches "feel" quality and the front panel looks cool.  I "think" the entire case and panels are made of metal.SUMMARY:  Do I long for something richer sounding?  To some minor degree.  There is a $700 DAC I would like but can't afford right now.  This DAC is good enough that, in the meantime, I'm quite happy listening to this.  Heck the DAC IC chip part cost alone (in this Topping) goes for $18.00 dollars.  I have yet to try this Topping DAC with 96/24 tracks so can't report on that.Much fun can be had with an inexpensive DAC and you can be using it NOW.  I have 3 entire home systems, can't afford to lavish a mega expensive DAC on all 3 of them.  I remember the occasions when I got each of them away from on-motherboard audio to an inexpensive separate DAC how much things improved.  I tend to forget that over time.  It would suck to go back to the old audio.  It's like peeling a veil off the sound and getting quicker transients.  My advice:  Find something that works for you and is affordable - don't look back.P.S.  If you are strictly looking for a DAC and don't care about the headphone output and extra inputs, something else to consider for a few dollars ($35.00) more:  HRT Music Streamer III  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00K2436MI?colid=ALWE9DUPA0FK&coliid=I17MGWABWYE33T&ref_=wl_it_dp_o_pC_S_ttl

Good looking pitcher, holds a lot - infusion or notAt work they are giving us free fruit-infused water.  I got the bug and bought this pitcher and also two personal use sized infusion bottles (by Bevgo).  Yes the infusion stick works but as many pointed out, you don't have to buy a product with the special separator to get started making your own lightly flavored water, it just makes it easier to manage if you are doing a lot of refills.  We make lemon / cucumber and cucumber mint.  You don't need to go nuts with the amount of added fruit and I actually recommend against it - I want subtlety that makes the water un-boring without having it funk out later and get too intense.  A small lemon wedge and one sliced wheel of cucumber are enough for me.  If you were having a party or had a large family and expected to be refilling this 4X a day, I could see adding more fruit than that.In other news:  This makes a great pitcher for mixed frozen OJ.  You could mix 2 large cans of frozen OJ and it would probably all fit in here.I have not had any issues with the handle or with cracking that some report so far.  There is NO WAY I would put this in the dishwasher, forget it, that would be a recipe for problems.  Will report back later if I issues arise.

Have had this a few weeks, so far very happy with slicer.  I bought it at a local big box store - my particular package came with two spare wires.  Compared to our regular hunky metal "old skool" slicer, this is very fast and effortless.  I see reports from other reviews about the tensioning adjustment wheel breaking.  I just set it an forget it.  Time will tell if reliability is an issue.  As far as usability I find it slices cheese effortlessly and is easy to grip.

REVISED REVIEW:This drill is supremely well made and precise.  I used this recently to drill through a section of my house that had 4X4 lumber and layers of siding in two passes.  I started with a long 3/8" Morse drill bit then switched to a Bosch 1" spade bit.  It was smooth sailing using the the first bit and fearless on the 2nd.  I never heard the motor bog down. The chuck has no slop in it.  I like the forward handle, it's a great assist when you're trying to keep things even while standing on a ladder.  So...I have my cordless Ryobi's for small jobs.  My cheapo Kawasaki (Alltrade) for those jobs where I don't care to risk expensive hardware.  Then I have this Bosch drill when I need precision and "can do".  Highly recommended._________________________________________UPDATE on 8/10/14I don't want be alarmist but I would caution do-it-yourselfers who are buying their first drill and are elderly, frail, inexperienced and/or not prepared for the sheer ferocity of this machine.  Reason:  If the drill binds on something you are drilling and you are not prepared for it with strong steady hands -- using the supplied brace, the torque could possibly wrench your wrist back.Another thing I would mention - if you are thinking of using this drill for backing out screws or lag bolts (with a socket attachment). I tried it. Forget it. I found that it's too easy for the power curve on this to run away from me (i.e lose control). Use a battery powered drill / driver instead.  This is a Jaguar XKE of 3/8" drills.  Yes it's variable speed but it is not meant for jobs or purposes when you want to "hold back".  I have accidentally bent a Bosch wood spade drill bit due to the bit binding (probably on an unseen nail) at an angle in some decking.  I have also stripped the threading on a Blu-Mol hole saw.  My point is:  when there's a conflict: the drill didn't give - everything else, the wood, the bits or the (possibly) operator is going to give.  Be physically fit, careful and thoughtful when driving this - it's more powerful than you'd imagine.

So I have my large boombox and my tiny Sony elcheapo ($12.97) radio but....What do you do when you are in a hurry and want something VERY portable with a semblance of actual bass output?  This is it!  It has rich full sound for it's small size.
