Their first case is a Mariachi guitarist who was shot 20 years ago, but only recently died from the bullet still lodged near his spine.  Was it a gang shooting, or something different; perhaps even intended for a different target?  That’s not the only case.  When Lucy was young, she was the only survivor of a day-care center fire.  Although it was ruled accidental, that may not have been true at all, and she wants answers.From the start, we have a sense of who Harry is and a tiny glimpse as to what drives him.  However, it also seems very clear that not only is Harry about to retire, but Connelly is very ready to retire him.As always, Connelly’s writing is crisp and spare, but it was also highly repetitive and became mired down in the details.  Yes, the procedural details were interesting and informative, but do we really need to know every road Bosch takes and every detail of every meal?  And let’s not overlook the massive coincidence.  About the only thing that was missed where his bathroom breaks.“The Burning Room” was a disappointment.  Normally, Connelly is a straight-through read.  This time, it was a slog and I couldn’t wait to get through it.THE BURNING ROOM (Pol Proc-Harry Bosch-Los Angeles-Contemp) – OkayConnelly, Michael – 19th in seriesLittle, Brown and Company – November 2014

First Sentence:  Death comes in on track three at 8:qr in the morning, seven minutes behind schedule.A killer is loose in Naples; anonymous and methodical, yet keeping a diary, known about only to him, of his actions. Insp. Giuseppe Lojancono is mistrusted as a suspected snitch to the Mafia, and has been transferred to an inconsequential post in Naples.  The only thing he is supposed to do is paperwork; no cases.  It’s not his fault that he’s the only one on duty when a call comes in about a murder.  In fact, it is the third execution-style killing of a young person, all within days of each other.  Magistrate Laura Piras quickly learns that Lojancono is the only one to have picked up on clues missed by others and orders he be assigned to the investigation.What a wonderfully evocative and compelling opening.  The narrative, which progresses through the story, is chilling for its complete objectivity.de Giovanni has excelled at creating an excellent character in Lojancono who is isolated by circumstances outside his own making.  It creates a strong bond of empathy to the reader.  Yet he balances that character with others who form a link to Lojancono, yet have insecurities and failings of their own.There are wonderfully descriptive passages throughout…”Dawn on a rainy day.  There’s not a specific moment when you see the dawn.  Suddenly it’s there, sliding into view while you had your mind on other things.”  The one weakness, however, is in the dialogue which often seems awkward, possibly due to issues in translation.This is definitely a darker book than his “Deed” series, but de Giovanni is such a fine writer, he draws you in and makes you want to know about the people and where the story is going.“Crocodile” is, in an odd way, a story of broken relationships, and includes a very good description of grief.  There is an excellent building of suspense as the pace of the story accelerates.  All the pieces are brought together to a stunning conclusion.  de Giovanni is an author very worth reading.THE CROCODILE (Pol Proc-Inspet. Giuseppe Lojacono-Italy-Contemp) – VG+de Giovanni, Maurizio – 1st in seriesEuropa Editions; Reprint Edition – July, 2013

except the murder scene of the lead’s understudy, in one of the ballets, to have been real.  Which man was the intended victim?  Lord Powerscourt is called in to find out.  But members of the ballet are not the only Russians in London. Two you men from very wealthy Russian families stole their mother’s valuable jewels in a fit of pique. They sent them to London with a member of the ballet company to be sold. Also, followers of the revolutionist Lenin are there to change millions of rubles, stolen from a bank in Russia, into pounds.  Can Powerscourt, with the help of his wife Lucy and friend Johnny Fitzgerald, put all the pieces together?There is much to like in this book, starting with the very chapter headings.  Good chapter headings are always a treat, and Dickinson wisely chose to use ballet terms and their definitions for this book.  What he also does is demonstrate the world of wealth, connections and protocol Lord Powerscourt inhabits, and the hierarchy of investigating the dead: if one was English, they rate an inspector; if European, a sergeant; Africans only rate a detective constable.Dickinson smoothly integrates real historical figures with fictional characters, as well as incorporating historical information into the plot.  One often hears about the Bolsheviks, and their involvement with Lenin and Stalin, but it is nice to learn about them, in a simplified context, and for what they stood.  The story also really makes clear the animosity and distrust between nations.All of the characters, are fully-dimensional, particularly Powerscourt.  We know not only about the investigation, but his family life and how that plays into the investigation through the connections both he and his wife have.  At the same time, it is pleasant that he is not a snob, yet quite egalitarian in this treatment of the young sergeant and others of a lower social class.  What is also delightful is the elements of observation and humor…”The answer came in a whisper.  Powerscourt had often remarked how people thought they could minimize the effect of some terrible news by announcing it in the lowest of voices.”For all the good, however, this is not the best book in the series.  Dickinson is very good at taking a seemingly small stream and adding tributaries until it becomes a wild, rushing, tumbling river, finally opening it up into a wide, flat body of water.  In this case, there were are few too many tributaries and it became a difficult river to navigate.“Death Comes to the Ballets Russes” contains some very effective drama, broken by subtle humor, but the narrative resolution is a bit of an anticlimax.  Still, it is a respectable addition to the series.DEATH COMES TO THE BALLETS RUSSES (Hist Mys-Lord Francis Powerscourt – England – 1912) – GoodDickinson, DavidConstable – January 2015

First Sentence:  It is a wood-paneled room of sumptuous size—the abbots of Perton have always done themselves well.In 1141, England was engulfed in civil war between King Stephen and his cousin, the Empress Matilda over who would wear the crown.  It is 1180 and a dying abbot has one last important task to accomplish.  He summons a young scribe in order to document a much more personal story set during that backdrop and occurring during a long, brutal siege winter.While readers were heartbroken by the death of Ariana Franklin and the incredible cliffhanger left in her last book in the “Mistress of the Art of Death” series, this does not resolve that series. However, for both prior and new readers, you are in for such a treat.  This book was begun by Ms. Franklin (aka Diana Norman) prior to her death, and has been completed by her daughter, Samantha Norman.  While that is wonderful in itself, what is truly remarkable is that the fusion is absolutely seamless.There is no awkward transition between the two authors; it is all one voice.  No, the language is not of the period.  To that, there was the explanation given by Ms. Franklin at the end of “Grave Goods,” …”…in twelfth-century England the common people spoke a form of English even less comprehensive than Chaucer’s.  In the fourteenth; the nobility spoke Normal French, and the clergy spoke Latin.  Since people then sounded contemporary to one another, and since I hate the use of what I call “gadzooks” in historical novels to denote a past age, I insist on making those people sound modern to the reader.”  One can’t argue with that.For us readers, the story begins with the history given, the stage set, the players assembled and the curtain drawn on what, from the very start, we know will be a wonderful tale.  The narrative is fascinating and, periodically through the story, moves the tale forward while providing historical context. The story provides wonderful details of castle life, and what it takes to run and defend a castle during this period.What a wonderful assembly of characters.  Each leaps off the page into full life and touches our emotions.  Gwilherm de Vannes, a mercenary soldier, and his conversations with God are a true delight…”And what now, Lord?  Eh?  How can I protect her from herself?”  “That’s a tricky one, Gwil.  That’s the question.  Even I can’t help you there I’m afraid.”  Young Pen, whom he rescues, is a survivor who learns to cope with events in her own way.  Maud, forced into marriage and now finds herself having to defend her castle with the help of Sir Rollo, commander of her troops and protect her son, William.  There is a mystery to the story, and a villain which is as evil as a villain can be.  This is the time of the Plantagenets, and the history is important, but the story is very much a human story.However, considering One really doesn’t want to say too much for fear of spoiling what is an absolutely wonderful read. It is a story one would love to see brought to the screen, but only if it included every single page filmed exactly as it is on the page.“The Siege Winter” is exciting, stirring, filled of tension and can bring one to tears but has a conclusion which makes one smile and touches the heart.  Do you know how hard it is to write review notes when one is crying?  It is a story which stays with you long after the last page.  At the bottom of my review notes, I wrote Ex+++++++.  Were it possible to rate a book 10 out of 5 stars, this would be it.  I loved every page; every word.  It doesn’t get better than that.  However, the best news is that this may only be the first in a series.THE SIEGE WINTER (Hist Novel – Gwil / Pendra – England – 1100s) – EXFranklin, Ariana and Samantha Norman – 1st bookHarper Collins – February 2015

First Sentence:  The angel of death made its way through the festa, and nobody noticed.The beautiful Duchess of Camparino has been found dead of a gunshot wound…or was she smothered?  It is up to the solitary Commissario Riccardi and his partner, Brigadier Maione, to solve the crime while dealing with their own personal issues.There is nothing better than an opening which is both compelling and done with very evocative descriptions.  What is particularly clever is that throughout the story, we have the diary entries of a nameless character.  Just when we think we’ve identified the writer, another hint is dropped and we are sent off in a different direction.The cast of characters is extensive, yet each character is distinct.  The most intriguing is Riccardi, who has the gift, or curse, of “the Deed”; the ability to see those who have died by violence—accidents, murder, or suicide—in the last few second of the life and to hear their final words or thoughts. This ability isolates him from all but a few people.  At his side, and ever loyal, is Maione who is married with 5 children, Doctor Modo the medical examiner, and Rosa Riccardi’s childhood nanny who still looks after him.While the story is a police procedural, it is so much more than that.  It is a character-driven novel which is very much about relationships; love, insecurities, passions, and the acts to which one can be driven by love.  The author meshes the characters with the story so skillfully; we feel part of the community.  Each character is fully-developed and we have no desire to by-pass any of them.Yes, the translation can feel awkward at times, particularly the dialogue, but that is easily forgiven. The quality and complexity of the story overcome any other shortcomings.“Everyone In Their Place” is a story of passion and human weaknesses.  There are no perfect characters; but each one is perfectly conveyed.  This is a series I highly recommend.EVERYONE  IN THEIR PLACE (Pol Proc-Comm Riccardi/Brig. Maione-Naples, Itlay-1931) -de Giovanni, Maurizio – 3rd in seriesEuropa Editions – Nov. 2013

First Sentence:  On a Monday morning in September, three weeks into the job, the Tiverton policeman took a call from his sergeant:  shots fired on Bitter Wash Road.Paul Hirschhausen ("Hirsch") has been demoted to Constable, and sent to back-of-beyond Australia where he's mistrusted and berated by his "fellow" officers.  Internal Investigations in Adelaide is still after him, trying to convict him of something and willing to plant evidence to do it.  In the meantime, even in his remote locate, there are crimes to be solved, including the body of a 16-year-old girl found by the side of the road.If one ever read Rhys Bowen's "Hamish Macbeth" series, Hirsch's posting will remind one of that.  However, that is the only similarity.  Disher takes us about as far as possible from Hamish's Scotland, down to Southern Australia, but acquaints us with the area with wonderfully visual descriptions..."October gathered its skirts and raced past."Disher provides very good backstory on Hirsch.  The inclusion of his inquest was both interesting, but allows for his speculation as to why some cops go bad.  We also see the frustration of a god cop working for, and with, bad cops; the blindness of "the thin blue line, and how corrupting that can be.  On the other hand, it is interesting to see the diversity of calls to which a rural cop must respond and the relationship he must maintain with the community.Disher does a wonderful job building up the suspense and tension.  One can't help but appreciate the source from which Hirsch's rescue comes."Hell to Pay" is an excellent read; an extremely well-written book dealing with very timely issues.HELL TO PAY (Pol Proc - Const. Paul Hirschhausen-Adelaide, Australia-Contemp) - ExDisher, Garry - StandaloneSoho Crime - June, 2014

First Sentence:  Betty Jo Dean lay as she had for over thirty years, shrouded in black vinyl, forever seventeen.In 1982, Jonah Ridy, a reporter for the Chicago Sun Times, is given the chance to restore his reputation as an investigative journalist by travelling to a small town for a follow-up piece about a man who has been shot and whose girlfriend is missing.  In spite of his very cold reception, he perseveres, even though people around him start dying.  One death finally causes him to walk away.  Thirty-years later, the town has a new mayor, an outsider.  The more he learns about the town’s secrets, the more determined he is to find the answers—no matter the cost.This is a story of three parts, each completely engrossing.  In the first part, we meet Betty Jo Dean.  Fredrickson makes us feel her fear and desperation.  No mater her background, we empathize with her.  In the second part, we come to know Jonah Ridy.  We want him to be redeemed and to solve the mystery, but we greatly fear for him.  In the third, and major section of the story, we have Mayor Mac Bassett who, with the support of his ex-wife, waitress and others, is determined to find the answers.  Fredrickson does a masterful job of introducing us to Mac and establishing his personality, thereby explaining his actions.The sign of a really good story is when you become so involved and invested in one time period; you are started when there is a shift.  You have to trust that the author will bring the parts together so that it all makes sense.  Frederickson definitely achieved that.The only very, very slight flaw to the book was having a prologue.  Rather than having that section at the beginning, it would have been better to leave it only within the relevant section of the story.  Having the prologue wasn’t really necessary and diminished the impact of the information when it did appear later.  The second, itty-bitty criticism is that the final status of the main characters was a bit twee, but perhaps that’s more a reaction of jealousy.There are some authors one discovers, and enjoys, but feels their writing could be so much “more.”  This book is definitely the “more” for which one has been waiting.  This book is the one from Fredrickson for which I’ve been waiting.“Silence the Dead” is very well plotted, without any reliance on coincidences.  Everything is rationally, logically, or emotionally based and appropriate.  The forensic information is critical, well-explained, and fascinating.  The level of suspense is ratcheted up at a steady pace with excellent twists right up to the very end.  Highly Recommended.SILENCE THE DEAD (Trad Myst – Jonah Ridl/Mac Basset – Illinois – 1982/Contemp) – VG+Fredrickson, Jack –StandaloneSevern House, January 2015

First Sentence:  On an evening in late March 1917, I climbed to the third floor of Lucius Grenville’s Grosvenor Street house in search of peace, and found a lady weeping instead.A society matron implores Captain Lacey to locate her missing necklace in order to provide the innocence of her maid.  With the help of his friends, Lady Breckenridge, Lucius Grenville and two of his staff, the path leads them to scandals and secrets from the past, as well as in competition with the dangerous criminal, James Denis.Followers of this wonderful series will appreciate this ten-chapter novella, set between “The Sudbury School Murders” and “A Body in Berkeley Square.  However, this story is also an excellent introduction for new readers.Gardner absolutely knows how to capture the reader’s attention from the very beginning.  She does an excellent job of capturing the flavor of speech from the period, without it being overdone, and the wry humor is delightful.  The descriptions of meals are nearly painful to read due to their lusciousness and ability to leave one nearly desperate to partake.Gardner is particularly adept at providing background details of each character, almost without seeming to.  We even learn the particulars of Lacey’s past injuries.  The characters are fascinating, particularly with the contrast of light—Granville—and dark—Denis.  One can’t help but enjoy the relationship between Lacy and Lady Breckenridge.  Marianne is a treat and adds a wonderful twist to the plot“The Necklace Affair” is so well done with a very good plot twist and justice being served in a most satisfactory manner.THE NECKLACE AFFAIR (Hist Myst – Captain Lacey – London  - 1817/Regency) - ExGardner, Ashley – Early in the series yet only recently publishedAmazon Digital Services, Inc. – January 2014

First Sentence:  As a practice, Harry Bosch did his best to Stay out of Tunnels but as he came out of Logan Airport, a tunnel was unavoidable—either the Ted Williams or the Sumner, take your pick.Los Angeles detective Harry Bosch is way outside his patch in Boston--Jamaica Plain to be exact—tracking down a suspect in a 15-year-old murder.  He’s not alone, however, and finds himself being watched by local P.I. Patrick Kenzie who is looking into the disappearance of a seventh-grade girl.  It only makes sense for LA and Boston to join forces.It’s hard to beat having two of our finest procedural authors join forces.  They both have such wonderful and distinctive voices.  It’s delightful having Bosch out of his comfort zone…”The passage was wall to wall with cars and trucks—a river of steel under the river of water, only one of them flowing at the moment.”The meeting of the two characters is a very good exchange of “I’ll show you mine..”  with good contracts between the LA and Boston styles.“Red Eye” is an excellent collaboration from two very fine authors, with very good suspense and a great last line.RED EYE (Pol Proc/PI – Patrick Kenzie/Harry Bosch – Boston – Contemp-2005) – ExLehane, Dennis / Michael Connelly – Original Short StorySimon & Schuster – November, 2014

First Sentence:  The night of the first murder.At the urging of his daughter, amateur poet Bob Naylor joins a local writers circle.  At the previous meeting, the group was addressed by a vanity-press publisher who’d come to critique their work; some favorably, most not.  The publisher is killed in an arson fire and Maurice, the group’s leader, becomes the prime suspect.  Because Bob is new and not a suspect, he is recruited to prove Maurice’s innocence, almost losing his own life in the process.  Because the local police aren’t making any progress, Inspector Henrietta Mallin is sent in to solve the case. Now here’s an opening to capture one’s attention.  I definitely compels you want to read on.  Lovesey writes wonderful dialogue with a very natural flow and a fine element of subtle humor…”Come and meet the chair.”  “Why?  Is it special?”  “Chairman.”  “Ah.”The members of the writing circle are a true delight and so recognizable.  One can’t help but like Bob and he holds the first portion of the story together very well.  One does appreciate the cameo of Peter Diamond as a segue to introducing Insp. Mallin.  That said, “Hen” Mallin is a very memorable protagonist being a cigar-smoking, no-nonsense character.“The Circle” is an unusual police procedural, but very cleverly plotted with plot twists, plenty of suspects and very good red herrings.  It’s somewhat reminiscent of “Midsomer Murders” and definitely keeps one involved right to the end.THE CIRCLE (Pol Proc - Insp. Henrietta Mallin - Chichester, England - Contemp) - VGLovesey, Peter – 1st in seriesSoho Crime – June 2005

First Sentence:  I was peering through the microscope at the tooth of an adder I had captured behind the coach house that very morning after church, when there came a light knock at the laboratory door.It’s not every day Flavia is summoned to her father’s old school.  Upon arriving, she finds a terrified boy and a bathtub containing a naked man covered in copper.  It’s time for Flavia to get to work.Bradley’s wonderful descriptions and excellent dialogue explain exactly why one can’t help but love Flavia.  From her anthropomorphism of her bicycle, to her brilliance and logic, there is something truly wonderful about this character.  She may be a fictional character, but Flavia represents that to which a young girl can aspire…without the poisons and bodies, however.“The Curious Case of the Copper Corpse” is a delightful, perfect amuse bouche until the next full installment of Flavia is available.THE CURIOUS CASE OF THE COPPER CORPSE (Myst/SS – Flavia de Luce – England – Contemp) – ExBradley, Alan – ebook Short StoryBantam, Dec, 2014

First Sentence:  When I think of my wife, I always think of her head.It is the fifth wedding anniversary of Nick and Amy Dunne.  When Nick goes down to breakfast, he finds Amy is missing and the back door open.  Did she run away?  Was she taken?  Or did Nick actually murder her?It is not an auspicious beginning when one starts out intensely disliking the protagonist, followed shortly by an equal dislike for the victim. Two things are required to like a book; at least one character for whom I can feel affinity and knowing that justice is done in the end.  This had neither, except for a couple supporting character and that wasn’t enough.  The book quickly degraded from there.The only redeeming quality to this book is that the disappearance was well done.  Other than that, this is an unpleasant story, about unpleasant people, doing unpleasant things to one another.  Only the twin sister, Go, was at all interesting.As to the plot; about half-way through, the ending seemed predictable.  Hoping my suspicions were wrong, I admit going to the end.  Unfortunately, I was not wrong.  The ending was not only predictable, but illogical and displayed the author’s lack of knowledge.  If this book is supposed to be a look into the minds of men and women, they are people one never wants to meet, let alone know.“Gone Girl” is a book that never should have come in the first place.  Dorothy Parker said it best, “This is not a novel to be tossed aside lightly. It should be thrown with great force.” Had I not downloaded the e-book, it would have been a literal wall-banger.GONE GIRL (Susp - Nick Dunne – MO - Contemp) – NR/DNFFlynn, Gillian – 3rd bookCrown, July 2012

First Sentence:  From Raymond Land to All Staff:  So, it’s a new beginning for us.The Peculiar Crimes Unit is now under the jurisdiction of the City of London and, as usual, their new top boss would like to see an end to the group.  However, two crimes are keeping them in the game.  A young man appears to see a body rise from a grave and claims it spoke.  Have Resurrectionists returned?  But what did the young man see that resulted in his murder a few days later?  Someone stole the seven ravens, symbol of the British Empire, from the Tower of London.  Only Bryant could discover a link between the two crimes.How wonderful that Fowler includes a cast of characters, in the form of a staff roster, at the beginning of his books.  And, right from the start, we are treated to the wonderful voice and humor of Flower.  It’s a rare treat when an internal memo can be amusing.It’s nice to have a true ensemble cast of characters, which each playing a significant role in the story and each being fully developed.  Although the primary characters are James May and Arthur Bryant—what a wonderful relationship that is--Bryant took the lead here.  He seems to have mellowed bit and we learn much more about his past, which is quite lovely, but we did not lose any of that which makes him so delightful.  However, all the relationships are so well drawn, the characters transform into being actual people to the reader.Fowler’s voice, wit and dialogue are such a pleasure to read…”Why have you got a house brick in there [Longbright’s handbag]?’  “Under British law you can’t stop a suspect with a weapon but you might be allowed to hit him with something that would naturally be in your hand at the time,”…. “PC Biggs folded her arms.  No honest citizen should ever do anything that makes a police officer stand back and fold her arms.”  There is also a delightful scene of the pathologist being thrust into a very different role than that to which he is accustomed.  Flower is very good at doing the unexpected.There is one small criticism and that is the inclusion of portents.  Portents are really, really annoying, unnecessary and, rather than create suspense, have the opposite effect.  They are also somewhat insulting to the reader as it’s as though the author assumes the reader won’t continue otherwise.“The Bleeding Heart” is very clever with wonderfully logical explanations of crimes which seemed so odd.  It is an absolutely delightful book.THE BLEEDING HEART (Pol Proc-Bryant and May-London-Contemp) – VG+Fowler, Christopher – 11th in seriesDecember, 2014

First Sentence:  “The Spirits are strong in this one,” says the man in the white robe and gumboots.For a woman who didn’t do Christmas, forensic anthropologist Ruth Galloway is challenged by making her 1-year-old daughter’s first Christmas special.  Nothing is quite going to plan, including learning from her druid friend, Cathbad, informing her that a Bronze Age wooden peg is missing.Griffith’s Ruth Galloway is a delight, particularly for those of us who have been known to eschew the accepted sentiments and traditions of the holidays, yet find ourselves attracted to them.  Some may even relate to the “Doctor Who” reference.The story contains delightful humor.  There is the inclusion of the character’s back story, references to previous books and fascinating factual information which is interesting and doesn’t detract from the pace of the story.  Griffith’s provides a very strong sense of place, often using weather to increase suspense.Like her description of faith…”It’s enough that someone, somewhere genuinely believes that the magic will work.”“Ruth’s First Christmas Tree” is not overly sweet, but much more a reflection of many of us, particularly those of us in our middle years, but still with a warm ending.  It’s not a deep, rich book; it’s a small treat, particularly for those who love this character.RUTH’S FIRST CHRISTMAS TREE (Short Story-Ruth Galloway-England-Contemp) - G+Griffiths, Elly – Christmas Short StoryAmazon Kindle Services – Dec 21014

First Sentence:  It was an ancient and attractive custom, one enjoyed by music-lovers and the stout-hearted but detested by those who were trying to get ‘a decentngith’s kip’, as Jack Boggis, the local misery, put it.Reverend Nick Lawrence has organized a Medieval Fair to celebrate May Day, complete with Morris Dancers, archery lessons and a maypole.  What isn’t planned is finding the body of a young orphan impaled by an arrow and secured to the maypole via its bright-colored ribbons.  On a personal note, it was delightful that the madrigal referenced at the beginning of the story is one I sang years ago and still remember.Ms. Lake created a delightful cast of non-stereotypical characters.  The vicar and subject to both questions of faith and desires, in a good way, of the flesh, but a true Anglican vicar nonetheless, …”I suppose if Christ came and sat on the bench beside you, you would accuse him of being an illegal immigrant.”  The relationship between Det. Tennant and his bagman, Mark Potter, is wonderful.  Daft Dickie, an autistic man with a horrible past, is a character you don’t know whether to pity or fear.  There’s even the Rectory ghost, William.Although the protagonist is a vicar, do not mistake this for a comfortable, English cozy.  Lake addresses all sides of human nature, and she does it well.  If anything, you might think of it as a dark Midsomer Murder.  The history and mythology of the old ways and legends is woven skillfully into the story.“The Moonlit Door” is, in the end, a mystery which touches on of the best and worst of humanity.THE MOONLIT DOOR (Myst – Rev. Nick Lawrence/Det. Dominic Tennant – Lakehurst, England – Contemp) – VGLake, Deryn – 3rd in seriesSevern House, March 2015

First Sentence; First Story:  It’s hard to argue with an old Indian or his tricks.How nice to have collection of Johnson’s annual Christmas stories, all in one place.  Plus, there is the added gift of a new story, and a wonderful, personal introduction by Lou Diamond Phillips, the actor who plays Henry Standing Bear in the Longmire television series, based on the series.  Phillips introduction expresses so much of what I feel about Johnson’s writing, as well as the pleasure of meeting Craig and his wife Judy.The stories are of the same, high quality we’ve come to expect from Johnson.  They are thoughtful and entertaining with each containing a small lesson as well.  From how one should never overlook the basics, to realizing that salvation can come from unexpected sources, to forgiveness and tolerance.  It’s lovely that there is even a small reference to the American actor Robert Taylor, perhaps best known for the Westerns he made in the 1960s, as an homage to the Australian actor currently playing Sheriff Longmire.  There are also lessons on acceptance, remembering others, giving, priorities, desperation and redemption.  But we also learn the history of the term, “Indian Summer.”“Wait for the Signs” is a classic example of Johnson’s humor, wisdom and wonderful writing.  As well as a treat for oneself, it is an excellent introduction to those who’ve not read Johnson before.WAIT FOR THE SIGNS (Short Stories – Sheriff Walt Longmire – Wyoming – Contemp) – ExJohnson, CraigViking Adult, 2014

As per Amazon review guidelines, I have to disclaim that I received this product to test and write an unbiased review.This is a super simple stand–it’s operated by a 1 button locking mechanism. Pressing it unlocks the support which you can adjust around to get the angle that you want. I like the fact that it’s made from metal, because it gives it a nice hefty weight which prevents the stand from moving around too much. However, there are 2 main design flaws that I’d like to point out which are a bit annoying.The first is that the area which holds the stand isn’t very wide. While most phones are quite thin these days, there are cases which add bulk and if that’s the case, this phone stand might not be able to actually hold your phone. Luckily, I had a relatively thin case, so it still worked. The second main flaw is that there’s no way to charge your phone while it’s on this stand if your phone is in the vertical orientation. There are no holes or space to accommodate the charging cable, which is unfortunate. You can fix this by putting your phone in horizontally, but this is still nevertheless a flaw.Aside from those two flaws, I think this is a solid phone stand. It’s super simple to use and the metal build gives it a solid feel.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 3.5/5==The Good==+ Metal build gives it a nice weight+ Simple to operate mechanism+ Affordable price==The Bad==- Area which holds the phone isn’t wide enough to accommodate thicker cases- No way to charge your phone in vertical orientation

The flavor is fantastic, and this high protein version is a bit more filling than the regular one. It satisfies for around 3-5 hours if you use a full scoop, and if you do follow their slim fast plan, you start losing weight simply due to the lower calorie intake. Also, you can't even tell it's a protein shake from the flavor--it's that good. I really love mixing this with a banana & soy milk to create a lactose free banana chocolate shake, to the point that I don't really even use this to lose weight. I just find it to be a great breakfast/meal replacement for when I don't have time. It's got a good mix of the essential vitamins & minerals, without being too high on sugar. The only reason I'm giving 4 stars is because you can find it cheaper in most grocery stores. It's $10 here, but I've seen it go for $7 and even $6 at Wal-Marts and Meijers.

As per Amazon review guidelines, I have to disclaim that I received this product to test and write an unbiased review.For almost $30, I think it's a bit overpriced, especially considering the size of the bottle. That being said though, I've not seen this much care and quality put into a bottle of probiotics anywhere else. From the packaging alone, you can see it's different. The decorated glass bottle & the box it comes in is unique and shows a business which cares a ton about their product. They also include a nice personal note about how the business was founded and stuff. It's even got organic cotton!The pills itself have a control-release technology which supposedly increases the bacteria's effectiveness, and it's all manufactured free of the major allergens. This specific bottle is formulated to boost your immunity & prevent colds, and I think it's been pretty effective. Flu season has hit and I haven't felt a single symptom since taking this. It's probably not the only factor, but it's the only evidence I have. The pills themselves aren't so big that they're impossible to swallow, but they're still bigger than your typical capsule. There's no real taste to them (I guess they're a little sour?), so I haven't had any issues with taking these.Overall, this is probably one of the best quality probiotics out there. Everything about it screams premium, and it reflects in the price. For those who can afford it and want the best, this is the product for you. There's definitely more affordable options out there though.

As per Amazon review guidelines, I have to disclaim that I received this product to test and write an unbiased review.It's a cool idea, and I suppose the illusion looks cooler if you look at the bucket from a certain angle. For the most part however, the illusion falls flat. If you can see it as a bucket leaking water, then props to you. When I looked at it for the first time, all I saw was a piece of transparent plastic supporting a bucket. It's very easy to tell that there's a piece of "transparent" plastic holding it up.Regardless, this is still a neat little pencil cup, and I can see this being a nifty little gift for friends & family. It's small so it doesn't take up that much space, but big enough to hold around 15-20 normal sized pencils/pens. I also like the fact that the handle can move, so you can kinda use it as a divider. Finally, despite the illusion falling a bit flat, it's still different from most pencil holders. It makes it unique and I've had people ask about it. For $8, the quality is pretty much what you expected--everything is plastic, but due to its simple design, I can't really see it breaking unless you try to do it intentionally.I'd recommend this for those looking for a cheap gift or a unique pencil holder!

As per Amazon review guidelines, I have to disclaim that I received this product to test and write an unbiased review.For $16, this is a surprisingly elegant shower head. It comes with everything you need, including the hose & wall mount. There are also some restricters included, which helps you save water. If your water flow is weak though, you might not want to install these, as they do lower the amount of water coming out. I like the stainless steel--it gives it a premium feel and look, despite not costing too much.Anyways, I'm no expert on shower heads, but I was still able to install this with ease. There's nothing to twist and turn here to change the "mode"--it's a single function shower head. The shower head itself is nice and large, covering a large area. I do think the water pressure is a bit weak (but that's more of a personal preference).Overall, this is a simple to use, elegant shower head. It works fine, it's cheap, it was easy to install and it looks nice in my shower. I have no complaints here

As per Amazon review guidelines, I have to disclaim that I received this product to test and write an unbiased review.When this first came in the mail, I had my doubts. The packaging looked a bit cheap and the English on the packaging was poor. It as very obviously made in China, and I questioned how well it worked. Upon opening it though, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the actual flashlight.It’s made out of metal and it feels good in the hand–not too light, not too heavy. I also like the fact that you can adjust the head of the flashlight to focus the light or make it expand to cover a larger. The best part though is actually the battery–it comes with a rechargeable lithium-ion battery & a charger for the battery, as well as an alternative battery holder which can take 3 AAA batteries if you don’t want to use the Li-On battery. It's a surprising amount of stuff to include with a flashlight, but I'm glad they considered all of these factors.When I turned on this flashlight for the first time, I was impressed. It’s really bright–much brighter than a typical flashlight, and in my opinion, what makes this stand out from the rest. You can soft-click the power button to change the modes from normal to dim to flashing, etc. It's a great flashlight for camping and outdoor activities.Overall, I may not have liked the packaging, but the flashlight itself is great. It's durable, bright, and I love the addition of the rechargeable battery/charger. It's nice not having to stress out about replacing the battery.

This is a good gaming headset for those on a budget. It’s not going to feel super premium, nor does it sound the best, but it gets the job done just fine. For $18 (at time of review), I'm satisfied with it. The entire thing is made of plastic, so it's a lightweight headset and feels a bit flimsy. That being said, I've dropped it a couple of times and nothing snapped off.The best thing it has going for it is that it's pretty comfortable. The pads are soft and I haven't had it clip my hair. You can adjust it to fit your head as well. I also really like the design. The blue on black as well as the logo makes it seem more premium than it is. As for the sound quality, it's mediocre. I can hear the game music/voice overs as well as my friends over skype/VoIP clearly, but this isn't meant for enjoying music. The sound seal isn't that great either, so it will leak a bit (other people can hear you if you turn it up loudly) and you can hear some of the environment around you as well. This wasn't a big deal for me, as I don't care too much for that "totally immersive" experience that some gamers desire. I'm assuming that since you're looking at a headset below $20, you don't care too much either. The microphone works fine as well--people were able to hear me clearly.One thing to keep in mind is that this comes with two cables--one for audio and one for the microphone (voice input). Some of the newer gaming laptops have a combined audio/voice input jack, so this would not be compatible. This should work just fine with most desktops & older laptops though. The cable is also pretty long, and I think it would work for consoles as well.If you are looking for a top-notch, immersive gaming experience, you won't find that here. I doubt you'll find it anywhere at this price range. However, this is still a comfortable & functional headset for under $20. I'd recommend this to anyone who wants a cheap budget headset which works.Disclaimer: I was sent this product in exchange for my honest opinion. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

As per Amazon review guidelines, I have to disclaim that I received this product to test and write an unbiased review.First off, for those who have never used biking gloves before, they’re essentially fingerless gloves with shock absorption pads which increase your grip and make it easier to handle your bike in rough terrain. The shock absorption is especially useful for mountain biking as it makes it a lot less painful to grip the bike. Thus, it’s not really made for people who bike to work regularly or anything–it’s more for those who enjoy the sport of biking and do it recreationally.As for this set of biking gloves, I really like them! I chose the green color, and I dig the sporty design. It’s mostly made of a breathable mesh material, and there’s a shock absorbing gel pad near the palm area. There’s also a rubbery type of material for enhanced grip. It works well–you can definitely feel the reduced shock and the grip, making for a much more comfortable ride. For sizing information, definitely consult the chart–it’s very accurate if you measure your palm correctly. There is some flexibility as the gloves are tightened via a velcro strap, so if you’re on the borderline and you prefer a tighter fit, you can order one size smaller.Also, this comes with an extra “multi-purpose head cloth”, which is essentially an elastic microfiber woven cloth with many uses. The quality and design of this cloth is way above average–most freebies that come with products tend to be pretty crappy–so I was pleasantly surprised here. You can turn this thing into pretty much anything you can think of, from a balaclava to a headband, to a biking mask to protect from the sand. The package has a diagram with all the various ways you can use it.Overall, this is an excellent set of bike gloves with some added value in the bonus head cloth. I recommend lots of products, and this is one of the few which I couldn’t really find a flaw with. It’s well made, worth every penny, and the design is excellent. I personally love it, and would recommend this to all bike enthusiasts!Summary: 5/5==The Good==+ Bonus high quality headscarf!+ Gloves do their job and are well made+ Sporty design==The Bad==- None

For those who have never tried Aloe Vera gel, it’s one of the best solutions for sunburn. The relief is near instant and the cooling effect is excellent. Aloe vera gel is extracted from the aloe vera plant which is shown to have certain benefits for the skin.I’m a big fan of this, as I go out a lot (especially in the summer) and sunburns are painful. I especially like that this is a good sized bottle for a decent price. The quality here matches other aloe vera gels I’ve used in the past, so it’s not a phony or anything.On a final note, this bottle comes with two caps: a pump cap as well as a squeeze cap, so you can pick your way of dispersing the gel inside. I found both to work equally well, so it’s really a matter of preference. Anyways, this is a good value bottle of aloe vera gel and I’d recommend this to anyone who gets sunburned easily (especially if you’ve never tried it!). In my opinion, aloe vera gel in general is one of the best natural remedies for sunburn.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

I’m usually hesitant when it comes to beauty products because it’s to tell whether or not something is working due to the gradual nature of most products. I’ve yet to use one product that works miracles instantaneously, and this is no exception.However, after using this for around 2 weeks, I’ve begun to notice some visible changes. They’re very minor, but some of my old acne scars have begun to fade a bit. I say this because old acne scars are usually pretty consistent in that they don’t really change. After applying this for around 3 weeks, they’ve faded ever so slightly. I hope to see improvements after some continued use!Regardless, this scar gel contains a couple of potent skin-healing ingredients, including strange stuff I've never heard of. I did some research on these ingredients, and there are some articles which claim they work (not sure if they're credible though). The gel itself is this brown paste which smells a bit like honey. The smell disappears after a while, so there's no need to worry about it. Also, It's easy to apply and you use it like a spot treatment, so you really don't use much per application (varies with the amount/size of scars). Thus, despite the small bottle, I can see this lasting a while.As with all beauty products, it works differently for different people. In my experience though, it’s worked out great!Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

After using this for around 2 weeks (every night), I've noticed an overall positive change in the smoothness of the skin. I don't think it's as drastic as they claim in the description, but it's visible--and that's not something that can be said for a lot of beauty products.Looking at the ingredients, this little bottle contains a mix of very potent skin-improving ingredients and oils. For example, stuff like jojoba oil is commonly found in natural acne treatments/moisturizers, and many people have attested to its effectiveness. Also, I've used products from InstaNatural before, and they've all been high quality(I've never received anything fake from them before). As for the cream itself, it's very easy to apply and there's a very light, inoffensive scent. This is good news for those with a sensitive nose, as the smell has never bothered me before.Now, at 100ml, it's not a very large bottle. Fortunately, you don't need too much per application, so apply it sparingly and it should last one or two months. I've found it best to apply after a hot shower, as your skin is soft and the pores are open. Overall, I do think it's a bit pricey at the current cost of $20, but the quality is good and it contains a lot of fantastic ingredients for the skin. If you can afford it, definitely consider giving this a try.Please note that I received this product for free for my honest and unbiased feedback. Feel free to leave questions & comments below.

This is a really easy to use thermometer which came exactly as described and looks like the pictures. To use, all you have to do is press the power button, stick it in some part of your body (recommended: armpit, mouth, or in the rectum) and wait for the thermometer to beep. Once it does, you can take it out and it will display the temperature on the LCD display.I’ve only tried this under my armpit, so I can’t talk about the other two (the tip is nice and soft though, so it shouldn’t hurt), and it was pretty accurate. I’ve had slight fluctuations of ~0.2 degrees F, but that could’ve been due to other factors.The only complaint I have is the battery; I have no doubt that the battery included will last a long time, but it seems a bit difficult to replace. It runs off a button battery and to replace it, you have to take off the cap and then take out the entire chipset to access the battery. It’s not the most convenient.Overall though, this is still a super easy to use thermometer which is fairly accurate.4.5/5Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

I got the one with the little prince design on it and I love it! The design is cute and I’ve received compliments from others who are fans of the book when I take it shopping. I love the outdoors, so I thought this would be a fantastic tool to protect my phone from the elements, as you never really know when it might rain. After a couple weeks with this, I’m pleased to say that it’s a well made and simple to use waterproof case. I suppose it’s a bit like a ziploc bag, but it’s made of a much more durable plastic and guaranteed not to leak in water as long as it’s sealed properly, making this much more secure.It’s made to fit most phones without issue–I have a 4.7 inch phone with a case–but I think it should be able to fit phablets in as well (6 inch phones might be a bit of a stretch though). I’ve said that it’s really simple to use, and that’s because all you do is open up the two clamps, put your phone in, and clamp them back together. It’s easy to tell when it is secured, and once it is, no water should be able to get through. I tested this by dunking it into a pool of water (while holding my breath) and it was perfectly fine. Aukey does recommend you test for defects by putting this inside a bowl of water first for 30 minutes sealed WITHOUT a phone instead. Your phone is still usable with this case on, but you might have to press a bit harder.Overall, this is a fine case which has made me more relaxed carrying my phone out on hikes and stuff as I no longer worry about my phone being damaged by water. It’s simple to use and it works, and it's not too expensive at the current cost of $6. There’s not much more I can ask for.5/5Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

As you can see from the pictures, this battery pack looks like it costs much more than it does. The design as well as the materials makes this feel quite premium. It has a rubbery material which gives it a nice grip, and the design overall looks very sleek. Even the cable it comes with feels nice and a bit different from a normal micro-USB cable.However, there are a couple of flaws that I’d like to mention. This has an indicator light which shows how much battery is remaining depending on the color. The only issue is that it’s a bit counterintuitive–for some reason, red means that the battery is full, while green & blue means half-full/empty for some reason. In addition to this, the battery has a “shake to turn on” feature where you shake the battery a bit to check the battery level. This is fine and all, but it feels a bit like a gimmick. I don’t see any advantage of this over the normal power button. In fact, sometimes it turns on by itself in my bookbag as I’m walking because of this.Overall, those two flaws are annoying, but they’re also relatively minor. It’s still a well made battery with a sleek design. It’s compact enough to fit into just about any bag, and at 8000mAh, I was able to charge my phone around 3 times. It also recharges at a good rate. At the current cost of $24, I think it's a bit on the high side. It's still a sleek looking battery which feels really nice, but just keep those two issues in mind.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

This is awesome. Compared to the plastic mandoline slicers I’ve used in the past, this is a huge upgrade. Not only is it super sharp (don’t cut yourself when washing this!), it’s also really well made, well designed, and versatile. Thin-slicing tomatoes and cucumbers become incredibly simple with this tool, and julienne cuts become quite easy as well, allowing you to make potato fries, hash browns, etc.It’s pricier than some of the other options for sure, but if you can afford it, this is definitely worth the upgrade.WELL MADEThe whole thing except for the blade inserts & other accessories are mostly made from metal, which gives it a nice weight and high quality feel. It also makes it incredibly durable, especially compared to the plastic ones. I want to give a special mention to the knife, which was incredibly sharp. It cut through all the stuff I threw at it with ease.WELL DESIGNEDThis is probably my favorite part. All the details have been carefully thought about, and this slicer comes with a couple of cool features. First off, there’s a stand with a rubber grip located at the bottom which you can flip out to place the slicer at a more optimal angle. It also comes with 5 different blade inserts (3 of which adjusts the thickness, and 2 with julienne blades at different sizes as well) which are all conveniently placed on an included plastic rack. These are really easy to switch out–you just press the big red button and slide them out. Everything is thoughtfully designed to be purposeful and simple. Having the additional blades also makes this a versatile slicer with multiple uses.Overall, this is a fantastic mandoline slicer with high quality materials and a thoughtfully designed build. It’s a bit pricier than the plastic ones for sure, but I think the durability as well as the ease of use is well worth it.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 5/5==The Good==+ Metal materials definitely lead to higher quality feeling+ Thoughtfully designed, simple to use+ Well built and cuts with ease==The Bad==- Not much–if I had to nitpick: It’s pricier than the other ones, and the different accessories means this takes up a bit more space than a normal mandoline slicer, so keep that in mind if you’re short on space

First thing: It’s huge. It has a large round base which is needed to keep the lamp grounded, and there are 3 hinges–one in the middle and two at the top. These allow you to adjust the lamp to whatever angle needed, and they’re tight enough that they won’t move by themselves. It’s a very unique, modern look which I personally enjoy. Just know that it does take up a large amount of space.The whole thing is made from plastic, but that doesn’t mean it’s bad quality. The build quality here is top-notch and doesn’t feel cheap at all. My favorite part about the entire lamp is the whole light “temperature” feature. There are essentially 4 modes–reading, writing, night mode, and the final one is a picture of a teacup (perhaps social mode?). Since it’s all touch operated, you can simply touch any of the pictures to change the color of the light. The icon lights up to indicate whichever choice you’ve selected. For example, night mode is a relaxing yellow color whereas the reading mode is a bright white. It’s a really cool feature which is complimented by the simple, intuitive controls.In addition to this, you can adjust the brightness for each mode by pressing on the +/- buttons. The range here really surprised me–it can go from the dimness of a large night light to enough brightness to light up a small room! There are a couple of nice small details included as well, such the power button lighting up when the light is off so you can always find it in the darkness. Also, there’s a USB port on the side, which works as you’d expect.Overall, I think this is an absolutely fantastic lamp. I love it. It’s certainly pricier than most lamps, but it also offers a lot more than most lamps. It has incredible versatility from its multiple hinges to the brightness settings, it’s got intuitive touch controls, and the sleek modern design looks great. Just make sure you have enough space for it!Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 5/5==The Good==+ Modern design, intuitive controls+ Incredible versatility and range in brightness+ Ability to change the light “temperature” is fantastic==The Bad==- Not much–if I had to nitpick: the difference between reading and writing mode isn’t that significant- Keep in mind that it has a large footprint

They work exactly the same as your standard micro-USB cable. They charge just as fast, they can transfer data, and the only difference here is that these are made of slightly more premium materials. The jacks are encased in metal and the cable itself is the more durable cloth type. They feel durable, but I haven’t had them for long enough to actually say.For this price of $7(at time of review), these are a step up from your typical cables at a decent price. Just keep in mind that they’re really long (6.6 feet!). I’d recommend these to anyone who needs extra cables for their devices. No complaints whatsoever.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

I ordered the medium ones and they came in a padded envelope. It’s a pack of 2 neoprene sleeves with a silicone elastic band near the top for extra grip to ensure that it doesn’t slip off. You can pull these up to slightly above your knees, near your lower thighs. There’s a sizing chart here, but know that the compression is a bit tight, especially around the elastic band. The medium size fit me just fine, but I can definitely feel the compression. If you don’t like that, consider ordering a size larger.I used these when running, and the grips do a good job of keeping them from slipping. It does get a bit warm with these on during exercise, but they wick sweat well and the compression + warmth are soothing for the muscles. On a final note, I’d just like to add that I love how they look–it’s 85% nylon, 15% spandex (machine washable)--and they look really sporty, similar to women’s workout tights but without the thigh part of course. I’m a guy, and they look perfectly fine on dudes as well, so long as you’re wearing shorts (please don’t go out in these with underwear). The Vive logo is reflective as well, which is a nice touch.Overall, this is a good set of compression sleeves. It’s well made, and it works. Can’t ask for more than that. I do think it’s a bit on the pricey side, but if you can afford it, know that you’re getting a quality pair of compression gear.Please note that I was sent this product in exchange for an unbiased opinion. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 4.5/5==The Good==+ Well designed+ Does its job of soothing muscles, etc.+ Sporty look==The Bad==- A bit pricey**Consider ordering a size larger if you don't enjoy tight compression.

I like this surge protector, but it is a lot larger than most of the surge protectors out there in the market today. That’s mainly due to its design–it’s made with plenty of space in between the outlets to give space to chunky adapters. There’s also the addition of two USB ports near the end for charging portable devices, which does come in handy. Near the tip is a LED light which glows red to indicate power.Now, the innovation here is the so called “smart” charging, which turns on/off the entire power strip depending on whether or not it detects devices using electricity. For example, if I leave a laptop plugged in and it goes to sleep, the power strip will detect that and turn itself off. When I turn on the computer again, the power strip will also turn on. This is supposed to help save energy, and it theory, it sounds cool, but it doesn’t always work well in practice. For example, it seems like the power strip doesn’t detect when USB devices are plugged in, and it stays off.Luckily, you can also turn off the smart charging and just use the normal mode, which turns into a regular, always-on surge protector.Overall, I have no real issues with this surge protector–if you are buying this for the smart feature, just be aware that it doesn’t work too well (I personally don’t think it’s worth the extra cost). It’s well designed and feels well built, it has no issues with large adapters, but at the same time, it is a very large power strip.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 4/5==The Good==+ Good quality plastic+ Nice design for large adapters+ Extra USB ports are useful==The Bad==- Large size- Smart charging feature doesn’t work too well- Pricey for a surge protector

It’s exactly what the description says–a double walled glass cup with a glass infuser for tea leaves–but it looks absolutely beautiful in real life. The teardrop shape of the inner cup looks very elegant when you add in the tea, and overall, the all-glass build is just fantastic. Check out the pictures to see how the double wall looks with liquid inside!Functionally, it’s great too. It does get warm when you pour in boiling water, but it’s not so hot that you can’t hold the cup thanks to the double wall design. The infuser works just as you’d expect it to, and it’s also extremely light, thanks to the special glass it’s made out of. Drinking from this thing is just a pleasure.Some of the other reviews have noted that it doesn’t keep your tea hot for long and that it lets small pieces of tea leaves through the infuser. In my experience, it kept the tea warm for as long as a regular mug would–it’s not a thermos. Also, tiny pieces do go through, but I think that’s expected for a glass infuser. It’s hard to produce a glass filter fine enough to sift through tiny tea leaves. The one flaw that I did notice was that the cover is a bit loose, so watch out for that.Overall, this is just a fantastic cup by Immortalitea. It’s well designed, it works perfectly, and it just looks stunning. It’s also pricey and probably not made for everyone except die-hard tea lovers, but that doesn’t keep this from being one stylish product. I love it.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 4.5/5==The Good==+ Fantastic design+ Tea just tastes better and looks better in this cup+ Surprisingly lightweight==The Bad==- Pricey, for a cup.- Cover isn’t the best fit

I never thought I’d call stickers “cool” ever since I graduated from elementary school, but these are pretty awesome. So like many of the other reviewers have noted, they’re basically thin black stickers which you can stick to pretty much anywhere–jars, closets, etc. It comes with a liquid chalk pen, which feels like those liquid white out pens, except these can be washed off the stickers by rubbing it with a damp cloth.The only thing I’d like to note is that the pens do come dry at first, so you have to shake it a bit and press the pen down in a pumping motion several times to get the ink flowing (you’ll see the tip actually go into the pen as you press down). Other than that, just write on the stickers like you would with a marker, and it looks really nice! I really like the contrast of the white and the black, and they look classy and traditional.Finally, keep in mind that it’s reusable in the sense that you can wipe off your writing and re-write it as much as you want, but the stickers themselves stick on pretty tight after you put them on, and it’s tough getting them to come off again.Overall, I love these stickers. I have them on my cabinets and closets now, and it’s fantastic. They’re versatile and look classy, and it’s a fantastic organizational tool.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

For a 5,000mAh battery, this is one of the most compact ones I’ve seen. It’s like a size of a thick cigarette lighter, and in my tests, it was able to charge my phone from 20%-100% twice before it drained. That’s pretty impressive.As for the design, it’s not super sleek or anything, but it’s simple and functional. The size and shape makes it easy to hold, and the power button is large. There are four lights in the front indicating the amount of charge left in the battery. I do want to give some credit to the cable included though–it’s a 2-in-1 cable with both micro-USB for Android devices and lightning for Apple devices–you simply have to put the lightning jack on top of the micro-USB jack to turn it into a lightning cable.Using it is super easy–just plug in the cable (USB goes into the battery pack, and micro-USB/lightning goes into your phone), and press the power button. It should start charging automatically. To charge the battery itself, all you have to do is flip the cable around (micro-USB goes into the battery pack, USB goes into your wall adapter/computer) and the lights will start blinking to indicate the charge status.Overall, this is a simple but very compact battery pack. I love the fact that it’s so small as it makes it super easy to just throw into a bag or a purse. The box does mention a couple of smart charging features, but I didn't notice any significant differences compared to charging from a regular wall adapter--they're both pretty fast. Recharging the battery itself takes around 2.5 hours. The versatile cable is cool too. I do think there are cheaper options available, but this has great build quality and works really well. No complaints!Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 5/5==The Good==+ Simple, functional design+ Very compact and portable+ Versatile USB cable able to charge both Android & Apple devices==The Bad==- A bit pricey

I’m not a bulky person (particularly not in the arms department), but the medium ones fit me just fine. It kinda looks like you’re wearing under armor, except without the whole torso part. This makes it more tolerable to wear in the hotter seasons, since your whole body isn’t being covered. The spandex material is similar though–stretchy, tight, and breathable. At the upper end of each sleeve (so the end near the biceps), there’s a small silicone lining which serves as an elastic band and keeps it tight enough so that it won’t slip off. It isn’t the most comfortable, and when you take it leaves marks on your skin due to the grip. It does do the job of keeping the sleeves from slipping off though. I included a picture of the little silicone strips so that you can see.As for the compression, the medium size fits me just right–it’s not too tight and not too loose. Movement isn’t restricted at all, and the compression helped me a bit with soothing sore muscles. It does get a bit warm when exercising, but they don’t get all sweaty due to the material which does a good job at wicking moisture.Finally, I really like how it looks! The logo isn’t too intrusive and the sleeves themselves are well-made. If you enjoy the look of under armor or compression shirts, you’ll like this as well.Summary: 4.5/5==The Good==+ Well designed & made with quality materials+ Works as intended+ Looks good==The Bad==- A bit pricey- Silicone band isn’t the most comfortable

This is a very simple knife sharpener, with tungsten blades for sharpening dull knives, and ceramic blades for fine honing. It’s just like all the other knife sharpeners out there. I do appreciate the rubber grips on both the handle and the base–they make it hard for the sharpener to slide around. Using it is very easy–sliding the knife 3-4 times through the sharpening blades at a vertical angle were more than enough for my knives to become razor sharp again.The rest of the knife sharpener is made of plastic, making this a very light tool. I do appreciate the longer handle, as it does make it easier to grip while sharpening the knives. However, it is pricier than some of the other options here on Amazon at $14 (at time of review).Overall, this is a solid knife sharpener that’s well designed and does its job. Nothing to complain about here.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

My favorite part about this pitcher is the fact that it comes with 2 cores. One is your typical fruit infusion core, which allows water and the fruit/vegetables/herbs to mix together and infuse, and the other is an ice core, which you can fill with water and then freeze. You can then put it in the pitcher to keep it cool while not diluting the drink (since the ice core is completely sealed). Both those cores are twisted into the cap to hold it in place. When pouring drinks, you do need to keep a finger on the cap to keep it from falling off.Everything here is made from BPA-free plastic, which keeps the pitcher light. The quality of the plastic is good–it’s around the same thickness of a BRITA pitcher, and it’s got a nice design with elegant curves. My only complaint about this pitcher is that there were a couple of scratches on the plastic when it first arrived, but that could’ve been the packaging’s fault.Overall, this is an excellent pitcher, and the inclusion of the two cores make it versatile for not only serving infused drinks, but also cool drinks like iced tea or fruit punch. You are paying a bit extra for it though, so I’d suggest the Prodyne one if you don’t see yourself ever using the ice core.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 5/5==The Good==+ Good quality plastic + elegant design+ Love the ability to change cores==The Bad==Nothing at all!

This is a very polished and modern feeling power bank for a very affordable price of $15. In my opinion, that is probably its biggest strength. It doesn't feel cheap thanks to its metal frame, and it's just a very slick and classy looking power bank.Functionally, it works just fine. You charge the battery with the included micro-USB cable which can also be used to charge Android Phones. It charges fast, and it recharges fast. To use it, you simply plug in your phone to one of the two USB-out ports and press the button on the side. There are indicator lights on as well right under the power button which show how much battery is left.All in all, a simple, sleek looking power bank. No complaints here. They also make fantastic gifts due to its nice packaging!

At a size slightly larger than a quarter, this is a simple Bluetooth headset that tries to remain relatively hidden. It’s hard to spot unless someone is looking straight at you from the side or looking closely, especially compared to a standard Bluetooth headset, but it’s definitely not invisible. It charges via an included proprietary USB cable, which isn’t bad, but it makes it harder to deal with should you ever lose the cable. When I first turned on the headset, it talked to me in Chinese, and I had to read the instructions to find out how to switch it to the English mode.Functionally, it’s also lacking compared to the larger headsets, but that’s not to be unexpected given the size. One button controls everything from the power, pause/play, voice dialing, and answering the phone. There’s no fancy volume control or rewind/fast forward here. Despite that though, this headset does its primary job–answering calls–well. The microphone works well, as the person I was calling heard me just fine, and the volume itself is fine. I had no problems using this in external environments, like a car. As for comfort and fit, there’s no replaceable tip here–it’s a one-size-fits-all kind of deal. Luckily, it seem to fit me fine, and it was comfortable enough. Just keep in mind that due to the nature of the design, it ONLY works in your right ear.Sound quality is adequate for calls, but not for music. Since headsets like these are primarily meant for calls, I don’t think this really counts as a negative. I personally love the fact that it’s so discreet, because it sucks walking out in public with an obnoxious headset on your ears and getting dirty looks. One thing to note though is that if you do intend to use this out in public, a lot of people might think you’re talking to them due to the fact that this is almost invisible.Overall, this is a nice, simple Bluetooth headset which does indeed stick true to its claim of being discreet. It works fine for hands-free calling, it’s nice and small, and it’s comfortable enough. The battery life is rated at around 3 hours, and I had no reason to doubt that in my testings.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 4.5/5==The Good==+ Sticks true to its claim of being discreet+ Works well for hands-free calling+ Comfortable enough==The Bad==- Proprietary charging cable makes replacement a hassle- Lacks some of the more advanced functions due to small design

My favorite thing about this lamp is its modern design. It just looks so sleek and modern–there are no knobs to turn, no lightbulbs to replace, and everything from the light to the base has that thin, modern look. The fact that it’s operated by a touch-sensitive power button and dimmer makes it even cooler.The LED light itself is a bright white color which can be dimmed down at night for a softer feel. LED lights are known to have a long life span, while using less energy than a typical light bulb. The lamp at its brightest setting is actually brighter than your typical CFLs, so that’s You tap the power button once to turn it on, but you have to hold your finger over the power button to turn it off. That felt a bit unintuitive at first, but you get used to it. Sliding your finger up and down the dimmer brightens/dims the light. Overall, it’s still really easy to use, and I’ve grown to love having a dimmable lamp, especially by the bedstand. There’s an included proprietary power adapter which you just plug in to a standard 2 prong outlet.The gooseneck is enclosed in a rubbery material which gives it a grippy, soft feel. The bottom half is rooted in place, but you can adjust the top half into pretty much any angle, making this a very versatile lamp. I like the feel of it, and I have no complaints about the gooseneck.Overall, this is a fantastic lamp–one that I have absolutely no issues with. For $30 (at time of review), it’s priced very reasonably, especially when compared to other LED lamps.Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 5/5==The Good==+ Solid build quality with a modern design+ LED light is bright and comfortable+ Touch operated controls are useful, if slightly unintuitive==The Bad==Nothing at all!

Jojoba oil is an ingredient commonly mentioned in many beauty magazines, and it’s with good reason–it’s found in many beauty products from shampoos to moisturizers. This bottle is filled with the pure oil itself, and can be used as a moisturizer for both the face and the hair. Having used this for a month now, I must say it’s a fantastic natural moisturizer.There are a variety of oils out there that also have moisturizing properties, including argan oil and rosehip oil, but Jojoba oil tends to be a bit cheaper than those two. Another thing I really like about this is the fact that it has a very light nutty odor–you can barely detect it. I put this on after a warm shower and applying a toner and wake up the next day with extremely soft skin–I love it! This bottle specifically may not look like much, but since you don’t use much per application, one of these should be able to easily last 2+ months.Overall, I think this is a great starting choice for anyone looking for a natural alternative moisturizer and want to give the oils a try. It’s one of the most budget friendly choices, and it really does work. For those who feel weird about putting oils on their face/body, they actually get absorbed by your body rather quickly and I haven’t experienced any breakouts whatsoever. If anything, they’ve helped my acne due to how nourishing it is for the skin. Just make sure to apply the oil sparingly–you really don’t need that much.Please note that I was sent this product for review, and I hope that it’s been helpful for you! Feel free to leave any questions/comments below and I’ll do my best to respond.==The Good==+ Works fantastically as a moisturizer+ Very light scent+ Great value==The Bad==- None!5/5

This is a really simple speaker, but it’s got most of the basic functionalities, and it sounds great for being so small(see picture for size comparison). It only has 3 buttons, but they each have two functions (play/pause = power button, volume up = fast forward, volume down = rewind). The latter functions can be enabled by holding down the button instead of a regular press.I’ll start this review with the features I like and then talk about what I didn’t like. There’s a couple of ports on the speaker–one AUX port for non-bluetooth devices(AUX cable is included), one USB out port for its charging feature, and one micro-USB port for charging the speaker itself. I’ll talk a bit more about the charging feature, since that’s something that’s not often found on Bluetooth speakers. It essentially turns the speaker into an external battery, allowing you to charge your phone. This is a clever use of the battery and it makes the speaker useful in situations where your phone is running low, but just know that the battery isn’t very big (rated at 1000mAh). That’s enough to charge an average phone up 20-30%. When using this, the battery drains quite fast, and the speaker will run out of battery, so I recommend saving this feature for situations where you truly need to charge your phone. The speaker’s battery life without using this feature is pretty decent, clocking in at around 5-6 hours.The other cool feature about this is its IPX65 waterproof rating, which means it’s protected against light splashings of water. As long as the ports are sealed by the caps, it should survive exposure to small amounts of water. I spilled a cup of water on it as a test, and it sounded a bit funny as the water got into the speaker grills. After drying, it sounded fine. It’s also pretty durable looking, with the edges all reinforced by some sort of rubber material.Now, for the one issue that I feel like was overlooked is the rewind feature. You have to press the volume down button for a couple of seconds before it rewinds, but unfortunately these couple of seconds are too long, and it simply rewinds to the beginning of the song rather than the previous song. This essentially makes the rewind feature useless, so keep that in mind. Other than that though, I really like this speaker. It has a good sound, it’s compact, durable, and has good versatility in its charging feature. It’s a shame it can’t rewind.Summary: 4/5==The Good==+ Good sound for a compact speaker+ Durable & waterproof+ Versatile charging feature for emergencies==The Bad==- Rewind function doesn’t really work- Battery is a bit small to be an external battery- Lacks microphone/answer call button (I rarely use this feature, but most speakers have it so I’m just leaving this here)Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions/comments below!

With wireless charging, there are currently three main standards–”Qi”, which is what this one supports, “Powermat”, and “Rezence”. Make sure your phone supports the Qi wireless charging standard before buying this!Anyways, regarding the charger itself–it’s a little rubber mat around the size of a floppy disk (er… a large post-it for the newer generation ?) that’s powered by a USB cord which you can plug in to a wall adapter or a computer. Regardless of the power source, the charging speed remains the same. After that, you just place the phone on top of the charging pad and it begins charging and an indicator light goes from red to green to indicate charging status.
