It sounds simple in theory, but it’s a bit more complex in practice. First, you have to find out where the wireless charging inductor is located on your phone and then place that area near the center of the pad. Not all phones have it in the direct middle, and if you don’t position the phone correctly, it either charges slowly or doesn’t charge it at all. Next comes the issue with a phone case. If your phone is in a case, then it’ll either charge slowly or not charge at all depending on the thickness, forcing you to take it off before charging.When the you take off the case and place it perfectly, the charging works just fine. It charges just as fast as a normal charger and it feels magical. However, that is rarely the case, and the inconsistencies makes it frustrating. I don’t think that’s an issue with the charger itself, but more of a widespread issue with the technology of wireless charging in general.Overall, I think the charging pad itself is well made. It’s small and portable, it looks decent, and it charges fast when everything lines up perfectly. My only question is–why use something so inconsistent when you can just plug in your phone?My recommendation would be to wait for a better, more standardized wireless charging technology to come through before moving on. I think wired charging just works more consistently these days. If you’re enjoy being an early adopter of new(ish) technology though, I suppose this isn’t a bad buy.==The Good==+ Well made+ Not too pricey==The Bad==- Wireless technology just isn’t there yet- Doesn’t come with its own wall adapter- Have to line up phone perfectly for optimal charging3/5Please note that I was sent this product for an honest review. I used a Nexus 4 for testing, and unlike the other reviewer, it's worked fine for me. You just have to make sure to align it well and take off any cases. Feel free to leave comments/questions below and I will respond!

If you’re looking for earbuds under $10, this is a serious contender for the best choice. The sound isn’t the most impressive–the bass is good, but the medium & high ranges can be a bit muddy. It’s definitely still an upgrade over included headsets like the ones that came with your phone (apple earpods, etc.). I compared these to other popular cheap Amazon headsets like the JLab JBuds Hi-Fi Noise-Reducing Ear Buds (Black) as well as the Panasonic RPHJE120K In-Ear Headphone, Black, and I would rate the sound quality on these as a bit better than either.It’s the other features that make these shine. It includes a mic/controller, a tangle resistant cable, and it even comes with a pouch to protect the earbuds. The pouch isn’t anything special, but the other two are well appreciated and work well. There’s also the standard 2 extra sizes of silicone tips. You usually don’t expect these when buying headphones under $10, so having these definitely increases the value of this headset. My favorite aspect of these earbuds is how comfortable they are. They’re pretty lightweight and once you find a tip that fits you, you can barely feel them at all. I actually prefer these over pricier ones due to the comfort alone, even if the sound quality is slightly worse.Overall, I think this is one of the best choices in the sub-10 budget. My one complaint is that there were some scratches on it when I first received it, but that could’ve been from the packaging or the shipping.=The Good=+ Nice set of features for such a low budget headset+ Feels well made+ Sound is decent=The Bad=- Was a bit scratched up upon arrivalFinally, please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave any questions/comments and I will respond!4.5/5

With neoprene knee sleeves, their main function isn’t to offer support–it’s mainly for heat retention & compression. This can help with inflammation and pain relief and can be good for runners/athletes who put a lot of pressure on their knees.Now, as for this particular knee sleeve, I think it’s well made. The first thing to note is that this package only includes one sleeve which works on either leg. I got the medium sized one (see the included size chart) and I definitely felt the compression when I slipped it on for the first time. It also felt pretty thick. Indeed, after a short jog, there was actually sweat on my knees when I took it off. Also, because it’s so thick, it restricts your knee movement a little, but it’s not enough to really impair any sort of exercise/walking. It definitely does it’s job of retaining heat and compression. As for the design, it looks very sporty and I personally like it.Overall, I think this would be a good product for anyone looking to relieve joint pain on their knees. Make sure you pay attention to the size (or the compression might be too much/too little) and keep in mind that this is a thick sleeve. Using it in the summer might be a bit overkill due to how hot it can get.Please note that I was sent this product for an honest opinion, and feel free to leave questions & comments below. I’ll do my best to respond!5/5

For ~$12, you can’t be expecting super high quality sunglasses like a Ray Ban or something similar. The frame & the lenses here are all plastic, it’s a bit wobbly at certain joints, and it doesn’t feel particularly well made–I’d say it’s slightly above the quality of those $10 gas station sunglasses. One thing that did surprise me though was the fact that it comes with a bunch of extras–a plastic carrying case, a microfiber cleaning cloth, and a carrying pouch.As for the sunglasses themselves, they’re a bit larger than most of the aviator styled sunglasses I’ve tried, so they might look a bit large on people with small faces (see pictures for comparison–this pair is the bottom one). If you like sunglasses with larger lenses, then these are perfect. They do their job fine–my eyes were quite comfortable in the sun–and the sunglasses are indeed polarized for glare reduction (you can test this yourself by looking at a computer screen with these on and rotating your head 60 degrees to see if the darkness changes).Overall, I think that these are a bit on the large side, but they do their job just fine. The sunglasses feel a bit flimsy, but the additions are a really nice surprise considering the price. If you’re looking for a cheap pair of sunglasses which get the job done, this isn’t a bad option.Disclaimer: I was sent this product for a discounted price in exchange for an honest review.Hope this helped! Feel free to leave questions or comments below!

I’ve never tried a lighter like this before, but it’s essentially a mini stove top on a USB stick. When you open it up, the heat coil automatically turns on and you can stick your cigarette in, breathe in, and it catches. It also turns on the dark light, which to me, is a bit of an unnecessary addition. The stick itself is made of metal, which is nice, but it also gets hot if you keep using it. After a couple of seconds, the heat coil turns off automatically (for safety reasons I assume). It’s definitely very safe–I tried sticking a piece of paper in there and while it charred it, there was no fire. I haven’t used it long enough to tell you the exact battery life, but it is rechargeable via an included micro-USB cable.Finally, as a side note, the instruction manual is not well written at all. Luckily, this thing isn’t too hard to figure out how to use. It also says not to charge it for too long because you can “overcharge it”, which seem like bad design. I did however forgot to take it off the charger this one time, and nothing happened, so take it with a grain of salt.Overall, this isn’t a very high quality lighter or anything, but it works, and it’s definitely safe. For the price of $9(at time of review), it's not bad. It does have the benefit of being rechargeable, so it'll never run out of lighter fluid like regular lighters. Just keep in mind that the instructions aren’t very good and I thought the inclusion of a dark light to be kinda random.Summary: 4/5Disclaimer: Please note that I was sent this product in exchange for an honest opinion. Feel free to leave questions and comments below!

This is a very simply designed lantern, but it works well. It’s just a very bright LED light enclosed in a detachable plastic cup which serves the purpose of diffusing the light, and it does the job. There’s three modes–regular, bright, and off–and those are all cycled through the use of one button. It’s very easy to operate.There is one major drawback to this lantern though, and that’s the fact that it’s just not that bright (it would serve to light up a small tent, and you’re able to see a couple of feet around you in pitch black, but that’s about it). Depending on what you’re looking for when you go camping, this might not be the most ideal solution. For those who simply need a light source in the tent or a small area, this would be ideal.The best feature of this is the fact that it uses a rechargeable battery which charges via a proprietary USB cable–it’s nice not having to deal with disposable batteries, and you can always bring one of those external batteries if you need to recharge it. Battery life is as stated, around 7-8 hours depending on the brightness level. The solar feature is also a nice plus, but it depends on the weather, so it’s not always the most reliable. When it’s charging (whether via solar or via cable), a red LED turns on as an indicator.All in all, this is a very simple lantern. It’s not a very bright lantern, so just keep that in mind. The rechargeable battery and the solar panels are definitely awesome features though, and that makes this lantern incredibly flexible and convenient.Please note that I was sent this product for an honest opinion. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!Summary: 4.5=The Good=+ Recharge battery+ Solar power is always awesome+ Easy to operate=The Bad=- Not that bright

These baking mats are fantastic and I love the fact that they're reusable. It comes with three different sizes, and each of them are made of the exact same material. I like these sizes--they're set to very standard baking pans, and the fact that it comes with 3 is a nice bonus. I've had no issues baking with these--they're rated up to 450F, and the mats themselves are fantastic quality. They're non-stick so you don't need to add any grease, they're very easy to wash, and this is a fantastic reusable alternative to the classic aluminum foil/baking paper.I suppose the only issue would be that it doesn't work in all situations. For example, with aluminum foil, you can wrap it around the entire baking pan. Also, since the sizes for these mats are set, you can't adjust the size like you could with foil. Personally, I think the reusability factor makes up for these slight trade-offs.Overall, this is a fantastic set of baking mats. They're good quality, easily washable, and they work. I think it's a bit pricey, but I suppose that's the cost of quality. There's a few trade-offs, but it's definitely a worthwhile investment for those who love baking.Please note that I was asked to review this product honestly at a discounted price. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

This is a set of excellent, high quality batteries. Most of the other reviewers have already backed up all of the technical specifications, and I can attest to them as well. Rated at 2600mAh, these batteries should be able to last a while (that's around the capacity of the battery in a large smartphone). Also, since these are made of lithium, they're very lightweight compared to alkaline batteries. You can recharge these in any battery charger which can charge Li-on batteries (most only charge Ni-Mh and Ni-Cd so make sure to read the specifications on your charger!). The same company which sells these also makes a decent charger, so you can look into that if you wish.Just keep in mind that these are very large batteries despite what the pictures say (much larger than AA) and they won't fit in appliances which take standard AA batteries. Make sure to only get these if you have something which specifically requires 18650 batteries.Overall, these are good quality batteries. I assume that if you're on this page you know what you're looking for. Those looking for AA sized batteries should look elsewhere as these are NOT your typical batteries.Please note that I was sent this product in exchange for an honest opinion. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

The ACEVIVI Nail strips are composed of some material that is like a combination of a sticker and a gel. This property of the strips was actually rather helpful as it helps one re-adjust the strips after application on the nail, but the bad thing was how sticky they were. This is good and bad of course.The good: application of the strips is very straightforward; as the packages instructs, you simply peel the strip off of the plastic sheet, and apply to your nails. After applying, they can easily be removed and readjusted. Once applied, the strips dry up and actually last on your nails for a lot longer than nail polish, and also don’t chip¨ (though they do peel a little at times).The bad: while their high-level of stickyness is good for application, I found that after I had done my left hand and moved on to doing my right hand, the strips would stick to the freshly-applied strips on the nails of my left hand, which got really messy and frustrating. Good thing the strips were re-adjustable though so it wasn’t a big deal. Secondly, the strips do take a while to dry. After applying the strips, I didn’t wait long enough to let them dry, so I ended up losing a few strips within an hour, which of course can be pretty disappointing. Third, the strips themselves are rather large for my own nails. I have really small hands with really small nail beds, so the strips, made to be ¨one size fits all¨ often ended up sticking to my fingers because I had so much excess from the strips. Because of this, I came to learn that not trimming down the strip to fit the nail before they dry leads to complete peeling of the strips because of the little ¨flap¨ on the skin that isn’t fully dried on the nail. Also, the package instructs one file any excess from the strips; filing the strip ended up tearing the part of the strip that was already on my nail - lucky for the ¨gel-like¨ texture of the strips I was able to easily hide the tear). Therefore I recommend instead to trim it off with scissors or a clipper. I also found that it helped a lot to have a nail pick to fully fit the strip to all the crevices on your nail! This will help the strips stay on the nail for longer!All in all, the strips themselves are OK. Everything I listed in ¨The bad¨ list can be fixed by taking a few extra measures, but it’s inconvenient.Given their durability and their diverse set of designs, I wouldn’t say that it’s a bad deal. As I mentioned already, I have had my current set of stick-ons for 3 weeks now, and it looks like they’ll be on for much longer. I would take these stick-ons over regular nail polish for a quick, long-lasting fix–just be aware of some of the product’s flaws.3.5/5 stars.-Please note that I was sent this product for review, and feel free to leave questions & comments below!

Here’s a compact adapter for families or just people with lots of portable devices. In our increasingly technological world, more and more devices need to be charged, and this adapter is able to fit five USB ports to charge all your devices. Despite that, it maintains a small footprint–it’s around the same size as thick deck of cards. It also comes with a cable of around 3 feet which connects the adapter to the outlet.As for the construction of the charger itself, it’s mostly made of a soft rubbery plastic with an aluminum band (the red part w/ the logo). There’s also a small blue LED light that indicates when there’s power flowing to the adapter. It’s non-intrusive & subtle, and I like it. The purpose of this is to get out of the way and charge your devices, and this design achieves that purpose. Now, in my use, it has gotten warm when I charged more than 3 devices at once, but that’s to be expected. The manual says that there’s a smart chip inside which determines what device is plugged in and charges it at an appropriate voltage, and that seems to work pretty well because both tablets and phones charged at its normal rate.Overall, this is a solidly built adapter which works well and boasts a portable design. I’d recommend this for anyone with the need to charge multiple devices. For the current price of $20, it's not the cheapest one on the market, but I think the build quality justifies the price in this case.==The Good==+ Compact build w/ five USB ports+ Non-intrusive, subtle design+ Smart charging allows for fast charging of both tablets/phones==The Bad==- Nothing!*Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

This, like the title describes, is simply a powerstrip with 4 USB ports instead of outlets. It’s around the same size as a small power strip, but it seems well built. It’s mostly made of plastic with some rubber around the edges as well as on the bottom for better grip. It’s a clean design that gives off a minimalist and sleek look. It comes with a simple power cable around 3 feet long, which is a bit on the short side, but my power outlet wasn’t too far away, so it didn’t present a problem for me. A blue LED light turns on when it’s plugged in and all of the USB ports also light up. This looks pretty cool at night, as you can clearly see where the charger is, but I can also see this being a bit disruptive if placed too close to the bed–I’d recommend placing this on the floor instead.Functionally, it works great. Obviously, the reversible USB ports are nice because you never have to worry about which way the USB is supposed to go in, and it’s been able to charge all devices (tablets, phones, kindles, etc.) at the same speed as a normal wall adapter, regardless of how many devices you have plugged in.All in all, as long as you don’t mind the blue LED lights (I personally think they’re kinda cool), this is a convenient USB power strip to have for those who want a central hub to charge all their devices.==The Good==+ Reversible USB ports are convenient+ Blue LED lights look cool (in my opinion)+ Clean, minimalist design==The Bad==- Power cable is a little short- Blue LED lights could be intrusive to some*Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

Most of the battery packs on the market these days consist of the battery & a micro-USB cable for charging the battery pack. This external battery pack does away with that cable and instead it is replaced with a foldable 2 prong male plug, so you can stick this directly into the wall to charge it. Other features include 2 USB output jacks (so you can charge 2 devices at a time), as well as a LED indicator light (blue = relatively full, green = around 50%, red = low battery, flashing = charging). What’s cool about this design is that it can double as a wall-USB adapter, since you can plug it in and charge both the battery & your devices at the same time–and when you’re on the go, simply unplug the battery, fold in the plug, and it becomes a portable external battery pack. It’s convenient & versatile. Overall, I really like this designNow, it does advertise this “shake & charge” feature, which in my opinion is more of a gimmick rather than anything useful. Essentially, instead of a power button to turn on the battery, you just have to give it a good shake. While that’s novel and different from the other battery packs, it doesn’t serve the function any better. To be honest, I prefer the good old fashioned power button, as shaking it to turn it on can look a bit strange–especially to others who have no idea what you’re doing.Finally, some technical details:- 5000mAh is able to charge most smartphones 2 times- Charging speed is on par with charging your device w/ a wall adapter- I didn’t get an exact timer on this, but it takes a bit longer to charge both devices & the battery at the same time vs just the battery alone.- Recharging time is around 5-6 hrs in my experience, which is a bit longer than other battery packsOverall, despite the gimmicky shake & charge feature, I still like the design & versatility of this battery pack. It doesn’t have a flashlight like most other battery packs, but those usually aren’t any good–and I think the versatility of this device as both a battery pack and a wall adapter makes up for it. Overall, I’d recommend this to anyone looking for a external battery pack and won’t mind the shaking feature. The price is decent, the quality is good, and the longer charging time shouldn’t be an issue when it’s used normally as a wall adapter and taken as a mobile battery pack while on the go.4.5/5==The Good==+ Unique & versatile design+ Compact & portable+ Charging is fast regardless of device==The Bad==- Shake & charge feature feels gimmicky rather than purposeful- Takes a bit longer compared to other battery packs to recharge*Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

I got this on sale somewhere else, but since there are no reviews on this product yet I thought I'd chip in my thoughts.- MSRP on the price tag was $48. Quality is good, as expected from FILA. I personally wouldn't pay more than $30 for this though.- It's thin, like a long sleeve shirt with a hood, but it's good for spring/fall weather & as an inner layer during the colder months.- I got the medium size and it fits perfectly (I'm 6ft, 150lbs--so a bit on the thin side).- The fabric is soft, and wearing it is very comfy. Wouldn't call it SUPERsoft though, it feels like a cotton long sleeve.- Didn't shrink or bleed upon machine washing cold. Would still wash w/ dark colors though.- The contrast colors add a nice touch.- It's FILA, so it does give off that athletic look.Overall, this is a good piece of clothing for those looking for a comfy layer to wear on those chillier days. It may not be supersoft, but it's comfortable, good quality, and makes you look like an athlete. Some of the colors/sizes are a bit pricey here though--I'd try to look for prices under $30.

For fans of lighter-flavored teas, the green spiral spring tea is one of the better ones out there. Having been to China before, I can attest that it is indeed one of the more famous and expensive tea leaves over there, and many value the green tea for its lightly aromatic flavor and its natural health properties. As for this specific product, it's packaged nicely in a vacuum seal in a tin can, so it's fresh when it gets to your house. The tea leaves themselves are great, and here are some of my recommendations to ensure the best tasting tea (from my experiences in China, at least):- Use water that's just below boiling temperature (water that is too hot will destroy the flavor of the tea, and leave a slightly bitter taste)- This tea is meant to be very lightly flavored, so no need to overdo the tea leaves. A light golden yellow color is the best tasting in my opinion- You can actually freeze the tea leaves after opening to keep it staying fresh longer and preserve flavor.Overall, I'd recommend these tea leaves for those looking for something different from the everyday black/green teas. It's not for people who enjoy strong-flavored teas, but for those looking for a more subtle aromatic flavor, this is a great choice.

The ACEVIVI eyeshadow “wedding party” palette consists of very neutral, natural colors, such as browns, greys, blacks, peaches and beiges. The palette comes in a black case with a sturdy build and includes a mirror and two eyeshadow applicators. The case itself is very nice and professional looking, and even after having it (accidentally) fall off of  the top cabinet in my bathroom (about 6 feet high) the case was still completely intact!On to the palette: I was very impressed by the color selection. You have all the colors necessary for highlights and undertones that will allow for many designs. Or, if you’re more into simple make-up (like myself) it’s perfect for that too. Personally, I love the smokey-eye effect, and this palette’s color selection made it possible to create smokey eye effects with different colors.As for the eyeshadow itself, for the price you pay, you get good-quality eyeshadows that are rich in color and easy to apply. The eyeshadows are so soft and almost have that “moist” texture that allow them to be applied easily without having to do multiple applications. What’s more, it makes it incredibly easy to blend different colors together to create different effects. One downside of this, however is that if you don’t shake the brush (or applicator) the eyeshadow will sprinkle down off your eye lid and onto your cheek,  but this is easily solved by shaking off the excess eye-shadow from the brush. Once applied, the colors stayed on for a long time without smearing or smudging, even without the use of eye primer, which is great for those rushed moments or when you need a quick fix-up.Overall, I would highly recommend this eyeshadow palette for the quality of the paints and the affordable price. Being a fan of more toned-down colors, I would most definitely buy this palette again.-Feel free to leave questions & comments below! Please note that I was sent the product for review.

I recently had the opportunity to go camping with this lantern, and this is going to be a short review of my experience with this lantern, as well as some things I think you should note before purchasing it.- Made out of plastic, maintaining a light weight but compromises a bit on durability. I haven’t tried it, but I think drops from onto hard cement would damage it.- The light turns on automatically when you expand it and collapses to a portable size of 3.5 inches (around the height of an average smartphone). It’s around the width of a Camelbak water bottle.- Rated at 65 lumens, it was bright enough to light the entire campsite and spot any lingering garbage, raccoons, creepy camper neighbors.- Can also be used inside  a tent, but staring right at it is a bit painful–best used outside.- Bright enough to be used for nighttime hiking!- No issues with battery life during my 2 nights of usage (I’d still recommend bringing extra batteries for longer expeditions though).Overall, this is an excellent lantern with a good brightness for camping. It’s powerful enough to light up 10+ yards outdoors and provide good visibility of the entire campsite, which was all I needed. It’s also relatively portable for a lantern this powerful, which is really nice. I love the fact that it can be contracted and it turns on automatically when expanded–really makes it easy to use. I’d recommend this to anyone who needs a convenient, easy to use electric lantern while camping.Also, for those campers who use propane lanterns, I would say this is definitely dimmer, but in my opinion, the convenience and the reliability that comes with electric lanterns makes it a worthy trade-off.Hope this helps! Feel free to ask any questions below if you’d like for me to elaborate.Please note that I was sent this product to review.

I had the opportunity to go camping with this lantern, and this is going to be a short review of my experience with this lantern.- It’s compact and portable–I was able to stuff it just about anywhere. It’s also versatile, since you expand it for the lantern and collapse it to turn it into a flashlight. Probably the most valuable features.- Rubbery texture feels pretty good with a nice grip. It’s essentially two plastic pieces connected with an expandable spring-like structure, with some kind of cloth mesh. Battery compartment is at the bottom & you twist it to change batteries. There’s also a hook at the top, which can be folded in for portability.- It does have 3 modes, as listed in the description, but at night, when it’s pitch-black out, you’re going to want to stick with the bright mode. (It’s rated @ 30 lumens, which lights up a few yards outdoors).- It’s most useful for inside the tent, since it was able to provide good light to the entire tent without being too bright.- Battery life seems fine; I didn’t reach the full 15 hours of use, but I didn’t have to change batteries either.Overall, this is a fine lantern for indoors or if you need to light a smaller area. Just keep that in mind as you're buying this and don't expect a super powerful lantern from such a small device. The main strengths of this are the versatility as well as the portability. I would recommend a more powerful lantern for hiking trails at night or an activity which requires a lot of light, since this only lights up a couple of yards. If you’re looking for a small portable lantern that can get the job done in a cinch however, this is a great choice.Hope this helps! Feel free to ask any questions below if you’d like for me to elaborate.Please note that I was sent this product to review.

When I was asked to review this product, I got pretty excited. A solar powered battery which could charge your phone/tablets/portable devices?! That sounded pretty awesome and futuristic–a chance to perhaps get off the grid–but alas, it’s not what this product is for. This battery functions more like the typical external batteries that you can find anywhere else, with the solar charging function built in for emergencies. It also features a semi-rugged, water-resistant design, with the entire battery being enclosed in a protective rubber case with rubber seals covering each of the ports. I’ll keep this review short & simple, splitting it into two parts–design & how well it functions.==Design==I personally really like the design. I had the red color, which was bold and striking. The water resistant seals covering the ports felt a bit loose, so it wouldn’t stand being submerged inside water, but it makes it gives it some resistance against the rain. There’s 4 blue LEDs across the top which indicate the battery level, and the first LED turns green to indicate that it’s being charged via the solar panels. In the top right corner is the power button, which you can press once to turn on/indicate the battery level and press twice to turn on the flashlight. Speaking of the flashlight, it’s just a small LED light at the corner. It won’t replace a regular flashlight, but it’ll do in a pinch. The rest you can see in the picture–but I do really like the rubbery feel and grip of the battery.==Functionality==In short, it works. There are a couple of quirks that should be noted though. First of all, it’s rated at 5300mAh, which means it should be enough to charge the average smartphone 1.5-2 times. For the current price of $25, you can get (non-solar)batteries with a higher capacity for this price (just look on Amazon, or message me for recommendations), so what you’re paying for is the extra functionality of solar charging. Unfortunately, the solar charging is really slow. This is no fault of the device–I just don’t think solar technology is there yet–but just be aware that you probably won’t be using this solar charging option very often. Just to give an example, the manual says that 7-8 hours of solar charging = 20-30% of battery in an iPhone. I didn’t stand outside for that long, but from my limited use, it does seem to be quite slow. It recommends you charge it via the micro-USB cable, and I’d recommend that too. In my testing, it took around 4.5 hours to charge the battery from 0-100.My second quirk is this: there’s two USB ports–one on either side–so you can charge two devices at once, but oddly enough you can only do that when your battery is full. It’s really weird, and if you try charging two devices when the battery is at like 50% for example, the battery would shut itself off. I’m not sure for the reason behind this, but it’s just something to keep a note of.Other than those two things, everything else works as expected. It seems designed for outdoor stuff (it comes with a carabiner after all), and I can definitely see this being useful on a camping trip or for emergencies where you have no access to electricity. Before you buy it, you should ask yourself if you really need a battery with a slow-charging solar option, because if you don’t, there are cheaper options available which work just as well. If you’re an outdoors person and could use the solar charging functionally, I’d recommend this battery. Yes it’s slow and it sometimes can’t charge two devices at once, but it’s well designed, it’s rugged, and it works.

I’ve always thought magnets were cool so when I got the chance to review this product I was pretty excited. Whereas most of these phone mounts work via some sort of clip to hold your phone and a suction cup to mount it to the windshield, this one works with a magnet to hold your phone and a clip to attach to the air vents on your car. While this was certainly a unique take on the car mount, I had a couple of questions as to how well this would actually work–are the magnets actually strong enough to hold it in place? Would the air vents blowing hot air cause the phone to overheat? Does the clip stay on well enough on rough roads? Will the magnet damage the phone? I’ll answer all those questions & more in my review below.First, I’ll start with what’s in the box–you’ve got the clip itself with the magnet. It’s a circular little thing as you can see in the pictures and it’s coated with this rubbery material that gives it a nice grip. There’s also two magnets for non-magnetic phones which come separately. There’s a rectangular one and a circular one. Both of these are like stickers, and you can stick them onto your phone. Alternatively, if you don’t want something permanently attached to your phone, you can just slide the magnets in between your phone and your case. If you have a phone made out of glass/plastic and you don’t have a case, your only option would be to stick the magnet onto the phone.Anyways, I personally have a Nexus 4, which is made out of glass, and a normal plastic shell case. I didn’t want to stick a magnet on my phone, so I just slid it in between the case and my phone. At first I was a bit dubious about how well it would work at first because it would have to stick to the magnet through the case. Granted, I don’t have an otterbox or anything (and I don’t think it would work as well if you did), but it actually stuck on very tightly despite the case. I was quite pleased, and the bond was strong enough to not fall off during driving. As for the other questions–it does block the vent a little bit and the phone does get hot if you have the heat up, but I’ve never had the phone overheat and shut itself off. The only slight negative here is that the excess heat might shorten the battery life a bit, but it’s all very conditional. The clip itself also holds on to the vent quite well, and I had friends comment on how cool it is to see the phone just floating near the vents with nothing holding it in place. My final concern was about the magnet damaging the phone–I’m sure we’ve all heard stories about how magnets can corrupt hard drives and mess up the screen on old computers, but after doing some research, it turns out that this magnet, while strong, isn’t nearly strong enough to damage the phone.Overall, this works really well, and it also looks a lot cooler than your typical mounts. My only reservation would be for those with either a very heavy phone (phablets perhaps?) or those with thick cases. If you have a thick case, your only solution would be to stick the magnet outside of the case, and I’m not sure how many would like that. For those people, I’d recommend sticking to a regular car mount, as the magnets might not be strong enough to hold the phone. For me though, I just leave the magnet in between my phone and the case, and when I get in the car I can just effortlessly attach it to the mount. It makes it a lot easier, and every time I use it, it feels like magic. Or perhaps it’s just magnets.In summary…=The Good=+ Feels like magic. Magnetic magic.+ Magnets are strong enough for most users.+ Looks awesome, easy to use.-The Bad-- Vents aren’t the most ideal position for a phone.- Not as great for users with heavy phones/thick cases.Feel free to leave comments/questions below!

With this magical little device, you can pretty much turn any regular speaker into a bluetooth speaker. It’s a very small device, but it does come with a bunch of wires. There’s a dedicated power cable/adapter and an AUX cable to connect the bluetooth receiver to an actual speaker. Within the adapter, there’s also an NFC chip which allows NFC enabled phones (search “NFC enabled phones” on Google for a list if you’re not sure) to tap the receiver to pair it up via bluetooth. For those without NFC, you can still do it the old fashioned way (via settings, etc.). Anyways, once you have it plugged in and paired to your phones, you can connect it to any speaker with an AUX input jack, and that speaker essentially becomes a wireless bluetooth speaker! It also comes with the more outdated audio adapter as well so you can plug this into your older speakers/TV and play music from your phone!I’ve personally found this to be useful for my old set of stereo speakers, because now I can essentially stream music wirelessly from across the room. That being said, I do think that this is a product with limited use, since you can essentially do the thing by just connecting your phone to the speakers via an AUX cable. The only benefit this gives you is that it allows you to have a wireless connection between normally wired connections. When I was using it, it took me around 2-3 taps using the NFC pairing function before it recognized it and paired it up with the receiver. After pairing it up however, everything else worked flawlessly. The range is around 30 feet, which is more than enough for my uses around the house. On a side note, since this isn’t battery operated, it has to be kept plugged in at all times. This limits the portability, but it also means you don’t have to rely on battery life.Aside from the limited functionality, it does work really well. I’d like to see it come with something like a car adapter as well, for example, so I could also use it in the car. Overall, I don’t think this is something that would be considered a necessity for everyone, but for those who would like what is essentially a wireless update for their older speakers, this is a solution which works well.Check out the pictures for the size comparisons–it’s around the size of a regular egg.Feel free to leave any questions and comments below, and please note that I was sent this product for review.5/5Summary+ Works flawlessly+ Easy to use+ “Upgrades” older speakers with Bluetooth- NFC function took multiple taps- Limited use- Has to be kept plugged in

With a full glass platform, this scale looks really nice and classy on the kitchen counter. It’s operated completely by touch, and with a limit of 11 pounds, you shouldn’t be running into any issues (unless you’re eating a LOT of food). There’s a TARE function which allows you to reset it to zero to take into account things like cups/packaging/etc. You can also change the unit from grams to kilograms, ounces, and pounds. It works well, and the product as a whole is well made. I personally think the size is perfect for a kitchen scale. The only slight downside is that it’s powered by a button battery, which isn’t the best when it comes to replacement time (not as easy to find as something like a AA battery, for example), but it’s not too bad.My one minor complaint about this is that the glass attracts fingerprints really easily. I suppose it’s to be expected due to it being glass, but after using it a couple times, there are fingerprints all over the power button area. It’s not the worst thing, but it does detract a little bit from the look and gets a little annoying.Overall though, it works well, and it’s built well. It’s very simple to operate. The design looks great–the thinness of the device really gives it a sleek look, and if you’re not too bothered by fingerprints on your scale, I’d recommend this kitchen scale to anyone who needs it.Check out the picture for a relative size comparison. Also, for those who want more information on how to use it, here's a summary:- Tap the tare/power button to turn it on- Tap the unit button to change the unit- Tap the tare/power button once on to reset scale to zero- Press and hold the tare/power button to turn it offDisclaimer: I was sent this product for review. Please feel free to leave any questions/comments below and I’ll do my best to answer them.

Jumping rope is something that’s been growing in popularity as a cardiovascular workout, and famous boxers and other athletes have been using it as an alternative to running. There are several reasons why one would choose to jump rope instead of running, namely:- You stay in one place/easier to do indoors (you can do it in your house if you have a decent amount of space)- No need for a more expensive treadmill- Outside conditions may not always be the best for running- They’re both great cardio workouts, though the muscles worked are slightly differentNow, as for this specific jump rope, here are my experiences with it. I’m going to assume you have experience with jumping rope–if not, look up some online guides (it’s pretty easy to learn and it’s fun too!)It feels like a durable jump rope–very well made. I like the fact that you can actually adjust the length of the rope by adjusting the location of the handles, making it suitable for all sorts of people. As for the motion, it’s like the other reviewers have said–very smooth. It’s very light and easy to use, and I think both beginners and more advanced users would like this jump rope. I will say that since the rope is made out of wire, it does hurt if you hit yourself, but this applies to most jump ropes as well. Finally, it does come with that pouch you see in the pictures. It’s a nice bonus, and it’s useful for carrying it around if you travel a lot.Overall, I have no complaints about this product--it works very smoothly and I like how light it is. It’s versatile and adjustable as well. I think this would be a great jump rope for beginners and more experienced users alike.Disclaimer: Please note that I was sent this product for review. Feel free to leave questions & comments below!

I got the wind lotion, because I’ve always wondered what does wind smell like exactly? That was the question I had in my mind as I was trying it out for the first time. I was curious. Well, I didn’t have many expectations for this wind lotion, but I tried it anyways for 2 weeks. Just on a side note, I have normal skin, and I tried it on my arms, legs, and various parts of my body. Here are my observations:+ It definitely feels good on the skin. It’s light enough to not feel greasy, but it’s not so light that it feels like water either. The skin absorbs it pretty fast as a result.+ After application, it does leave a cool, tingly feeling. It’s very subtle though–it’s not like rubbing mint on your skin or anything.+  It came with 2 caps, which was pretty cool (one pump-styled, and one that’s seen in the pictures).+ I personally like the design of the bottle–feels and looks quite stylish.+ As for the fragrance… well I can’t say it smells like the wind. It’s very light, and it has a masculine smell to it. It’s not your typical masculine scent (you know, the one that smells like bear piss on evergreen trees)--it’s a bit more exotic. It’s really hard to describe the scent, other than saying it smells a bit like those artificial ocean wave scented candles but way lighter.+ It did moisturize the skin really well, and the scent lasted for around 2-3 hours afterwards.Overall, I loved how it felt, and it worked well. I wasn’t the biggest fan of the scent, but it was tolerable still.Finally, as a disclaimer–please note that I was given this product for review. Feel free to leave any questions & comments below!

Just wanted to say that I bought the army green one and it's definitely not as dark as it appears in the pictures--it's lighter and not that green, but I'm still okay with the color. I think it looks pretty stylish overall, and I like it for the most part.First off, I love how many compartments there are--2 side ones, one on the front, and there's even a small one in the back that you can't see in the pictures. Within the main compartment are like 4 more smaller pockets to help you organize things better. The canvas feels solid and durable, and the buckles/straps attached to the zippers feel like actual leather (not sure if they are or not though). The zippers itself seem decent, but time will tell. That being said, I do think it feels a bit small (6 ft male here). I think it might be tough to fit something like a 17 inch laptop in here. There's a designated sleeve for laptops, but my 11.6 inch chromebook barely fits in there with a case on. Also, there's no designated spot for a water bottle, which is something I'll miss coming from a traditional backpack. I haven't used it enough to comment on the durability yet, but I'll be using this as my day-to-day backpack, so I'll update the review after a couple months.Some final notes:- It's made in China--the packaging and the tag are in Chinese.- Overall quality feels pretty good; I just wish it was a bit more spacious- Feels comfortable to wear- Did some research to compare prices between canvas bags on Amazon, and this was one of the better deals. Overall, for $33(at time of purchase), I think it's worth it.

This is a collection of both floral and whole leaf tea, and it's absolutely delicious. I just wanted to point out a couple of things that I really appreciated about this collection:+ The packaging is great. Everything is vacuum sealed, making all of the flower buds/leaves incredibly fresh.+ Quality of the entire collection is very high+ Goes great with Tea Beyond's teapots, since you can really see the flower blooms unfold in the glass teapots as the tea is brewing. Takes the tea experience to the next level.+ Also great for parties for when you want to make an impression/have a conversation starter. You don't usually see hand-sewn floral tea blooms everywhere.I tried all of the different teas in this collection and I loved them all! I'm relatively new to floral teas, and I thought they were delicious. I wish they provided a little bit more information in the packaging about what's inside the flower blooms since they only have a name like "paradise" or "forever love", but I would still recommend this to any hardcore tea fans or just people looking to experience tea in a completely new way.

Just a disclaimer–I was sent this product for review. Here’s a lightning cable that feels more durable right out of the box, especially when compared to Apple’s included one. Apple’s cables aren’t bad, but they’re not the most durable either–especially for those who carry them everywhere due to the poor battery life of smartphones in general. Now, it’s a bit pricier than some of the other replacements that are here on Amazon, but some of the other cables have gotten poor reviews with them not lasting very long or the cables somehow breaking the phone. This cable just feels incredibly tough and durable–the two jacks are reinforced with metal (aluminum I believe), and the cable itself is like those you find on rugged headphones. It's long enough for most use cases, and it works flawlessly. Overall, It’s a solid cable, and I think the current price of ~$13 is reasonable for this quality.I’d recommend this for anyone looking for a more durable replacement cable for their iDevices.

I’ve never tried magnesium oil–nor have I even heard of it–until I was sent this product for review. I was curious, so I did some research on it and apparently it has a bunch of health benefits, with the most notable ones being better sleep, stress relief, and better digestion. Some of the studies done have found that ~70% of Americans consume less than the recommended dose of magnesium, and this topical magnesium oil should help with that.As for my personal experience, I have been sleeping well and feeling pretty good after using it, but I can't say for sure that it was because of this magnesium oil. There are just too many variables when it comes to digestion and sleeping like better exercise or a better diet. Also, what works for one person might not work for another. Anyways, with that in mind, I’ll write down some of my observations after 2 weeks of using this product:+ It seems to work best after a hot shower, as that’s when my skin was the softest and most absorbent.+ I would compare it to rubbing salt water on yourself rather than an oil–it leaves a layer of salt on your skin after it dries that you can’t see but you can feel. I accidentally applied it to a small wound this one time, and it burned like salt water would.+ Instructions say to rub it on your feet, especially on the bottom of your feet. That made me feel itchy (but only slightly…), which is apparently a sign of magnesium deficiency (oh no!)+ It doesn’t really have a smell. I tried smelling it once after rubbing it on my feet and smelled… my feet.+ I haven’t experienced any negative side effects since using this product.+ It feels a bit funny having salt on your skin, but it’s also oddly comfortable.As always, my advice with health supplements is to try them if you think you need them. In this case, if you think you need magnesium (usually found naturally in cocoa, leafy greens like spinach, and nuts), it wouldn’t hurt to try this out. Most of these supplements rarely have negative side effects, and if it doesn’t work–well you don’t ever have to buy it again.

I’m going to write the review with the assumption that you know what a UV light is and what it does (it’s not a flashlight, and it definitely doesn’t light up the dark like one). The most surprising thing about this model is how powerful it was based on the size. The beam is bright and it can cover a decently large area, despite the compact size. Unfortunately, you can’t adjust the focus like you can with some of the other lights. Using it in the dark provides the best results, as with most UV lights, but it can still work with some light.Build quality is solid. I like the fact that it’s made out of metal which gives it a nice solid feel. When I tried it for the first time, I was quite… surprised by the amount of stuff on my bed. Really does show you what you normally wouldn’t see. It’s advertised mainly as a pet urine detector, but you can detect a lot of stuff with this. Overall, there’s not much to dislike about this UV light. It works well considering its compact size, and it’s well built.Just be warned, you might not like what you see.Please note that I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review.

Our daughter has the Sofia the First version of this one and now our son has this Spiderman one.We think these are great lights for kids to take to bed with them, yet still soft/crushable in case they toss and turn in bed (ie. a lot better than a plastic flashlight!)Do note that the light is very dim and generally not disruptive at bedtime, but dim enough that you really couldn't read a book next to it.We also like these lights because the light automatically turns off after 5 or 10 minutes.  (Ie. Still a lot better than a plastic flashlight)

This pet blanket is so soft, us humans like to use it too! ;--)  Can't stress how incredibly soft it is and I wonder if the company makes regular throws, hah!Our Pomeranian cozied up to it immediately.Seems to be high quality, no stitching issues and large enough to protect one square cushion of a couch or a car seat or as a nice landing pad on the floor.  (We also have the Bone Dry dog food mat that I actually did not give a high rating to, but this one is a solid 5-stars)

Our 3 year old daughter really loves this and takes it with her to bed every night.  No buttons to push to turn it on and none to push to turn it off and it turns off automatically, too.It is definitely not something mommy or daddy could read her a book next to as it is quite dim, but perfect to not disrupt sleep if she takes it with her and cuddles with it.We also like the fact it is a very soft squishy light, in case she were to roll over it, versus a real hard plastic flashlight, not that we would let get sleep with one of those.The only reason I gave 4 stars (instead of  5) is the current price as of this writing; we received this for free as a Vine reviewer, but as parents, we would not have spent more than $10 for an item like this.

This mat does come folded and not rolled and still has a crease down the middle after a week with two dog bowls on top to try and flatten it out.Also the piping edge has already peeled up in one spot so I would question initial quality, but I wonder the longevity if I were to put this in the washing machine, which it does state is machine washable.We are okay with the size as it is the same size as our existing plastic one, but keep in mind we have a Pomeranian.If this came rolled instead of folded and if there were no flaws we'd give this 4-5 stars for use with a small dog.

We use a lot of essential oils at home for a variety of things and have access to therapeutic grade lavender essential oil and the wife and I do not think this smells like lavender even with just the hint of sage.  She has refused to keep using this because she doesn't like the smell, though I don't care either way.I will state however that this doesn't feel very moisturizing, because after using my hands are squeaky Tupperware clean.  Other hand soaps are not like this.  Perhaps in this case, squeaky clean is not a good thing for the hands.

We installed this on an 18' ceiling to replace an original and quite outdated foyer pendant light.The product is beautiful, the welds look fine, very high quality.The reason I gave it 3-stars however is because we felt the product dimensions were a little misleading.  We were replacing a 24" pendant light and this one states it is 25".  Well, that includes the pole pictured at the top.  The large portion of the light itself is maybe only 16" tall, the rest of that length is that pole.Even the 24" pendant light I removed had a 3-4 inch pole at top that connected to the chain and no, I didn't even consider that as part of the overall product dimension, ie...our original light is not really a 27-28" light, it is a 24" light.I make a big deal of this, because who cares how long that pole is, you just shorten the chain as needed, what matters is the exact proportions of the light when compared to something like an 18' ceiling!  So yes, we were a bit disappointed.We debated returning it, but decided we'd try it out and though we do wish we had something that matched the perfectly-sized 24" light we replaced, we were willing to live with this one.And yes, we used every single chain link for the 18' ceiling drop to match the length of the 24" light we replaced.

Only six inches long, so beware.  Have used this with a an iPod, iPad, iPhone with no issues only because my work desk has an outlet on top of the desk.  If my outlets were near the floor then this wold be quite a pain.  Works for me for my purposes, for my desk at work.

Works perfectly AND this ALSO includes the mini/standard type adapters that I almost bought separately until I found this exact one on Amazon.  This was almost a 2 for 1 type purchase.I just used this to cut my micro SIM card from my Nokia Lumia 1020 into a nano size to fit into my wife's iPhone 6 and it worked great.Then, I used the nano to Micro adapter and put her iPhone nano SIM into the supplied micro-adapter into my Lumia 1020 micro SIM slot and made some calls and that worked great.Then, to complete the testing, I put my recenty-cut nano-sized SIM into the same micro SIM adapter and put it back in my Lumia 1020 and that worked great again.So basically I was able to test every piece of this nano sim card cutter kit and verify everything worked.

I bought this to replace an existing one of these from another manufacturer.  That one was at least 5 years old since our car is 5 years old.  It ended up tearing, but we have no complaints and it served us well.  We got these key guards only because we had 2 Hondas and both keys looked similar so this was the easy way to differentiate them easily.Now THIS key guard seems a little higher quality than our other one and THIS one does not seem to attract as much pocket-lint as the previous one, maybe because it is blue and so is our pocket-lint, HAH!So far so good, perfect fit, easy to spot, serves its exact purpose.  Really no complaints and seems to be high quality and if we get 5 years out of this and or the Honda, we'll still be happy. :--)

We actually drank this brand in Vietnam while visiting family and liked it so much, the family mailed us some for the holiday.I ran out of that gift and was soon addicted and very thrilled to have found the exact one here on Amazon.Really great coffee all around.  Even better with a little bit of condensed milk.  (The mother-in-law likes to make it with coconut milk, but that's not my thing.)Since then, for good or bad, I drink one cup of this coffee every day in the morning.

In full disclosure, I received this from the Amazon Vine program to review for free.  I was actually slightly worried about the "gold" color and looking a bit too "bling-y".Fortunately, when it arrived, it was a perfect fit in every way, and because of the different shades of gold (but not 50!!), you really have to look and concentrate to see that it is gold, versus a dark grey, but in different lighting, sometimes a dark gold.  In other words, I'm not embarrassed to use it and it does not give off a gold-sparkle bling effect at all.  My manhood is secured.

I have used 2 different Speck cases for various phones and an iPod Touch, too, no complaints.  This is another 5-star case for the iPad Mini 2 (and should presumably fit a Mini 3).The typing mode allows you to type even with heavy hands and then the viewing angles are nice, too - this is all for Landscape mode.  You could get away with Portrait mode, but no tilt or type for Portrait.Additionally, I like the clasp - no buttons or snaps, just friction clasps in place.  Good all around case!

I don't give a lot of 5 star book reviews, but this book by a former employee is well executed.It starts from the very beginning of the Alibaba Apartment and describes how it has transformed into the world's largest e-commerce conglomerate that most Westerners have never heard of.This book sparked my interest based on the recent IPO in the US on a company I knew nothing about.  The book is a very fast read even though it is 230 or so pages.  I learned a lot about the story, the Alibaba ecosystem that consists of AliPay, Taobao, Yahoo China, Alibaba.com and a few more entities.  I appreciated learning of the struggle of Jack Ma, a former teacher, and founder of Alibaba Global and how he transformed his company.The story of how they were the David to the Goliath of EBay China was fascinating, as well as the not so rosy story of Yahoo China and dipping their hands in the Search business.From 1999 to 2014, they wanted to take care of business first before taking on a U.S. IPO, though they could have tried 10 years ago and ended up with a potentially different business than what they are today.  I found it amazing their transaction volume exceeds both EBay and Amazon combined!  That really helps you understand their size.Overall, a great, enjoyable, informative book that has a perfect title.  And yes, I will now buy some BABA stock!

I rarely give 5stars on toys, but this one is quite entertaining for our 18 month old.  He really does laugh at the antics of the clown car on the spinning race track.  It is actually a hoot to watch.  Now the learning part, well those buttons are there for numbers, colors and shapes, but he is more mesmerized by the crazy car.  Our 3 year old also likes to play with this and make other toys spin around.  I like the fact there are 3 levels of learning, but those buttons are rarely pressed.
No complaints here, tasty, resealable bag, not over-bearing in salt.Would definitely purchase this on my own!

Great for the imagination, *probably* okay if you have <3 year olds around, too!We have a 3 year old (the minimum age range) and an 18-month old who puts everything in his mouth.  This is a great play set with a lot of learning opportunities like:What animal is this?How many blocks?What color is this?What sound does a <animal> make?The pig is hungry, where is his food?  (There are large, long, pieces for a food trough and water)To building and being creative, etc. for our 3 year old.The smallest pieces are large enough that we are not overly worried if our 18-month old grabs them if we turn our heads for a second, but I wouldn't allow this without adult supervision in the presence of <3 years old.  Do NOTE this is our experience for OUR 18-month old, your little one might be bigger framed and might be able to easily swallow a piece, just want to make that clear!I give this 4 stars overall, because, brand new out of the package, I did notice a few small chips in the paint in the edge of the blocks that did flake away with my thumbnail.  I have not noticed additional peeling or flaking (even by trying with my fingernail) since then.  I don't recall if it stated what TYPE of paint was used and I'd only be concerned if it easily peeled or flaked off.  Again, exposure is limited with adult supervision.

This is a reasonable peace of mind device if you don't already have an All-House-Security System in place or you don't know the pin#.We are using this on a newly-installed (never existed before) attic-access swing-door.  Though we have a deadbolt and a locking handle, we don't want to chance our little ones getting into the attic.Now that I think about it - these items would be GREAT if you are in an apartment!  You likely don't have window alarms.  Depending on how the window is broken, there's a fairly high chance this alarm would alert you or others nearby and scare off intruders.  (I DO see the possibility that the window is somehow-broken such that the sensors are still in contact, but still, the intruder would not be able to unlock and open the window without triggering the alarm.  (Unless you have such a gigantic window they could fit through without opening)All in all, nice peace of mind, if not, extra peace of mind with an existing alarm system.

Warning: this 7 piece set is a bit misleading!You really get 6 actual double-ended bits (12 bit ends total) and a magnetic screw-holder, but it actually gets worse than that.There are FOUR of the #2 Phillips bit out of the 12 total!Then, there are THREE of the #2 hex and THREE of the T25 torx.Then you get one T20 torx and one 8-10 flat head.So really you get 5 varieties of bits out of 12; the rest are just duplicates.  I just find that completely strange!  If I want a 7-piece bit set (double-ended), I expect a lot of variety.  Basically you get just one Phillips bit and one Flathead to choose from.My disclaimer is that I received this product free through Amazon Vine, but if I had purchased this without zooming in closely on the package details or counting the bit-variety, I'd be a little upset with a wasted purchase.  I've purchased plenty of multi-bit sets over the years and I don't recall a combination of bits as ridiculous as this.  Who really needs 3 of the #2 hex or three of the T25 torx in the SAME set ?  What does that say about the perceived quality of the bits (having to duplicate them).So far usage has been reasonable, but I'm just an average consumer, nothing heavy duty; so far it has been face plates, kitchen cabinets, hinges, but those are all very low torque demands.

Update: 1-8-2015 - my original review was 1 Star.  I have now raised it to 2 Stars since the vendor responded to my feedback and gave me a 40% refund, which puts it in line with the price of other 300-350 lumen LED bulbs.  I have other fixtures where I can use these bulbs, where 300-400 lumens would be acceptable.---------------------Original review is here:Does NOT produce the 830 lumens as advertised.  Tried this over a 530lumen KX-2000 Xenon bulb and night and day difference (pun intended).I specifically sought this one out since it said 9W and that's fairly high for any candelabra LED bulb I've researched and with a published rating of 830lumens it seems to back up the wattage.So if my 530lumen Xenon candelabra bulb is the benchmark, then THIS KingSo bulb is probably 300-400 lumens tops.

Fun toy, with its own folding, self-storage!This is an excellent age-appropriate toy for learning to use "Legos" err, these "mega bloks".As parents, we like the fact that it is self-containing storage with its own "lid"  (The platform becomes the lid and the bloks can be stored underneath).  The height adjustability is nice, even though we keep the legs folded out, but our infant son could use this as a platform with the legs folded in.  Also the fold-away legs helps so you can store/stack it easier when cleaning up the toy room.  We wish more toys were like this to keep all of the pieces together.We also have a separately-purchased big bag of the same Mega Bloks brand that does work with this, too - just so you know.We will be a Mega Bloks family for a few more years until the kids are older, but we are comfortable with our little girl using this and not having to worry about our infant son getting his hands on these large mega bloks and large pieces since they would be very, very difficult to easily choke on due to the large size of everything contained in this toy (and with proper supervision of course).  Also our infant son can and will climb on top of this with the legs out, but it is still low enough that it is not as much of a concern in our carpeted toy room.  (Also it is low enough to show him how to climb off without falling)

This is a fun way to "spot the match" for all of the little girls world-wide that love the movie, Frozen.I will even admit that Daddy takes a few seconds to "spot the match" as you have to process a lot of items to find the matching one!I think the Age Range of 3years+ is very accurate and would not recommend for kids under 3 due to the concepts needed (ie. cognitive ability to determine and remember what is missing or rather, what is or is not similar across 8 different objects)The various games (err, different ways to play) do help with learning the alphabet, identifying specific objects, searching for objects, name recognition, and a multitude of other fun activities.Our own learning games:=====================For example, we make up a game like, find us 6 Olafs and the kids frantically search to be the first one.  As a bonus, you can try to make a princess castle out of the round cards, too, which teaches them to be calm and delicate!

This book chronicles the 'transformation' of the author, Guy Spier, as he progresses from his first job out of school to the pinnacle value investor.  He shares many growth stories, from working at a firm with a less than stellar reputation to making mature decisions along the way, including a bid to have lunch with the Oracle of Omaha - the one and only, Warren Buffett.I am left with slightly mixed feelings from the value-principle of spending over half-a-million-dollars on a single lunch even with Warren Buffett, versus the value investment of research, reading his memoirs, listening/watching all of Mr. Buffett's speeches, etc.  He could have spent less than 1/10 that and hired a team of interns to provide him every reference of Warren Buffett online or in print in a few weeks.  But on the other hand, one of the central themes of the book is the concepts from that legendary lunch and it is good to have themes to help tell your story.  (Though admittedly, that theme was slightly a bit too heavy throughout the book!)Overall, I had wanted more of the "golden nuggets" distributed through-out the book, versus provided in the ending chapters.  While each chapter builds upon the transformative progression on how *the author* becomes a value investor, the ending chapters do completely switch gears, flow and focus and provides the "golden nuggets" for *YOU* to become a value investor once the transformative story has been told.  I would give 3 stars for the autobiographical story leading up to the end and then 4-stars for the valuable value-investor wisdom shared at the very end.

What we received is more on the beach poncho towel side versus a real bath towel.  The material is not super absorbent terry-cloth thick like a bath towel, rather, really thin like beach towels.You wouldn't use this as a bath towel, but as a beach-robe (poncho) or beach-wrap for when you are done with the beach/pool and are walking back to the car, etc.With those expectations set, this is a 4-star beach poncho towel for our daughter, she REALLY LOVES IT!  She loves to wear this as a costume and play around in it.  It is very cute and fits her great, even though she is on the smaller side for a 2.5 year old.As a costume only, we would probably get more of these in other characters, but as long as you understand it doesn't serve as a "dry me off after a bath" type towel, but as a beach-poncho or play-costume, this is really great!

Worked exactly as described and expected.  We are using it in a very large arch entryway.  Nicer quality than older models from the same company.  Just make sure you also have the Wide Portico Arch Gate to go with this.

I am rating this as a 3-Star - "It's Okay" based on usage from a 12 month old and a 2.5 year old.First, this was easy to assemble and does seem sturdy and I do like that it has a few height adjustment points, including a low setting for a toddler who might be sitting up.  But our daughter is in the 10th percentile for height and this toy is rated for 12-36 month old kids and the tallest adjustment is low for her.  She's roughly a head shorter than most peers her age at daycare.  So the realistic age would be 12-24months for 90% of the kids out there.In terms of usage, it is quite busy.  She likes to belt out the "Let it Go!" song from the Frozen movie soundtrack, but if she wants to play along on the piano while singing, the VTech's built-in songs take over.  If Daddy tries to help out and taps on the drums then a pre-recorded drum tune starts going at the same time the keys are going all while she is singing. :--)I also took 1 star off because I thought she would absolutely love the voice-changer effect like other toys out there that change your voice.  Unfortunately, you can't really hear a difference, no matter the selection, unless you cup the microphone and your mouth and direct your voice in the center of the microphone.  (Ask Daddy how he knows that... ;--)  )  And why can't she hear her voice change (much less my own)?  Because the tallest height adjustment is low even for her in the 10th percentile for height.Now for our 12-month old, whether this product is on the lowest setting or taken off and placed on the floor, it's still a bunch of lights and sounds for him.  So I think 3-stars is pretty fair here, "It's Okay."

I was excited to receive this product because it doesn't have a horizontal brace along the floor that you can trip on, like other brands do.Unfortunately, this particular design is quite flawed:1. I read the instructions multiple times and myself and my wife could not consistently get this gate to lock in place.2. Eventually, I figured out that you should not expand it to fit the area you want to secure by compressing the pressure-mount pins.  You should expand it so that they barely touch the wall and then, you can more easily press the handle to lock the gate in place.3. Though the instructions state "baseboard adjustment pins" are on the bottom, in reality, with every wall I tried this on with baseboards (like to the kitchen) there is not enough "buffer" so that the gate will lock in place.4. I could ONLY securely/consistently lock the gate in place in a smooth doorway (but DUHH, you would just close that door!)5. Fixating and removing this in daily use is a chore; we specifically wanted it for our kitchen, which has 2 arch entryways.  The other entryway has a Northgate Supergate on it already which works great and has a swinging gate.6. Yes, THIS model does have a swing mode - but you are still faced with issues #2 and 3 above.  If you have baseboards, which we do, including at the top of the stairs, then you essentially cannot use this product and lock even a swinging gate in place.7. You could install this product above the baseboards where the smooth wall surface is, but then you need two hands to do such since you need a lot of pressure to lock the handle in place which pushes the "pressure mount pins" out.  (You still lock the handle in place in the Swing-Mode, just the non-swinging side is pressure-fit)8. Unless a lot of homes don't have baseboards, I seriously have no idea how this product was released and how there could be any positive reviews.  If the manufacturer would move the bottom pins a couple inches higher, most of the issues would be resolved, provided you figure out the trick on how to lock the handle in place that the provided instructions are not clear on.

Just returned this to Amazon, glad they were the actual vendor, else another vendor may not take it back.I wrote that it was DEFECTIVE since the description says it is Heavy Duty.  Never got to use it; put it in the dishwasher to get the darn sticker residue off (had already hand-washed it twice), it came out all grey-black and left black residue on your hands.  I DID save it so I could return it.Why did I even get this given the 1-star reviews?  Well...I was ordering a popcorn machine for a party and this scoop came up on the Amazon page as "Other customers ALSO bought this item, buy them together" so although I researched popcorn machines for an hour, I thought a simple metal scoop was a no-brainer and only bought the scoop because it was an Amazon suggestion.  I should've clicked further and seen the 1-star reviews.Regardless of reading the reviews, there should be a disclaimer or sticker stating it is not dishwasher safe.  (Even still, I don't think it would survive too many hand-washings with your typical dish/scour sponge, even the no-scratch variety).This is NOT heavy duty.  I guess there's simply no replacement for stainless-steel or pure aluminum.  This is CAST-aluminum.

I can only compare this to an Epson Artisan 837 wireless printer thus far.Some notable differences over the Epson Artisan 837:==========================================1. This WorkForce Pro WF-4640 is considerably louder in operation.  (Maybe 2-3x louder?)2. The touch screen unfortunately does NOT pivot like in the Artisan.  This is a feature you don't realize you need until you've used it.  Depending on where you put the printer, having a touch screen window that pivots makes a big difference in ease of use and visibility.3. The WorkForce Pro (WFP) is definitely more business-like and higher capacity, as it is more than twice as tall, and holds probably quadruple the paper that the Artisan holds.4. The WFP is a matte black and doesn't show fingerprints whereas the Artisan is a glossy black that shows everything.5. The WFP has 4 extra-large capacity color cartridges, whereas the Artisan has 6 "deck of cards sized" cartridges.  I can only imagine that something that has 6 colors would produce more accurate color prints than something that has to mix 4 colors, BUT THE WFP WINS HANDS DOWN.  I did have to run the Print Head Alignment tests on the WFP 3 times, but once I did, there were no more overlaps and the color out is superior to that of the Artisan 837.  Without color correction, both print outs did look similar with a bluish hue, but with the built-in color correction, the WFP more closely matched what was seen on my monitor and was quite vibrant.  The Artisan, even in non-high-speed, best-photo mode didn't look as crisp in detail as the WFP even when I used high-speed mode in the WFP.  The WFP won all color print-out tests.6. The WFP has a more commercial-like, full physical keypad, but I've never used the fax function of either printer.  The Artisan has a touch-keypad.  The WFP touchpad has a nice tone as you are pressing the buttons, but seems to require just a bit more effort than the touchpad on the Artisan.7. The speed difference is pretty amazing however.  The WFP is probably 10x faster in print speed than the Artisan, yet still produces more vibrant/crisp print outs even in high speed mode.8. Setting up the WIFI on the WFP was a little easier on the WFP than the Artisan.9. Color copying was incredible on the WFP.  First, out of the box, and just pressing COPY, there's no comparison, the WFP was super high quality and incredibly fast and superior.  The Artisan is a good bit slower and still retains a bluish/smudgey printout.  I'm not aware of any other color settings than can be done on the Artisan for Copying to have improved the output.10. Overall, the WFP is probably 2 feet high and 18" wide.  The Artisan is probably 10" high and 18" wide.  The WFP is considerably taller because it likely holds quadruple the paper.  You could make the WFP about 4" shorter if you took the second paper tray out completely (it stacks on top of it).Compared with the newest model of the "Artisan 800 series", THIS WFP model is about $100 more and in my opinion, worth it for the print quality and time saved from the print speeds alone.  It's not really more bulky, rather, just taller on your desk.I was prepared for the "4-color-cartridges" to be less crisp than "6-color-cartridges" but I was blown away by the quality and 10x faster print speeds.  From print quality to scan/copy quality to incredible speeds that still maintain a higher print quality to more than quadruple paper capacity, this may be a WorkForce Pro for a small business, but still wonderful and relatively inexpensive for any household.  I'd say it rivals even the color laser printers at work in quality and speed that I've seen!

Thankfully this was a product that Amazon Vine provided for review purposes, versus something we purchased or a friend may have purchased for us, else I'd feel terribly bad with a 2-star product.My main comparison is to a Baby Jogger City Mini GT with the never-flat all-terrain wheels.We've used the BOB Duallie Stroller on a number of outdoor walks and outdoor festivals and fair events.  In our last trip to SeaWorld, we purposely chose to leave this at home and instead, bring our single City Mini and City Mini GT and push around 2 strollers instead of this one.Why would I give this 2-stars?========================1. For the first outdoor festival, I never remembered to check the air in the tires and simply lugged it through the house and into the car.  When the pneumatic tires are underinflated, it's a pain to push around.  Our Baby Jogger City Mini GT has never-flat gel-filled all terrain tires that never need air, not sure why the BOB couldn't either.2. Part of the reason in choosing to NOT bring the BOB duallie stroller on a distant road trip to SeaWorld is because we'd have to pack a bicycle pump to ensure we wouldn't be stranded with under-inflated tires all day.  Sure there are travel sized pumps the size of a 6" Subway sandwich, but one less thing to pack and worry about is still one less thing to pack and worry about.3.
