They store solar power throughout the day, and shine bright at night! My husband and I received a complimentary set, to test and review. We absolutely love the curb appeal that these have brough too!

I love the idea of these lights... I envision them hanging from large, wispy, tree branches. Of course, in my minds eye, the breeze is making them sway & they look like beautiful custom lighting. I'm sure they could look like this. However, I have been unsuccessful in obtaining this look.They're really neat lights, and they're solar powered, so you won't have to worry about wiring them. They come preset for hanging, and even include hooks to hang them from. Unfortunately, my trees aren't quite the right style to pull off lighting like this. Plus, the cord that they hang from, doesn't hold them straight. Because I'm anal retentive about everything, they're not the right product for me.I received a complimentary set to test and review, and I do recommend them. If you have big trees, or even medium/ tall shepards hooks to hang them from, they would look amazing!

These are a larger version of a similar set of wall lights, by Frostfire. Because of their large size, I recommend mounting these on either side of your garage door. They require little maintainence, and are pretty easy to install. Plus, they're wireless! No electricity bills to run these... they're solar powered!For solar lights, they're quite bright. The solar charge also lasts a long while. As long as they have access to some sunshine, you really wont need to worry about maintaining them for quite some time. I live in southern FL, and for the past few months, have been testing these lights out. They were sent to me complimentary, to review. So, I wanted to really test them out before giving my honest opinion. So far, I've not had any issues with them, and they look great beside my garage door. You could also put them on either side of a back patio, or a front door. Providing you have a large entryway, and a large door --- It would look quite nice there as well!

This mouse is lightweight, and perfectly suited for laptops and tablets. You can also use it on desktops PCs, but it's a basic model mouse. No frills, although it is wireless. I use it most often with my laptop. I find that it works well on the go, much better than a wired mouse, or the standard mouse pad on a laptop.I received this mouse complimentary, for testing and review purposes. I truly appreciate the smaller size, and lightweight feel of this mouse. It's easy for me to use, and doesn't weigh me down when I travel --- every ounce matters!

I've struggled to find a half decent sprayer for my garden hose. Every time in thought I'd found one that was worth while, it would fail. They all broke or leaked, or completely stopped working.I ordered this sprayer with no expectations, only hoping that it was at least one step closer to finding something that actually worked. My first impression when it arrived, was that it was exceptionally well made. However, it's quite a bitheavier than any of the other sprayers I've used. It also happens to be the best sprayer ive ever had! Ive had it about a month, and ita not broken... and it doesnt leak. It does offer different spray functions, so I can use it on my garden, deck, and yard. So far, the only draw back is the weight.I received this sprayer complimentary, to test and review. I was quite skeptical at first, but I've grown to really enjoy using it. It may be heavy and a bit cumbersome at times, but it's the only one that hasn't let me down!

If you love instant cappuccino, or cocoa, you'll love this frother! Its lightweight, and small enough to easily manage. Plus, it doesn't take any special batteries, so you won't have to spend a ton of money to replace them.To use it, just put your mix and liquid Into a cup, and insert the wire portion of the frother. Turn it on, and it will mix up the drink in just a few moments. Its a lot easier than stirrim by hand, and does a much better job on lumps too!I received this item complimentary, to test and review. I absolutely love having it, as its made it so much easier to mix breakfast shakes (protein drinks), and it works wonders on foam for specialty coffees!

I LOVE this headset! I'm really into gaming online. I usually play World of Warcraft, and a few others. A good headset is imperative, as a lot of the games require cooperation with other players. In order to make things work, we need to be able to communicate. This headset fits comfortably, and is quite easy to use. It even has awesome sound, which is a huge bonus--- Who doesn't like to listen to their games in surround sound, stereo quality?!?I received this headset complimentary, to test and review. I'm beyond impressed with the sound quality, and absolutely love the ease of use & comfortable fit as well. I definitely recommend this headset,  It's well suited for any online gamer!

This scale is pretty awesome!I work for a major airline, and I've  compared  this scale to our airport scales. It's pretty darn accurate, and it's super portable. It's lightweight, and is easy to pack and take along on trips. This helps immensely, because you're able to weigh your luggage before you get to the airport and have to pay an overweight baggage fee!The best part is that it includes batteries! Most items always say "batteries not included ", but this comes ready to use! It has a large, back lit, digital display that's easy to read. Because it's always accurate, and easy to read, it's a must have for anyone who travels often!I received this scale complimentary, to test and review. I really like how accurate it is, and also how easy it is to use & read. Plus, I never have overweight bag fees anymore!

This is a pretty cool phone case. It allows you to see the time / date portion of your display --- This means you don't have to open your phone case and fool with buttons to see the time. Just push the power button and co the time & date through the open display window.It also has built in function buttons.  These correspond with your phones buttons, and so you to access your phones features without removing the case. It's quite handy, and works well. Unless of course you're like me, and use your phone as a laptop... It's not really the right case for me, but it is quite nice!I received this product complimentary, to test and review. It may not be the right case for me, but it's definitely worth checking out...  Especially if you're not as heavily dependant on your phone, as I am.

This pillow is a must-have for anyone who travels! I work in the airline industry, and I've tried just about every travel comfort and sleep product out there... So far, this is my favorite, hands down! Its ridiculously comfortable, and can easily be used in many ways. Plus, it's easy to clean! Most travel pillows are not washable, and at nearly impossible to clean.This is actually a pouch filled with microbeads. It's housed in a removable sleeve, and has adjustable straps with clips on each end. The sleeve is machine washable, and so far has held up well. The straps can be used to hold the pillow firmly in place, or to attach it to rolling luggage while walking.Whats really neat about this pillow, I that it's not just for your head! The straps are long enough to be fastened around your waist too!  This provides excellent lumbar support while sitting in uncomfortable airplane seats... I've even used this pillow under my legs while traveling. Hard seats do a number on my thighs, and this helps to relieve the pressure while sitting. Because its so soft and moldable, you can really use it anyway you want. Want to take a nap, but it's too bright? Put it over your eyes! It's super light weight, and ridiculously convenient.I received this product as a complimentary  promotional item, for testing and review purposes. It's become a staple item on all of my travels. In fact, after trips, I clean it and keep it in my car. I like to keep it handy, as I'd hate to travel without it!!!!!

I love this pack! It's definitely a must have here in southern FL. Our daily temperatures are around 90 degrees, and any outdoor activities require lots of extra water intake. This pack has been a blessing on bike trips, beach days, and even long nature walks.It holds a good deal of liquid, and stays relatively cool. The pack itself is a nice, breathable material, and is quite lightweight. As an added bonus, the water keeps my back cool! It's easy to use, and relatively easy to clean too. The hydration bladder is removable, so you can use the pack by itself or with the water pouch. The hydration bladder is durable, and has a hose that clips to the bag. This is for easy use while in motion. You just put the hose to your mouth, and sip. It acts as a straw!I received this product complimentary, to test and review. It's been an awesome addition to my daily outings, and I've gotten quite a few compliments on it too!

This is a really neat thermometer. It's completely external, and uses infrared technology to determine temperatures. You just point it at the person/ object/ room and press the button, and within a few seconds you have an accurate temperature reading!Yes...  I mentioned people, objects, and rooms... This thermometer has a setting for all of the above! You push the function button, and select what you need a temperature reading for. Example: body temperature, or room temperature. It works well for food, and even has a high temperature alert! This feature is helpful for body temperatures as well, and will let you know when a temperature is too high or too low.The temperature is displayed on an easy to ready, digital display. My mom has bad eyesight, and can read this thermometer without issue. It's a little bulky, but still portable. In fact, we take ours on trips with us. It's been a real lifesaver when the kids get sick on vacation!I received this item complimentary, to test and review. So far, it's the nicest and most accurate thermometer that I've owned. I highly recommend it, and think it would make an excellent gift as well!

I'm  a HUGE fan of frameless candles. I have quite a few, in varying sizes and colors, and I've decided that I really like these the best. It's hard to find flameless votives that look real. White candles are nice, but the "flame" doesn't look authentic. These Kohree flameless votives are the next best thing. The coloring is perfect, and they look beautiful anywhere you use them. I do wish they were wax vs plastic.  However, they still look great, and I've thoroughly enjoyed them. Plus, I like knowing that if my children somehow get to them, they won't get burned!I received a complimentary set of these candles, for testing and review purposes. Personally, i absolutely love them, and highly recommend them. They work well with flameless pillars and tealights, especially if theyre also a cream/ yellow color as well!

I came across this book on Pinterest and was intrigued.  Well worth the tiny price - it reminded me of a Matrix type read.It is a very short read but the author packed a lot of detail in it and I felt it was well worth the 99 cents to read it.  Even though it was a short read, it was a cool story with plenty of action and a good ending.If you like sci fi, I think you'll like this cool read.  Definitely recommend and hope to see more by this author.

As a retired teacher, I'm on a budget.  My daughter and granddaughter are also on budgets. Each of us have a different set of circumstances, spending habits and income. Some of our budgets work better than others.With the economy the way it is, the roller coaster ride we have all been on has affected our spending and saving habits.I came across this book and liked it from the first page.  It is easy to follow and can be used no matter what age, income or spending habits. Sometimes looking at finances can be a gut wrenching feeling, especially when you see there is more going out than coming in or as many say, you have more month than you have income. Sometimes your situation changes - the addition of a baby or pet, an illness, a layoff or a promotion and the end of a credit card bill - so now what?  This book walks you through the now what? and also helps you plan in a smart way for a stress free financial future.  Highly recommend.

This is a wonderful short read for both adults and kids.  Dog lovers of all ages will enjoy this cute tale - pun intended.I bought this book as a quick read while waiting in the doctor's office and knew my granddaughter would also enjoy it.As a retired teacher, this is a book I would have loved to have had in my classroom.Highly recommend.

My granddaughter is newly reading chapter books and we spend a lot of time looking for the right reading gradient as well as a story that she finds interesting. When I came across this book I was intrigued as, like most of us, I recalled the classic story of Pinocchio.As a retired teacher, Pinocchio was one of the long time favorites in my classroom library. My granddaughter's interest was piqued enough by the idea of a story about Pinocchio's son that we decided to purchase this book.It is evident that much time and thought was put into the story.  The reading gradient is good and children have an interesting story that pulls them easily into reading time.As a grandparent and a retired teacher, I highly recommend this book

Yesterday was Grandparent's Day at my granddaughter's school. Our normal tradition is that we then purchase books at the school book fair.  This year, she asked if she could have a book from Kindle and do one less from the book fair.  I am a retired school teacher and it makes me happy when kids not only want to read but find favorite series.The book she wanted was this one by Christopher Craft.  We follow Alex on a madcap and wacky adventure in this fun read and are eagerly awaiting the next book to continue the story.  Kudos to the author on another fun read.

I bought this book as an after school surprise for my granddaughter.  My grandson, who is two, was just as entertained as my granddaughter was with the story.  The author delivers a well written story that has just the right gradient for young readers to learn a lesson while also enjoying a fun read.The illustrations are first rate throughout and complemented the book perfectly.I'd like to see more stories about our main character, Nancy, in the future.Great read that will definitely be a re-read.  Highly recommend.

The play on words and then the idea of this diet intrigued me enough that I bought this book. With the holiday season fast approaching, weight gain is always a given.  This year I wanted to be a step ahead and have a plan in place instead of fretting over weight gain.This book is well written, factual and contains diet advice that I have not read elsewhere.I am going to start this diet plan tomorrow and have high hopes for success.

As a retired teacher I remember the trepidation that many children had when it came to learning about prefixes and suffixes.  I would have loved to have had this book in my classroom.I purchased this book as I often browse Amazon looking for books that my grandkids will enjoy - from a reading for pleasure standpoint and a learning standpoint.  The author takes the mystery and scariness out of prefixes and suffixes.The illustrations are great as are the examples.I highly recommend this book.

As a retired teacher, I remember how much students enjoyed learning about homophones. Homophones are words that may sound alike but have different meanings such as blew and blue.My daughter has instructed ESL - English Second Language - which is another area that many people do not think about when it comes to homophones.  Learning about homophones isn't just for kids, adults learning ESL will benefit from this book also as it is an easy and fun read.It is important, regardless of one's age, to have a good grasp of the English language and not be "tricked" by words that sound alike but mean something different.I purchased this book for my grandkids so we could learn about homophones.  It was a fun weekend activity and this book made learning fun.  It is nicely illustrated and a good gradient when learning and understanding homophones.I was very pleased with this book and definitely recommend it.

If you are a parent - seriously consider purchasing this book for your child.  As a retired teacher, I strive to encourage children, including my grandchildren, to read.  So many kids are glued to electronic devices that are not developing skills such as reading and problem solving that they will need in life.  The author tapped into the secret of getting kids to beg to read and I am so glad that I came across his books.The saga continues in this book, the people who live in the village are not out of danger yet.  The zombie children progress further into the mission and mystery.  There is just the right amount of action to keep kids glued to a book - and reading.My grandkids love these books and I love buying them - keep on writing Mr. Craft!  Highly recommend.

The Maze Runner books came highly recommended to me.  After wading through the first one, I bought this summary and analysis to use with book 2.  Huge difference in my reading speed and comprehension with the help of this book.If you haven't tried summary and analysis books yet, I do urge you to try this one as you read The Scorch Trials.  I think you'll find it to be a very beneficial tool.

I bought this book to read aloud to my two grandchildren ages 2 and 7.  I liked the overall story as it centers around two friend and their adventures.  The author crafts a story that kept even a rambunctious two year old still while we read aloud.As  a retired teacher, I recommend this book as the story and illustrations are good.  The sentence structure is good and gives young readers an easy to read story that holds their interest.

I bought this book to read with my two grandchildren ages 2 and 7. This book makes the perfect bedtime story and, as a retired teacher, it is a book that I would have loved to have had in my classroom too.We have a lot of squirrels in our neighborhood so it was fun to imagine that one may be the Sammy that was in this story.Vet well written story with lovely illustrations.I definitely recommend buying and also buying a copy for your child's school library or classroom.  I am sure teachers would love having this book available to share with students.

As someone who loves sci-fi genre, I'm a bit embarrassed to admit that this is the first book by this author that I've read as I have been missing out on a real find. This is book one in the series.  The cover and title caught my attention and I downloaded it for something to read over the long holiday weekend.Mr. Sartison sets the stage nicely in the beginning and takes us into the future – 2177.  Technology has greatly advanced and drones, pirates and aliens are part of one’s daily vocabulary. Our main character Steve spends his days protecting others from alien invasion.No spoilers here, but the end leaves you wanting to know more.  Fortunately, the author includes a link that takes you on to the next part of the story.If you love sci-fi, this author should be on your must read list.  If you have been thinking about reading the sci-fi genre, I think this book is one that will hook you on sci-fi.Well written with lots of details.

I bought this book for my granddaughter.  She is almost eight and when I read the book description, I knew she would love it.  I started skimming it when I downloaded it for her and ended up reading it myself.As a retired teacher and as a grandparent, I was more than pleased with the story.  The author mixes the right amount of magic and being a kid into a quality read. I'm a huge fan of the Percy Jackson stories and as with that series, I see a solid story line that kids will enjoy reading and will follow.In this day and age, with so many children not voluntarily reading as they did before, when you find a gem like this book, it stands out.Definitely recommend and suggest buying a second copy for your child's classroom library.  I'm sure teachers would be pleased to have this author's books in the classroom.

I bought this book for my granddaughter.  She is seven and I am always looking for quality books that inspire her to read more.As a retired teacher, I really wish this book would have been available when I was teaching.  It is the perfect book to encourage children to read and learn while making the process fun.Science and weather are sometimes daunting topics to children and adults.  The author created an organized read filled with a lot of quality images.  It is definitely a step above many of the other books that I have chosen for my granddaughter.I definitely recommend this book and I suggest you go one step more and buy a second copy.  This book would be a welcome addition in any classroom library and your child's teacher will be pleased to have it on their classroom bookshelf.

I remember reading To Kill a Mockingbird many years ago.  When the news of another, call it hidden if you will, book by the same author surfaced, I was more than intrigued.  I read Go Set a Watchman and probably like many others, the book made me curious.  Why was it never released until now?  It was written before To Kill a Mockingbird so was it the inspiration for that book?This after read edition was the perfect companion as the author has the same thoughts as I had regarding the two books.I liked this after read as it gave me plenty of food for thought to discuss later with friends who also read Go Set a Watchman.  This book is a must have for anyone who reads Go Set a Watchman, especially if you are reading it in a book club.Very well organized and well written.  I definitely recommend it.

As a retired teacher and grandparent, it is important to me that children enjoy reading. My granddaughter enjoys the Minecraft books by Christopher Craft and we have been waiting for this one to be released. My granddaughter gives it a thumbs up for a great story.  Jon the pig and Bernard the Iron Golem are back together in this story and they end up having to figure out a way to save a village in this fast paced and fun read.I also am giving this book a thumbs up as when I see a child engrossed in a book and eager for the next book to be released, I know we have found a winner.So with this being said - two thumbs up.  Great read - surprise your child or grandchild with this book, I think you'll make their day.

As a retired teacher, I know firsthand it is sometimes difficult to entice children to read as in many cases reading is associated with homework.  I  came across this author as my granddaughter loves his books and now I see why.What a brilliant idea to combine video games and reading. This book was a fast paced read and my granddaughter liked it a lot.  Do your child's teacher a favorite and purchase this book, or better yet, a few of these books for your child's classroom library.Highly recommend this author.  Great read.

I bought this book to read with my granddaughter.  The authors put together just the right mix of  fun - cute animals, a story with a great twist and history.  You may think history isn't fun but I think adults and kids will enjoy the time travel and the way the authors made history come to life. When you take two adorable pets, a dog and a cat, and add in the journey of a lifetime , you end up with a truly special book.  As a grandparent I really enjoyed being able to share this book with my granddaughter.  As a retired teacher this would have been a book that I would have loved to have had in my classroom library as it teaches children about history in a very fun manner.  Highly recommend this one.

The author has a knack for taking a rather sensitive topic and using it to teach children a lesson with a good moral to the story.  In this book, our main character, William, has a penchant for passing gas in all the wrong places.  As a retired teacher, I've crossed path with a  William or two over the years.  While other children suffer due to his actions, William finds the whole matter hilarious until one day....................This matter of fact read shows children why one should practice good manners when it comes to passing gas.This is a rather cheeky read but I have to say, William is a rather likable character despite his offensive behavior.  He also quickly learns his lesson when the tables are turned.

I downloaded this book as I was looking for a shorter read on a quiet Friday night. I don't think the full impact of the story or the author's writing ability really registered until awhile after I finished reading.  This is a fairly fast read but it is rich with detail.  The author has his finger on the pulse of relationships.  Taking us through what may be a somewhat ordinary day in the reconnection of two people, this story while simple is also hauntingly special as it captures that still new relationship feeling, the feeling of not being good enough, of hope and of the future.  I was very pleased with this novella.

I was pleased to find a summary and analysis of Sue Grafton's "X". It is currently the number one bestseller in private investigator mysteries.The original book is one of a very large series centering around the main character Kinsey Millhone. The original book is number 24 in the mystery series.  I was debating upon reading this book and another best seller.  I've found the fastest and smartest way to choose between potential reads is to quite simply read the summary and analysis of each book.I am a fan of summary and analysis books as I've found that they increase my comprehension when I read the actual book and they make me aware in advance of things I may have otherwise missed.  Plus, being blunt, they are a fast way to see if you want to invest a lot of reading time in the actual book.This read was more than useful to me. The author provides a break down in detail of characters, plot analysis, and chapter by chapter recaps. Highly recommend.

Fasten your seatbelt - this is a relentless, heart in your throat read.  Patel portrays the angst of dysfunctional stretched to the breaking point.  The sins of the past haunt the hopes of the present and what a wicked web is woven.This read is not for the faint of heart but it is twisting and surprising all the way through. Solid read from the ultra creepy cover to the white knuckle finish.  No sweet dreams in this tale.

This is a cheeky read but the author also does a very good job in educating children regarding not "holding it" when they need to use the washroom.  As a retired teacher, I had a few Patricks over the years.  Children are of course embarrassed when they have an accident of this type.  The author did a great job in using Patrick as an example, showing info on how the bladder works and having a happy ending to this tale.

As a retired teacher, I have relied upon summary and analysis type books for many years as the implementation of them usually helps considerably when reading a book in a classroom setting as well as for personal reading.I came across the book, A Bridge Apart, and was delighted to see the author had created what he refers to as Literary Turning Points, which is this book.  This book is a companion guide to the actual book.The author provides insight and answers questions regarding the actual book.  I know many people use this type of book after reading the actual book.  I prefer to use it beforehand as I find it helps with comprehension and I notice content that I may have missed otherwise.This book is well written, informative and easy to use.  Definitely recommend.

I bought this book to read aloud to my two grandchildren ages 2 and 7.  We enjoyed it from start to finish.  This picture book contains excellent illustrations sure to hold the attention of the most wiggly little boy - my grandson included.As a retired teacher and a grandparent  I definitely recommend this book.  This one is sure to be a repeat read.

The cover of this book caught my attention and while it is marketed as a YA read, adults will enjoy it just as much.  This is book one in a series - it centers around our main character, Lucas. He is your average kid living an average life until......... he finds himself in a totally different world and his task is certainly not an easy to do, quick fix - he is being counted on to save a group of people - no small feat.This is a great read with plenty of action.  As a retired teacher, this is a book I recommend as it brings a story that will interest kids to read - no small feat in this age of technology.  Definitely recommend.

I bought this book to read aloud with my two grandchildren ages 2 and 7.This is the perfect length with truly lovely illustrations. We follow a child through the story as he asks questions about God.Easy to read and perfect for children, this book is a great anytime read for children.The colorful illustrations really complemented the story perfectly and the author crafted a perfect story to read to children who may wonder - where is God?I was highly pleased with the book and I know we will be rereading it more than once.  A plus rating from this retired teacher and grandma.

I read The Paris Wife, so when a new book came out by Paula McLain, I was interested in it.Circling the Sun is considered historical fiction - and I am a huge history buff.I recently started using summary and analysis books as they help increase my reading speed of the book that they are a summary and analysis of.  I also have found my reading comprehension is considerably better when I utilize a summary and analysis beforehand. Sometimes I go back to the summary and analysis while reading the book. I am a fast reader but sometimes I would find myself going back and re-reading or feeling like I didn't quite understand a section in a book, now I feel my reading is much smoother.The author of this summary and analysis created a great read that was organized and also pointed out things that I know I would have flown right past when reading. I'm looking forward to reading Circling the Sun.

I am a fan of short stories as they are ideal when traveling or waiting at the doctor's office.This set of stories took me on a different path as they are short stories with an Asian theme.  The author writes in a way that gives one plenty of details and  a lot of bang for the buck.  With an imagination that seems boundless, the author transports the reader from situation to situation in each unique story. Each story is rich in vivid characters and written with solid imagination, the author drew me in on the first page.  I won't say I had a favorite story as that would be like saying one of my children is my favorite.These stories will stay with you afterwards.  Definitely recommend.

The title and cover of this book caught my attention.  The story is a solid read and the attention to detail - even the smallest detail - is what makes this book stand out.I had to laugh more than a few times since, as a retired school teacher, I noticed the author has teenagers pegged exactly in this book. In the beginning when Grace is tugging up her skirt to get to the shortest allowed length - you have no idea how many times I saw that in my classroom over the years - that action alone in the story showed me the great attention to detail.I think it is more important than ever to have books available for our youth to read that are truly interesting.  While I know vampires have been ever so popular with kids - finding a story that focuses on a coming of age story blended really well with a dystopian theme was a delightful find.  While the book is presented as a YA story, I think adults will also enjoy this story.

I read the author’s other book, Flight of the Tarantula Hawk, a summer or so ago as the title caught my interest.  I then went backwards to read his first book.  I read this book because now the author himself has caught my attention with his solid writing ability and I wanted to see what Lance was now getting himself into.What I think I liked the best is how much our main character has grown, and I don’t mean age wise, since the first book. In this story, we know Lance will be called in to help on a case but we also find Lance getting himself into quite the predicament along the way.  This adds a good additional layer to the story.There are the necessary details smoothly peppered in throughout this story and the author has a way of showing the reader what is going on behind the scenes many times while setting the stage for events further along in the story.Put this one on your reading list – I think you’ll thank me later.

I bought this book because I saw it was based on a true story.  I was looking for a book that would be a good read but not too long as I wanted something to read while I was waiting at my doctor's office.  The nurse had to call me twice lol as I was so engrossed that I didn't hear my name called.She and my doctor both wanted to know more about this book.  The author writes really well and draws you into the situations with him. He addresses the subject of voodoo and the cultural part of voodoo also.  The story is about a contractor and his interaction with someone who professed to practice voodoo.I see now that the author has more than one book and I definitely will be following his writing.  This is a really good story and worth every single one of five stars.

I bought this book for two reasons - the first reason being I have read other books by this author over the years and have seen his investigative nature which I liked.The second reason being that I have heard about bitcoins numerous times from my grandchildren, especially my grandson, and was clueless as to what exactly this bitcoin was and how one used it.So when I saw the author had written an investigative book on bit coins based on his opinion - I felt it was worth reading.While I see a mix of people saying yay to this book and people saying nay, as a retired school teacher, I keep in mind that one is entitled to his or her own opinions. I personally had no opinion before reading this book as I had no information other than hearing the word bitcoin several times recently.  I'm not sure if I am spelling the word bitcoin correctly as Amazon keeps marking it as a misspelled word.Mr. Robinson is slanted towards those not in favor of bit coins.  He walks the reader through his reasoning and I think he provides good documentation for his logic.Maybe some people disagree and maybe some people agree with his findings.  This appears to be a volatile topic with strong feelings by both the yays and the nays.  In my case, it as given me some interesting food for thought and I will certainly be sharing this book with my grandson to find out his opinion.

I bought this book to have on my Kindle for one of my granddaughters.  As a retired teacher, I remember countless times when children would ask me how things were in the "good ol' days" before the rush-rush world that we live in now.  When I saw this book, I thought perhaps my granddaughter would like a glimpse of the past too.The author transports the reader back to the late 1950's - before the Internet, before mobile phones - some people were actually glad to even have the luxury of a regular phone, usually with a party line and when life was a bit simpler.  Yet we find that teens still had some of the same problems that they do now - wondering if a boy or girl likes them, trying to fit in and wondering what the future will bring.This is a well written story.  The author takes us back in time to life on a farm in the late 50s but yet we also see some situations when growing up are timeless occurrences be it 1956 or 2015.From a teacher's viewpoint, this would be a great book to have in a classroom library.  From a grandparent's viewpoint, this is a book I feel comfortable sharing with my granddaughter.

As a retired teacher, I know firsthand that there  are subjects that are often taboo or passed over in a classroom. Children often talk amongst themselves and other children are singled out or avoided. I also have seen firsthand children who have been in the middle of family battles, courtroom matters and incarceration matters.  In the majority of these situations, the child or children is confused, frightened and in many cases will blame him or herself.This is a wonderful book for children who have family members who are incarcerated.I highly recommend this book

I really feel as though I have hit the jackpot with this book series.  My granddaughter wanted to move into reading chapter books and we had a few hit and miss experiences.  I wanted to find a series that she could enjoy so we would have a continuing theme.The stories regarding the two princess sisters are well written and result in a lot of after reading commentaries about the stories from my granddaughter.As my granddaughter loves princess stories and is quite the ballerina the combination of both in this book was perfect.  I'd like to thank the author as she has helped build a little girl's self confidence in reading chapter books.

I bought this book for my granddaughter over the holiday weekend.  I have told my share of made up stories about princesses for years - first with my daughter and now my granddaughter.  As a retired school teacher, I have seen the importance of cultivating a love of reading in children as early as possible.  With this being said, I focused on Ms. Right's series as the reviews are excellent and it is a continuation of books.My granddaughter loved this book.  It was the perfect gradient for a 7 year old.  The illustrations are wonderful too.In this book, the princess sisters discover a mystery tunnel and begin yet another adventure. Kudos to the author for creating such a wonderful book and series.

I am planning on taking my granddaughter to the Art Institute in Chicago later this month.  She is in second grade and I wanted a book to use as a pre-trip guide for her.  As a retired school teacher, this is a book that I would have loved to have had in my classroom.  It is easy to use and the author did a great job organizing the material.I can use this book as a guide for my granddaughter to prepare her for our excursion and also have a great reference book that I can enjoy afterwards.  I'm very pleased with this purchase.

I bought this book for my granddaughter.  She recently started reading chapter books and I liked the idea of this book having several shorter books revolving around the two main characters.  As a retired schoolteacher, this is a book that I would have definitely had in my classroom library.  My granddaughter highly enjoyed the stories and I was pleased with the caliber of the writing.  The author has her finger on the pulse of what children in today's world enjoy to read and I feel she has created a great book.

My daughter is hosting a Summer sleepover for my granddaughter and a few of her friends.  As a retired school teacher, I was tasked with the project of finding a book for my daughter to read to the girls at bedtime.I chose this book and read it before giving it to my daughter.  I liked it from a teacher's viewpoint and I also liked it from a grandparent's viewpoint.My daughter and the girls loved it.  Several parents asked my daughter for the book title afterwards as the girls wanted their own copies.We follow a delightful girl Melanie into the fairy realm through her dreams.  The book flows nicely and the illustrations add the perfect touch.I will be buying the next book in the series and highly recommend this book.

I bought this book to have for bedtime reading with my two grandchildren. This book was a perfect for as there are actually five stories included and all are ones my grandchildren enjoyed.As a retired teacher, I have strived to instill a love of reading in my children and now grandchildren.  Finding a book like this one made my day.

I bought this book as a surprise for my granddaughter and as a retired teacher I was extremely pleased with the concept.This is a short read, much like a comic book.  It has  illustrations and a puzzle at the end. As a teacher, this book is ideal reading material as it is fun. The short length makes it easy to finish which helps the child who may need a little boost to become interested in reading.  As an extra plus, the puzzle is a clever addition that tests the reader's comprehension.With so many children interested in electronic gadgets, I worry that developing a love of reading may be a fading experience.  Books like this one are perfect for teachers to have in the classroom and for parents/grandparents who want to help their young readers develop a sincere interest in reading.  Very well done with kudos to the authorThe goal is to make the books "finishable", giving reluctant readers a positive reading experience and to test comprehension with the puzzle (without the readers knowing they are learning how to become better readers in the process).

I bought this book for my granddaughter.  I found myself as captivated by the story as she was and the illustrations really made the story come to life.  This was  very enjoyable story. As a retired teacher I would have liked to have had this book available when I was teaching as it makes a great read aloud story and definitely holds your attention.

I came across this book when I was looking online for a book to help a neighbor.  Her son is five and will be starting school this fall.  As a retired school teacher, I have seen firsthand the skill levels of children entering school.  The ones with little preparation beforehand often struggle despite the effort of the teacher to get them up to the speed of the children who enter school prepared.In the case of my neighbor, her son is what I would call unprepared for school.  I was more than pleased when I came across this activity book as it is the ideal book to prepare a child for school while making learning fun.  I definitely would recommend this book.

My granddaughter recently discovered chapter books and I am always looking for new ones to share with her.  This book was an ideal choice for numerous reasons.  She is in second grade - soon to be third grade - and could relate to the girl in the story as they are close in age.  The writing is the perfect gradient for a second, soon to be third grader.  We read together a very cute story about Anisha who just like my granddaughter faces the fun and sometimes scary times that come with moving up a grade.  Excellent story that was fun and also teaches children a valuable lesson.  I liked this story from a grandparent's point of view and also a teacher's point of view as I am a retired teacher.I was pleased with this purchase and definitely recommend this book to others.

I bought this book for my granddaughter based on the reviews.  As I usually do, I skimmed through it before she came over and found a great read.  I ended up reading it from cover to cover and was very pleased with the age appropriate story that was fun to read.  As a retired school teacher this is a book that I would have definitely had in my classroom for my students to borrow.I am looking forward to my granddaughter reading this book and hope she enjoys it as much as I did.  Truly a gifted author.

My granddaughter has recently discovered jokes and I have been looking for a book of jokes geared towards kids.  As a parent, grandparent and retired teacher, I was determined to find a book that was kid friendly and contained "clean" jokes.  Madcap Mulligan really delivers what families want - good clean family and kid friendly jokes.If you are a teacher - this book is one I would highly suggest adding to your classroom library.  If you are a parent, grandparent or someone looking for a great gift for a child - you cannot go wrong with this fun book.

As a retired school teacher, when I read a book to my two grandchildren, I often think about how much my former students would have liked the story.  Hump T-Rex is a rocking and rolling fun read.  My grandson who is, as they say, "all boy"- a mix of being two and always on the go and my granddaughter who is 7 - loved this story.In a nutshell, or in this case an eggshell - we take the classic Humpty Dumpty story and put a big spin on it - big as in dinosaur big.This is a fun, feel good book that kids and adults will love.  It will definitely become a family favorite.A Plus all the way with a great story and really cool illustrations.

What a fun adventure--in a place where everyone does magic and some kids' magic comes out "upside-down"... so there's a "flare" who can start fires but then everything freezes, or a flier who can go up but not come back down, and the main character who can transform herself, but instead of a simple animal becomes a combination (like a dragon-kitten when she is aiming for a simple kitten).The book is fun, adventurous, and easy to relate to. My 10-year-old read through it breathlessly then asked me if there was a sequel. It reads as a complete story, but I'll join her in hoping the author turns the book into a series. Content-wise this is good for any age, but especially for kids who may be approaching ages where friendship dynamics become more complex, since it includes a couple of examples of someone's "friends" who aren't particularly nice, and the idea that perhaps your real friends are those who treat you well.

I think this book may be targeted toward a slightly younger crowd than the previous series. I enjoyed the fast pace (and haven't read the previous novels), but for whatever it's worth my 11-year-old (who read and loved the entire first Spirit Animal series) had this to say: "It goes too quickly. It's like they had too many ideas and not enough space. If they were going to make this many things happen, they should have made the book longer. Four major things happen just in the first 10 pages--that's too many!"Honestly I think a fast pace will appeal to people who may be slower readers, or who may not have expectations set by the first series. But it's worth bearing in mind that the read for this book is slightly different than the others.

This bag appears mostly as displayed--a smooth, flat bag that's 16 3/4" x 3/4" x 12 1/2". (Amazon currently describes it as "16.5 x 1.6 x 13.8 inches" but I just took out a ruler to measure it, and the product I received doesn't match the official numbers.) In the official product image it looks like the edges might be leather, but in person they look feel more like a plastic denim--really not bad, but if you're looking for fancy this isn't it. Most importantly, I'm not convinced this has enough padding for the way I use my laptops. It feels like maybe 2 or 3 mm (at most) embedded in the sides (which do wrap around to the bottom). It's better than nothing, but most of my backpack-style laptop cases (and certainly my suitcase-style laptop cases) have a LOT more. So this is a decent way to carry your laptop from here to there, but it's not something you'd want to travel with or otherwise challenge.Incidentally, the front pocket *does* have enough room for a cord, though it makes the bag bulge out a bit, ruining the nice "streamlined" look. Still, it does work.
A pretty good glove for this price--good stitching, decent padding, a single velcro strap that's at least 2 inches wide for firm hold but easy removal. Gets the job done.

Wow, it appears that in the years I've been epilating, women's electric razors have finally caught up with men's! This glides smoothly over the skin and even handles knees gracefully (though you do have to give it some extra time and use small circles). Overall it works well (dry or in the shower) charges well, has a nice grip, and comes with a convenient stand for charging. You *do* have to charge before using because the power cord disables the unit (otherwise you could used it plugged in WHILE showering and risk electrocution). Multiple messages on the packaging say you're supposed to replace the blades every 12 months, so that's good to know up front.Note when you're unpacking: there's a lid hidden inside the cardboard packaging where you'll never see it (nothing else is there). You have to break open the box and cut it out or dig for it, but it's useful to have (though it won't be the end of the world if you overlook it either--it's just a clear plastic cap that fits over the blades).Note to manufacturers: does EVERYTHING for women have to be pink? I hate it, my daughter hates it, but we buy it anyway simply because there are no other options. If you could offer something in another color (personally I'd prefer navy or black)... even aqua, surely tons of people would buy it for the color alone. Think Frozen! Or spend 20 seconds in any girls or women's clothing store of your choice. Heck, 98% of my daughter's wardrobe is aqua. Pleasepleaseplease stopit with the pink (even though this one is less "Barbie" than most). Thank you!!

Overall this is a decent chapter book for kids. It's about 200 pages long and most of the chapters are 2-4 pages long (though some are 6-8) and it has good pacing for this age group. My kids didn't enjoy it as much as they have some others (like the Kane Chronicles by Rick Riordan, which are a  more difficult read), mostly because the gore level is higher than they prefer. I myself didn't care for it either, even though I read lots of children's fiction. Some of it is OK--like blood falling from the sky instead of rain, creepy zombies, kidnappers, or a walk through a sewer with rats and scorpions (book 1)--but some goes just a bit too far, like a woman on the "good" side hitting multiple pedestrians with her car, multiple children being murdered, etc. This *will* be OK with some kids, but if yours are on the more sensitive side, it may be best to skip this book.

Great headphones -* Sturdy construction* Skullcandy brand (a good brand)* Fits well - you can't flip left vs. right, but when you get it correct, it's a perfect fit* Adjustable; spouse, myself, and 2 kids can all wear it easily--the earpieces just slide up/down as needed* Nicely padded for comfort* Easy button to click to talk* Muffle noise nicely (about 30db), though you can still hear* Lightweight, but not flimsyUPDATE: after just 2 months of regular use by my 10-year-old, the foam came off one of the earpieces, and it took me about 5 minutes to get it back on. She's not hard on headphones (though she's not super-delicate either), so I'd recommend handling these carefully to prevent that.

This supplement is the ONLY chewable calcium I've found that doesn't have phosphate in it (and apparently phosphate REMOVES calcium from bones, so I really wanted a calcium supplement without that). As a bonus, they're also the only calcium supplements I can get my kids (ages 8 and 10) to eat.If you're buying these, be sure to do a web search. I found "myshaklee" which lists these at a much lower price (although they tack on $9 shipping plus tax, so be sure to factor that in).

Overall this is a solid game. Everyone takes turns guessing facts about an animal (locale, weight, length/height, and tail length), and then you pull the card out of the holder to see the real facts, and everyone gets points for either guessing correctly, or being "adjacent" to the correct answer. It's fairly well made (about as well as most board games) and attractive, and the cards themselves are sort of interesting to look at--they include the picture and name as well as the details you're guessing about--and the replay value is high since there are about 150 cards and you use only 5-15 per game. The instructions are easy to follow and 2-6 people can play. My complaint? Apart from the animal pictures, it's not all that interesting. I wish they had included intriguing or little-known facts about the animals along with all the data. As it is, it's slightly more fun than memorizing multiplication tables, but it *does* have a sense of "memorizing tables of data" rather than "these animals are inherently interesting." Yes, I now know that a platypus is smaller than I had thought, and the Mountain Hare is in Europe, not North America, and I could probably persuade my kids (ages 8 and 10) to play the game again, but it's definitely not on their shortlist.

These wheels are precisely as described--84mm 84A with the K2 branding on the side, white in color. My only complaint is that they wear more quickly than other 84mm 84A wheels I've purchased in the past. Admittedly they're half the price so perhaps I shouldn't complain, but it is worth noting. I should also point out that they come without ANY excess packaging--just a bunch of loose wheels in a padded envelope. Perfect for my use, but if you're buying them for a gift (or to resell them) you'll want to package them somehow.

All you do is take orders for different Lego ice cream cones and sandwiches. Then, stack a block in the specified order from several different groups of blocks presented.I guess it teaches a mimic skill, but the main thing is that it entertains my daughter without her vegging out in front of the TV or something that is TOTALLY mindless. It challenges and engages her with something that is mildly educational instead.

The headlight is bright. But the rubber inserts that it clamps against and the finger screw clamp don't hold it in place tightly enough. The result is that when I hit bumps or go up or down a curb, the headlight aim wanders upward. On a 20 minute bike ride, I need to adjust it at least twice.They tried to make it adaptable to fit many diameters of handlebar tubes. But in doing so, they kind of wrecked it for the more common sizes.Since the mounting of the light to the bracket is proprietary, there's really no way to fix this, that I can see.

Great tool set for a travel-friendly multi-tool. (MT) Everything is useful, except (ironically) the wire cutter. It half-shears, half-cuts whatever kind of wire is attempted to cut.+ File is great; with a coarse and fine side+ Saw is great; takes U-shank jigsaw blades+ Scissors are great, as you'd expect from a Fiskars-owned company+ Good range of flat head screwdrivers+ Very good #2 Phillips, with a thick square shank that accepts Gerber's excellent adapter for any 1/4" drive hex bit+ One-handed opening for pliers is great for fellas who work on ladders or similar+ GREAT value+ TSA-friendly; a great tool for traveling technicians who don't need to check bags- Black oxide coating comes off in the hand for a while, even after dish-washing it first- Wire cutter on pliers is terrible; doesn't work well on ANY kind of wire.- The can opener should be replaced with something more useful for an urban tool like this; it's kind of a wasted tool on this one

The flames aren't quite as even as they were with the original Weber burner. Some parts are hotter than others, which means the holes were not drilled with exactly the same size bit.The problem with the Weber one is that it costs half as much as the WHOLE REST OF THE GRILL, and I refuse to pay that. The Weber Q grate doesn't adequately protect the burners from drippings, so plan on replacing this every year or two. Or keeping that cast iron grate really clean. (which I don't)

I'm surprised these aren't more popular among the multi-tool (MT) aficionados. (yes, there is such an animal) The compound leverage means only half as much gripping force from the hand is needed for an equal amount of gripping force at the pliers head. Put another way, a typical out of shape woman could grip something harder than a typical fit man. A fit man could easily grip something hard enough to bend the fine-tipped pliers head. Be sensible with how much force you apply to that fine tip; remember that you have compound leverage at your disposal.The inclusion of a V-cutter is a great idea. I do with they would make the razor blades inside it replaceable, instead of having to replace the entire V-cutter.Speaking of that, SOG is the only MT manufacturer that makes their tool set interchangeable without voiding the warranty. So if you find you'd rather have a scissors after all, you can just order a set from SOG and swap them out. Or if you break a tool, you can just replace it.I'm not convinced the Phillips will work well for #2 heads. It's too fine and probably not strong enough, with that thin shank. (it's only half as thick as the #1 head) However, if you need it for #1 screws, like are typically found on battery doors for kids' toys, it'll be perfect.The chisel grind they sharpened the main part of the blade with stinks. They should've gone the extra step and given it a double-bevel job, like Gerber does on their combo blades. As mentioned in the previous review, whittling by a right-handed user is not doable. You can fix it by just re-sharpening the plain edged part of the blade with a coarse stone on the side that it's not sharpened with. However, for everything else, the design works fine: opening packaging, cutting rope and boxes, etc.This can be flicked open, balisong-style with one hand, and so it is the only viable alternative to Gerber's slide out head design. The whole level of fit & finish is well above Gerber's, up there with Victorinox.The tools inside the handles clump together when pulling them out. This is a byproduct of having them be interchangeable without little dividing washers falling out all over the place. Just be careful when separating the tool from the sharp blade next to it.These are just my first impressions, compared to other MTs I own by Victorinox, Leatherman, and Gerber. I'll update it later when it gets some mileage on it.

+ Blunt nose pliers are rugged and useful. Better than the needlenose pliers on the competition for work in the trades.+ File is great. No diamond coated, ultra-fine side, but coarse and fine is all that is needed, really.+ Wharncliffe blade is great: thick and rugged along most of its spine, but with a sharp tip for precision work.+ One-handed pliers deployment is great. SOG advertises one-handed opening pliers, but they're not, really, compared to this. SOGs need some breaking-in to truly be one-handed, and even  then, one has to separate the handles a bit with the fingertips before it can be butterflied open.+ Locks are great, and double as a comfortable place to put one's thumb when using the internal tools+ Best pliers grip ergonomics in the business. The competition's, that open butterfly style, are not at a comfortable angle to hold while working. They want to slip down in the hand, due to the V-shape. The only exception is Victorinox Spirit series, but that costs triple what this one does, and it's not as heavy-duty.- Tools are hard to pull out with the fingernail notches, at least initially. They probably needed to make them tight, so when they loosen up with wear, they won't fall out too easily- Two knife blades, no scissors or pull cutter. That's dumb. Make the blade a combo one (ground on both sides) and add a pull cutter or scissors where the serrated blade is now.- Finish-wise, it's a little rough around the edges. There's no need for all the sharp edges on the tip of the pliers, for example; they would just eventually cut through the sheath. The handle edges could also have been broken a little better. 5 minutes with a dremel and sanding drum or grinding wheel cleaned them up though.- Can opener on a rugged full-size multi-tool is kind of dumb too, especially when there's no saw. This is not a camper's tool, so skip the can opener and put something useful there instead, like a flat #1 Phillips to go with the 3D #2 Phillips.- Internal tools take a few seconds to get to, so this MT is best paired with a one-handed opening folding knife clipped to the pocket.- Wire cutter is completely useless. It kind of half shears, half cuts, but doesn't work well any ANY kind of wire, solid or stranded. I didn't even try coat hangers or bailing wire, after reading of that causing the carbide cutters to shatter.My advice to Gerber is to fit a combo blade and replace the serrated blade with a scissors. Then, go back to the original design with the wire cutters; just harden them a bit more, or use a super-hard steel, like Leatherman does with their replaceable cutter models.Conclusion: Currently the best multi-tool available for work in the trades. True one-handed opening pliers

I bought this as a gift for my four year-old niece. But it is too hard to open; the spring tension is OK, but operation is just rough, like the implements weren't finished properly. it is not smooth like a Leatherman Micra or Squirt. But Micras and Squirts are not yet offered in bladeless versions.The flat phillips is suitable for #1 screws. You could grind it down and it would work for #2, but if that #2 is tight, you'll bend the tool. Lots of people in the multi-tool community like to hate on the hook, but if you keep in mind you have a sturdy hook on you, you'll be surprised how often you use it. Fishing wires and strings out of small gaps is one application.The file's pretty short; it will take a while to get much done with it, but that's kind of a design limitation.-2 stars for cheap construction, but they get one star back for being the first on the market to address TSA issues in a multi-tool of this size. Gerber has also led the way in offering a full-size bladeless MT. (MP600 bladeless)I think the tool opening and closing stiffness will loosen up with use.Scissors are good. Small flat head screwdriver is pretty short; you won't reach any recessed screws with it, but it works well enough.The pliers is a light-duty one, but that is what one would expect from an MT that is only 2-3" long.

The chrome plating must be REALLY thin, or really low on chromium, as this bike has some notable rust after sitting outside, and without being exposed to rain. Just the humidity in the air is enough to rust it.The steering handle for parents *seems* like a good idea, but it isn't. It doesn't teach your kid about balance and how it relates to steering, but instead teaches them that "daddy will steer for me." My daughter has much more fun with this without the handle, but with the training wheels fitted.A straight handle without the steering linkage would be preferred. Sometimes the old way is the better way.There is a quick release clamp for the seat post height adjustment. Good idea, right? Only if it is executed well. Which this one is not. It cannot clamp tightly enough on the seat post to keep the weight of my daughter from pushing it down, and she's only 30 lbs. I have to take this out, throw it away, and replace it with a proper nut, bolt, and washer from the hardware store. Then, get some naval jelly to clean off the rust. Then wax everything so it doesn't rust so easily.Good thing kids outgrow this quickly, or it would be a REAL rip-off.For now, I just think $100 would've been better spent on a used Trek kiddie bike instead.It does work though, and my daughter just loves the bell and handlebar bag for her teddy bear.

I bought this one because it is UL Listed and has a proper USB power supply in it. Just plug your USB charge cords into these jacks, and you don't need the separate power supply that came with them. At least in theory. But I've found that about 5% of the time, I plug it in, the phone indicates it's connected, and when I get my phone in the morning, it isn't charged. WTH? There's either a bad connection inside or the power supply is not up to spec.It comes with a nice long screw to go through the middle. Remove your receptacle's face plate, and replace it with this outlet extender/power supply, then fix it in place with the long screw, which replaces the shorter screw you just removed from the receptacle's face plate.

After trying several different brands and types of these, I've come to the conclusion that the best way to go is with an inexpensive wire brush with stiff bristles from the home improvement store and an oven mitt. They're much cheaper and work better.The bristles on this are a bit soft, and while they reach into the nooks, they don't really clean in there that well. (I have a cast iron grate on my Weber Q)The expensive Weber-branded ones work better, but clog up with grease and barbecue sauce very quickly. Then, you have a nice bamboo handle with a grease blob head that is ready for the trash. I'm going to cut the head off of mine and make another tool out of it.

Looks super-cute. There's not much else to say about it. The material is cotton knit, like T-shirts are made from. If your tot is on the big side, get the next size up, as it will shrink just a bit. (< 10%)
Just like the original, in other words. Buy with confidence.Pull your old, used-up pen out of your little SAK, push this one in its place. Done, and good for another year or two.

It's such a simple thing, to glue the rubber to a table tennis paddle. But if it's not done right, there will be bubbles, it will come off, etc. This simple kit includes the glue (contact cement type) several foam applicators, (which look like big ear plugs) and a "chip clip" to hold onto the applicators and keep the cement off your hands.The way it works is that you apply a squiggly bead of the cement on your clean paddle. Then, smear it all around with the ear plug, which you'll hold sideways with the chip clip. Make a smooth coat. After removing the backing film from your new rubber, apply it the way way there. Wait for both parts to air dry for ~5-7 minutes, until you see it has dried a bit. At this point, when you stick it together, it will be a permanent bond. (or you'll screw it up trying to get it apart) So make sure you align the bottom of the rubber (with the molded printing) with the squared-off part of the handle that's glued on to the paddle. Then apply it, kind of rolling it down. Trim it off with a sharp X-Acto knife from the reverse side, using the paddle itself as a template. Repeat with the other side.Also invest in a rubber cleaning sponge. I use Windex or rubbing alcohol. It cleans the dust and skin oil off of the rubber after every day of play. This will extend the life of the rubber many times. I'm maybe a lower mid-level club player. Good enough to easily beat anyone who hasn't seriously learned some skills. For me, a set of rubber applied this way will last a couple years. For the pros, I think they change every week or so.

I paid a little extra for security printing on the inside of the envelopes, and a little more extra for the adhesive strips, so I don't have to lick them any more. Or wet my finger and end up with my finger all sticky. I feel a little guilty, throwing the backing for the adhesive in the trash; I've just made more garbage because I don't like licking them, hehehe.Anyway, try a box. I think you'll quickly prefer them to the old style ones. Mead's basic quality is still there. Don't hesitate to pay a bit extra for it, compared to off-brand office/school supplies.

This is one of the great 3-layer Swiss Army knives. (SAKs)I've had the Victorinox Super Tinker, Climber, and Hiker before, and this one trumps them all. Why?It has a more durable scissors spring. The lever you see in the pic actuates a backspring for the scissors, instead of having a leaf spring, which will eventually break or get bent out of alignment.It has the self-locking large flat head screwdriver on the end of the bottle opener, carried over from Wenger. When you bear down on a flat head screw, it wedges in place, rather than folding up on you.Instead of a small blade, it has a nail file. The tip of it works in #0 and #1 Phillips screws and also as a light-duty prybar.Now that this is a Victorinox model instead of Wenger, it has the great Victorinox can opener.The Evo scales are quite comfortable in the hand.The corkscrew works great, not just on wine corks, but also for helping to untie knots.The 85mm length is more comfortable in a hip pocket than the 91mm Victorinoxes.

This Swiss Army knife (SAK) is my favorite, because it represents a great balance for the urban or suburban user.The 2 and 3-layer SAKs are more comfortable in the pocket, but often times, it means being caught without the right tool for the job.The 5+ layer SAKs have additional functionality, at the expense of not really being pocketable. (belt pouch or high tolerance to lots of weight in the pockets)BLADES: I use the small blade for my day-to-day utility tasks, and "save" the big blade back for occasional food duty or as a spare.CAN OPENER: Sometimes, I use the can opener for fun. It is surprisingly effective; an order of magnitude better than any other one out there. (except the ones that shamelessly copy this one) The small screwdriver tip sometimes comes in handy. On lesser SAKs, that tip is used for #2 Phillips, but we don't have to resort to such Rube Goldberg tactics here, do we?BOTTLE OPENER: This is the #2 most often used tool. It not only opens bottles, but the tip is useful on everyday flat-head screws and as a light-duty prying tool. The wire-stripping notch is questionable. For it to work well, one has to cut a notch around the wire's insulation with a knife blade first.SCISSORS: Probably the most often used tool on most SAKs, and it's no exception here. Don't abuse them by cutting wire or something, and they'll treat you well for years and years, on everything from thread to coupon-clipping to de-tagging that new shirt.INLINE PHILLIPS SCREWDRIVER: This is one of the defining tools of the mighty Explorer. So often, a screw is recessed in a housing or right next to something else, and a Phillips as a back tool or the small tip of the can opener just won't get the job done. This one is wonderful. Maybe tied for #2 most-used tool, with the flat screwdriver/bottle opener. It has a stop half-way out too, to help break those stubborn screws loose. Don't let it slip though, and strip the driver tip!MAGNIFIER: Another defining Explorer feature. It is very strong, but doesn't have a big field of view. Note that the newer ones are molded from one piece of plastic, not gray with a separate lens, as is shown here.KEYRING: Not really a keyring, but a lanyard ring. I use it to hang the Explorer from my belt vertically in my hip pocket, which is a more comfortable way to carry it. Others like to tie fancy lanyards to dress it up, and still others carry the Explorer around their neck by this! Put a small lanyard on it, and it is great to pull the Explorer out of a belt pouch/sheath.HOOK: Keep your mind open, and you'll find a ton of uses for this.CORKSCREW: Works a treat on wine corks, but even if you're not a wine drinker, you can use it to help untie knots. Of course it is also the home for the mini screwdriver, which works great on watches and eyeglasses.PIN: Works in perfect harmony with the tweezers and magnifier to remove slivers of wood or metal from your clumsy hand.PEN: Great little pen. Pressurized and writes easily and smoothly.TOOTHPICK: Works great for its intended purpose. If you're wary of using it for your teeth, then use it to pick pocket lint from out of the knife's nooks and crannies.TWEEZERS: Surprisingly effective, but not strong enough to tweeze your monobrow.REAMER: A great multi-purpose tool. I use it to drill extra holes in my belt, so I can always have that perfect fit. (tighter AND looser, you in the back!) It is also a good general-purpose pointy thing. Use it when you need an extra light duty, but precision prying tool, and don't want to ruin your knife blade.********My previous favorite model was the Super Tinker, which is a little nicer for pocket carry. But the T-Phillips just doesn't cut muster sometimes. It's also not offered in a Plus version at this time, so you lose the pin, pin, and mini screwdriver. Oh, there's no corkscrew, due to the often-useless T-Phillips, so no home for the mini screwdriver anyway.Ladies and Gentlemen, I'm a collector of SAKs and multi-tools. I have probably 100 of them. But if I could only pick one, it would be this one.if I could pick two, it would be this and the Rambler.
Not much else to say here. They fit my daughter great the first time. She has wide feet, but not too long. One time through the wash, and they were on the edge of being too small.

This model is a little thinner than the Swisschamp, but I would argue it has a more useful tool set for the typical urban/suburban person. The Swisschamp is the one to take camping and fishing, but this is the one you'll use every day.The thing that sets this apart from SAKs that aren't in the Cybertool line-up is the Cybertool driver. It is long and thin enough to get to recess screws, which most Swiss army knife drivers aren't. That is a thick layer to add to one's Swiss army knife (SAK) but it packs 10 drivers! Medium flat head (small and large are on the can and bottle openers), 3 sizes of Torx, 2 metric nut driver sizes, one metric hex (allen) driver, and 3 sizes of Phillips. (#s 0, 1, and 2)As always Victorinox's scissors are great. Sharp and maybe the most often-used tool on any SAK.The pliers are another thick layer, but are perfect for when you need more than a tweezers, but you don't so much power you need to go get full size pliers of some type. The crimper and wire cutter are of questionable use; they would have to be very small crimp-on terminals and wires.The Cybertool models also have the Plus scales, which contain a pin and ballpoint pen, which are both very handy. The pin, combined with the tweezers is a perfect combo for removing slivers from one's hands.It's a bit too thick and heavy to pocket carry on a regular basis, but is great in a belt pouch, and as a bonus, it doesn't get full of pocket lint that way; the tools retain their snap for much longer.
This one was very good. A proper end to the trilogy. There's still ROOM for sequels, as no one can turn down a buck. But Terminator Salvation was not that great of a follow-up.

Leave room for it to shrink in the dryer. Tagless design is nice; more comfortable than the old ones with the itchy nylon tags. I wear one of these every day under my button up work shirts during the winter. I like that I can wear my button up shirts probably 4 times between washes, because these take the sweat.Material is not paper thin, either. These are worth the bit of extra money compared to the paper-thin ones.

These have live hinges both for the hinge and for the latch. I don't get a feeling they'll last too many cycles. Since they're designed to accommodate either 4AAs or 4AAAs, they rattle a bit for either one. The Eneloop ones don't rattle at all, though to be fair, they cost a lot more.I bought these as I have quite a stock of high-end rechargeable AA batteries now, and I start to worry they're going to get shorted out by keys or something when carried in a bag.In a year or two, these will be like $0.20 each and available everywhere. For now, they're priced kind of high for the cheap things that they are.

This is what I give my 2 year old daughter when I need to be left alone to cook or drive. She learns something, and it is interactive, so it is a notch better than educational TV or DVDs, and a MILE better than anything non-educational. The content changes from time to time. My 2 year old enjoys building a snowman, Jack-O-Lantern, and gingerbread boy/girl. When she's in the mood, she will do colors and letters.The great thing about this app is that kids don't even REALIZE they are learning, but it is sinking in somehow.

I would prefer to have an Apple iPad, as we have a Macbook Pro and two iPhones in the family already. I bought this because it seemed to be spec'd quite well for the price. The display is wonderful. The interface is OK, but not quite Apple-caliber. It locks up and crashes much more than an Apple though. Not enough that I want to give up on it, just don't buy this thinking it is going to do everything fluidly. For example, I tried to go to YouTube on the built-in web browser, and that was a flippin' disaster. It either crashed or locked up 100% of the time. I looked and saw they have a YouTube app; so I installed that, and it works great. Would I buy it again? I think so. Samsung and Apple devices are much higher in price, so high that I couldn't justify buying one and letting kids use it. Probably not myself either, as a laptop is still loads more capable and an iPhone is still loads more portable. But this is 1/3 the price of an equivalent iPad, which even though it is not as GOOD as an iPad, it is still a good buy. It is like comparing a well-equipped Camry Hybrid at $35k (iPad) to an entry level Kia Rios at $12k. They both get the job done, and the Camry (iPad) is certainly nicer, but nice enough that it is worth triple the price? I guess that depends on your budget. For me? This will do nicely.In addition to my 2 year old daughter playing Starfall, my 11 year old son plays Minecraft on it. This constitutes about 95% of the use it gets. It is great for reading in bed. No lights to keep on that will disturb my wife's sleep. I choose the white text on black background, as this draws the least power and also bombards the eyes with the least light. It was almost as pleasant as reading an e-ink Kindle in daylight.This device is also great for checking email.The most limiting factor at this time is the amount of apps available to its Kindle-proprietary operating system. For example, I would have loved to install WeChat and QQ Chat for my wife to chat with her Chinese friends. Those apps are easily available on Droid or iOS. I like the TapaTalk app for browsing internet fora, but it isn't yet available here. I'm sure Amazon will get them eventually. I think the result will be that it is not quite as "open source" as Droid, so it'll have fewer virus and malware issues, but also not iOS, so they can keep the price down.The colored plastic case provides a little bit of scratch and impact protection, and is more easy to hold than Apple's smooth and rounded aluminum. Still, I went ahead and grabbed my ankles and bought the FreeTime kid-proof case for it. (not necessary unless you're clumsy or have kids)

Works for Kindle HD7 MUCH better than using the web interface.Functionality is a bit more limited than the computer web interface though; I'd like to see the same functionality in an app as I would have from my computer.

"Kid-Proof" is really an exaggeration, but let's just say it makes a Kindle Fire HD7 as durable as one could reasonably expect. If it is dropped such that something hard that protrudes from the floor surface hits the screen, kiss your HD7 goodbye. If you drench it in fluids, kiss it goodbye. This case will withstand any other kind of abuse that I can think of.

My only fear is that they've tried to run this on forever, in an effort to milk the idea for all its worth. I see that future books are from different authors.It very complex, at times, to follow all the variants that come up from changing the timeline.A fun read, especially as a free Lending Library book!

Winona Ryder was as talentless as usual. Everyone else was great.It was dark, but really draws the viewer in. My wife, who watched it with me for the first time, said that it wasn't fair, how Dracula came and stole Harker's wife. Hehe.Now that I watched it again after all these years, I wonder why Dracula kept hanging around outside the victims' windows as a wolfman, when he could have just morphed into a mist and slipped in. ?Great movie anyway. I'll watch it about every ten years, from now on.

It is *marked* RG-213/U, but it is a lower grade than what I bought at DX Engineering; very stiff.
