The jacket seems to be plastic, rather than the more flexible rubber-type material used by DXE.However, it works fine, the connectors are fine, although again, not as beefy as those used by DXE, and they used heat-shrink tubing at the base of the connector.It shipped coiled up tighter than it should be too, so it'll fit in a 8.5 x 11 padded envelope. Doesn't seem to be damaged though.
Yep, they work, and seem to be fresh.

For those times when a single person wants just a couple mugs (or 5-6 teacups) of tea.This one's lid stays put when pouring, all the way to empty, and the handle is big enough for three fingers. The spout drips just the tiniest bit; but it's better than any other teapot I've used in that regard. It blows the small Brown Betty out of the water.

Works great. As a previous reviewer said, both connector bodies are a bit bigger than the apple, and the cord insulation is slicker than Apple's, which is more like a rubber.I just could NOT bear to fork over $17 for an Apple cord. I bought this one just to stick it to them and still get a decent quality accessory.

This is simply the best sounding speaker in this size and price class.The highs are crystal clear. Mids are good. Bass is great. I listen to a huge range of music, and every genre sounds great. Aqua's 'Barbie Girl' and Ace of Base's 'The Sign' are good representatives for how it handles deep, thumping bass. Consider that representative of hip-hop.The majority of my listening is 60s-70s folk and classical. Simon & Garfunkel, Neil Diamond, Jim Croce, etc for the 60s-70s. Bach, from pipe organ to orchestral suites, sounds awesome. Mozart operas too. When I auditioned this in Target with my own music, it was love at first hearing. It is often repeated in speaker reviews here that "it would be fine for classical, but not for [some modern genre with thumping bass]. Nothing could be further from the truth. If you've ever heard a pipe organ in a 600 year old cathedral, you know what I'm talking about. When the low notes are keyed, one can feel it in the chest. When at a classical symphony, one can likewise feel the bass section in the chest, as well as really hear the lows. It's just that we get used to not hearing them, because of either inferior recordings or poor frequency response. (the older crowd who tend to listen to this music don't tend toward bassy sound systems, right?)Once in a while, I listen to the 80s and 90s Metallica and Ozzy Osbourne of my youth. That kind of music is not too demanding of a speaker, compared to classical; it has a much narrower frequency range. That just requires no distortion and ability to play loud. This speaker is not going to make your ears ring with hard rock and metal music like a bigger system will, but it will sound really good within its range, which is plenty loud enough to upset others in the same house.This SRS-X5 handles at all with grace.I bought this for portable use around my 850 sq. ft. apartment, mostly in the kitchen and bedroom. It is shallow enough to just sit on the windowsill, not taking up any counter space while I cook. The dual bass radiators in the back use the window as a reflector, and make the bass sound about 50% deeper than it does when sitting out in the open. I start up the tunes from my iPhone, then either put it back in my pocket or go back to the recipe I'm making on allrecipes dot com. Do you notice that cooking with music is much less like work, and much more like singing while doing some light work?Pressing the SOUND button engages a DSP circuit which simulates much better stereo separation than would seem possible, considering the full-range drivers are only a few inches apart. It really works; it makes the speakers sound about 2-3X as far apart as they really are.The speakerphone works great. MUCH better than using the speakerphone built into the iPhone. The USB charging works great too.COMPARED TO:Bose Soundlink Mini, same price, at the time of this writing. After comparing this to the Bose Soundlink Mini, there is no comparison. The Soundlink Mini has "The Bose Lows", which sound pretty muddy compared to those of this Sony. The lows also don't sound as deep. The highs are not as crisp or clear as this Sony. It DOES sound huge for its size, but it doesn't sound as good as the Sony, and it is deeper too, so not quite as good on a narrow surface like the aforementioned windowsill.Bose Soundlink III: ($100 more) - The SRS-X5 and Soundlink III are about the same size. The Bose is a smidge bigger in every dimension, as it has a larger battery pack. The finish treatment is a bit more interesting on the Bose; nicer to look at than the plain, minimalist Sony. The lows on the Soundlink III are equal to those of the -X5, but the highs on the Sony are much better, and with the SOUND mode, stereo separation is better on the Sony too. The Bose has better battery life and regular buttons, instead of the capacitively coupled ones on the Sony. Seems like it plays just a bit louder, esp. on battery power. But... it is 50% more money, so not even really in the same class.Jawbone Big Jambox: ($50 more) is not in the same class. It has the metal speaker grille which surrounds the unit, which will be prone to pick up dents on the corners. The bass is not as deep and the highs are not as clear either. The Big Jambox may be the original, but The Sony SRS-X5 easily trounces it.JBL Pulse: ($10 less) Not in the same league as the Sony, nor even the Big Jambox. Lows are totally absent, in comparison. All it really has going for it is the light show.JBL Charge: ($70 less) Not in the same league as the Sony. Sounds about like the Pulse, but without the fancy lighting. To be fair, this is in a lower class, and is priced commensurate to its class. A good value, but in this price range, the Sony SRS-X3 sounds better; same highs and a bit more bass.Sony SRS-X3: ($50 less) Sounds awesome for its size, on par with the Bose Soundlink Mini, at half the price. (though it doesn't have the cool extruded aluminum case as the Bose) It's kind of like the -X5, but without the subwoofer.TDK A34: ($50 less) Couldn't compare the sound, as I didn't audition it in person, but it is splash-proof and has replaceable batteries. About the same specs as the Sony, except that reviewers say the highs can be a bit lacking at times.Klipsch KMC 3: ($150) more. By all accounts, this one has outstanding sound, both highs and lows. It has triple the RMS power though, and is much bigger and 75% more expensive, so not really in this class. I was going to stretch to get this, but decided that if I can't put it on my windowsill easily, I may as well just use my old Sony boombox w/subwoofer and a cord. This has the advantage of using D batteries too. High-capacity rechargeable ones are available from Tenergy, though they are pretty dear. If you only will use it on battery power occasionally, just get alkalines and don't look back.I wish I could have auditioned the TDK A34 in person, as it has a great price, ($50 less than the -X5) and a bit more rugged construction. Replaceable, rechargeable NiMH battery pack is a nice feature, as the Sony's Li-Ion pack doesn't seem to be replaceable, but after reading several reviews that said the highs are lacking, I decided to give up some of the future-proofness of replaceable batteries for better sound. Maybe I will regret it several years from now when my -X5's internal battery dies, but for now, I'm super happy.That brings me to the last point: I deducted one full star for the non-replaceable battery issue. Maybe it was part of their design spec, (less things to rattle loose, without a battery door or screws) or maybe it is planned obsolescence, but either way, I don't like it. When I spend this much money on a quality product like this, I want to be able to use it for 20 years. I finally decided that by the time the battery on this dies, there will be completely different products available, and that $150 extra that I would have spent on the Klipsch KMC 3 can buy something new in the same class as this Sony.I'll post updates to this from time to time, so click that checkbox to be notified if you want to read them.***Update: Oct. 18, 2014****I just got back from my birthday part at my mom's house. I brought this little gem with me to show it off to the family, as this is what I'd bought with my gift card from Mom and my sister. Everyone was impressed with the sound. My brother, who listens to classic rock almost exclusively and who is also a guitarist in a garage band. My mom, who has a bachelor's degree in music, and who played flute and piano in weddings, privately taught flute and piano professionally, etc. She always complained that the bass in classical music is lacking, unless the sound system REALLY has good bass. She was impressed too. We listened to everything from AC/DC to Scott Joplin to Mozart. My bro even tried it out with a live Cream recording and Ozzy's 'Diary of a Madman.'Compared to my mom's sound system, which consist of a pair of Bose 301 speakers and a nice older Sony Receiver with Dynamic Bass Feedback (DBFB) and a single tray Yamaha CD player, it is not quite as room-filling or bassy. But it sounds as good or better than a 10 year old Sony boombox with powered subwoofer that is at least 5X as big.This is a thing I like about Sony: they make so many things so well. They're not always top of the class, but they usually make something that is NEAR the top. This X5 is one such device. The Sony X9 looks and reads really great, but I doubt it competes with the Klipsch KMC 3, which costs half as much. (350 vs 700) Their TVs are great, their phones are great, their boomboxes are great, their clock radios are great, their shortwave radios are/were great, their digital photo frames are great, etc.
Not much else to say than that ^

First Impression and Suburban Range CheckGot the radios yesterday night.The face plates snap in; they're not held in with the small Torx screws. (this is a good thing, as not many of us will have tiny Torx screwdrivers at home) With a little prying and patience, they came right off. I quite like this. Now, the boy has the yellow one, wife has the orange one, and I've got the green one. If one of them gets busted up, we'll know who the guilty party is. (most likely the 10 year old boy!)The instruction sheet is well-done. I think it was originally written by a native English speaker, which is nice, for a change in the radio world!The menu layout is great; pretty intuitive for anyone even a little bit technical. It's going to take me a while to remember that iVOX is for use without the external mic headset and VOX is with the headset. They could have come up with a better convention to help differentiate between those two. Maybe they just wanted to get "iVOX" patented before Apple does...One feature that sold me on these instead of the Midlands is the battery options. The Midlands use AAAs and the Motorolas use AAs. AAs have triple the capacity of AAAs, for one thing. For another, we can either use a pack of series-connected, shrink-wrapped NiMH AAs that Motorola provides, our own AAs (I like Sanyo Eneloop), or Alkaline AAs. Lithium AAs could probably be used, and would be the idea choice for back-up radio use, as they have a 12 year shelf life, higher energy density, lighter weight, and better voltage stability under cold weather conditions. (compared to alkaline and NiMH)The physical construction is solid: Motorola always uses durable, thick plastics for their housings. These don't feel *quite* as solid as their $200 commercial talkies, but a notch above what one would expect in this price class.The power/volume knob has that nice well-damped feel to it, although I would like it to have more traction. It has just a few little rounded bumps for knurling; they could have done better here, I think.Another part of the design that should probably be reworked is that the PTT buttons should either have equal priority or the low power one should be the prominent one. As is, it is recessed under the high power one. The radio is programmed such that even of one presses the high power PTT button when on an FRS-only channel, it will STILL only transmit at 1/2 W.The flashlight is a brilliant addition. There's a smallish constant contact button on the right side of the radio for the flashlight, which is on the bottom of the radio. That light is bright enough to find your way outside at night, and maybe even OVERLY bright to use indoors at night. (it will hurt the night vision)Range check: In our suburban neighborhood, near to Chicago, there are lots of old trees and buildings. Under these conditions, on a clear night, we got 0.6 miles. The audio was fully intelligible, but "snowy." There were buildings between us. To get more range, I could change positions slightly (a small change in position can make a huge improvement, with a walkie-talkie) or try to get in more direct line of sight.Soon, I'll try VOX, iVOX, the headset and the belt clip and update this review.Can't wait to try it out in our Gurnee Mills mall here, which is laid out all on one floor, and shaped like a big 'Z.' I expect it'll work down one row, but once around the corner of the 'Z,' it'll drop out quickly.
Fresh and they fit well. The text that says which ones they replace is super-useful.

There are cheaper and smaller study guides out there, but they tend to just be question pools with explanations. Not really easy to read, even though they're smaller.This is the one to get. (or whatever the latest version is, when you read this!)I'm slowly making my way through this, trying to find time and motivation to take the General Class exam. (I'm a father of a young family, and find myself needing to do other things when I have spare time)
Got these for my sister. She loves them. Perhaps just as importantly, her KIDS love them! :)

I started with a similar product by Butler GUM many years ago, but couldn't find them any more when it was time to get new floss spreaders for my family. I found this similar product and discovered that it is the US-made original, and that Butler's was the copy! Wow!These are much larger than the cheezy disposable ones you'll find in the local Walmart. It's quite easy to reach back to floss between the molars using these.When you're winding the floss around the spool, press the tips together, so that when you're done, there's some tension between them. If you have tight teeth, get some good quality floss. (I like the basic Oral-B floss that I find locally)I find myself skipping flossing, so one trick I got from my godfather, who was a dentist, is to floss in front of TV.
They work fine, not too flimsy for our 5th grade boy. (which is saying something)

I bought this to replace the worn out stock strap on my mom's Tissot Desire. The glossy finish really dresses it up a notch, compared to the dullish stock one.It has a gold buckle though; something to keep in mind if your watch has a steel case.I just swapped on the original buckle to this strap.The lining is really soft calf skin, only the outer part is lizard.You really get what you pay for with watch straps; a good leather one is LOADS more comfortable than any bracelet, and can be just as dressy.

I quite like the watch.+ Light weight, like a plastic Casio, but doesn't stick to the wrist like one.+ Feels warmer on the wrist than steel+ At 39mm, it is considered "midsize" by today's standards. Great for guys with smaller wrists or ladies who prefer a bigger watch+ Bezel action is good, 60-click.+ Movement is silent. Some cheaper Seikos these days tick quite loudly.+ Lume is good. Not as good as what is used on the Swiss watches, but still visible in pitch darkness after the night+ Hands are long enough for the dial+ Bracelet links are solid Ti+ Bezel sits about 1mm proud of the crystal, which will protect it from some glancing blows that would tend to scratch the mineral crystal.- Not that well-spec'd for the price. For example, it should have a sapphire glass crystal at this price point, and solid end links for the bracelet- Bracelet pins back out a bit with wear. Not enough that it will fall apart, but enough that the wearer will notice- Diver's extension is near impossible to get loose. A tool is needed, and that will certainly scratch the braceletWould I buy it again? I guess that depends on how long the rechargeable battery lasts. If it lasts at least 10 years before needing replacement, I count it as a good deal. If not, I'd have to recommend looking at a non-rechargeable battery quartz watch with a scratch-proof sapphire glass crystal in the two hundred dollar range instead.The timing bezel is a very useful; kind of a low-tech, low resolution stopwatch. Don't underestimate that.

My mom has about 15 watches, and ladies watches have small batteries, so it's important to keep spares on hand to change them annually. This is one common size, so I buy them in multi-packs.Lithium batteries have a shelf life about about 10-12 years, so buying a 5-pack is a safe bet.

I live in an apartment where gas is included in the rent, but electric isn't. I have a gas stove, so when it was time to bring my electric kettle to work, I replaced it with an old-fashioned kettle.As another reviewer said, use it on the small diameter burner on your stove for best results, and maybe don't even turn it up all the way. If you do, the heat from the flames will whip around the side and super-heat the handle, making it so that you need a hot pad to grab it. Also, make sure it is centered on the burner, or even offset a little so that the handle is away from the heat.Lastly, I fill it only within 2" of the top, so it doesn't boil over or sputter boiling water through the whistle hole.The whistling action is audible, but only from the next room; not from across the house.It takes about 20 minutes to boil a kettle of water; much slower than electric, but if you're having tea at home, what's the rush? It's kind of nice not having another electric appliance around. Electric appliances work so well, but we've already got an energy source in the form of natural gas; may as well use it sometimes, and cut down on the clutter.As I type this, I'm boiling a pot of water to make some organic tea from Amazon on this Saturday morning. Can't wait!
I drink this for breakfast each weekday at work. Great taste, like black tea SHOULD taste.
This is your basic aluminum crush washer; hard to screw it up. It works fine to keep the oil drain plug sealed to the oil pan on my 2012 Accord 4 cylinder.

Great feature set, intuitive interface. It has a date-programmable alarm that is really slick, just like the DW-5600E G-Shock. The backlight is quite strong, and a nice amber hue. It has nice bold digits, and a late-70s cosmetic style. Really a great watch; a notch above the A158W, A168W, and F91W, none of which have a countdown timer or date programmable alarm. It has the return-to-home functionality of the MODE button that Casios used to have, but which they now lack.

Even if you don't use the telememo feature to remember phone numbers, the other features of this watch justify its price:  all-inclusive display, 6-button interface is fast, 4 date-programmable alarms... Just a useful feature set too.Bracelet's a bit on the cheap side; it pulls arm hairs if you wear it loosely.

I remember this movie fondly from when I was a kid in the 80s. Now, I watched it here with my 10 year-old son, and he was as on-edge as I was at that age. But it is not as good for grown-ups, maybe because we don't spend as much time in "Fantasia" as kids do. Still, it's worth another watch for us old folks and worth watching with your kids.

The case is chrome-finished plastic. The bracelet is Casio's typical hair-puller that is found on their inexpensive watches. Wear it just a bit snug, and it's fine though. It's very easy to size; all you need is a small screwdriver.to me, it has the elegance of a simple analog dress watch AND the basic digital functionality I've started to take for granted from Casio. It looks sharp enough to wear to the office, is lightweight and not too big for small men's wrists. The stopwatch hasn't got split time or multiple finishes; just start, stop, and reset. The alarm is a simple daily one. The movement is quiet too! If one listens closely, one can hear the minutes hand tick to the next position every 20-30 seconds. It also has dual time, so that if one is traveling, one can read home time on the analog hands, and dual time on the main hands. If you wanted to track three time zones, one could even program the main digital clock for another time zone than the main analog, then the DT clock for another one altogether.The reviewer who said it takes a while to set the analog time is right. But I think Casio made the right call to make this a button instead of a crown with mechanics, ala AMW320. Having time-setting mechanics and a crown would make the watch bigger than it is.I'm really happy that Casio can still make a watch like this and offer it for such a fair price. It seems like the price has gone DOWN since the 80s, rather than up, even before accouning for 25 years' worth of inflation. Add to that the fact that they make them in black and white dials, with plain markers or arabic numerals. Wow.In short, it's a great value for a dress watch or even an all-around watch. I may buy several more of these as stocking-stuffers for my family. They'll roll their eyes, but may end up liking them quite a bit!

The lenses give a very slight brownish tint to things, but not enough that stoplights don't look like the wrong color. Just a touch different. I prefer these to gray; the world just looks a bit more beautiful when wearing them.As expected from a pair of expensive sunglasses, they don't distort one's view, even at the edge of the lenses. Mine included a semi-hard vinyl case that is of good quality, along with a microfiber cleaning cloth.The one probably I had with them is that the "socks" are not that heat-resistant. I left them in the sunglasses storage compartment in the ceiling of my car and the heat from the summer sun baked the elastomer out of them to the point that they just disintegrated in my hand one day after work. If you don't have a local Ray-Ban stocking dealer, then you're up the creek. I'd like to see those socks made of a material that can withstand 150 degrees F, year after year, since this is a normal storage condition for sunglasses.

I have one of those wall shelves for keeping everyday items orgainzed. It has four hooks on it, but between mine and my wife's keys, my son's keys, and some other sets of keys that are not used every day, it is over-crowded.I ordered two of these, stuck them high up on the fridge, and now they fill that gap nicely. In fact, my wife and son sometimes bicker over who gets to use the other one. ^_^  I'll end up adding a third one to some future order.

RTFM = Read the flippin' manualThere are an inordinate amount of review by people who have the wrong expectations of this watch because they are too stupid to read the manual. They pull it out of the box, charge it for not enough time, in not enough light, then, when it dies on them, they get all indignant, write a bad review that "it won't hold a charge", return it, and write a slanderous review.Here's the deal, if you're going to charge it in indoor lighting, it takes dozens and dozens of hours to give it a full charge. Solar power from a small panel is simply not that fast. Put it on a windowsill and leave it in full sunlight for a couple of days, THEN buckle it on, and it'll be fine. Do you see the little sun icon on the display in the promotional photo? That means the watch is hungry. 'means the watch may die at any moment. Go ahead and feed it when it gets down to that point.Why? ^ Because this watch is truly batteryless. All other solar watches use a rechargeable battery that will eventually die. They can only handle so many charge cycles, that's just the nature of the beast. This watch uses a capacitor instead, which is made to charge and discharge hundreds of times. Motors use capacitors that are charged and discharged 60 times per SECOND, for example. The drawback on a low voltage DC design is that the capacity is lower due to space constraints, and therefore it needs recharging more often. But it may also last a lot longer; maybe 30+ years before that capacitor goes belly-up.If you're thinking of buying this watch and you want to be happy with it, here is the expectations you should have:a) Plan to leave it on a window sill in full sunlight for a couple days to get a full chargeb) Set the watch and wear itc) If you ever see that little sun icon, it means it's not getting enough charge in its everyday life to be maintained. This may happen, for example in wintertime in cold climates if you wear long sleeves and it is covered up most of the day. If you just make sure it gets light each day, it'll be fine. Roll up the sleeve a bit or just have a back-up watch, so you can leave this one at home on the window sill to recharged) The bracelet is inexpensive. It's made from folded steel links. If you're the kind of person who wears it a bit snug, so it doesn't slide back and forth on the wrist, or you've got a hairless wrist, it'll be fine. But if you wear it loose, plan to replace that bracelet right away with a quality leather or nylon strap. Or just buy the black plastic version of this watch, which comes on a comfortable resin band. At this price point, Casio can't afford to outfit it with a solid link bracelet.e) Button presses don't result in beeps, except when needed, for example when starting or stopping the stopwatch, when the alarms go off, etc. They don't beep when going mode to mode. (energy-saving measure)f ) It hasn't got a light of any kind; that is a huge power drain. If you often need to read the time from your watch in the dark, this could be an issue.The previous version of this watch, the A180, didn't have a countdown timer, nor multiple alarms. This one does. The timer is an ever-useful feature.The digits for the display are nice and dark; easy to read against the light gray background of the LCD. (liquid crystal display)There's no Adjust button, as I'd become used to from owning Casios for 30 years. The upper-left button is Select. Once I got used to it, it was fine, and I like how it is not recessed. Folks with really short fingernails never did like the recessed Adjust button, especially when it was required for everyday operations like resetting the stopwatch or timer.I consider this watch to be one for connoisseurs and collectors. Or people who wear short sleeves almost all the time and either have a hairless wrists or don't mind wearing it a big snug. For what it's worth, this watch would look smashing on a glossy, black lizard skin strap.Update, Nov. 26, 2014:After wearing this maybe a few weeks' worth of days, my skin has broken all the sharp edges on the bracelet, and now it rarely pulls an arm hair.

You may not be aware, but there are different options for manufacturers, when it comes to 3rd party safety certification of their products required. In the US, the big players are UL, (Underwriters Laboratories) ETL, (Edison Testing Laboratories) and CSA. (Canadian Standards Association) UL is the premier and the one that doesn't cut corners by waiving tests without justification. However, this makes them more expensive, and so as a way to cut costs, manufacturers more and more frequently choose ETL or CSA. Yes, the appliance my work fine, but it may also burn down your house when you're not nearby because corners were cut.I didn't try this, returned it immediately when I found out it wasn't listed. Interestingly, Aroma's larger model IS UL Listed.Presto makes one about this size that IS UL Listed. We bought that one after returning this one.

+ Countdown timer accessible from the home screen+ Comfortable, even on small wrists (mine's 6-3/4" circumference)+ Negative display is legible all the time+ Light is bright enough to easily read the time+ Time of day is visible in all modes+ Light weight+ Vibe Alarm is brilliant; no one has to know you're reminding yourself of things with the alarms or timer or hourly signal+ Alarms default setting is to go off one time, so one doesn't have to manually go in and cancel them in order for them not to go off every day afterward- Bulky, thick- No multifunction alarm= Not atomic, but has the top level +/- 15s per month accuracy spec= Not solar, but has a 5 year battery (CR2032; the big boy lithium coin cell)= Not available on Casio's nice, high-end Ti or steel braceletsI'm sure this will get less wear when winter sets in and I'm wearing long sleeve sweaters and coats, but for now it is great.I hope they release this module in a thinner,

I have them on my ERBE with the long suspension links for a bit plusher ride. They have slightly better forward traction than the stock Talons, and better turning traction, despite being narrower and easier to steer. Pro-Line seems to have picked just the right rubber compound; they don't last FOREVER like the rock-hard 2.8" Traxxas Talons, but they also grip pretty well.I use these on every surface except pavement with great success. I'm sure they'd work fine on pavement too, but with greatly reduced life.

This is a dive watch. The dial color is a beautiful cobalt blue. The hands are the right length. The red-tipped seconds hand adds some interest to the dial without making it too gaudy. It is 40mm in diameter, so not too big for those of us with smaller wrists, but not tiny for the fatter guys either.Day/date is handy, as always.Bracelet is solid stainless steel, 22mm, non-tapered. Quite heavy, and balances the watch head nicely on the wrist. The end links, where the bracelet meets up with the watch head is folded steel, but it doesn't seem to pull hairs, in this case.The one big disppointment with this watch is that the serrations on the timing bezel are overly polished, which makes it QUITE hard to turn. If you're not going to use the timing bezel, it's no big deal. But I use mine all the time, so it is a big disappointment to me.Compared to something like a Seiko SKX007, this watch has a nicer profile for everyday wear. It slips under the sleeve cuffs much more easily, due to its lower profile timing bezel. But that same thing can also be a weakness as shown here. They either need to make the bezel serrations sharper, or loosen up the tension on the bezel. As-is, one has to grab it tightly with the side of the finger and a big section of thumb to turn it, and even then, one's grip slips on it.

It is one of the few models to have a #1 Phillips, though it should be noted that its home is beneath the scissors, so it takes a few seconds to deploy. Both the #1 and #2 Phillips' are in-line too, (rather than T-handle on the back) so they can get into recesses most times.The file is quite sharp, as is the saw. In everyday suburban life, the file is more useful than the saw, but I have used the saw a few times to cut some plastic part down to size. It is thick and too heavy for pants pocket carry, so DO plan to buy a belt pouch along with the knife.It would be nice if Victorinox would give this model the heavy-duty locking flat screwdriver from the military models, instead of the medium duty one supplied on this and the rest of their line.The pliers should be thought of more as a heavy-duty tweezers; they can never be used for loosening a nut or something, but they're quite a lot stronger than the tweezers.The can opener works fine, as always with Victorinox, but I find myself using this implement more for the small screwdriver tip it has. I wish they'd just drop the can opener pretensions and give us a better mini-screwdriver. :)Can you see the little gray micro screwdriver next to the corkscrew in the picture? This is just the right size for eyeglasses and some screw bars on higher-end watch bracelets.In short, this is a good alternative to a Leatherman plier-based multi-tool for those who value easy access to a big tool set instead of a heavy-duty needlenose pliers. I use screwdrivers more than pliers these days, so I usually go with a Swiss army knife instead of a plier-based multi-tool.Last but not least, Victorinox quality is hard to beat. One side effect of that is that everything is really polished well, and on the screwdriver tips, this is not A Good Thing. They slip out of slots a bit easier than the ground Leatherman ones.None of those little nitpicks are enough for me to deduct a start from this fine multi-tool.
My 1-2 year old daughter loves this book. Something about having not too much text for her 5 second attention span and the bloated style of the characters is always attractive to her.

This watch has been made for at least 30 years now. I went for the chrome A158W, instead of the plastic F91W, which is the same watch, internally.I suspected the bracelet would be a hair-puller, and I was right. As a watch collector, I expected that, and I put a Swiss Army strap on it; much better. I really wanted the dressy chrome look on the watch head, and I figured I could dress it back up again in the future with a glossy lizard strap.The feature set, you can read about on Casio-USA's website, so I won't go into that much.The key things to note from ownership and use are as follows:+ Simple. Everything's easy to use and set if you take 2 minutes with the manual. If you're familiar with Casios, you won't even need the manual.+ Very light and thin. There's no other watch that packs this level of features and legibility into such a light package. When I'm wearing this watch, I forget that it's on, sometimes.- Hair-puller bracelet. OK for Asians, not so good for the rest of us.- No countdown timer. I miss this useful feature, but in many cases, the alarm can be used instead.+ Loud beeper. It is not sealed up so tight for waterproofness (this one's only rated as splashproof) that it makes the alarm notably quieter.- LED sidelight is barely adequate. There's a similar model with "Electro-Luminescence" that is no-doubt better in this regard. I knew that going in, but I felt the big blue "ELECTRO-LUMINESCENCE" banner on the watch face kind of ruined the 80s look of it. (yeah, I'm an nerd)In the long run, I use this as my back-up watch. I leave it in my desk drawer at work for those days when I forget to wear a watch leaving the house in the morning. This is the perfect watch for that duty, as it will run at least 7 years on a battery, if the alarm and light aren't used much.

I married a Chinese woman and brought her over to the US. One thing missing from the kitchen for her was a rice cooker. I had an older Black & Decker steamer that cooks rice, but it takes 45 minutes to do so.This one does it in half the time, and also holds it warm when done. The included rice spoon is good, as is the manual. It can also be used for steaming things in the included basket, though we haven't tried that yet.It is true that the rice on the bottom ends up being just a bit more stuck-together than the rest of it, but many people, including Chinese, actually PREFER that rice from the bottom. I'm one of those people. If you DON'T like this, then you may want to consider the spendy Panasonic cooker with "fuzzy logic". This is just a fancy way of saying thermostat-controlled, as opposed to weight controlled like this one.One last thing is that this cooker is UL Listed. Most of the lower priced cookers are ETL. UL Listing is becoming increasingly harder to find, as UL Listing is the premium 3rd party safety certification; it is one area that some manufacturers decide to cut costs to bring down the overall price of the product. I don't know about you, but I don't want cost-cutting in electrical and fire safety in my home appliances. It's like giving a pay cut to the mechanics at the airlines: there WILL be repercussions.

Posting now on this as a past purchase. I thought I would "upgrade" to a Pathfinder or Pro-Trek triple sensor model. Unfortunately, I found the barometer not to be useful for predicting weather, and I live in an area with very little elevation change.This watch skips the barometer/altimeter sensor, but retains the more useful compass and temperature sensor.Even if you don't use these two features at all, the watch is still a great value. The main display is very large and legible, and the sub-display shows the time of day even when you're in another mode. This is quite useful, when using the timer or stopwatch, for example. One can time one's activities and STILL see the time of day without having to switch modes.The backlight is not bright, but it doesn't really need to be, if you think about it. It lights up just the digits, but quite visibly in the dark.The buttons are big and easy-to-press, but the case is shaped so as to protect them from accidental actuation.The nylon band is extremely well executed. It is kind of stuff, but it is padded and sonically welded together. The holes for the buckle are melted through, so they won't stretch and cause the band to unravel. It is more comfortable than Casio's usual resin bands because nylon breathes with the wrist a bit better. Resin can be made to do this if shaped properly (and a lot of Casio bands are) but it doesn't take anything exotic on this. I'd like to see this band type on more Casios in the future.Over the last 30 years, I've had probably 30 digital Casios. Not because they need replacing, but because I'm always searching for that perfect feature set and comfort level. This one and the GD-350-1B are the top two so far. This one is thinner and has the compass, thermometer, and big display. The GD-350-1B has the Vibe Alarm and one-button access to the countdown timer from the home screen. (but is much thicker and twice the price)The one change I'd make to this watch would be to implement the thermometer sensor such that it can be use for instantaneous, on-the-wrist, temperature measurements. As it is now, I believe it uses the case back to stabilize readings, thus making it totally inaccurate unless it is taken off the wrist and left to sit somewhere for 20 minutes or so. As it is, it can still be useful, like for measuring different ambient temperatures in different places in the house. For example, in my apartment, I found that it can be 55 degrees in the bedrooms while it is 72 degrees near the thermostat. :-\
True story, but a real downer too. I'm always sad for Chinese people, even if their economy is doing well.

I was a little hesitant to pay so much (three eighty) for a quartz watch. But the combination of a reasonable size (38 mm case diameter w/o crown), solid titanium bracelet and case, and solar charging eventually won me over.The blue dial is just as pictured; a deep sea blue. Blue enough to look nice, but not at all flashy.The action of the timing bezel is nice; smooth and solid, but doesn't turn accidentally. The movement is very quiet. (Some cheaper quartz movements tick so loudly they can be heard across the room, and that is the sign of a cheap movement)The diving extension is not easy to use. Even after reading the instructions, I couldn't get it open after several minutes of trying.Also, at this price point, and as a Prospex series watch, it really SHOULD have a sapphire crystal.The issue with the diving extension is a non-issue for me, but the crystal may become an issue at some point, when I pick up some scratches. Seiko's Hardlex crystal is just hardened mineral crystal; steel, sand, and stones will scratch it. Not so with sapphire.I don't bang my watches around like I used to, but if I do scratch this, I'll just have the watchmaker replace it with a sapphire one.The bracelet is held together with pins and sleeves. It's quite easy to lose the little sleeves that make the pins fit snugly. If you DO lose them, the pins won't stay put afterwards. Be mindful of this, and you'll be OK. Screw pins would be better, and this isn't unreasonable to ask this of a watch in this price range.The titanium construction means that it feels as light as a plastic watch, but with the quality feel of a stainless steel one. It also feels warmer on the wrist than SS, and is hypo-allergenic. (Though I've never known anyone who is allergic to SS)All in all though, I love the watch. I'm just a bit nitpicky, as I'm a collector.

For the older digital cameras, they would not take SDHC cards, and the biggest SD card is 2 GB. So I picked up one of these for my old Canon SD600 Elph, after I kept getting memory card errors. It works a treat. Cheap price too. Between this and the Lenmar batteries, one can keep the old cameras going for a while, even after the OEM has dropped support for them.My poor old Elph has a ding in the case, one on the screen, and the anti-reflective coating on the screen is all scratched up. But it still takes good pictures, thanks to having aftermarket support like this.

The pieces that mate the canvas strap with the nylon lower strap are vinyl. It is functional, but just cheapens up the whole package. Everything else is super-nice. If they have to, I'd rather they charge a few bucks more and use leather. If I wanted vinyl, I wouldn't pay Domke prices.I picked this model, without swivels, so that when I fold the strap on top of the camera, (Pentax MX-1) it doesn't scratch it up.The woven in rubber tracks in the canvas are nice.

I had the Kitchenaid one before, and it was a little better. This one has its little nice touches, like the easy-grab handle on the blade.It has the reverse, to help keep things from sticking, but the way it works is that one has to hit one direction for a second, then the other, then forward, then reverse, etc. it clogs up easier than the Kitchenaid model.It is very easy to clean, and very powerful. If I were to buy it again though, I'd get the smaller, original Kitchenaid one over this.

With the above two buggies, their shorter wheelbase makes it so that they wheely if one puts too much power into them. With the Glamis Uno, it has a longer wheelbase and a bit heavier chassis, so it keeps the front wheels on the ground.The stock tires are quite good. The rears have better traction than one would think to look at them. The foams are pretty firm, and the wheels are beadlock, though that isn't a good thing, in this case. They break loose from the wheels regularly. With a power driver and 3mm hex bit, it is a quick fix, but by hand, it is quite tedious. After a few times, I glued them onto the wheels, and all has been well since then.The Dynamite Fuze 4-pole, 3300 kv motor is quite impressive. Nice strong magnets and very torquey. Quite a lot nicer than Traxxas' Velineon 3500 motor.There are little details here and there that lets a person know it is German. For example, the battery hatch on the bottom is a snug fit. On the face of it, that seems good. But when one takes it off to change batteries, one has to clean out all the dirt and sand from every little corner, or one cannot get it back on. Reminds me of the stories my grandpa told me about why the German Lugers were retired; too tight a fit for the dirty battlefield.Another example is the rubber boots that are provided to keep the shock shafts working clean. They really work too, the suspension action stays smooth, even when the car is filthy. The motor screws go through two elongated holes, so when adjusting the gear mesh, it is quite easy to get it precisely right. There is a roll cage around the transmission, and and most of the car. But to get the gear cover off only requires taking out a few screws in that area, and one bar of the roll cage just swings out of the way. Very elegant!The battery bay will accept long narrow batteries the best. For example, the Traxxas 3S, 25C, 5000 mAh is a good fit. The SPC 2S, 8200 mAh pack is about a PERFECT fit. The hardcase battery packs, where the leads exit the top, but can be bent horizontal through a little groove also work, but it is a bit of a trick to get the leads exiting right out the side, like they need to be for this car.The rear wheels/tires are kind of a strange size to me. Bigger diameter than 1/10 buggy, smaller than 1/10 monster truck and smaller than typical 1/8 buggy. They use 14mm hexes. I have a set of 2.8 Pro-Line Trenchers on the rear now, and the ribbed originals on the front. Looks goofy, but has good traction on a rocky beach.The ESC is not quite as impressive as the motor. The fan has a high pitched whine, which is not a huge deal. it runs faster with 3S than 2S. The instructions talk about lights, to help program it, but I could see no lights. Legend has it that one can see lights somewhere if the room is dark enough. That's a bunch of hoo-ha, if you ask me. The ESC also causes the motor to "beep", but weakly. One cannot barely hear the louder pitch over the fan noise, and one canNOT hear the quieter one over the fan. So I unplugged the fan to program it.The rear shocks are not sprung stiffly enough, even with two of the thickest preload spacers on each side. I replaced the springs with Traxxas red ones with white stripes, and with one thick preload spacer on each side, those are about perfect. Stock, it squats quite a lot under accleration, and only rebounds halfway up its stroke.It does not take a hit like a Traxxas though. Not quite as durable overall. Not fragile either, but not shockingly durable. When you have a crash where you'd expect something to break, it will break. It takes the basic flips and cartwheels in the grass and send with grace, but hit something hard, and something breaks. That's not so bad, but if you order parts from Horizon, they rape you pretty good for shipping. Best if your local shop stocks Vaterra.Roll-over crashes at high speed will break the wing mount, forcing you to buy a whole new wing kit. I did that once, but wound up not mounting it. I'll just drive it without the wing, even if it doesn't look as tough. The roll cage protects everything else back there well enough.Speaking of parts, this shares most chassis, suspension, and driveline parts with the Glamis Fear, which is still in production at the time of this writing. So if you're looking at buying a new old stock one of these, and you don't mind the styling of the Fear, that might be the one to get. I see the profiteers here have raised the price by a hundred fifty bucks since it went out of production for the US. To me, for two fifty, it was a screaming deal. For three hundred, it is still a deal. For three fifty, it is fair, but not an obvious choice. Four over four hundred: no thanks, I'd rather have 4WD at that point, even if it means a more demanding power system. This 2WD platform is as fast on 3S as a 4WD 1/8 buggy is on 5S. As always, it requires more skill and throttle discipline to drive well, compared to 4WD.Overall, it's a great car. I would buy it again, but not at the four hundred thirty bucks they were getting for them when they were in full production. Three to three-fifty is about what it's worth. Better than a Bandit VXL for three forty, that's for sure.

This is something that gets lit, then stays lit for maybe 30 seconds max. So it should NOT be hard to light, especially since sealing wax is 100% decorative these days.Maybe I need to do some wick-trimming, but that's a lot of darn work just for this. I'll be looking for another maker of these next time around.
It seems like a zany comedy when you watch the previews, but it has a remarkable amount of violent murdering and blood and action. There are many surprises too.

I'm surprised that an all-around company like Sony can do so many things so well. But they do. These sound as good as the more expensive Sennheisers they are replacing. The lead insulation isn't as tacky, so they don't get hung up on things like the Sennheisers did.I could deal with that alone, but I lost the rubber parts for specific fitting into the ear, and lost the spares too. It'd be hard and expensive to find replacements, so those are done, even though they work, audio-wise.Onto these. They come with a little rubber/plastic thing to wrap excess cord on, which is a nice touch. The inline volume control is kind of useless to me. It is just an attenuator. Why not just control the volume from the MP3 player/iPhone, and not have this unsightly tumor in the middle of the cord? I guess it could be handy when listening at your desk and the phone rings or something.The only thing I'd like to see different is for Sony to put it on their cord reel, like they have with their cheaper headphones. The one where you reel it in by cranking the wheel with one's thumb. Then, no tangle issues. The wrappy thing this comes with will have you twisting the leads as you wrap, rather than just pulling it straight on or off with no twisting.

LOVE this little gadget! We recently got two new laptops that are business models and lacked HDMI (boo). We knew the display port would be our hookup going forward and that we would need an adapter. Since we also needed DVI and VGA at times I started looking into some multi type adapters and hoped that one would work well (sometimes the more one thing does the less it does each thing successfully :)We've used this five or so times and each time it's been PERFECT - no issues, no jumping, no connection problems, a very very secure physical connection that can't come out with a bump or even a trip, and compatible with anything we have used. All connections have been perfect and we have tried each one a number of times, a few in use the entire day with some massive equipment.  The unit itself, while lightweight, feels nicely made and sturdy, and NOT a cheapo item that seems on the brink of a quick death with every use. Very impressed at the quality for an under $20 list price item! It's small enough to throw in the laptop bag and even tape down if you need for work etc.This is a great solution if you are like us and lack an HDMI, and/or have needs for these few connection types and want one unit to do everything. Can't recommend this enough, and at under $20 it's a steal - it performs like a $60 adapter would, which is very surprising as the market is flooded with a lot of low level computer accessories that fail.  Regardless of the fact that this was  test/review item, I can't recommend this enough - we will without a doubt purchase more of these if we need at any point down the line!Please note: Product received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

Not a bad protector at $7 or so, in this category they honestly are all very similar and are cheap enough to replace when you break them. Drops will at times break any glass so you can't fault one over another every time, but some do hold up a bit better than others even at the lower price point. This one is fine, but not the best of the many we have tried.The GOOD: Nice fit, as usual doesn't go to the edges due to the phone design, but it does cover the viewable area and I did not have trouble with bleeding or it not quite getting to the edge of the backlit part. You do have to be extra careful to get it just right, but with the little sticker things they include it isn't that hard. You get good at it after a while :) Smooth finish with no sharp edges, and held up well to a few falls so far.The BAD: I prefer the rounded bottom shape, this straight U shape is a little weird, but it's as minor issue (however I know there are some ultra picky phone accessory people out there like me :) It does have a slight bit of pulling at the edges, so the adhesion is maybe not as great as some others I have used. The photos with metal "drilling" into the surface is a little silly, all glass will help with impact but none are going to save phones from crazy pressure or crack from power tools etc :)Overall not a bad deal for $7 but there are some slightly better ones at the $10 and under mark, in my opinion.Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

These are a steal at around $30-$35 (it looks like some size/color combinations are even less) as they are well made and should last a lot longer than many other flip flop style sandals. KC Reaction puts out nice quality shoes for this price range and these are no exception.The GOOD: Looks great - lots of sparkle and a fun design on top, with a solid and sleek shape and look on the sole and sides. They look good dressed up or down, and while the stones are somewhat large and there are a good amount of them, it really isn't TOO much - good for casual around town outfits also. Feel and look like a great construction and while they are not padded, they hug the foot nicely - for most people without foot issues or a need for a soft insole, they will work. They do have a slight bit of height but they are not bulky or clunky (unless you prefer a very thin slight look.)The BAD: Ended up not keeping them only for one reason (and was disappointed because really do love the look and quality.) - the strap is placed a little too far back on the shoe. This is the biggest problem with flip fop style shoes, and Ive found it tends to happen more the higher the price is, strangely. I happen to have small feet with shorter toes, so if you have long toes it would not be an issue but there is just a lot of space at the ends for me which looks and feels strange. I'm a 6.5, and the 6.5 fits great - just about to the back, not too wide or narrow, and comfy on the mid part but just a lot of space in the toe area. I do have a lot of other flip flops and FF sandals, and almost none have this problem (although Tory Burch sandals all seem to have this too - it's definitely not just this brand.)I can't speak to the comfort over a long time as I didn't keep these, but when trying them on and walking for a minute they felt fine, and did not rub (and I'm pretty sensitive to that.) Again this will depend on your foot shape/size the same as with the toe issue.If they had fit me right this would be a 5 star, especially at under $30

Cute little kit - just the right size for those who need to sew a button / hem / hole here and there, but don't do much more than that so don't need a huge set. Good combination of things and they pack a lot into such a little pouch! I think 30 piece - all the colors you need, little tools etc, and just a very handy little kit. Great to travel with also and at this price can get a bunch.Nice that they included scissors as most little kits do not have them - we find tons of uses for them and they really come in handyThe only thing I would prefer (and this is really the case with all little kits) is 2 of the black spools and less of the random colors least used (yellow etc) - but that's how most kids at this price range come.Please note: Received at a discount in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

While the set came with all the right parts (pads, stickers, dust thing) it unfortunately did not match the listing "curved edge" - it's flat like most of the others on the market. Was a bit disappointed as I have tried a lot of the flat ones and was interested in seeing how this was different.The good - solid shiny white, if you like the matching look and have a white phone it will look nice. Fuller cut, so if you want more width coverage this will work. Comes with the accessories, and cutouts are accurate.The bad - not curved, cracked while applying (first in about 20 I've put on, and I'm super careful) and the wider edge can actually be a minus since dust and junk gets underneath, and it's easier to start pulling up or catch on something.Overall not a bad protector at a normal price, and a bonus if you want the white - but isn't curved as seems to crack a bit more than othersPlease note: Received at a discount in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

In fairness - this sleeve is very accurately described: "Reversible design allows you to turn over the sleeve for use according to different occasions.Slim and lightweight to carry, smooth to slide the sleeve into your backpack, briefcase or other bag. Special designed flap keeps your precious device securely inside."All of these things are true, and this is MEANT to be a thin lightweight layer - no bulk, no weight, and to protect from things like drips and scratches. It does all of this well and is a good fit for most 13 inch laptops (thought it won't be snug on them all, it fits well even with a bit of extra room)No, it does not give a huge thick layer of protection and wont prevent damage from rough handling, falls, crashes, etc etc. This would be ideal to use on a laptop that is regularly carried within another bag that has some padding, using the bag for more actual damage protection while using the sleeve to keep it covered when taking it out and moving it around, or when inside the bag pushed up against other stuffI prefer the zipper style as this is a little less easy to get in/out but it is secure and there is no zipper to break or get stuck, so that kind of evens it outNicely made for something that is $10 and looks/feels like it will hold up to regular use, no loose ends or weird stitching. The nature of the material will attract and hold on to lint and little pieces of "stuff" (see photo - this is after it was cleaned.) but it's not too bad, and many materials do this. Easy to remove with a piece of packing tape or lint brush.Please note: Received at no cost for testing/review purposes. All my thoughts are 100% honest and unbiased. Thanks :)

Grabbed a box on sale w/ S&S and when these are combined it's a good deal - we prefer scented bags but I can definitely see how it would be too overpowering for some. It does depend on if you have a covered can or  not too - ours is covered and snapped on pretty tight, so you don't really smell any of the scent or garbage at all until it swings open, and then only for a second. Anyone sensitive to smells woudl want to skip these kinds of products.Nice and strong and has held up as well or better than the other top brands for us (although we dont have a long way to go as our chute is about 10 steps away) Check the size before ordering - these seem to be taller than standard but not extra extra tall so if you have a can on the larger or  taller size but want to use a 13 gallon bag it will likely not go all the way to the bottom.

Everyone we know that has switched from the softer type flexible protectors to glass has liked glass better - it will chip from time to time but are very cheap to replace and well worth the sleek clear look that doesn't wear, and the extra protection. This one has lasted longer so far than the previous ones we've had on and that's a good plus - some will crack/chip at the lightest fall.Shiny, crystal clear look - very accurate fit and not too short side to side like others can be - it covers all of the lit up area and is not overly difficult to position - just be very careful and go slow.As I always warn people - DON'T touch any part of the sticky part or you'll never get it clear again. Gently hold it on the edges or with the little stickers some kits come with, place the top part down first lined correctly, then do the bottom. I go from top to bottom kind of holding the top pressed on at the edge while i line up the bottom and drop it quickly when it's right. You CANT take it off easily and replace (stickiness isn't always as good, dirt gets under, so go slow and make sure the first time is the only time!)We always make sure we have a bunch of extras just in case we mess one up or it craksPlease note: Received at no cost for testing purposes. All my reviews are 100% honest and unbiased. Thanks :)

Scent is subjective, so it's not that helpful to say "BEST" or "WORST" scent ever - I think it's more helpful to describe it in general. I love Coconut and Lemon and obviously anyone who does too would like this - it's a gentle scent, mostly lemon, and does not smell chemical-y. Really nice combo and i appreciate the benefits "Cruelty free, paraben free, polysorbate free, disodium EDTA free, gluten free, non-GMO verified, sodium laureth and lauryl sulfate free." HUGE bonus points for all of that!It does not lather as much as normal soaps but that's a well worth it trade off. You do need a bit more prroduct as well but probably not as much as you think. I did not have any problems with residue (we just use it on our skin so can't comment on it as a shampoo.)The only down side is that the pump is too short and dispenses too little - it's not the easiest to use with a puff, and you pump like 15 times to get a good amount out (first world problems, I know.) This is easily fixable and not relevant to the acutal product, thoughOverall a nice smelling scent and a product that works very well as a body wash in our opinion. Five stars with the pump fixed!I paid $12.89 and for the amount and that it's a natural product, it's a good price. We will buy again!

First - this is a LOT of scrub - we knew it was 16 ounces but still were suprised to see the amount and happy as it will last a good amount of time. Nice packaging and came secure and no granules in the box etc. Opening it for the first time we noticed a strong scent - menthol but in a good, fresh, softer way (if that makes sense.) I don't normally like a heavy menthol but this was actually nice and not overwhelming (but definitely strong!)TIP: Use a little bit in a hot sink with a towel over your head and it TOTALLY clears your nose when you're sick or just feel stuffed up.We got this mainly for us to use when we have tired and overworked feet (one of us is on them all day often.) Followed the directions and put a little extra in :) and it felt great, softened, relaxed - no it wont take away all your pain or fix more serious foot issues but for general relaxation and softening skin it's great. It does improved things like hard or cracked skin - follow up with a good peppermint foot lotion - and you will see improvement. Great for those like us who live in warm climates and live in flip flops half the time!Good price at under $12 - you got a lot for the money. Really like this and anything that's made in the USA also.Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own, good or bad.

This was the fourth dog shampoo we have tried and the only of the bunch that has a PUMP - huge bonus, especially when dealing with a dog that does not love the water or baths! The bottle is really nice - sleek/modern packaging and the pump is sturdy and works very well. Love the colors too.I will note (and one star taken off for this) that the ingredients are not ALL natural (as the title here says but the bottle does not)-- definitely some chemical-y sounding things in there, but I will say it's a solid step in the right direction. I don't mind things saying natural, but the "all" should go in this listing. Of course it's up to use to read labels and be diligent about choosing what works for your pets also. If you need 100% natural/organic etc this wouldn't be your best choice, but if your pet isnt sensitive or allergic to anything it would be more than fine. Did not seem to irrirate her eyes when the soapy water got in them which is nice.As far as the cleaning - it worked with a normal amount of product, not the double that we somestimes have to use with natural things. Points for that.  We both thought this one smelled good - not overpowering - and as usual with natural products, not that much lather (kind of used to it by now.) Got some gunky spots out and some caked on dirt around the paws, and overall did a solid job.At $11 and change for 16 oz in a nice looking pump bottle with some natural aspects - I feel it's a very good deal. Woudl recommend to all except those who have pets that need 100% natural/no chemicals at all.Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own, good or bad.Also like that it's made in the USA - love to support companies like this!Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

Great deal for $13.00 - much easier to use and more secure than some of the others styles (coil ones, zip ties, etc - ones that are impossible to adjust or add to later on!) This is a good length at 40 inches and a great deal as it's a two pack! You can insert/remove at different points and the flexibility is great, enouhgh to be firm but with a good amount of give to make it easy to maneouver.The white is great if you have white walls so you can barely tell it's there, and you dont have a thick black blob snaking around your desk :)It's fully customizablel to any length and easy to cut - this is a big bonus over many other management systems and looks more customized.An added bonus is their two year warranty. Definitely recommend this one for your cable needs!Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

The 5th or 6th dog shampoo we have tried and like this one a lot - does not lather as much as the others (generally the case with more natural products) and I do feel you have to use a slight bit more (again not uncommon in this category) but other than that it works nicely and does a thorough cleaning job, leaves a fresh natural scent, does not irrirtate eyes or my hands, and of course the more natural the product, the more comfortable we are using it on our pets :) It's a good quality product and at a little higher priced due to the "natural" factor, its a good deal.Also like that it's made in the USA - love to support companies like this!Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

Cute pair of socks - we love the short style and they stayed put without sliding down as some pairs do. A bit on the thin side but terribly, they do seem nicely made and have washed up well so far. We use these for around the house socks and not for long days at work or at the gym etc, and they have been great for that purpose.Great colors too - different from the standard white or black! Fits a M size 10.5 well and snug but not too small - may be too smal for a M 12 or similarly large foot.Please note: Received a pair at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

BEST whole grain pasta brand by far! It's not easy getting everyone to eat this stuff but this is actually good. No, it won't taste like white pasta but you will either like it right away understanding that,, or get used to it quickly and at least not hate it. With some good spices and ingredients and maybe some protien it really is a good choice and healthy swittch to make. We have tried all of the brands and this one is our favorite by far for whole grain pasta.Price on here tends to be a big high, though there are sales/coupons from time to time. Also depends on your specific grocery store, of course. But one less thing to put on the list and shelp home is a good thing :)

First thing  -we got this for $79 at another store, and feel this is what it is worth - not the $100+ that it's listed for here and other places. Once you are over $100, you can certainly get one of the more well known brands (Panasonic etc).At $79, it is a good deal. Microwaves tend to give out just before the warranty is up, and are really tough to service (heavy, big, not user serviceable) so it really is one area where it's worth it to spend more and get something a bit more dependable or with better warranty terms. In the end, we returned this after a month or so mainly because it was too hard coming from something a little larger and a more powerful (came from a 1.2 1200 watt one) Other than that we would probably have kept it. If you are on a budget and want something decent this would not be a bad choice.This would be best for light use for 1-2 people or a small family that does not count on this for too much.  It's large enough for a full plate but overall a slight bit smaller than what I would say the average microwave is. For us at least, it fit nicely in a corner, wasn't a bulky eyesore, but still had enough capacity for basic stuff / a normal sized plate. Power is maybe a bit under average which can be okay for some, but for others like us who are used to more power hard to adjust to. Not the unit's fault, but important to note if you are coming from something stronger or larger. Most standard options on this one but no frills or extras.It does look nice and sleek - combo of black and silver is nice without being a stainless overload. Love the handle - so much easier to open and then you don't get fingerprints everywhere (wooho!) Nice huge buttons for start/30/stop, and it's really easy to clean and wipes down well.3 cons - no rubber feet on the bottom - we fixed this by taping four small squares of grippy pads under the feet - the stuff you put under rugs. Without this, if you have a slippery surface the whole unit might move when you open the door. Also, when the door is open 70%-100% it does not stay open..it slowly swings back. If you open it partially it does stay, but most people do open it more than that. Also, it is a bit louder than average, not a huge deal but kind of "sounds cheap" if that makes sense - none of our other 'better" brands sounded like this.All that being said, for a nice looking unit that has most functions you would want and a handle - $79 is a good deal. Some of the other stores offer a few years of warranty for $7 or so which allows for a very easy/quick replacement and lets you avoid the long, annoying, shlep of bringing this in or paying for shipping to the manufacturer - I would suggest getting that if you do buy this one.

Great cable - exactly what we needed and did the job for a recent event. No issues with connection, fit or anything like that. It does feel slightly lightweight/plastic-y but that is pretty much the standard for items around this price point. Hopefiully it will continue to last and not fail prematurely - will update if it does. So far, so good though and it has worked well for all of our needs. Would recommend this one for sure :)Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

I agree with many of the other reviewers - VERY soft, and appears to be constructed nicely for this price point -- if a little bit on the thin side - but it's just way too short in the front. I'm on the short side and nothing is ever short on me :) The front is going to be way too short for anyone with a chest larger than around a B cup, unless you are very short waisted and/or like the short look. It rode up way too much on me which is the first time that has ever happened and I own a number of shirts like this. The photo shows it hanging a lot longer than it does even taking into account different body types...Probably would be fine on someone very petite/thin/small bust and who orders a size up. Otherwise, the fit becomes a bit strange. While I like how soft it is, and at the $15 price point it's not a bad top - it just fits too weird on any other body types :(Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

I paid $11 and change for this binder which I think is an absolute steal. I needed something for a speech and it had to have rings, pockets, and not be ugly. The padfolios didn't have rings and the regular binders looked horrible, so I was happy when I saw this. At this price range (under $25, seems to be a little over $20 right now.) this was a great choice!It's a navy denim-ish look texture (but is plastic) and is about as cute as a binder can get with this material and at this cost. Not sure how the other colors will look but dark always helps inexpensive items look a lot better so I would suggest going with the navy. (Neutral too so will blend in and go with any outfit :)It has the pockets and a card holder in front, and the binder rings are 1 inch. Great size and not too big - I had maybe 15 page protectors in it with 2 papers in each and a few pages of photo paper and there was more than enough room for lots more. It's a nice construcion and the rings worked perfectly, and it has a slight bit of weight but is still light enough to hold for a while if you're giving a speech or something. Feels better than a normal binder for sure.Only thing I would have preferred is if the elastic on the outside came off - it was hanging awkwardly during use but of course a non issue if you don't need to use it for presentations or speeches. On the other hand, it won't get lost since it's attached so that's good :) Probably not really a con for most people who get this but just wanted to mention it.I would definitely buy this again even at a higher price, though keep an eye out for sales as it does go down from time to time. Really good purchase

Have been using this cable as a backup/extra/travel cable for about 2 months now and it's performed extremely well. Of course you always an an mfi cerfitied cable if you aren't buying Apple but even some certified ones can work terribly. At $8 this is a great deal and there is no reason to keep buying more Apple cables at full price!It has fit without any problem in our various cases - Speck, Otterbox and Spigen. The base on either end is very similar if not identical to the Apple ones so most people won't have problems using it with cases etc. There has not been any wear or tear near the lightning end yet which is the main issue with cables like these in general. Of course we don't use it every day so I can't speak to very high amount of use but I will update in another few months if any wear starts to happen. This is just inevitable with most cables so nothing new, but some do hold out much longer than others. Also, have not gotten any error messages about not being compatible and we have used it with 4 devices so far so that is a nice plus.Overall a solid certified replacement cable that is a steal at $8.00 - would higly recommend this one.Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

We love these - got introduced to them by accident from a friend who needed the low sugar and kept buying them for ourselves. Do not taste weird like some others and appreciate the better ingredient list - definitely a step up from some of the similar products on the market. Cases always come fresh and well packaged/sealed.Only downside is the price - $32-$40 ish for a case of $24. If they brought them down to $1 a bottle that would be ideal :)

Usually love Speck cases and have had a number of them over the years - good mix between protection and a nice look - but this one falls short.As many others have said - the case does NOT flay flat. Not sure why but the 6 version is made with a little hump as mentioned and it spins around. Seems trivial but with a device we all use a lot of the day it can get annoying, plus it wears the case down in that area. I type a decent amount when it's laying flat so it's more noticeable to me (others who rarely lay it down like that may not care) and I had to return it.I did try the Candyshell grip which helps mask this (the case is the same, but the grips make it a little more even and grip the surface enough so no spinning, so it's mostly fixed.) Not the prettiest case but it's not bad and the grip is a great feature, it does help with texting when your hand is on the small side.I'd suggest going with the grip or something else if you lay it flat often, if you don't then this would be a great case for you as the rest of the case is a good one - nicely made, good cutouts, moderate protection and some good colors.The price if just under $20 for the black one is a good one though as the retail is $35 (imo a bit high) Warranty is solid for a year though.

The good - its a cute bottle, modern and I like the clear/black combo - looks nice if you keep these kinds of things out.  Pump works well, and the product is nice smelling and not sticky or goopy like some others are. It's as pleasant texture and scent and really works well. It works great for everyday use and I've tried it with some heavier messes (after cooking, planting etc) and while it does take a little more product, it has gotten off everythinThe bad - it is overpriced at around $15 ish. As others have mentioned, store prices for this size are around $5, so there is a huge difference. The bottle is worth a little more but not 3x times as muchOther than that really like the product and it feels, smells and looks good - would definitely recommend this one.Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

While this Spigen case is defnitely is not massive/rugged or anything that will offer a huge amount of protection - its one layer of TPU will help prevent marks/scratches etc give a light level of protection. If this is what you need it's a great case.It is a somewhat thin (but not the thinnest around) slightly slick TPU, with a thin layer frame of plastic (a little flimsly in my opinion, but fits well and secure when installed.)  The back does have the "industrial" look as listed but the finish/feel is a little slippery overall.  Spigen consistently makes well thought out and well produced cases easpecially when it comes to the accuracy and finish of the cutouts and this is a good quality nicely made case - just keep in mind it's light protection and not for anyone clumsy or who is hard on their phones.It will work with screen protectors (suggest the tempered glass ones.) Also easy to take on and off so that is a plus.At the current price of $16 it's a little high but I know these usually go up and down and many of the Spigen similar ones are $10-$12 ish which is priced right. They do have great CS and warranty service so that is defnitely a plus over some other less known compaines.Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.

We have sheets that fit mattress/combo heights up to 18 inches, however ours is around 15 inches - meaning lots of loose fabric left over, especially after a few days of use. Which sometimes results in a shifting of the pad and a bit of an annoying task of moving and refitting everything every morning (first world problems, I know!) We have tried 3 sets of fasteners - each a little different, and happen to like all 3 but these are probably the easiest to get on and off as you switch sheets.Very easy to use and hold tight, but do not tear (so far) anything.Stretch but are nice and firm so you aren't doing all of this for nothing  -some tend to hold but very lightly, these are really secureHold up well over time, no fraying or breaking or holes or anythingMaybe a few dollars over the normal price for a set of 4, but the fact that they are sturdy and hold up over time makes it worth it :)Please note: Received at no cost in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. All thoughts are 100% my own.
