3-1/2* Review - First of all this is a very long book, and the beginning I found to be very slow.  It starts out with the heroine, Emma Elliott being killed in an accident, and suddenly found in a very mist covered version of London.  Emma is approached by Father Eamon who does his best to explain to her that she is dead and she must accept that fact and come with him to the Sanctuary.  (All of this is then explained during their long walk).  In the Sanctuary, she even meets friends she’d known but had lost contact with over the years.Fr. Eamon explains to Emma that she is in-between planes; he is her guardian; and she has a quest she must complete to decide which way she could spend her future in (think good vs. bad).  What Fr.Eamon doesn’t explain to Emma, until much later in the book, is that she is a very special person who could definite the world in a big way.  While working to complete her task – after so many forays out of the Sanctuary to complete this mission Emma couldn't help but notice people  staring at her and some even frightened by her!  It takes some time though before she discovers the reason as to just how special she actually is.What was interesting was how she could cross the planes from being noticed in that misty plane to the present day where people could walk through and not see her.  As the book progresses she learns more things which only lead to more and more questions and Fr. Eamon didn’t seem too keen on giving Emma all the answers.The character of Emma was okay, but I never got that warm fuzzy feel I generally get with a lead character I really like.  It’s possible that the slower pace of this book was a bit of a turn off, and some of the relatively graphic descriptions of some of the monsters, and plague victims were really not to my taste.  Unfortunately, I found this tome very hard to get through.  The ending was very good, but let me just say I was happy to get through it.Bottom line:  Writing was very good, it just wasn’t my cuppa and the slowness and long length made it tough to finish.Marilyn Rondeau

In the past, as 15 year old youths, Vander, the future Duke of Pindar and Emilia “Mia” Gwendolyn Carrington the daughter of Vander’s mother’s lover were thrown together at different functions.  Mia had developed a crush on Vander and had written a poem (not very good either) to him.  As it turned out Vander got a hold of it and he and his school chums read it and they had great fun spinning it in a decidedly boorish and disgusting translation.  Unfortunately, they did this in the library where Mia had been sitting hidden from sight as they totally tore into it.  Finally, having heard enough of their disgusting comments Mia came forth; told the boys off and told Vander she wouldn’t marry him if he were the last man on earth.Years later, Vander has become the Duke, and Mia has come into her own.  Mia has a dowery, but more importantly, she has a career as a writer of fabulous romance novels that is paying her very well.  However, ins spite of all that, Mia has come to the Duke of Vander’s home to ask him a great favor, she asked him to marry her.  Vander was aghast - not only was this out of the blue but he had no intention of marriage and certainly not to the daughter of the man who openly cock holed his father.  But Mia was desperate, she needed this marriage but not for her benefit.  She needed Vander to marry her in name only, for a year at most so she could obtain guardianship of her nephew, Charles Wallace.  And if took blackmailing Vander to accomplish it, so be it!Stubbornly, Vander never read the provisions which explained what Mia expected with their marriage but with his back against the wall - Vander counters with his own provisions stating he would spend only 4 nights a year with her and only if she begs for them! However shortly after the marriage, things changed and Vander decided he must work on seducing his own wife!What follows is another profoundly and brilliantly executed historical romance from the always exceptional pen of Ms. Eloisa James, who has personally given me so much pleasure from reading her marvelous Desperate Duchesses series.  Her brilliant dialogs give this story great humor and I loved Ms. James use of chapter intro’s using Mia’s notes of an author plotting her for her latest novel’s storyline.  Very cleaver and quite amusing!Bottom Line:  I’ve never been disappointed with Ms. James effervescent wit, fabulous plotting and wonderful storytelling.  A winner every time!Marilyn Rondeau

Ousted from his family home in France, Lord Philippe Lavay took to the high seas armed with charm as lethal as his sword and a bold determination to restore his family’s fortune and honor, no matter the cost.  Victory was within his reach until a brutal attack snatched it from his grasp and lands him in Pennyroyal Green to recuperate.For Elise Fountain, an afternoon of bliss brought a cascade of consequences where she was shunned by her family and ousted from a job she had loved.  Her fall from grace and down the social ladder led to a position no woman has been able to keep for very long;  housekeeper to a frighteningly formidable prince.  Fortunately, for Elise she sees past his battered body and into Philippe’s barricaded heart… and her simmering sensuality ignites his blood.  Now Philippe, who thought he could never love, and Elise who thought she would never trust again were in a quandary over a passion they could not deny.*** Once again Julie Anne Long has brought to life another romantic and beautifully scripted love story in her Pennyroyal Green Series that left me breathless.  Here was an old plot theme but under the masterful and creative pen of Ms. Long it was made exquisitely beautiful and fresh.  Long’s characterization of Elise who understood what even Philippe hadn’t figured out what he needed to be comfortable in his own home was perfection.  Elise and her charming young son were beautifully portrayed; but how Elise took the bull by the horns in turning around the slovenly and disrespectful household staff that had established themselves in Philippe’s manor house was brilliant!Simply everything about this story was rendered beautifully by the brilliance of Ms. Long’s wonderful writing and Philippe’s declaration of love to Elise simply brought great tears to my eyes.“I thought I needed everything I once had… I thought I owed it to my family to preserve it as it was. But the only thing that gave those places meaning was love. …. All the memories  I wish to keep were comprised of love.  And home is anywhere you are…”I don’t know about you but this was one of my more memorable reads.  I love when an author can move me so emotionally by words alone.  To me that is always worthy of my rating in the five star range!Bottom line:  Ms. Long’s Pennyroyal Green Series has been nothing short of awesome and IT STARTED WITH A SCANDAL is just one more reason that it has become such a favorite of mine!  Highly recommended.Marilyn Rondeau

Julia, the Duchess of Colton has been patient enough and now it is time for action.  Eight years ago she was married to the Duke of Colton’s heir - not only was he two sheets to the wind, barely looked at her but left immediately after the service for parts unknown.  Gone from sight but tales of his escapades and the nickname of the Depraved Duke forced Julia to make a monumental decision.Julia was now in desperate straights and had to do something before she is out on the streets. Beginning with hiring London’s leading courtesan to learn her most intimate secrets; pretend to be a courtesan herself and travel to Venice to find her husband; and lastly seduce said husband, conceive an heir and secure her future.*** This is my very first example by newer author Joanna Shupe.  Personally I couldn’t be happier that this is the first book in what I surmise is going to be a fabulous new series entitled Wicked Deceptions.  Believe me it was not only a pleasure to discover this new author and her first book being so cleverly  creative and interesting that I cannot wait to continue on with her series.I loved the way Ms. Shupe fleshed out her characters with understandable motivation for the abhorrent way the Duke of Colton treated his wife.  Yes, it was terrible what he did, and how he just disappeared from Julia’s life never bothering to discover how she was getting on – especially knowing what a bitter and miserable mother and mean father he had left Julia with.  Colton had no excuse for being so arrogant and unforgiving of the innocent bride he left behind.  For that reason, I was cheering Julia aka Ms. Juliet Leighton her plans to seduce and get herself pregnant by her husband.Not to give to much more away, THE COURTESAN DUCHESS was a splendid read, with plenty of surprises, wonderfully touching sensuality,  and wonderful secondary characters some of which were so wonderful I can’t wait to read their stories; and some so miserable that they deserved everything they got in the end.Bottom line:  THE COURTESAN DUCHESS was a fully robust and engaging read I can highly recommend and hope to continue this series and following this author.Marilyn Rondeau

I have come to love the gentle and beautiful stories that have evolved from the pen of Ms. Linda Hays-Gibbs and FROST FLOWER, the first book of her Frost Flower series promises to be as beautifully rendered as all of her other beautiful novels.This is the story of Lady Lina, the daughter of a Duke who thought his baby girl was perfection, however everything she did, how she looked, walked and talked must be perfect as well or she would be severely and horribly punished by her father. Because of how she had been trained from birth to act, she was isolated; shunned by her peers; and labeled an “Ice Princess”.Unfortunately, Lady Lina doesn't trust men, having been mistreated her entire life by the people who should have loved her – her parents. She decided it was because of all her flaws as she couldn’t speak without stuttering (so she didn’t speak in public); and didn’t smile because she thought her one crooked tooth was horrible.Lord Baltimore took one look at Lady Lina’s ethereal beauty and fell in love, but soon after because of the rumors of Lady Lina’s arrogance, he was led to believe they were true.  After all could the beautiful Lady Lina see in him, after stumbling in their waltz and knowing that at any time he could lose his leg.What follows is a superb story of two very broken individuals who began a slow road to friendship and understanding, almost to the point of a long awaited marriage proposal. But as always the road to happiness almost never runs smooth and a traitorous act of kidnapping and a loss of memory  could very possibly destroy both their chances at a happily-ever-after ending.Bottom Line:  Creative, emotional, and brilliant writing are just some of the things one can look forward to with Ms. Hays-Gibbs FROST FLOWER.  And as the first book in her new series I can only hope she continues along this same vein for a long time to come.Marilyn Rondeau

After reading this cute, quick and captivating read - I sincerely wish I had started with the first book in the Montgomery Brothers series.  The whole concept is so cute and unique using not a woman matchmaker but an older gentleman who is the ‘Uncle’ of the Montgomery boys.  The entire concept is really delightful with strings being pulled in the background as the author builds a very credible background with Selena Ainsley and James Montgomery’s history.  In this she paints the  motivations behind our two protagonists.  Once Selena and James had been deeply in love, planning to marry until an accident threw a wrench in their plans.  Now each held the other responsible for their 10 year alienation. Naturally no one could deny that Selena and James weren’t too proud and too stubborn to find one another to work things out!  Hence - Uncle William decided to step in and take things in hand.RETURN TO YOU by Samantha Chase is simply the best kind of entertainment to curl up and enjoy a sweet romance become viable again after a long and lonely existence both Selena and James had spent apart.  With a lot of hard work Selena had grown her event planning business into a very successful enterprise, which made her best friend Jen (recruited by Uncle William) able to coerce Samantha back home to help plan a Ten Year School Reunion, which was Step One in at least bring these two protagonists back in the same city.Toss in a nuisance stalker who was harassing Selena’s best friend Jen, and the fact that James just happened to be the chief police detective and let emotions get stirred up a bit after they lay eyes on one another – then just let nature take its course.Bottom line:  A delightful romance and I’m looking to backtrack and also put future books on my auto-buy list!  Great writing and great story - highly enjoyable.Marilyn Rondeau

I’ve read many of M.J. Rose novels to date and I have much admired her prose and Gothic type stories.  Reading the description of THE WITCH OF PAINTED SORROWS, I knew that mixing a couple of my favorite genres, historical with a bit of paranormal, ghosts and witchery, I was full of anticipation.In 1890, Sandrine Salome is witness to a violent argument between her husband and father overhearing the gist of how her husband had been embezzling from her father’s bank and signing false documents in his name.  The shame of the scandal was too much for her father and the following day she discovered her father had killed himself.  Fearing her husband, and as soon as she could, Sandrine packed her bags and fled to her grandmother’s home in Paris, France, only to find that her grandmother had left the house Sandrine had grown up in for another house she was renting in Paris.What followed were secrets and lies where her grandmother did her best to keep Sandrine away from the infamous house where their ancestress the, famous courtesan La Lune once reigned.  Sneaking into the house which her grandmother said was being remodeled Sandrine met a young architect Julien Duplessi whom her grandmother had hired to turn the house and it’s valuable antiquities into a museum.  Sandrine seemed taken with Julien.  And the longer Sandrine stayed on the premises she felt more alive, powerful, sensual and welcomed.  As it turned out the house was haunted by La Lune, her evil ancestress and powerful witch who needed Sandrine as a host to control, find love and continue her passion of painting.As stories go, this was compelling and intriguing, but I just couldn’t get myself to truly like Sandrine the more she was overtaken by La Lune.  Her lies and deceit with her grandmother whose only sin was to try and protect her really turned me off.  Sandrine and her relationship with Julien was at first innocently romantic enough but as time when on it lost it’s appeal and was no longer romantic. [Probably wasn’t meant to be.]Unfortunately, I did not truly enjoy the story.  I struggled through the story but towards the end it became very rushed and abrupt where I had no sense of where it was going.  In my mind, it went completely off track leaving a lot of issues hanging.  Sandrine got involved with the occult in the underpinnings of Paris; gets practically buried alive, but is naturally saved. Her husband finds her grandmother in a mental institution who then gave him the address of Sandrine’s lover Julien.  The husband challenges Julien to a duel; then gets shot and killed.  There is another bit that follows but it would reveal too much.  Suffice it to say that other than the gorgeous cover, this was not a favorite and I’m afraid I can only give it a very low rating.Marilyn Rondeau

The crash of a Dallas-bound jet not only changed the existence  of TV reporter Avery Daniels; but altered her entire life giving her a chance to make a comeback in her career.  At first it wasn’t something Avery had planned but as the days of recuperation and surgery continued where she could not speak to correct her mistaken identity, she learned of a plan to assassinate her supposed husband, a famous senatorial candidate Tate Rutledge.  Following her surgeries and recuperation  in the hospital, Carole as she was now being called, was torn between telling Tate the truth or trying to identify the killer.  One thing for sure - she knew the killer had to be a part of his immediate family.One might wonder, why Avery didn’t come clean as soon as she could speak but as the story evolved there were many reasons, why she couldn’t.  One, she was beginning to care for Tate, in spite of his private disgust of ‘Carole’; two, she was worried about Carole’s fragile child Amanda; and three she didn’t know who was plotting against Tate.  If she confessed, the killer would have to eliminate her.What more can be said of Sandra Brown that hasn’t already been said?  Her plotting, twists and turns, red herrings, deep characterizations and non-stop action rate this author at the top of the plateau of amazing suspense/thrillers.  To start a novel by Ms. Brown is to settle in for the long-haul to finish because she writes heart-stopping thrillers that keep a reader totally engrossed with her fast action stories.MIRROR IMAGE was one of those non-stop reads and seeing as how I listened to this on audio narrated by the always great Dick Hill, one can understand why I always took the long routes to listen longer in my car.  If I were to nit-pick just a bit it would be that his interpretation of one of the female characters tended to grate on my nerves – otherwise, I will state that Dick Hill is one of my favorite narrators and I will always gravitate to the audio books he records.Bottom line:  Sandra Brown’s  MIRROR IMAGE may be one of her older titles but her mastery of story-telling is exceptional.  Highly Recommended!!Marilyn Rondeau

The only thing I can say about this latest volume in Christine Feehan’s Ghostwalker Series is that she dazzled me again, and I hope she never stops writing these stories!  Her story plotting of what a crazy, immoral and mad scientist puts human children through to create the ultimate soldier are simply amazing!  With VIPER GAME - not only has Feehan developed a new strain of DNA experimental children and their mother, but she has also introduced new characters from the Fontenot family, i.e. the eldest brother Wyatt and his team of  Ghostwalkers who have presented to my mind, a whole new slew of stories for the amazing talent of Ms. Feehan to develop.With VIPER GAME we are introduced to Pepper, who was programed and experimented on to be an assassin, albeit as it turned out a very reluctant assassin; so she was listed as a failure and scheduled to be disposed of.  However, before that happened she escaped along with Ginger, a small child, who as it turned out was actually her child, born from her egg and - yup - Wyatt Fontenot’s  sperm.  Just another planned experiment by the madman Dr. Whitley.Not only did Pepper have the ability to kill with venom secreted in her saliva, but the baby toddler Ginger, could kill with a bite from the venom secreted in her tiny fangs.  It was one thing to keep Pepper and Ginger safe from the soldiers searching for them, but then Pepper let Wyatt know that Ginger had two other sisters [triplet little vipers] - and naturally Wyatt and his team had to storm the prison they were kept to rescue them all!Bottom line:  Classic Ghostwalker adventure, hot and sizzling sex, and the most amazing characterizations that come from the creative mind of Christine Feehan!  Fabulous as always!Marilyn Rondeau

He was the son of one of the most notorious serial killers, and whether that had decided his career choice, homicide detective Thomas “Veck” DelVecchio, Jr. had grown up in the shadow of evil.  Today, he balances between good and evil as he tracks another vicious serial killer, and battles his subconscious to arrest, saving the state the bother of a long trial, or just kill the slime himself.  After tracking him down, Veck seemed to blackout then found his quarry mangled beneath his feet.  Veck was totally confused but did the right thing and called 911 – not sure whether he had ripped the man apart or not.Assigned to monitor Veck is Internal Affairs officer Sophia Reilly, who is fighting her professionalism with the fact that she finds Veck blindingly sensual.  While both fight a damaging professional attraction, another complication enters into the mix; Jim Heron, a mysterious stranger with another agenda that has Veck teetering on the edge of eternal damnation unless Heron can help him make the right decision.Once again, Ms. Ward has penned another delicious entry into her Fallen Angels series as angel Jim Heron fights for souls in a contest of good vs. evil.  So much is at stake and the action and story is fast and palatable keeping the reader/listener on the edge of their seat.  The good people, angels and humans are wonderful, and the evil forces are chilling and very sinister.  Ward is a master at this game and the plotting, writing, characterizations, and the twists and turns were as always amazingly good.Having a vast library of Audible tomes, I must also congratulate the narrator Eric Dove on a fabulous job of mastering all the voices involved and the pacing of the telling of this story.  This was again a most fantastic listening experience to the fabulous writing of Ms. J.R. Ward.  Outstanding!Marilyn Rondeau

Surviving the Napoleonic Wars, Sir Benedict Harper for the last six years has struggled mightily to heal both body and soul.  Benedict retained his legs despite the doctors never expecting him to walk again, but he has struggled and in pain and perseverance has managed to surprise everyone.  After the yearly reunion of the Survivor’s Club the men and woman have left to return to their lives.  Benedict choose to visit his sister who was recuperating in the country, never realizing that in doing so, he would meet a beautiful woman who would give him purpose.Samantha McKay has dutifully cared years for her ailing husband, another mishap from the wars, until his lingering death.  For months she has been bound to her house by the oppressive presence of her prudish and spinster sister-in-law whose outlandish ideas of proper mourning are suffocating Samantha.Meeting Benedict who made a horrendous first impression actually turned out to be very fortuitous for Samantha, once he apologized and introduced his sister, Samantha’s neighbor to help bring some sunshine into Samantha’s closed off world.  While both Samantha and Benedict gave each other the benefit of doubt to one another, they formed an easy alliance and when Samantha was ordered to return to her miserable in-laws, she remembered a property that was left to her in the wilds of Scotland.What follows is the memorable journey Samantha and Benjamin took to her new home, and a journey of discovery for both Ben and Samantha as only Mary Balogh could have depicted with the most sensual and exquisitely sumptuous writing that offered an almost surreal quality to it.  Couple that with the amazing performance by esteemed narrator, Rosalyn Landor and you will find yourself totally suspended in time as the story unfolds in a most exquisite way.THE ESCAPE is totally worth the credit and the time to listen to this wonderful tale.Marilyn Rondeau

First of all - I loved WICKED, MY LOVE - it had a great story, it was sensual and the dialogues were oftentimes outrageously funny!  For myself - I totally loved this and read it in one sitting!The protagonists began early in childhood with a very hateful relationship.  Thrown together because of their father’s great friendship and affection for another they were still from different stations in life. Randall a young Viscount was destined for politics.  Isabella was a manufacturers daughter. Wanting to impress her father Isabella had studied finance was enormously bright.  Having lost her mother at an early age Isabella was brought up by a devoted Mary Wollstonecroft feminist follower and oftentimes this precocious, and brainy 8 year old spouted out some very enlightening and humorous information to her childhood friend.  (As an example - how babies were conceived)Childhood aside our two protagonists grew up with each assuming their desires, his in politics and hers now running her father’s bank with Randall being a equal majority stock holder.  Naturally neither could stand one another and their dialogs were still snipes at one another, that is until a disaster of masterful proportions threatened both Isabella’s bank and Randall’s political career.What follows is a hilarious alliance of these two foes that ended up with each other finally looking beneath the surface of their love/hate relationship.  Nothing more can be said except, you won’t be sorry you picked up WICKED, MY LOVE by Ms. Ives.  It was simply Wickedly Good!Marilyn Rondeau

4-1/2*  MARRIED TO A PERFECT STRANGER was definitely not what I was expecting when I picked this up.  It didn’t follow the norm of the hero coming home from time away to discover a wife as a femme fatale.  No, it was much more subtle in the changes that both protagonists had made over the two years apart.After one month of marriage, Mary’s husband John set sail for China with the trade commisison.  With shy Mary left behind her family had sent her to care for an ailing and aged relative.  With no one else in authority, Mary had to learn to shoulder a huge responsibility for a household and grow a backbone.  In the meantime, her art skills which were an immense gift, came to the forefront where she herself was rather amazed at what she turned out.  It seemed that when she was capturing an image, Mary would not just capture the image of a person but would see beneath the surface and capture feelings and emotions.After John came home, now a man with purpose, he also noticed the changes in Mary – no longer the retired shy housewife but a woman who knew her own mind. Along with the change in his wife; a nasty coworker out to show John in the very worst light; and Mary’s gift of portraitures having a devastating effect on John’s hopes of advancement; along with a murderous plot to destroy foreign relations with China, and you have a very lovely and interesting read.Employing a delightful set of secondary characters to add depth and humor to the story, MARRIED TO A PERFECT STRANGER was a sweet, delicious morsel of writing.Marilyn Rondeau

In this last book of the Burrowes’ Sweetest Kisses series, we get to see the eldest Knightley brother find his soul mate.  Naturally we have met MacKenzie in the previous two books - strong, handsome and all that, but he’s always kept to himself.  Finally we discover the reasons for his self imposed celibacy.Sidonie Lindstrom is a foster mom who’s moved to the farmhouse where the Knightley brothers had grown up.  Sid is grieving the loss of her beloved brother, and worried sick that she might lose the Luis her foster son.  She has no love for lawyers, in fact despises them, so when Mac drives up in his blacksmith truck to help her out when she discovers two huge draft horses in her pasture, she was able to lower her defenses and allow Mac help her out and figured he was a nice solid guy.  Got along with her foster son; was not too hard on the eyes; and let herself more or less fall in love.Mac was very supportive and when the new DSS agent came around to inspect Luis and Sid’s home she was aware that this social service agent was nothing but trouble.  Mac agreed, and when the DSS agent implied that the property would not be a suitable place for foster care, Mac was Johnny-on-the-spot with getting the property set to rights with the help of neighbors and his brothers.Ms. Burrowes goes on to indulge the reader in another court case where good people have to challenge the foster care system and endless rules that are often not in the best interest of the children.  It also serves to show where a lot of the endless jokes of bad lawyers come from and that not all lawyers, should be judged by the one’s that drop the ball.Bottom line:  Burrowes develops strong characters, complex plotting, subtle humor and believable scenarios, that are refreshing with an eloquent voice.  What more could one ask for?Marilyn Rondeau

In a continuation of the Renegade Royal Books,  Ms. Kelley has brought to the forefront Captain William Endicott, a royal spy and illegitimate son of the Duke of York.  Will’s father has summoned him to investigate rumors of a planned assassination plot to which he believes an old friend of Will’s may be associated with.  The suspect - Will’s childhood sweetheart and best friend from long ago, Evie Whitney.  Knowing her as he once did, Will thought it highly unlikely the shy reserved young girl he once held in high regard would be capable of anything so nefarious.  However, years have past and what he does find is that young love-struck Evie has grown up  and apparently doesn’t want anything to do with him!*** In Vanessa Kelley’s series of the illegitimate children of the Royal family, most have been located and William Endicott, always striving for any kind of recognition from his father has been sent on a mission he truly doesn’t want.  Evie Whitney had been the light at the end of a tunnel for many a year during their childhood, and unfortunately, Will knew that he had hurt her when he refused her advances and broke her heart.  Now she seems to have found a place and a new beau for herself and Will truly did not want to have to spy and lie to her in order to complete his mission, but for all that he also didn’t want her to be hurt if her beau was leading her into danger.As he and his cousin Alec (and spy partner) proceeded to investigate, Will was reminded of the past and how much he missed Evie who had grown into such a beautiful young woman.  The author used this vehicle to test both the protagonists.  Evie who was trying to maintain her devotion to Michael the man she was hoping to marry - all the while trying to stay away from Will who had a distinct impact on feelings she would rather smother than try to sort out.Author Kelley did a fine job of keeping the action moving rapidly and supplied a wonderful ensemble of secondary characters with helped to keep the attention and the mystery moving along as time began to run out in trying to stop any kind of assassination.Bottom line:  The romance was lovely; the many protagonists repartees were totally enjoyable and fit right in with the plot lines.  A lovely read and quite enjoyable.Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

Emily is a sweetheart, happy and waiting for her husband, Sandy Portman to arrive after work.  He made a point to tell her he would be home after work so she happily prepared his favorite meal in anticipation.  Unfortunately, on his way home to meet Emily, Sandy was struck and killed in a tragic accident.  Before the funeral was even over she received the shocking news that her in-laws were making plans to evict her from her Upper West Side apartment in the famous Dakota building.  But nothing was more devastating than slowly uncovering the truth that she never knew Sandy at all, that her entire marriage with him was made up of lies.***  I originally picked up this audiobook at the suggestion and praise of a friend, who being a dog person like myself, thought I would find it a wonderful audiobook.  Naturally, the dog on the cover also helped me to make the selection.I didn’t know quite what I was expecting, but it was quite a journey that Emily took in discovering a lot about herself and the man she had been in love with. Suffice it to say that I found myself not liking Sandy Portman very much at first, although he did begin to grow on me after he began to understand himself after he was given a second chance at life.During her grieving, Emily found some comfort in the adoption of Einstein, a rather scruffy looking dog at the pound which Emily had been volunteering at.  Through the caring of Einstein, Emily could sob all her heartache out, and it almost seemed as if Einstein understood all that she was going through.  As it turned out, by taking Einstein out to the doggy park Emily meets a very handsome and gorgeous young man. A young man Emily tried her best to smother her budding interest in only to find that they were actually neighbors in the Dakota.Bottom line:  EMILY & EINSTEIN was a delightful story both emotional and touching, with several laugh out loud moments coming from Einstein.  Fun and very entertaining.Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

After the death of her father, Abby Mortimer thought that things would finally begin to fall into place and her long-time boyfriend, Edward would finally propose.  Instead of hearing ‘will you marry me?’ she heard, ‘I’ve found someone else’.  Devastated and heartbroken, Abby made a quick exit and flew to Majorca to stay with her sister Liv and brother-in-law Robert at their upscale hotel.Days later after the numbness had worn off, Liv asks Abby to help them out in the bar by singing with their pianist Rafa, a very suave and attractive Spaniard they had hired for the summer.  What started as simple attraction swiftly turned to passion.  Then Edward showed up hoping to apologize and win Abby back.***  THANK YOU FOR THE MUSIC turned into a real treat for me.  It had all the elements I enjoy including a smart rather independent heroine, and two suitors vying for her attention. Couple that with a very nicely fashioned ensemble of secondary characters giving the story depth of happiness and snakiness and you have a very real story ripe with all the inherent problems of true life.Abby, for all her smarts was at some point very naive when it came to men. She was no virgin, but let us say she was very gullible, but understandable as well when you factor in the big twist and reveal at the end.  Rafa was of course lovely and hunky in that tall, dark and handsome way.  And in spite of Abby’s short-sightedness - he was also smart, and a wonderful pianist.  The secondary characters really made the plot move with all the behind the scenes manipulations including the waitress Ellie wanting to be the wanna-be singing star; and the two music producers who were rather eccentric at best.The only complaint I have is that it ended too soon and felt a little cheated as to what the future would hold for Abby and Rafa.Bottom line:  Having the location set in Majorca (on my bucket list to visit) only made the story all that much better.

Plans had been made a long time ago where Mathilde Miller would one day marry Joshua Bowman, a long time family friend from Pennsylvania.  Years later since her family moved away from Pennsylvania, Mathilde loved her life cooking at her family’s inn on the Virginia frontier.  When her father hired Will McGlashen to run the blacksmith forge for him life changed. Mathilde’s life became a restless wave focusing solely on Will, the Scotsman with his lovely brogue sounding like a song in her heart and a balm to her now restless soul. Would the daughter of a Pennsylvania German, be able to find a life with and marry a hired man from Scotland who harbored a secret past?***  Not only was TEMPTING WILL McGLASHEN a very good story, but the mouth watering meals Mathilde was cooking had my saliva glands working overtime.  Which is not to say that this was any kind of cookbook but in my opinion it had a little bit of everything in it, making it a a very tempting morsel of literature.  First and foremost I love history, any type and the early days of the Virginia frontier and early America to me are fascinating.  Combining this with a sweet and lovely romance coupled with food served during those early days just made it ever so much more appealing.To me, Mathilde herself was a bit ahead of her time.  She knew she wouldn’t be content to go and be a farmers wife.  Mathilde loved cooking, working in her parents inn, or as it was referred to in the day, her parent’s ordinary, and meeting all the people passing through.  For her parents sake Mathilde tried to recapture some of the love and friendship she once had for Joshua, but over the years, they had both changed.  Couple that with Mathilde’s feeling towards Will McGlashen who was now prominently in the picture, she knew where her heart truly led.Very well written, author Liz Everly did a wonderful job of creating a great romance with plenty of issues that needed to be resolved concerning Will’s mysterious background, including a surprise twist that could make the relationship Mathilde and Will were building go careening off track.  But then I don’t reveal spoilers.  Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of TEMPTING WILL MCGLASHEN and I am sure you won’t be disappointed.  Very highly recommended.Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

Dominic Hunter is a relentless magistrate with a mission – a mission to track down the illegitimate children of England’s Royal Princes and help them get their due.  Unbeknownst to most though was the fact a portion of his search was also extremely personal for Dominic.After fourteen years not much had changed about Chloe Steele. She was still the most beautiful and the most stubborn woman, Dominic had ever met, and he was still madly in love with the young girl who had been his constant childhood companion.  Had Chloe not given in to her uncle who promised to protect her from scandal after finding herself pregnant at the age of 14, Dominic would have been the one to protect and give her a loving life.  Now that he had re-discovered her, he couldn’t let her slip away from him again.***  TALL, DARK AND ROYAL is a short novella, a little over 100 pages.  In spite of the short length, the author managed to explain a bit of the protagonists background so that even being read out of order, I knew exactly what was going on.  With a wonderful bit of a succinct explanation of Chloe and Hunter’s background, the reader was brought right up to the moment 14 years later when this story takes place.  With such an excellent overview of past history, I was completely invested in both the story and the moment.Chloe had suffered much after the back-stabbing manipulations of her uncle who laid such a guilt trip on her back and then manipulated her life by cutting her off from anyone from her past. A lesser person would have given up, but as china-like as she appeared, she had a spine of steel.  With the good luck of finding a position with a wealthy couple she assisted and took up their work of providing a safe haven for young girls like her who had gotten pregnant and had no where else to turn.  Chloe’s benefactors, left her their fortune and the pledge that she would continue their work.Even though Hunter had finally located Chloe his most important mission now was to convince her that they belonged together.  With the talented pen from author Vanessa Kelley Hunter was able to do just that and wrote some of the most emotional and sensual scenario’s that were part of the ammunition that Hunter needed to convince one very stubborn lady to give in to the inevitable.BOTTOM LINE:  Beautifully written and tastefully sensual - what more could one ask for?Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritques.com

CHRISTMAS AT THORNCLIFF TOWERS is short novella about Karina Petri, a gypsy witch who dearly misses her best friend and love Constantin.  Some years ago, when hunger had led her to try to steal food for the starving Gypsy camp she involved Constantin’s brother Viktor in her scheme.  As a result, the supposed werewolf master of Thorncliff caught Viktor and demanded he pay by working for him.  As a result, Constantin was finally able to have Viktor released and he would then pay off the debt owed by working the stables in his brothers place.  In order to save Constantin’s grandfather who was dying, Karina had to lure Constantin back to the camp in order to work a cure, but Constantin wanted nothing to do with her, blaming her for Viktor being caught and him having had to leave his home.***  It was a pleasure to read this short novella and I was able to complete it in a couple of hours.  Normally, I do not like novella’s because they are so short and my preference is to get totally involved in the characters lives and emotions. However, with that said, CHRISTMAS AT THORNCLIFF TOWERS, in spite of the short length, kept me captivated for the entire time.  Yes it was short but in that time, the author was able to bring forth and flesh out the main characters as well as their motivations.  Basically this story is about trying to do a good thing, and having it backfire in your face as Karina found out.  All in all it was not only very well written but the pace was quite remarkable.Bottom line:  For a quick and entertaining holiday read, CHRISTMAS AT THORNCLIFF TOWERS would be a perfect break to indulge yourself away from the hustle and bustle of the holidays.  Very good short story!Marilyn Rondeau for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

Bowen MacRieve of the Lykae clan was practically destroyed when his chosen mate was killed before they were ever wed.  He has been like a zombie for over 180 years blaming himself for her death and has searched high and low for the means to bring her back.  Bowen entered the Talisman’s Hie (similar to the Amazing Race)  with the intent to win the prize - a chance to go back in time to change events.During the race Bowen meets Mariketa the Awaited, she is young, mortal and more importantly has not come into her witch powers just yet.  For some reason, Mariketa awakens desires in Bowen he hasn’t felt in centuries and although the attraction is mutual, the fact remains - each has their own reasons to want to win the prize!  Let the games begin!***  If anyone has not read the series Immortals After Dark yet - you must begin immediately for you have no idea what you are missing.  Additionally, while each book stands alone, it is so much better if you begin right at the beginning with  A HUNGER LIKE NO OTHER.  This series has everything one would expect and want if a lover of Paranormal Romance as it contains demons, witches, valkyries, Lykae, and just about any other fae type creature one can think of.  And on top of that, they can really be funny as well!The adventures that Bowen and Mariketa go through both during the race and after when he realizes that he did her a grave injustice (after she stripped him of some of his powers) was super fast action and suspense.  Finally realizing that Mariketa is actually the mate Bowen has been waiting for all his long (1200 years) life, author Cole puts him through the grinder in order to beg, borrow and steal his way back into Mariketa’s good graces.  [The romance and sensuality and Bowen’s oft times blunt speaking is both funny and very sexy]Considering I listened to this via Audible, I must also applaud the fabulous narration by Robert Petkoff.  After listening to four of the books in this series, I can’t imagine how I would be able to enjoy it more if anyone but Robert were to narrate this.  His many voice changes considering the numerous amount of characters filling this book were nothing short of amazing!Bottom line: Each book in this series just gets better and better, and for those who have not had a listen yet, you have no idea what you’re missing!  One of the best series out there!Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

On a dare, Ross Thornbury, considered a rake by some authored THE RAKE’S HANDBOOK.  Since then he has been publicly condemned by the ladies of the ton, and privately revered by the gentlemen.  Unfortunately for Ross his notoriety is preventing him from gaining an important approval of his plans to make build a foundry on his land.  Word has gotten out and the good people surrounding his land are sure that his foundry is going to poison their water, and unleash black soot into the air they breathe and blackening the countryside.In particular, the most important consent he needs is to gain access to the river through the young widow Elinor Colton’s land.  However, the gossips have convinced her that she should stay far away from her rakish neighbor. As much as Elinor holds the memory of her beloved husband close at heart, she has discovered that her newest neighbor with his delectable grin somehow makes her feel happy again.***  In her debut author Sally Orr has penned a lovely romance THE RAKE’S HANDBOOK and FIELD GUIDE.  Using the hero’s book as a vehicle, she had our hero Ross, translate by words and actions each chapter to the young widow, who although she kept telling herself she really shouldn’t - actually enjoyed their repartee.  Ross was indeed a charmer, and widow or not, Elinor was delighted to be able to relax and enjoy his company.Adding to the lively mix is Elinor’s ward Berdi.  He is introduced as a young dandy with no direction other than trying to impress Beau Brumell with his latest originally designed cravat knot.  He is silly and funny, and a trial for Elinor who wants to see him basically grow up and have direction in his life, but in the meantime, he provides a lovely amount of chuckles.All in all this is a very light-hearted romantic tale, with no real suspense although we do run into a couple of skirmishes when a former candidate for Elinor’s affection finds her interest in Ross quite inconvenient for his plans to wed the wealthy widow.  It was a fun read, not too exciting suspense wise and very mild in the sensuality area.Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritques.com

Attorney Rachel Wainwright is struggling to make a name for herself, and pro bono cases are a means to an end when starting off.  Because of her own past history, Rachel had agreed to take on and reopen a decades-old case, convinced that the accused murderer was, if not innocent of the brutal crimes he’d been found guilty of, deserved at the very least to have DNA testing done on the only piece of evidence that was used in his conviction.Opening up this 30 year old case, didn’t garner her any friends in the city. Number one because of the brutality involved, and two because the victim had been so beautiful and admired. However, Homicide detective Deke Morgan was not about to make it easy for her, mostly because it was his father who had cracked the case thirty years ago and made himself a hero in the town.***  As with most of Mary Burton’s Thrillers there should be a warning label that says - not for the faint of heart.  Burton doesn’t pull any punches in the telling of vicious crimes perpetrated on the victims - right down to the time they know they are going to die.  And with that said - she knows exactly how to draw a portrait of insane and psycho villains.  COVER YOUR EYES is no exception.Right from the very beginning the reader is thrust into the both the mind of the victim and the mind of the killer - and you will find yourself terrified.  The fact that Rachel was also opening up the old case, and the most recent victim seemed to have died from the same type of assault only made Rachel more determined than ever to get those DNA results.  Deke Morgan however, was just as determined to prove that his father made a justified and righteous arrest while putting the true murderer in jail.  But as bodies started piling up and Rachel was attacked with the same type of an object as the original murderer, perhaps there was something there that had been overlooked.All in all - COVER YOUR EYES is one fast action and superior thriller that will have you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.  It’s hard to top Ms. Burton in this genre and she always delivers!Marilyn Rondeau, for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

Hearing that his father had a debilitating accident , Richard Barrett, Lord Hartley was called home to take the reins of the estate only to discover that the family’s finances were in a bad way.  Bad investments, bad weather causing bad crops; there was but one remedy – find and marry an heiress. Unfortunately, he had all but proposed to another and she was about to descend upon the family estate with her parents in tow.As much as she loved her parents, Miss Sophie Goodnight certainly wasn’t keen on being bartered off just to gain a title for her father’s future grandchild.  As such Sophie did all in her power to sabotage all Lord Hartley’s attempts to woo her.  However, as much as neither was too keen on arranged marriages, there was something that was simmering between them.***  Mia Marlowe is a newer author for me and I must say I see a bright future for her if she can continue to churn out wonderful tomes such as A RAKE BY ANY OTHER NAME.  I thought her pacing, and plotting was excellent, specifically with the lovely twist that came at the end of this one, and I never saw it coming.Sophie was my kind of gal who spoke her mind.  Her parents were tradesmen - highly successful and very wealthy tradesmen, and although she had a dowery that could put most titled lords and ladies to shame, she didn’t want to be bartered like some animal.  Sophie wanted to be loved and wanted for herself.  Her attitude was that all titled folks were stuffy and she wanted no part of them and did her best to insult and chase Richard away.  In the beginning it worked but as Richard got to know more about her, he realized that not only was she lovely (when she cleaned up), but she was fun, exciting, and highly intelligent - someone he could relate to!If that were not enough, he soon found out a few other things that gave his life a whole new meaning!  And in the course of not giving any spoilers away - you will just have to read this marvelous book to discover what they are and be as surprised and delighted as I was!  You will be glad you did as I highly recommend A RAKE BY ANY OTHER NAME.Marilyn Rondeau,  for www.ck2skwipsandkritiques.com

I just finished this book and can't wait to read the others in the series. My teenager (who reads college level and is in the 7th grade) saw this book and read it in one sitting. He really enjoyed it. He says it's fast-paced and full of good clues to solve a mystery. It has action and creative solutions to fixing the main character's problem. He says it was a good book for anyone to read.I think so too. It's a fun book. There is nothing super scary in this book other than a brief description of bear fighting. This book is about Spencer Plain who was sent to live at Bearhaven after his activist/bear rescuer dad was kidnapped by a rogue group. Spencer's parents have been involved with rescuing bears for years and things were getting kind of dire by the time Mr. Plain was kidnapped.The biggest surprise for Spencer was living among bears. They were able to talk so Spencer can understand them. They were actively involved with bear rescue and more.I found this book to be a well-written mystery caper. If your child is struggling with reading, this book would be a great start to getting him/her inspired to read. It has a great story line and a well-executed plot. I would definitely recommend this book to other children, even though my twins are older.

I have to admit that once my family saw the package on the banister in our house, they could not wait to try it out. I chose it so I can have something to wear while cleaning the house or do some writing. It looks like I will have to buy several pairs just so I can have my own. (When I do, I am tempted to put some hideous pink tape on the headset so I don't have to share!)My one son loves it. He figured how to hook the headset to my cell phone. (I have a Samsung Galaxy if anyone is interested.) He begrudgingly allowed me to test it out. He tried it on his tablet and it works like a charm. My other son finally got to try it out this morning and he loves it. In fact, they were almost late to their bus stop because they wanted to finish listening to "The Eye of the Tiger" by Survivor.I had originally intended for my husband to have this after I reviewed this. He finally got to test it out last night while cleaning out the basement and he is thrilled with it. He says that it allows him to listen to music without having to subject me to listening to his music. He is able to walk away from his phone and still be able to hear it in spite of being in the different parts of the basement. He says the music coming across is clear and crisp.I finally got to try it. I have a cochlear implant processor and I am always looking for headphones that will rest comfortably on my ears; to listen to music clearly without static and the ability to put the headphones away without too much trouble.This one does the trick for me. I was able to hear the music clearly and without static. I can wear it comfortably without it pinching my ears. It doesn't slide off my head. It is just a nice piece of equipment. Even better, it does not have to be tethered to my phone like my other headphone set is. I love the bluetooth capability. I love the fact that I can wear it around the house without having to miss out on the songs. My son said he was able to go down in the basement (my phone was upstairs in the kitchen) and be in the farthest part of the basement and still be able to hear the music clearly. He even went outside and was able to hear it. He didn't go that far, just out to the driveway and back.There are only 2 complaints we have and they are relatively minor. One is that, every time I get a notification from one of my apps on my phone, it beeps on the headset. That is easily fixed. The other thing is, it's rather pricey. But since it is Christmas time, this would definitely be a great gift to give to your music lover. It is that good.And no we did not test it out for gaming or for phone capability. We don't normally use headphones for gaming or for the phone, but I can see why it would be attractive to others. We are not the people who likes to talk on the phone all day long.

I have been looking for a gentle cleanser to wash my face with. This one does the trick. I will be honest. I have never heard of Vichy before and this product is really nice. It smells good (not too sweet) and clean. It lathers up nicely with just a little bit of gel. This 6.76 fl oz bottle is going to go a long ways since you don't need a lot of gel to lather up your face. I have sensitive skin and this one does not irritate it at all.It is a bit pricey for a facial cleanser, but when you look at how long it lasts, you're getting your money's worth.I love the fact that it is paraben free. It seems that just about everything has these chemicals in their products and it's hard to find something that doesn't have paraben in it. This helps a lot.I will definitely be on the outlook for more Vichy products. This is definitely going to be one of my favorite facial cleansers. It's better than Oil of Olay, which I have been using.

I love these dish cloths. I have the white ones, so that is super handy to see if the dirt is coming off of the walls when I am cleaning it. I use the scouring cloth to wipe off the dirt left behind by the movers who didn't watch what they were doing while moving the previous owner's possessions out of our house. As a result, all of our white walls looked like someone went around with black crayons and left scuff marks. I tried to clean the area by the front entry way and it seems to do the trick. I am impressed. I've tried to clean it before and it didn't do the trick at all. With this cloth and a little bit of water, it worked.I also used it to clean the baseboards and it works like a charm, getting into the cracks where it's harder to clean. I also used the polishing cloth to clean my trash can, any of my stainless steel appliances and that works as well.I am in love with these cloths and the price isn't bad at all. I plan on buying more eventually, so I can stock up on them in different parts of the house.It makes cleaning up a breeze and these days, I am all about efficiency.

I love water. Plain water with lots of ice in my insulated tumbler. I drink about 60 oz of water a day along with my hot tea. I thought this Ocean Spray flavored water would be delicious as I love cranberries and I love raspberries. It would definitely add some flavor to my water intake for the day.Until I found out that it contains sweeteners. I cannot stand agave. It leaves an aftertaste in my mouth. Any sweeteners leave an after taste in my mouth, just like drinking diet pop with aspartame in it. I honestly wish I can drink these drinks with natural sweeteners in it so I can have something other than ice water and tea. It just doesn't agree with me.The flavors in this water is good. I cannot drink the entire 16 oz bottle. It's too much for me. I know that it sounds weird. It is weird.  I get too full from drinking it and adding ice to it just makes it watery and flat-tasting.The price for 12 pack is expensive, I think. That would be a deterrent for someone who wants to drink this flavored water and can't afford it. Hopefully, the price will come down so more people can enjoy it. I just wish I am one of them.

I chose this for my Galaxy S5 since my boys have misplaced my other armband. I have my phone in a slim otterbox case, so if I leave the case on, it is a super tight fit squeezing it into the armband. However, it is a perfect fit for the phone once I take off the otterbox.It is a large armband. It fits my husband's arm a lot better than mine. I am petite, so I have to wear a jacket so the armband will stay on. I am still figuring out how to adjust the armband width so I can wear it all year long, despite the temperatures.I like how you can still use your phone through the plastic covering. I didn't have any trouble getting to a texting app, but do have to slow down to type a message. However, I won't be texting while I am walking or running. It is just nice being able to have that ability if I need to.It is a stylish case and while the price might be offsetting for some people, this might be worth the splurge. It is a nice armband and definitely a lot lighter, more pliable than my other one.

I don't think this book should be compared to "Gone Girl" at all. There isn't enough twists and turns in this novel to qualify as that. I also would not compare it to "The Girl on the Train," either, though it is sort of similar in the same story-telling style. The characters all have a turn at sharing their stories. There is Jean, the wife, who stands by her man, Glen Taylor, who was accused of kidnapping a tiny 2 year old girl from the gardens of her house, while her mom was inside. The stories alternate between her, the stony-faced detective, Sparks, who is determined to find the missing toddler, Bella, and also the hard-nosed reporter, Kate, who refuses to give up on the chase for the lead story. There is even a chapter where the accused speaks for himself.All in all, it is quite a suspenseful story, but it had a very slow start. Maybe that was the author's intent, but I don't like to keep waiting for something to happen. I also don't like being able to predict the outcome of the story as well. It is a good story, don't get me wrong, but it just wasn't as suspenseful as I had hoped for. For someone who is new to the suspense thriller genre, this book is perfect for them as they haven't been exposed to many different writers' techniques and plot twists. As for the seasoned reader, this book falls just a teensy bit too flat for me.Having said that, I will be on the lookout for her next book as I am sure she will write more.

We have just moved into our new house this past summer and this ornament is just perfect to commemorate a wonderful start to our new lives. It is made out of china but is absolutely gorgeous. It is not too heavy to put on the tree.I don't think I own any Lenox product, which is a flaw on my part. I have always loved their products especially their ornaments. They always seem to capture a lovely moment/sentiment and it lasts for years.I have the First Year in Our New Home ornament and it is just lovely in its simplicity. It is a design of a house with the saying Our First Year In Our New Home 2015. It is ivory looking with the words in red. It is cheerful and I cannot wait to put in my tree. The packaging is sturdy and well-protected.If you're thinking of buying something special for someone for Christmas and they have just moved, this is a wonderful gift to give. Because of this, I will be on the lookout for more Lenox ornaments to buy for gifts.

My husband swears by the Otterbox and its products. I have always found them to be bulky. I don't want to carry a big box in my back pocket or in my jacket when I decide to go for a walk or a run. I love my Samsung Galaxy though and the flimsy cover I got is that, flimsy (though super cute). I decided to try this one out and love it. I love the pink. Now my 2 boys won't be seen carrying this one out in public (though it doesn't stop them from trying to play on my phone). I love the fact that I can insert a design in the back though mine didn't come with any inserts. I'll just have to be creative.My previous Otterbox cover is a bit thicker (not as thick as my husband's) and it was made out of rubber. I don't mind the rubber, but it does make turning on the phone a bit of a challenge or even to turn up the phone volume or ringer. I didn't care for that. They did not offer a lot of feminine colors at the shop I bought my phone from, so this is a plus. Not only that I can turn on the phone without having to squeeze it hard. That is a benefit for someone who might have sore hands.Over all, I really like this product. I think this series is an improvement on the Otterbox line. I like the ability to change my design at will, along with the assurance that my phone will be protected. It's not a bad price either. I will definitely look for this series again as I really do like it.

This is one of the loveliest tales I have read in a long time. I normally don't like reading what passes for "Christian literature" these days; not because of its contents, but because of its poorer language structure. This book is written well and obviously, well-edited.I have read a lot of books about the Holocaust, both fiction and nonfiction. This one doesn't really qualify as a Holocaust book because it didn't delve into the deeper issues that faced the countries at the time. It was the starting point for the novel, but it is a personal novel about 2 people who connected because of the war. Gretl Schmidt is a young girl who lost her mother and grandmother and her sister. Jakob is a Polish student working to liberate Poland from the Germans when he rescued her. He had found her in the woods after Gretl jumped off the train. His family took care of her till he read of an organization taking German kids to South Africa to people who wanted to adopt orphans.There are a historical facts woven into the story of Gretl and Jakob; their lives after the war went separate ways. The author, Irma Joubert is a teacher who turned to writing and it shows in this book. The stories of the two characters are interwoven in a seamless path as they grew up in different parts of the world only to be reunited years later. There are stories of how Poland became a communist country; there are stories of how the Catholic faith colors the lives of the people in Poland and how people in South Africa view the Catholic church through the personal viewpoints of varying characters. There are historical tidbits interwoven through the every day lives of the characters.It is also a love story. It is a lovely story. It is a story of faith as well. It is a book to curl up with on those dreary winter nights. It is a book to discuss over book clubs. It is just an inspiring international tale that ends well. It sounds so simplistic but it really isn't. It is a good story and I can see why it is a best seller in other parts of the world. I hope it becomes as successful here in the States as well.

I love this 3 piece set. I love the ice cream scoop as it is sturdy and a bit heavy, but it scoops up ice cream quite nicely. I love the basin that this set comes with. I don't have to hunt for a bowl to put the scoop in (and worrying about the bowl making a mess on my counter as it's not deep enough for the ice cream scoop and I have melted ice cream leaving a stain). I love the insulated ice cream container. It really is perfect to take on a road trip and it stays cold for a long time.We love home made ice cream and frozen yogurt. We do have another one of these containers that a friend has left behind, so reviewers are right about having to have 2 of these containers to contain your home made ice cream. It is good for the store-bought ice cream as well.We got the kiwi color one and it's bright and you definitely cannot miss it while out and about. It is hard to open up the lid once it's frozen but we just set it in a hot water bath for a couple of minutes and that does soften up the ice cream as well as allowing us to open the lid.We like this and would recommend this for other people as well. It's a great addition to our ice cream making process.

I have been using it for about three days. I am not noticing a real difference in reducing my wrinkles (probably because I don't have that many ... just laugh lines), but my skin is softer. It feels good and the smell is not medicinal. It is rather lemony and to be honest, it is refreshing.I don't use a lot of it and I do put it directly on my skin and I just rub it in. It goes a long way and I put it on before I put my moisturizer on and two hours later, my skin is still feeling soft.The only reason why I am giving it a four star rating is that the price is a bit prohibitive. $71 is a lot of money to spend on anything and I will treasure this bottle for a long time since I cannot justify spending this kind of money for something this nice. If I was able to afford it, I would buy it and give it to my friends as it is such a lovely product. Whether it works permanently remains to be seen, but I do like this.

We like our bubbly in this house.We also like our wine. This is for champagne though, and it is a big distinction since I did try using it on a bottle of wine. It doesn't work for an ordinary bottle of wine, but it sure works on the champagne bottle. I don't have the strength to wrestle with the cork, but my husband does and he loves this. We will probably drink a little bit more champagne now that we have something that will make opening a bottle so much easier.And we love the sealer. We have several for bottles of wine, but none for champagne. It is a good tight fit and does seal up the champagne that is left over. (That is if there are any left over!)This would make a great gift for anyone who likes their bubbly. With wedding season upon us, this is a perfect wedding gift ... one that they never knew that they needed.

We love playing games in our house. Our game closet is full, bursting with games and fortunately, I have two guinea pigs who like playing games as well. This game is not the best game in our closet, but it is pretty fun. It goes pretty quickly and it was definitely not Apples to Apples or any of our other favorite games, but it was fun.For ten bucks or thereabouts, it isn't a bad game. It can be confusing at first as the instructions are not exactly clear, but for nights on the road when we can't dig out the big board games, this game will do in a pinch. It might not work for the four of us in the long run, but playing this with other people, it can be fun.

This is such a fun toy I have tween boys and they love their Nerf gun collections, so when I saw that I could review this for Vine, I took the chance to do so.The only regret I have is that ... I never get to play with it. My boys have commandeered it for their collection and their dad has been using it too as well. They obviously don't care that it has girly colors on it. It is a Nerf gun. It works. And it shoots very far very fast. That is all they care about. They do wish there were more ammunition for it. So do I. They really don't care about reading the secret messages with the secret keeper case. That wouldn't be a reason why I'd buy this for my nieces. I'd buy this because it's fun, flashy and shoots very far. One of my sons did shoot me in the arm at close range and it did sting, so definitely heed the warnings not to shoot this in the face. That would be painful and might leave a nasty bruise.The price seems to be average for this sort of toy and it would be perfect if they added more darts when offering this for sale. It's a great toy and fun to play with, no matter your age.

This is a good blend of Gothic romance and fantasy. The setting isn't in a remote castle but it is set in a croft buried in the mountains of Wales, an ancient home that keeps secrets over the years. Artist Laura Matthews was looking for a new place to live while keeping her muse inspired by the natural beauty of the hills in Wales. There, Laura hopes to produce her best work yet and to maybe get pregnant with a baby that she and her husband, Dan, have wanted for years.Though the hills are remote, they are alive with secrets and there are people who live there with their own secrets. There is also a legend of Merlin walking these hills at one time. In fact, the other side of the story is about Megan, who is the nurse-maid of the local nobles' children, and the keeper of Merlin's heart. Megan's story intertwines with Laura's till its final conclusion, which is slightly predictable, but still fun to read.If you're looking for a romance to while away an afternoon of reading, this would be a good one to read. I have not read Paula Brackson's books before but she does have a flair for carrying you deeper into the story, silencing the cynic in you till you're just in the midst of the story and can't wait to see what happens next. Brackston has a way of keeping you involved with the characters till the last page has turned.

In our house, we adore Reese's Peanut Butter Cups. My husband tends to go for Snickers and that is our second favorite, but the boys and I adore Reese's. There is something magical about peanut butter and chocolate together.This bag is a huge bag of divine goodness. It'll last us for awhile since we don't eat chocolates every day, but yum! It is the miniature size, which I have always found to be perfection itself because sometimes, after a meal, you want something sweet but you don't want a big dessert or something rich, so this miniature size is perfect for those moments. Just enough to take away the cravings.I love to bake and I see on this page, there are recipes to try. I will definitely have to try the cheesecake recipe. That will make one of my sons happy to see since cheesecake is his favorite dessert.I have two concerns ith this yummy bag of treats is the price. It is quite a bit for bulk sized. I would pay the price for it if I am planning on giving most of it away (like at Easter time or maybe Christmas), but just to buy to have on hand for snacks or desserts, it might deter me a bit. That is a concern. The other concern is the shipping. My UPS person always leave my packages out in the bright sunlight (or rain or snow) and they generally don't even ring the doorbell to let me know that my packages have arrived. I do worry about the chocolates melting in the sunshine or get soggy in the rain. It was double-packaged though today, when I got the box. But I am not sure if the double packaging would help prevent it from melting.Other than those two concerns, this is still a delicious bag of yummies! I cannot wait to share it with others!

I have two boys and they can be rather messy, no matter how hard I try to keep after them in keeping clean. I love tablecloths for the simple fact that it protects my oak table from messes and dings that comes from normal wear and tear. This tablecloth is no exception.In fact, it is really elegant and perfect for spring/summer weather. It's a light blue and tougher than it looks. It covers the table quite nicely. I also put place mats on top of the table cloth to give it more color and it blends in well with my spring/summer theme. It just brightens up the whole dining room. I also can have an elegant table at dinnertime, either for the four of us or for the six of us (when my mom and friend comes to visit).I love the fact that it is wrinkle resistant and virtually stain-proof. These are big pluses when I shop for table cloths and this one fit the bill. The price is more expensive than what you might find at Walmart, but it is still a good price for something that won't wear out so quickly either. The weave texture is lovely and it drapes nicely off of my kitchen table.I just love it!

I will admit to this. I have read all of Marie Bostwick's novels, even the ones that are no longer in print. I love her books. I have all of them. Her books are guaranteed to keep you in your comfy armchair and read till the last page has been turned. Her writing keeps getting better and better every time she churns out another book.This one is not one of her Cobbled Court books, which is to my surprise. I depend on the Cobbled Court series to get me through another busy season of raising two ornery kids, but this book is even better. It is about Lucy coming home to Nilson's Bay, WI, since her older sister, Alice, died unexpectedly. As part of Alice's will, Lucy has to live in the cottage that she has spent her entire adult life running away from for eight weeks before she can sell it and go back to Washington, D.C. where her boss just became the elected president of the US.Lucy reluctantly stays in Nilson's Bay for the required eight weeks to finish out her requirements before heading to the White House to resume the frantic pace of her harried life as an campaign manager. She meets up with the FOA girls, who happened to be Friends of Alice as the town dubbed them and with their help, she learns how to quilt. And along the way, she learns more about her sister, who left a gaping hole in folks' lives than Lucy has ever realized. She realized that she doesn't have the sole right to miss her sister as Alice has befriended everyone in Nilson's Bay, even her own lawyer, Peter, who also happened to be Lucy's high school crush.This is a lovely novel about a woman who was forced to take several steps back to step away from a busy and storied career to realize that life is more than just winning campaigns. It is also a great story of how a woman finds the small joys in life are actually the big things as well.I rely on Marie Bostwick to produce these gems of a novel and if I have to be really honest, this one is my favorite yet.

I love lipstick and will collect as many as I can. This one is one of my favorites. I do have to reapply it every so often but it's so easy to apply on my lips. It also has a bit of moisturizer in it as well, so my lips don't get chapped when wearing it.The price is right too at $6.39. It is small enough to put in your clutch or evening purse if going out and even in your jeans pockets. The color is rich and comes on smoothly as well. I love it.

This author is funny. I picked up the book and was taken right in with his wry commentary about auditioning for American Idol. He wasn't there to sing as he will tell you upfront that he is not a good singer. He was just there to observe all the people auditioning and try to figure out how normally-sane looking people can lose their mind at the opportunity to be famous.His very first experiment was to try Gwyneth Paltrow's cleansing diet. With a dry wit, he shares his experiment with the cleansing and how it did work ... for those three weeks that he lost weight but it all came back on as soon as he finished the cleanse. He also noticed that instead of feeling enlightened, he felt crabby throughout the experiment.Along with his insights and commentary, he will intersect scientific studies to back up his claims or his observations. Some of these are down right disturbing as how much we depend on celebrities to have the answers for the weight loss, their careers and so on. Or even jump on the anti-vaccine bandwagon or the gluten-free diet (which I have always deplored before reading this book as an impossible solution for behavioral problems but people obviously believe a gluten-free diet can control their kids or themselves).There are so many insights in this book that I have already agreed with before reading it, so it can be redundant in a way. However, I wish more of my friends and family would read this and see that they are uprooting their lives based on some celebrity's say-so is not always the best way to go.  But that's just me.This is a great book to read and perhaps as a conversation fodder as well. There are quite a few scientific claims to back up what he is saying ... though if one has common sense, they wouldn't need to read this book.

I absolutely loved this book. I thought it was going to be a sweet but boring novel about love and loss, but not this one. This one took me into two different stories within the same house in different centuries and I just absolutely loved it. It was definitely the perfect antidote to the last rainy days I've been experiencing. With nothing to do but to read, this book fit the bill.The two stories are told wonderfully and were not lacking in details, so I never felt like one was dominating over the other. They also both coincided with each other.In 1984, the mansion was used as a make shift hospital for wounded Yankees. Charlotte Portsman was the wife of the owner of the plantation. She was a transplant from England and during the time of the war, she became enchanted by the Yankee captain, Will. But since she was married, there was nothing she could do about her attraction to him. She has a child named Ben who is the world to her.In the present day, there is Julia Presley, who is a mother of a missing boy and there is Eli Donovan with deep secrets of his own and his own son. Eli comes to Peach Orchard Inn due to a car trouble, and finds his story starting anew while working for Julia.These two stories of two different couples are about love, loss, forgiveness and grace. It is definitely one of the best reads I have read this year.

I am always looking for a good read to keep my two tweens interested in reading. I think this one is definitely one of them. It's a great tale, fast-paced and appealing to the younger generation who enjoy reading stories about surviving in the wild without adults around. One of my twins absolutely love this kind of story, so it will be interesting to see what he thinks of it.This book focuses on Urgle, a young boy who is charged with raising a younger brother, named Cubby. Urgle is part of a tribe called Ikkuma, a society of young boys who have been abandoned shortly after birth to live among boys and boys only. When they reach a certain number of years, they celebrate a "Leaving Day," which means they then strike out on their own. No one knows how it is started and no one knows anything different than what they have always grown up with.Till one day, Cubby is kidnapped by a group of goblins and Urgle chases after him. He may be "useless" in his society, but he wasn't going to give up the fight for his brother. Two of his friends joined the chase with him into the big unknown.Then Urgle and his brothers are on a journey that expanded beyond their comprehension especially when an older brother, Blaze, joins in the story. One thing leads to another and then another, with mystical tales thrown in the midst and wild chases and confusion reigning throughout the rest of the book.
