I can't believe we thought they were even decent systems.

Since it seems some people don't like lengthy reviews, here's my review overview:-Spent over $1400 on the i5 w/8GB memory and 256SSD, plus the type cover keyboard.-Out-of-box issues which took a couple hours to resolve.-LCD has yellowed whites, grayed blacks, and text is not very sharp.-LCD touch is somewhat inaccurate compared to other touch screens I use-Graphical capabilities bottlenecked by internal hardware.-i5 processor bottlenecked by internal hardware.-SSD runs slowly. Comparable to SATA III spinning drive performance. About half of how today's SSDs perform.-Windows touch button unreliable.-MicroSD card slot means you must carry around an SD card reader if you want to pull images off a camera.-Bad price:value ratio.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------FULL REVIEW:Bought one of these yesterday at a local Microsoft store. I was so excited. Spent over $1400 on the i5 w/8GB memory and 256GB SSD, plus the type cover keyboard.Got home, booted it up, it took almost 30 minutes for it to go through its setup processes. I swore it was hung, but I waited it out. Finally it came to a desktop screen where nothing would happen. Couldn't touch the start button, the hardware button would work every few presses, and the screen would flicker on and off. Rebooted it, and it fixed nothing. Finally had to do a full reset by holding power and volume up, which finally made it come back to life and I could start using it.First, the LCD screen is a joke. My iPad air has a far brighter screen, the text is WAY sharper, and overall the Surface screen just doesn't look as good as the iPad or my NINE year old laptop with a 17" screen. Whites on the Surface look completely yellowed, where on the iPad air they are bright white, and black text is dark black. The Surface has text that is pushing into darker shades of gray.I started browsing the internet and noticed a few web pages that were awfully slow, so I started comparing with my nine year old laptop, and iPad. In every page I tested, the Surface was so slow... We're not talking about molasses, but scrolling was terribly choppy, zooming in and out caused several graphical artifacts as the machine had to keep up and display the video. Sometimes zooming out would tape upwards of 2-3 seconds to complete the zoom. My iPad never acts that way.I ran an IO test on the SSD, and what a joke! Read speeds of under 300MB/sec, and write speeds closer to 200MB/sec. This is just barely faster than most SATA III spinning hard drives. My old laptop, with a SATA I SSD gets around 140MB read, and 90MB write speeds. For a 9 year age difference, the performance difference should be astounding. The 2 year old SSD in my desktop computer, on a SATA II controller, gets well over 400MB/sec red speeds, with 300MB/sec write speeds. My work computer with SATA III SSD gets well over 600MB/sec read and 500MB/sec write speeds. A colleague of mine has an original Surface, and his SSD gets 423MB/sec read and 263MB/sec Write, blowing away the Surface 3. Microsoft cheapened components of these machines in areas they thought most people wouldn't notice, and it shows. for $1,400, I expected WAY more than this.Then we get into the touch screen. It's absolutely terrible and inaccurate. Every touch registers lower than where my finger actually is. I tested this literally hundreds of times, and even wrote a quick program to show exact positioning of the mouse cursor with a touch. It was always registering several pixels away from the center of the finger touch. This caused me to constantly select items that were one down in a drop-list. It was thoroughly annoying.The windows logo touch "button" was terrible. When in standby, there were times I'd tap it 10 times before it'd finally register that touch. When on, not every touch would cause a reaction. Simply not reliable in any way.One annoying thing is the microSD card reader slot. These days, there are still a ton of cameras which use SD cards. Most notably, pretty much ANY SLR camera. This means you must carry around an additional USB card reader in order to pull pictures off your camera, or you have to hook up to the camera via cable. But then... I guess this could go the other way around. If you have a camera which uses MicroSD, and you have no microSD slot. At least in that case all you need is one of those tiny adapters for micro/mini SD cards.Aside from all these issues, it's a nice device. Looks good, isn't THAT heavy, and would be great for a traveling professional, but the lack of ability to upgrade, and the lack of performance, means that a cheaper laptop is a far better option, and brings better performance.The price:value ratio just isn't there. I will be returning this and getting a regular old laptop.UPDATE: I returned the Surface and the guys at the Microsoft store swear that I got bad hardware, or that the firmware was old and needed to be updated.UPDATE 3-16-2015: Bought a Dell Inspiron 13 7000, which is a 2-in-1 laptop. While it's slightly heavier than the Surface, it blows the Surface away in literally every single other aspect. Battery life is better, CPU performance is better, SSD performance is better, windows button is physical and reliable, LCD quality is FAR better, has a standard SD slot, has passive stylus w/storage spot, and it was more than $400 less expensive. Also compared the performance of it to a friend's Surface Pro 3, which works better than the one I bought, and it still blows it away. Sorry Microsoft, but the Surface just doesn't meet the price:value ratio.

I'm extremely impressed. I was ready to throw this thing back in the box and return it, after having nothing but problems with it. I have an old Linksys WAP we're been using for a couple years, and I was testing this out to replace it, and add a couple repeaters in our new office building. I was getting 1-3Mbps throughput from it on the down side, and 10Mbps on the up side. So confused... I came to find that having the SSID the same name for both frequencies (2.4GHz and 5GHz) was causing a problem. Once I created SSIDs for each frequency, problems disappeared, and I was seeing 100Mbps on several devices, which is exactly the speed of our internet connection. Impressive, being that the Linksys could only produce about 47Mbps, even on 5GHz N wireless. I replaced our Linksys and mirrored the SSIDs and passwords from it. Nobody has made any complaints about connectivity, which is awesome. I'm curious to see how it works once I add another as a repeater.The other beautiful thing about these is that they are PoE, so they are easily mountable in office ceiling tiles, and look very clean. I believe I'll be ordering a couple of these for my home, as we have signal issues there. I have conduit running from my basement to my attic, so I can place one on the upper floors with just one cat5 cable. No power run necessary.I wish they were a little bit cheaper, but they are still reasonably priced for what they can do, especially considering I spent $180 on my current access point at home.I only have one complaint. When setting each radio to automatically select a frequency channel, it would almost always select the most congested channel. I used its channel usage monitor tool, and it would show all the APs around, and what channels they are using. In our current building, 11, 6 and 1 are very congested. This Zyxel would rarely auto-select a channel that was least congested. It almost seems like "auto" is synonymous with "completely random".Support is the best you can get. Zyxel has great support, and it's always free.

This device, and its companion TC-TP1 probe, have a price:features issue. I bought this with the TC-TP1 for work. At home I have a cheap VicTsing toner/tester, and it's more capable than this setup for what I'm doing.PROS:-The transmitter is capable of testing a cable plugged into itself, or at the other end of the remote terminator.-Better built than the VicTsing. Definitely of higher quality-Can stop on a single wire for troubleshooting, or will continuously test all 8, one after another. VicTsing can not stop on a single wire.-Comes with adapters for testing/toning BNC cables-TC-TP1 has non-conductive probe tip for insulation from electrical currentsCONS:-This tester does not come with an RJ11 to alligator clip adapter, for attaching directly to wires. This becomes an issue when attempting to trace a cable that you do not intend to terminate with RJxx plug or jack. The VicTsing comes with it.-This device is more than the VicTsing, and doesn't include the toning probe.-This comes with a carrying case, the TC-TP1 probe does not. The VicTsing is only 2 pieces, and comes with a case that fits everything, and the two pieces attach to each other without a case.-2.5mm headphone jack. VicTsing has standard 3.5mm. 2.5mm seriously limits your options.-You have to flip a switch to go from speaker to headphones. Why the headset plug doesn't have this capability built in, is confusing.-Only generates one tone type which generates no tones in the higher frequencies, which makes the tone harder to hear (at least, for some). VicTsing has two different tones, one being the standard high/low alternating frequency tone used on many other tone generators.-No light on the TC-TP1. VicTsing has an LED.-Must continually press the trace button on the TC-TP1. VicTsing has the option to press button, or switch on constant.The transmitter has two completely different button styles. It really looks like it was designed in the 90's. To me, it's just weird.for this and the TC-TP1 probe, it's almost 3 times as expensive as the VicTsing. I'm pretty sure I'll return these and get the VicTsing. It's a bit cheaper feeling, but seems to be a better fit for my needs.

Grandstream products DO NOT have a manufacturer's warranty. Here I am about 9 months after purchase, and the camera has crapped out. I can no longer load the web interface or the video feed. It's unfortunate, because this camera had a GREAT picture, and awesome features.I've spent a little bit playing with this camera, and it's pretty sweet. SIP stuff works great. I love how you can trigger a SIP call from a number of different events. It can then be hooked to an access control system to trigger the release of a door from a SIP phone.The reason I'm taking a star off is because you can't face the camera lens upward enough. Even on a 9' ceiling, 22' away from our front door, I can only catch the bottom 2' of the door itself. No way to see people's faces.  Now, at a 9' height, 8' away from the door, it's easy to see a 6' person walk in the door. The microphone and speaker also seem to be designed for exactly that distance. Speaker isn't very loud, and microphone hears people perfectly at the 8' mark. Any farther away and it's hard to hear them.Unfortunately, I don't think this camera is going to work for us for our lobby. I'd totally order one for home use. Great bang for the buck.

There's a serious issue with these. I bought a set about 3 years ago. I cut my hair once a month. I'm simple... just a #1 all the way around. So, based on their claim, right there on the box, that it will hold a charge for up to a year, I figured I could charge them after I use them, then unplug and store. Oh, no... that's not at all how it works. It doesn't hold a charge for very long at all. So I'd leave them plugged in all the time. Then about 14 months after I bought them, I cut my hair, left them unplugged, and came back almost 2 months later to cut my hair. They weren't just dead, they were DEAD. Would not charge, charge light would not come on. Completely dead. Wahl has a 5 year warranty, but I can't wait for that. I'm a shaggy, terrorist look-a-like. I need to cut my hair. So I went and bought another one, with the intent of having two, and returning the other one for repair. I forgot to send the other ones for repair. So, here I am about a year and a half later and the second clipper set is also dead. EXACT same issues. Wouldn't hold a charge, and once it was completely dead, that was the end. 2 dead clippers.There's something ALWAYS draining the battery. Something is absolutely wrong with the design of these clippers.They cut great, and when they are charged, I don't have any issues with them. The battery thing is really annoying, because it's no better than NiCad.

I have yet to sleep on this mattress, since it's winter time, but I spent a bit of time on it. It's very comfortable, though I think the top needs a bit more cushion, and that's what I expected. It's a pretty firm mattress, but there's no reason to deduct stars because of it. The pocketed coils do exactly what they're supposed to do, and don't transfer motion to the other side of the bed. I do plan to add a memory foam topper, which should make this a great mattress.

I've made a lot of bad decisions in my lifetime, but purchasing an Xbox One is definitely at the top of that list of bad decisions.First, my xbox had a VERY noisy fan. Then 2 days later the Kinect sensor died. Asked Microsoft to replace both. They sent me a new xbox, but not a new Kinect sensor. After a bit of complaining, Microsoft sent out another Kinect sensor. By that point, I was already at my 30 day mark, so I couldn't return this pile of junk, because I undoubtedly would have.Since I purchased mine on release day, I noticed that Microsoft did a terrible job at making sure the xbox dashboard had what I like to call "features". This platform came out as if this were the first xbox ever made. It lacked features the original xbox had. It lacked the majority of features that the xbox 360 had. Things as stupid as a lack of controller battery level. The inability to do almost anything DLNA. The inability to set an auto-sign-in profile. Inability to disable controller vibration. Inability to set inverted look for game defaults. Inability to do one-on-one chat sessions. Inability to have friends in a party playing different games. Lack of dashboard themes. Inability to get a notification when a friend comes online. That's just the beginning. I could go on endlessly about the stuff this system was lacking from the start.Now to a year later, the thing locks up all the time. A running game in the background often causes choppy TV video and audio. Still lacks features the 360 had. It's much better than on release day, thanks to Microsoft's regular updates. Original controller died about 2 days after the warranty expired, and Microsoft refused to replace it. I've played EXACTLY 3 games, start to finish, on that controller. That means that literally every piece of hardware in my box was defective in some way.The Kinect sensor is a freaking joke. I develop software which uses the original Kinect sensor, and it's really a lot of fun. The speech recognition is great, for a first generation product, and overall it just works. But this new kinect sensor is junk. It NEVER hears me correctly. My daughter's first word EVER, was "xbox" because we'd sit there saying "xbox. xbox. xbox. xbox. xbox. xbox.", trying to get it to understand commands to just stop listening or to change the channel, mute the volume, you name it. We said it so often that it was the first word she picked up. What's funny is that half the time she'd say "xbox", it would recognize it, but for the rest of us it would get it far less often. It would take 5-10 times saying "xbox on" before the xbox would turn on. But hey, let's just keep going about this junk kinect sensor. I don't even plug it in anymore. My wife and I would be talking to each other, making hand animations while talking about our day, and suddenly the channel would change. Microsoft added a feature to disable gestures while watching "video", but some moron at Microsoft didn't include "TV" in "video". So, you can't stop it. The controller could be bumped off a chair, while on, and one trigger would get pressed, the video would fast forward, and sometimes change the channel. No way to disable that either. Often the kinect itself would lock up, then cause the xbox to stop responding. It's just so much better to leave it unplugged. But even when unplugged, if you touch a controller trigger while watching TV, it comes up with the OSD showing that it's trying to FF/Rew, even though the system should be engineered to recognize that the kinect sensor isn't there, and therefore not make any attempts to send IR commands, nor show the IR OSD. It's as if there's a bunch of monkeys in a barrel, and that's Xbox Engineering. Then there's a box of monkeys which makes up Xbox QA. Once again, I could go on and on about how poorly thought out and planned this system is.Now, let me get to the games. They are great. I enjoy playing the games. I'm glad I get to play the great games available on the system. I love the TV passthrough. I like knowing a friend comes online while watching TV. There are some really great advantages over the 360, in that sense. But, sadly, I use my 360 far more often. It's just a better system, when you look away from the improved graphics and other capabilities like TV.We have 3 of these systems in our house, and they are all the same. Remember how Windows 8 was a feature-lacking joke? This is the Windows 8 of the gaming world. Microsoft will come back during the next round, but they really screwed things over this time around.This system is, without even the slightest doubt, the worst piece of technology I've ever purchased. The biggest waste of $500. I seriously considered, at one point, finding an attorney to force Microsoft to take this worthless pile of junk off my hands, since I couldn't return it after the 30 day mark. I will NEVER again purchase another generation of Xbox consoles. I'm done.One last thing worth mentioning... The Xbox One utilizes about 80 watts when at idle, watching TV. In my case, I'm running a 58" Plasma TV which uses about 550 watts. An equivalent LED LCD would use 100 watts or fewer. This means that if you own an LCD TV, you are literally doubling your power consumption just to watch TV. In my case, it's an increase of 15%. If the TV is on 8 hours every day, times 30 average days, that's 240 watt hours, which is just over 19Kwh. This is relatively minimal, but it can add up. In my case, at 12 cents per Kwh, it's $2.28 every month just to run the xbox while watching TV, since there's no way to pass TV through while the xbox is off.It increases the average cost of watching TV from $15.84/mo., to $18.12. It would be great to have an option to turn off the xbox, and let it be just a passthrough.

No way does this thing deserve 5 stars. It's a $100 camera. Far better than the $30 cheap-o camera I came from. I don't need the best camera in the world, but I do want something that takes good video. This camera takes pretty good video, though sadly my old $30 piece-o-junk took better video at night. The main problem with this camera is that every street light and car brake light creates a massive light-blur sphere. In some cases, so big that brake lights will cover the license plate of the car in front of you. It's not the best at night, but aside from the light issues, it takes pretty good video.The biggest problem with this thing, is that it's base is designed for a right-hand drive car. What I did is took out the two little screws on the connector that connects the camera to the base. I then turned the connector on the camera 180 degrees, trimmed off some unnecessary plastic underneath to make it fit right, and now the base faces the same direction as the camera. I'm not really sure whose bright idea it was to put so much strain on the camera and base. Now the whole assembly is much more compact, the power plug on the base faces towards the rear-view mirror, which is where power comes from. I tried so many other ways to mount it, but the mount is very poorly thought out. You can't flip the mount around in its stock form and twist to adjust the camera. The camera won't twist that far. The camera really needs to be able to twist 270 degrees at a minimum, but the best you get is 100 degrees or so. It's just hard to get right. I have mine mounted about 8" to the left of the rear-view mirror at the very top of the windshield. It catches everything. I like that this has all the capabilities of GPS and video, but it's still pretty cheap. I guess we'll see how it does in the summer. For now, it's cold here in Colorado. Overall, the mount sucks. Having to stick it to the windshield is stupid, but it is nice and compact. I do like that I don't ever have to unplug it. I think eventually I will epoxy the base to a proper suction cup mount.The audio is fine. Better than my old camera. I can hear my daughter from the back seat if the stereo isn't up.The blue LED light is extremely annoying at night. Too bright. Had to cover it with a piece of electrical tape.It takes a good 30 seconds to get a GPS fix, first thing in the morning.The interface is cheap. Pretty much identical to my old camera.I'm sure it's going to lock up one day, and there is no reset button. Even my old one has a reset button.It's exactly what I want out of a $100 camera. I'm not trying to make feature film in my car.UPDATE 3/16/2015: I've been using this thing for 3 months now, and while I have yet to catch any accidents or injuries, I have caught many police breaking the law, which have resulted in citations being issued. I also got a recording of a police officer misinforming me of a reckless driving law on private property, which resulted in a formal complaint being filed against that officer. Audio is crystal clear, and the video is great. I'm happy with this camera, but we'll see how it goes when it starts to get hotter outside, since there are so many complaints about issues with heat.

We bought this card and popped it into a new phone system we bought. We couldn't get it to work. Contacted Sangona and they said the card was bad. So we returned it, and Sangoma drop-shipped us a new one. We got the new card and installed it in a completely different, BRAND NEW Dell server. Couldn't get it to work. Contacted Sangoma again, and they said the card is defective, but for a different reason.TWO, ONE-THOUSAND DOLLAR CARDS, IN A ROW are defective? Yeah, I don't think so. If they are, then this hardware is thoroughly unreliable and I have no interest in using it in our phone system. What a joke.

There's 8 of us in the office. Not everyone drinks coffee every day. Maybe averaging 3-6 cups of coffee made every day, M-F. I literally never use it.I just ordered our third one of these. Bought the first in Feb of 2011. By April, it had already crapped out. Heater died, would no longer brew. Keurig sent us a new one. That one lasted until just a week ago. Brew pump pretty much failed and would not give enough pressure to brew when a k-cup was in. I'm guessing we ran around 3,000 - 4,000 k-cups through it (I'm probably high), but it seems like these things should be more reliable. We always use bottled water, and clean it on a regular basis.This is actually our 7th Keurig brewer in 6 years. The first were lower-end brewers, but they died within a few months or a year. Keurig replaced a few of them. I was not surprised when our first K155 died after only 2 months of use. Hoping this third one lasts a lot longer than the rest. It really is the best bang-for-your-buck k-cup brewer for a small office, plus it supports a dedicated water line with an accessory tank replacement.Straight up, Keurig brewers just aren't very reliable. I bought one for home a few years ago, it died within a few months. Only made like a dozen cups of coffee. Keurig replaced it, that lasted a few more months. Keurig replaced it, and that one worked great for like a year, then got to the point where it would never start brewing until I literally smacked the very top of the unit, and INSTANTLY it would start brewing. Worked for a couple more years with seldom use, then finally died. I own a Starbucks Verismo at home, and it's the most reliable thing I've ever used. My wife and I use it every day, and we religiously each run 2 pods (2 espresso shots) each. 2.5 years later, we're nearing 4k pods run through it. It has never once given us a single issue, EVER. Heats up in less than 10 seconds, and just works... always. Problem is, Starbucks has absolutely no variety of coffee/espresso, and nobody else will make Verismo pods. It's very limited, but they have my favorite bean in the world, Antigua Guatemala, in espresso and coffee pods. The rest of their coffees suck. Keurig really does have this market relatively cornered, and that's the only reason we keep buying these machines with their endless problems.Buy it if you dare...

Purchased this "gaming" router to use specifically for 6 different xboxes in the household. Being a "gaming" router, I would expect it to properly support UPnP, but it does not. With my non UPnP firewall, Xbox One says NAT is moderate. With this "gaming" router, NAT type is Strict, and will not go to moderate or open. What this means is that it does not properly implement UPnP, nor PAT.

This 4-CD set from Jasmine containis 114 tracks by the group, the majority of which were Decca singles issued from the mid-40s until 1958. Four early albums are featured in addition, namely “In a Mellow Tone”, “Wonderful Words” which comprises eight hymns, “Memory Lane”, and "Meet the Mills Brothers". There are two tracks with Victor Young & his Singing Strings, two with Tommy Dorsey & His Sentimentalists, and two with Peggy Lee. It's a generous compilation of songs by this archetypal quartet,

This is a 2-CD set, the first of which includes two Columbia LPs, namely “Night In Manhattan” with Bobby Hackett and Joe Bushkin amongst others, and the Vincent Youmans/Irving Berlin album.  The latter was originally issued as two separate 10” LPs, with 8 tracks apiece, but two tracks from each was sacrificed in order to combine the two onto a 12” LP, on which this reissue is based. By way of compensation, the first CD is completed by the two tracks Lee contributed to an obscure RCA Victor LP “Dave Garroway Presents the Wide, Wide World of Jazz” on which she was accompanied by Deane Kincaide’s Dixieland Band. The second CD comprises two RCA LPs, namely “West Of The Moon” with Ralph Burns & his Orchestra, and “A Touch Of The Blues” with Billy Butterfield & his Orchestra, the latter in stereo. It’s a fantastic bargain; grab it while you can.

The dictionary definition of a diva is a great female singer, and virtually all the subjects of this compilation merit the epithet. It offers 74 tracks ranging from jazz to popular song by an eclectic but mostly familiar company of song thrushes. plus some you may have forgotten, like Chris Connor and Jeri Southern. Most of the songs are standards, many of which originated on stage or screen, and that information, together with details of the accompaniments, could with advantage have been included in the tracklist. Disregard that minor quibble, because this is an excellent compilation

This 2-CD set offers 44 tracks, including Humph’s early recordings issued on 78s by Parlophone, and all but one of the numbers from the 1954 album recorded live at the Conway Hall. Most were drawn from the existing jazz repertoire, including some quite obscure items, such as “Elephant Stomp Blues”. Others had their roots within the band, with allusions to clarinettist Wally Fawkes, trombonist John Picard, and eccentric saxophonist Bruce Turner. Humph’s strong lead dominates the proceedings, and these are classic recordings which merit their place in any collection of jazz, be it British or more general.

The songs in this generous compilation fall into two distinct categories, to the extent that it’s difficult to see at which audience it’s been targeted. On the one hand there are songs that featured in his Great American Songbook series, and secondly those he would have heard contemporaneously. Whilst no great enthusiast for Rod Stewart, I recognise that in applying his granulated tones to the standards, he introduced a lot of his fans to that wonderful galaxy of compositions, many of which were written for, and featured in, plays and films of the thirties (although you will not glean that from the basic tracklist). I hope this concept will attract some of those beguiled by Rod’s efforts to discover the delights of the originals, although a few versions, like “Manhattan” and “I Get a Kick Out of You”, have dated. On the other hand, the inclusion of more modern artists such as Sonny Boy Williamson, Arthur Crudup, and Howlin’ Wolf seem somewhat incongruous in such company.

This double CD set presents earlier versions of songs reprised by Michael Bublé, who drew largely upon the Great American Songbook, standards that made their appearance in the theatre or on screen, sung here by some of their greatest interpreters. It’s disappointing that the tracklists show only basic information, without the background that helps to deepen appreciation. Nevertheless, it’s an interesting compilation, which includes some selections from the outfield, including Dick Robertson with Angelo Ferdinando & his Hotel Great Northern Orchestra, and the original recordings of “Fever” and “Kansas City” by Little Willie John and Little Willie Littlefield respectively. It also duplicates two of the numbers included in the companion “Inspirations” compilation “Rocked by Rod”, namely “My Funny Valentine” by Chet Baker and Try a Little Tenderness” by Ray Noble (vocal – uncredited – by Val Rosing).

Apart from 2-CD sets, I can think of only one earlier multiple release, namely the 2003 3-CD Avid set, unless you count the 1995 3-CD Claves set (strictly speaking, a tribute to Lew Stone). So this 4-CD budget-priced set is a welcome addition to the catalogue. It’s not really surprising that it’s weighted in favour of Lew Stone (31), Ray Noble (20), Roy Fox (11), and Monia Liter (7), but since it offers 100 songs, in broadly chronological order,  that still leaves room for some less well-known recordings. For example, “Goodnight Sweetheart”, “Love is the Sweetest Thing”, and “The Very Thought of You”, the NMDO versions of which are practically de rigueur for reissues, are included here in alternative versions. The vocals are most extensive on the studio orchestra sides, and some with Monia Liter show Al to have been no mean guitarist. On the down side, prospective purchasers may wish to be aware that the volume varies depending on the recording. Also, Elizalde’s “If I Had You” was recorded at less than 78 rpm, so it needs to be slowed down to achieve the correct pitch, but that has not been catered for in the remastering process, with the result that it’s been reproduced too fast. Against that, the compilation has been selected with care, and includes definitive versions of some of the best popular songs ever written on either side of the Atlantic, which have never been surpassed. Allowing for age and rarity, sound quality is bright and generally very good, the US air check being an exception. It includes a booklet with a detailed tracklist, and a 6-page biography. This is a landmark set, which for recent Bowlly fans will afford instant access to many of his best recordings, and will plug gaps in all but the most complete collections.

Somewhat unusually for Avid, these four albums appear in the order in which they were recorded. A 19-piece orchestra (which included Bernie Glow, Ernie Royal, Bob Brookmeyer, Urbie Green, Al Cohn, Terry Pollard, and Osie Johnson) was deployed in October 1956 for “Swingin’”, an album which fully justifies its title. In contrast, a quartet was used for the February 1958 album “Terry Gibbs Plays The Duke”, with Pete Jolly on accordion (shades of Cornell Smelser), Leroy Vinnegar on bass and Gary Frommer on drums. This may be small group jazz, but it’s amazing how much depth of sound and variety of tone was created. “More Vibes on Velvet” followed in November, and the 9-piece band was conducted by Mel Lewis on drums, who also provided the arrangements for ten standards. I hesitate to describe this as smooth jazz, because nowadays that term denotes bland, which it’s not. Finally, a quintet including Herb Ellis on guitar, Frank Strazzieri on piano, Al McKibbon on bass and Frank Capp on drums produced the 1960 album “Music from Cole Porter’s Can Can”. It’s a lively ending to an excellent compilation.

The oldest of the four albums here is "Dancing on the Ceiling" which was recorded for Decca over four sessions between July 1952 and April 1953. To begin with the trio comprised Red Mitchell on bass and Tal Farlow on guitar, but the latter was replaced midway by Jimmy Raney. "Music to Listen to Red Norvo by" was recorded in early 1957, with a sextet that included Buddy Collette on flute, Bill Smith on clarinet, Barney Kessel on guitar, Red Mitchell, and Shelly Manne on drums. "Red Plays the Blues" was the product of two sessions; the first in January 1957, the second twelve months later, and "Red Norvo in Stereo" was recorded in March 1958. with a 13-piece orchestra.My preference is for the two earlier albums, particularly "Dancing on the Ceiling", where the accompaniment provides the perfect setting for his vibes, which he deploys to good effect in a set of standards. The sextet album is ostensibly under Norvo's leadership, but composer/clarinettist Bill Smith is much to the fore, and the album concludes with his complex four-movement Divertimento. I suspect that for some this will be the main attraction. "Red Plays the Blues" offers four tracks from the earlier session by a sextet including Harry Edison and Ben Webster, and three by a 13-piece orchestra, with vocals on two by singer Helen Humes. Finally "Red Norvo in Stereo" offers 12 standards by a 14-piece orchestra, featuring Helen Humes on 8 tracks. Her vocals have a throaty quality in the middle register, but acquire a harsher tone as she ascends the scale, and it's that stridency which holds me back from a five-star rating.

NOTE: Not for the first time I wonder what Amazon is doing, because if you search you'll find this self-same item with a later release date, and considerably cheaper.The oldest recordings in this compilation feature the trio which featured Herb Ellis and Ray Brown. Three tracks, split across the two CDs, were recorded at Carnegie Hall in September 1952, at the beginning of the twelfth national tour by JATP. Next is the B side of the Verve album of the August 1956 Stratford Shakespearean Festival, which is considered by many to be the finest album recorded by that trio. When guitarist Herb Ellis left he was not replaced; instead drummer Gene Gammage, who’s present on the November 1958 recording of “My Fair Lady”, was included.The two later albums were recorded within a month of one another, both with Ed Thigpen on drums. “Porgy and Bess” was recorded in October 1959, and “Swinging Brass” in November. Arrangements for the latter album were produced by Russell Garcia, who also conducted the 11-piece backing orchestra. Oscar Peterson was a stylish pianist, and this quality shines throughout the compilation. He was shrewd in his choice of accompanists, with the result that the trio recordings were more than the sum of their parts. I hadn’t heard “Swinging Brass” before, and was bowled over by the arrangements, which clearly were designed to complement the pianist, rather than render him subservient, as might have been the case.

Beautiful colors.  Vibrant.  I wanted to get a larger variety of colors for the coloring that we do and chose these pencils.  I do think the colors are nice, I was hoping for more variety, but these were just fine.

This is one of the best resources I have come across for different forms of aggression in dogs.  I foster dogs and you never know the whole story when they come into your house.  This helps diagnose the type of aggression and how to approach it safely.  An absolute must if you work with dogs.

The title states this is a normal sized notebook, but in fact the notebook is 9.5 inches by 6 inches, So it's a bit smaller.  I was a little disappointed at first.  But the notebook is still a little work horse.  The covers are plastic, the binding is covered by fabric so the binding doesn't catch on other things.  The dividers are moveable to save your place in the notebook.  There are little folder slots on either side of the dividers.  There is even a little handy elastic loop on the front of the notebook to hold a pen.  The pages of paper are are perforated.All in all despite the misleading size the notebook is a handy size and well made.

Well received by my dogs.  I have one dog who will eat anything edible, and a few items that are not edible.  I have one dog who eats most offerings.  And one dog who will turn up his nose at almost every food option.  I often change up my dogs diet, and have for years.  Most days I cook for my pups and I add the cooked food with a bit of kibble.  When I typically change up their diet I have one base brand I always use and then I mix in the new bits.  I have found adjusting their diet by small changes keeps them rather excited about dinner, I can't imagine eating pizza every day, I can't imagine my dogs enjoy the same dinner every day.  I'll admit, they are somewhat spoiled, but a number of years ago, my oldest dog developed seizures and every since I'm extremely particular on their food.  Since I changed their diet their have been no seizures.So I wanted to see what Nutro had to offer.  I have fed the dogs Nutro before and it went over fairly well.  As long as the first ingredient is meat, I'm willing to try it for my crew.  The kibble looked pretty good and smelled alright.  The dogs were happy to give it a try, and when we rotated to the next bag, they were pretty energetic about the change.  I like that I didn't have to figure out the mix to change their food.  I like that the food all arrives together.  I like the ingredients list, there is nothing to hide.  I like that my dogs enjoy it.  All around I would do this again.  The dogs appreciated the variety, I didn't have to think it through to much.

Very attractive, non slip, very absorbent.  The mat is non slip I have it under the water dish, it absorbs quite a bit, the non slip backing is great so that the bowl is not slip sliding all around the kitchen.  The down side, I don't know what it is about this mat, but our youngest and smallest dog loves to chew the edges of the mat.  So great mat, just for us this is there is the small problem of our sassiest dog trying to eat the mat. She may atypical.
Smells delicious, very strong, I would not recommend for a small room.  This burns nicely and evenly and the scent is strong but not unpleasant. The candle is beautiful right down to it's wood cover.

It's bigger than I normally use, this is the same size as a notebook.  The pages are large boxes on a month glance calendar.  The boxes are large enough for me to add my appointments.  I think that I like a notes section though to add additional thoughts, addresses, or special notes for the days appointment.  If I have more than three appointments in a day, I can't add special notes for the appointment.  A very nice book, but not practical for every user.
Worked great for one day.  Then it didn't work.  Changed the batteries, worked one more day, then it didn't work. And I'm not leaving it on all night, or even all day.

My old case did not rotate, so I tried for this.  It's not perfect, the iPad fits in the case snugly but not permanently, if my iPad case should sort of flop over my lap the iPad will pop out of the case.  My old case held my iPad more secure in all occurrences. My old case had more spaces to prop the pad up at different angles.  I feel if the iPad is vertical and in the furthest back slot I have to adjust myself to see the screen best.  So it's nice.  It's not perfect.The case is very pretty though. I got the antique globe.

I have three small dogs.  I wash the dogs I dry them off.  I usually have to use three towels to dry all three dogs, because well, I guess my towels stink.  I washed my first dog, dried him and hung the towel up.  I moved to the next dog, grabbed the towel, feeling somewhat iffy about whether or not it would be too saturated to dry the next dog, but no, it felt a little damp, but not bad.  Third dog, same towel.  I was impressed.I washed and dried the towel.  It is really soft.  We went to the beach, one towel, three dogs, and it did its job.  I am really considering a few more towels.  One by the back door for rainy days.  One in the bathroom for bathed doggies.  And one in my car for swimming dogs.

I got this for my fitbit zip. You don't just spend 50 plus dollars on something you wear on you daily and gamble you won't lose it. One - the fitbit really stays on your person very well, wether you wear it on your bra, your pants, chuck it in a pocket, etcetera.  The clip just makes me feel warm and fuzzy.  I especially clip it on when hiking, and if I put my zip in my pocket I clip it to my pocket, in case in an emergency I grab for Chapstick and my zip falls out.

I love my fitbit.  My very beloved pedometer broke.  I looked at the other products offered by fitbit, I really only wanted my steps counted, it seems that a lot of people who had the other versions only used it for counting steps.  I do wish I could count stairs, but I wished that for a day and got over it.What I like, I like the display, not all the wrist versions have a display.  I like that my fitbit and phone exchange info by Bluetooth. I like competing with other people. I workout harder on those days.What I don't like, I can spend the day kayaking, and it sure doesn't look like I did a thing.

The color was amazingly rich and beautiful. I always worry about fade, but in all fairness every hair color fades. This is a temporary color.  The conditioner in the box says it will help keep your color vibrant.  After a week of washes my hair color is still vibrant.  I did go to get a haircut the other day, and they do a scrape test, there did some to be an awful lot of brown buildup on my hair.  Generally I would worry that the buildup is weighing down my fine hair, but it didn't seem to.  This is a pretty standard procedure hair color kit.  Mix A and B, wear gloves, wait 20 minutes, rinse, condition.  The coloring did leave my hair very soft and smooth.  Again this color is rich and really beautiful, it's like a beautiful ribbon of chocolate.

This food is sort of like a compact stew, and all the carrots were settled to the bottom of the carton.  The smell was slightly better than some other soft dog food.  I have three dogs. Two who eat anything and one who is particularly picky. Two dogs devoured their food. One, was disinterested.  One of the pups who devoured his food, shortly later brought it back up. So, I took two stars off, one for the dog who wouldn't eat, and one removed for my puker dog.

I really liked this.  Kept our produce crispy longer.  We buy a lot of fruits and veggies for shakes, and for our guinea pigs.  We use both crisper trays at full capacity all the time.  I hate floppy celery which seems to happen within a week of staying in the fridge.  Other veggies seem to go limp faster than usual too.  Cilantro, Kale, Parsley, they get pretty limply quickly.  This is so easy to put up, and it stays powerful for a month.  Then change out the filter.  I will definitely continue to use this and bought one for the other crisper tray.

This was super simple to put together.  It is a very attractive grill. I liked the grill cover.  It is a snap to clean up, everything comes out easy, for cleanup.  The first time you use it, you get a little stink to it.  I used Pam on the grill and vegetable tray.  The first time out, I made eggplant steaks and grilled potatoes and brussel sprouts.  They tasted great.  The grill was easy enough to use.  The reason for four stars, the thermometer was broken.  It just would spin and spin in its holder, and when I turned the grill on the thermometer stayed at 0, went up to 300 and back down to zero, and stayed there.  So that was a bummer.There is a little drip tray for emptying out grease. I removed the plug and put it in the house, but I put the cover on the grill and left the grill outside.

Love, love, love, love the spicey marinara. My family and I enjoy food with heat. When we buy canned sauce we look for spicey. Just really love this flavor.We do a lot of different dishes that require sauce so buying four pack of sauce makes sense. Four of us like heat, one of us has no desire for heat. So a variety pack is good for our one picky child. It's nice to have the variety for other dishes, and it's nice for a change of pace. My husband wasn't as keen on the roasted garlic when it was used stovetop, but it seemed to be just fine for him baked.They way these are packed, kind of phenomenal. They aren't going anywhere. I saved the box because on occasion my husband and I take trips stop at breweries, distilleries...etcetera...and the packing box fits and protects a number of different glass bottled beverages.

I'm a dog lover. I picked this book because I like stories about dogs. This is charming. It's a refreshing read that makes you smile most of the time.I think this would be a great book club selection. Possibly for a church book group. There are bits of religion but God isn't worn on the sleeves of every character, it's a reminder that he is around us and if you were not terribly religious you can handle it.

We have an adorable 1950s pop up - which is to say it is a canvas tent on a base with wheels. We bought it from someone who stored it in their barn. They used mothballs to repel rodents and other insects. It's a great idea. However, it smells, bad, I can't stand how bad it smells. I can see using the mothballs for bugs but we clean very thoroughly every time we put it away, it is in a garage all winter and sealed pretty good. But rodents love to try and sneak into the camper. (My neighbor breeds rabbits and keeps the rabbit feed in a shed near my garage, the mice are well fed and the looking for a place to get cozy.) we put the mint oil rodent repellent near the camper and one on the side were the mice are feasting. No mice in my garage. I'm not sure where they are going, but they aren't coming here.

Everyone needs bags from time to time. I like these. We were traveling, I like to keep all my items that could spill and ruin my luggage inside storage bags. Last time I went somewhere my dogs medicine leaked, the bag unfortunately wasn't sealed. About 40% of the contents oozed out onto my clothes. So I had to wash clothes when we arrived. Yuck.I recently went somewhere and bags would be thrown about, but I need to conserve space so no plastic tote to separate liquids and spillables. These arrived. I felt 99.999999% sure it was sealed (I have always been a mild skeptic). Nothing leaked on this trip, but my son did put some shower essentials away wet, and they didn't leak into my bags. Sometimes you just absolutely have to know the contents are secure.

In the past I have used DHC cleansing oil, but I felt like I really needed to change things up, like if I use the same cleanser for too long my poor face dries out.  It might be in my head, but I do like change things up.  I like oil based cleaners, I have large pores, combination, super sensitive skin.  The oil based cleansers make my face feel pumped up and dewy, without over drying my face and oddly without clogging my pores.A little bit goes a long way.  I like to rub the oil cleanser on first, then after I have worked the cleanser for awhile I like to add the water and create a little bit of lather and rinse off.  I don't like over perfumey cleansers, this has little to no scent.  It can clean your waterproof eye makeup off.  My skin did not have that painful dry feeling.  I almost forgot to put my nighttime moisturizer on.This is really great stuff.  I like oil cleansers.  They are good for your face, the older your skin gets the more moisture it needs.  I would use this again.

So good for my tender skin around my eyes.  I quite prefer to blend makeup with my fingers, but I press or rub too hard, I end up using far more makeup then I should and it goes to waste.  I have another small brush I had been using for applying concealer, and primer.  When I saw this brush I thought, that is ridiculously large.  Really? Hmmm, about the same shape as a fingertip, perhaps it isn't too large.  The first day I used it it was so soft and just a flawless application.  Now, I love the size.  I love how it feels on my face.  I love that the tip is white so you know when it needs a cleaning.  I love the little pouch it comes in, and now all my brushes are hanging out together in it.  I love that it boosts being Eco friendly.  I'm very satisfied with this brush.  My eyes look a lot better too.  You save money using brushes because you use less makeup and when you use less makeup, you look more natural as well.

I love this brewing cup.  I just do. So here's the scoop.  I happen to have a water cooler in my home that also has a hot water spigot, so for me I do not need to heat water, my water is already very hot.  You get two cups or chambers.  The outer cup is where you put the grounds and the water.  My suggestion, rinse your cup with really hot water before you add your brewing water and coffee, why, your contents will stay hotter longer.  The first brew I did the contents stayed hot for about 3.5 hours and warm only for another 45 after that.  Rinsing with hot water first I got 4.5 hours of hot and another 45 minutes of warm.  Why does it take me so long to drink coffee, it just does, I move around, I don't sit at a desk, I don't always get to it when I want to.  (if you are looking for keeping your coffee hot for up to 8 hours Thermos has an amazing mug that will keep it really hot for 8 to 10 hours, but you can't brew in it.).  So rinse cup and insert with hot water, pour in coarse ground coffee and hot water into outer cup, cover and let it brew for a bit.  Then you take your insert and plunge it down, ala French press and cover your coffee and go about your awesome day.If you are not familiar with a French press, it's the same thing.  Only glass and large enough for several people to have coffee and not at all portable.  The grounds stay beneath the press.I have to say that the metal filter, which I'm sure has a technical name and I can't think of it right now, is extremely fine and very well built.  I have had French Presses in the past or heck even tea balls where I still get grounds or tea in my beverage.  I was expecting some in this cup, but that didn't happen.  The plunger fits very snugly inside the outer cup, as it should, and there is no way the grounds are getting through.I used 4, less than generous tablespoons and about 14 ounces of water in my mug.  The flavor was great.  As for the grounds when you are done, you can compost them, you can put them outside by a plant that needs slightly more acid in the soil, you can pitch them or flush them.  They are easy to dispose of and the mug cleans up really easy and quickly.My only complaint, the mug top is a a rubber top.  The rubber cover that arrived with mine smelled like a strong perfume or air freshner, yeah, that is going to take a while to go away as the rubber top is holding onto that smell with all it's might. So that makes taking a sip a weird experience for me. Hopefully that was just a fluke.  Otherwise I have showed several people my mug and have passed the word around.  I would buy others for my other coffee drinking friends.  It's a great idea, I love it.

I didn't notice a change within 10 minutes, and I didn't observe my face every few minutes, but about three hours later I didn't notice that my blemish was already improving.  No scent to report on the cream.  You can get a very small controlled amount out of the tube, which is great, it blends into the skin. There was a small amount of skin drying up and flaking next to the blemish, nothing a nightcream couldn't fix.I would still keep this in your beauty arsenal for days when a blemish can wreck the whole day.  It will diminish the blemish with out scarring the skin.

We opted out of aluminum and other metal pans, they are difficult to clean and it's debatable if the cooking is done evenly.  So we have tried glass...still not as easy to clean...porcelain...much easier, and bakes up nice.  The size of the pan is great, it's a 15 x 10 which is perfect for my giant cinnamon rolls and enchiladas.  The cooking is evenly distributed.  The presentation is beautiful.  The clean up is easy.This pan has such a simple charm in appearance.The little recipe booklet had a few really great veggie centered ideas.  I was excited for the ideas.  But the size and ease of use really make this dish a great choice.

I actually just cut off about four inches of hair, because it was so dry and damaged, I am sort of a conditioner junky, I collect them like some ladies collect shoes.  I was not expecting an instant miracle, but this is very honestly the best my hair has felt in months.  Right after I cut all the damaged ends off I expected my hair to feel softer, and it didn't. Apparently my hair was still lacking moisture and prone to frizz, I have fine wavy hair, but the drier it gets, the more it resembles a static electricity experiment.  I tried this conditioner and the first day my hair felt soft and lovely.The conditioner itself is very thick.  A little bit, goes a long way.  The smell is very fresh, not overly perfumey.  And an odd side effect was that even my hands felt softer after I used the conditioner (hands working the conditioner in).  I was pretty pleased.  I would use this again.

I would prefer to buy more natural products when they are a available.  I used to use the deodorant rock, then I got a job that required me to move around a bit more, a deodorant was going to cut it, I needed an antiperspirant.  When given the opportunity to try this I thought it was a great idea.  So it goes on smooth.  That's pretty nice, some natural deodorants are a little rough.  The staying power is good.  No wet armpits after walking dogs, mucking kennels, cleaning house and chasing kids.  My only downside was that the scent, was more medicinal than fresh meadow.  Normally I wouldn't care one way or the other, my underarms are dry, yea!  But my husband was quite turned off by the smell, he said it smelled like I had put eucalyptus and vapor rub on my underarms.I liked how it felt.  I liked how dry I was. The smell was a bummer, since it's my husband I like to snuggle with.  The scent wears off during the day, but right after I put it on, he backs away from me.

For using these labels you need to use the Avery website, there is not a downloadable template.  This is not the most awful thing ever as their website is very user friendly.  You just enter your template number and get going. Decide on your tab names before entering them, you can't rearrange once you start, if you need to rearrange you will need to delete and retype.  There are some graphics that you can use, either stock or your own.  This was a fun option, and I spent way too much time looking for the right little graphic only to find that they were really tiny upon printing, so keep your graphic simple and easily recognizeable once shrunk.  I printed a test page first, because old habits die hard, the test peg lined up really well.  Placing the labels was a bit putzy.  To make them look nice your placement really needs to look spot on, and the stick on these labels is incredibly sticky, so if you place them on with all the confidence in the world you might not be able to readjust and get them straight.  I used a heavy tote I have to sit on the folder and use it as a guide on where to stick...but is tuck them lightly at first to leave some wiggle room.I do like the labels, I am pleased with the outcome.  The dividers are heavy duty with reinforced holes.  I didn't like that this was not compatible with my tablet. Not that big a deal, I have a regular computer as well.  I didn't like that I could only use the website.  The graphics were really little, and putting the labels on might be more time consuming than some would like to spend to make them look good.

As an adult returning to school and finding that her mind is not as nimble as it used to be I need extra resources just to stay above water. Supplemental instruction is key.  Extra practice.  Other ways to learn.  I love this.  I would like one with Chemistry equations to practice as well please.  It gives you the opportunity to put your knowledge down on paper, quiz yourself, learn a little more or a little differently than you your instructor taught you.  It is a great idea and a remarkable help.The only downfall is that the paper is sort of soft and I feel like if I don't use pen I can't see what I wrote and if I use pen I make a mess if I have mistakes.  The paper is my only complaint.

The kitties were pretty happy about this.  I have two very old, blind rescue kitties.  And one of them is also deaf.  We want them to live out their golden years happily.  We also can't call them for dinner.  So their dinner needs to smell good to bring them out to the kitchen.  This has a very tastey aroma and my little wanderers come quickly to see what special goodies awaited them.  They are nice sized morsels, and crunchy for that teeth cleaning bit.  Ingredient wise it seemed alright, and the kitties were pretty happy with the swap, leaving behind their old Nutro morsels (a lighter brown) and opting for the Purina (darker brown).

Reviewed by HeatherProduct provided by the manufacturerOriginally posted at Romancing the BookI have had an entire tote full of baby blankets and pillows sitting in my closet for several months. I am so happy that I decided to review the Space Saver Bag Vacuum Compression Seal Bags because they were perfect for what I needed to store away.Obviously I want to keep these blankets and pillows safe because they are my children’s baby items. It never occurred to me to use vacuum seal bags until I received the offer to review the Space Saver Bag Vacuum Compression Seal Bags. I was very skeptical about them. I literally had 12 blankets, a sleeping bag, and 3 pillows I needed to fit into these bags. When I received the bags I was a little disappointed that they didn’t come with instructions. However, they are extremely easy to use. My package came with 3 bags, 3 plugs, and two removable zipper-type sealers to seal the bags before vacuuming out the air. I was able to fit everything I mentioned into only two of the bags, with the exception of the sleeping bag. With one bag left, I was able to fit the sleeping bag and several articles of clothing and seal it with no issues. These bags are huge!I really wish I would have tried the Space Saver Bag Vacuum Compression Seal Bags sooner because they are perfect for putting up seasonal clothing and extra blankets. I am very pleased with the quality of these bags as well. I expected them to be flimsy and tear easily. After vacuuming out the air, my children, ages 7 and 3, jumped all over them and they never tore. As for the anti-leak, I put one of the bags into our garden tub and started filling it. After letting the water drain, I opened the bag and everything was completely dry.I am extremely pleased with the Space Saver Bag Vacuum Compression Seal Bags. I would highly recommend them to anyone. I’ve already told my parents and best friend about them and they are both interested. This is a great product at a decent price.

Reviewed by JenProduct provided by the manufacturerOriginally posted at Romancing the Book I tend to be a bit of a neat freak.  It’s not compulsive, but I do like having things in their place, especially when it comes to my desk.  There’s nothing worse than trying to find something and having to dig through a cluttered drawer.  So, when I was asked to review a desk organizer, how could I say no.20151111_163827The 9 in 1 Multi-functional Mesh Desk Organizer arrived pretty well packaged.  I appreciated that the drawer was twist-tied closed to avoid damage during shipping.  It was easy to get ready for use.The organizer has a drawer, 4 pen holders, 3 smaller trays and then one longer tray.  I decided to take the organizer into my day job since I don’t really have a desk at home.  I was able to get all my pens, highlighters and dry erase markers to fit in the pen holders.  I used the drawer to store a few pieces of candy and then the trays held my ear buds, a USB cord and some other odds and ends.  And there’s still room for more.I like the look of the black mesh.  The mesh allows you to clearly see everything in the organizer, while still looking stylish and clean.  It’s also relatively sturdy.  Unless you’re standing on it, you shouldn’t have any problems with it bending or warping.I like the idea that this organizer can be used in other rooms of the house.  Imagine it in the bathroom with toothbrushes and floss or makeup brushes and eyeliners.  Or how about in the garage to hold loose nails, screws and other tools?  If you’d like a versatile organizer, look no further.

Reviewed by MelissaBook provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookClaimed by the Sicilian Tycoon is the third book in the Criminal Seduction series by Emma Shortt. While this book can be read as a standalone novel, I find it best read as part of the series to get a better feel of the characters.Andros Casstellini is a billionaire. He has the world at his fingertips. He can have whoever he wants, and when he stops a beautiful woman names Lyra. He wants her. Andros thinks woman are only good for one thing and that was sex. Despite Andros’s warped view of women, he has trouble-letting Lyra go. He worries about her in ways he never expected.Lyra Matthews does not see why she needs a man other than one to scratch an itch. She is known as a man eater. She is a beautiful woman on a mission, one she is not telling Andros. She is also very strong, and focused. Nothing with disturb her mission. I loved how forward Lyra is. She is willing to put everything on the line and tell it like it is.Lyra and Andros are perfect for each other. The chemistry between them is blistering. Each of them is so strong and unwilling to give an inch unless they had too. Life between them will always be interesting.I loved this story a lot. Ms. Short does a great job of drawing the reader into the story and before you know it, time has passed. I had a hard time putting this book down. The main characters and the secondary characters are engaging and appealing. This book was very well written. Overall, this was a fabulous book.

Reviewed by VictoriaBook provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookThe Fighter’s Girl is the first book in The Fighters of Absinthe series by Jenika Snow. I chose this book because I enjoy reading Ms. Snow’s books. The second reason is in enjoy reading about hot sexy men.Izzy Castle is a twenty five year old woman who works at a dead end job in an adult toy store. While her life is boring, but she does not want to spice it up by going after her roommate of six months.Brock Larson is a cage fighter working for the underground circuit. Broke is a hot and sexy man who is physically fit. He lusts after Izzy but worries about perusing it. I loved when he finally decided to pursue her he was a gentleman about it.You could practically feel the chemistry between Brock and Izzy. The sex was scorching hot. I enjoyed this story a lot and found it well written, however I wished it was a bit longer. The story seemed a bit rushed in places. The main characters and the secondary characters were interesting and appealing. Overall, this was a great short story.

Reviewed by AndreaBook provided by the author for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookThis was my favorite of the three books in The Vengeance Series by Lana Williams.  In book two, we met William, who was on the brink of death.  This is the continuation of his story.Christiana is dead-set on seeking vengeance on her mother’s killer.  When she is told that she has a new guardian and it is the very person her mother told her to stay away from, Christiana is determined to escape.  William is the man who is sent to get her and deliver her to the Bishop, who knows about the special gift Christiana has and plans to exploit it.  The longer she is in the Bishop’s household, the more they learn about just how horrible of a man he is.  William vows to get Christiana away from him but will she give up her revenge?William and Cristiana are my favorite characters in all of the Vengeance books.  Their chemistry is amazing.  From the first few pages, you know that this romance is going to be epic.  The subject is unique and the story flows so well that I finished this book in one night.  I couldn’t put it down.  I had to know if Christiana was going to leave with William and if they were going to live happily every after.I love the humor that Lana Williams added to this story.  William has a great sense of humor and Christiana’s attempts to get away kept me giggling.I am sad to see this series end but look forward to future books from Lana Williams.

Reviewed by Amy W.Book provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookAuthor Karyn Gerrard brings back the characters of her short story, The Riding Crop, giving readers another look into the budding relationship between Olivia Durham and Lord Gideon Broyles.To get the most out of the book, do not treat it as a standalone read. The first installment is a free quickie read on the publisher’s website. I am very glad that I did this before starting the book because there is a lot of important background found in the short story that will enhance the reading experience.A Riding Crop for Two returns the reader to Regency times where two people skilled in aspects of physical pleasure get a crash course in the emotional side of pleasure. Both characters are strong-willed as individuals; together they provide a dynamic connection.There’s also a sense of drama that threatens their relationship. Given that both Olivia and Gideon have trust issues, these barriers are serious. The heat factor is high, with plenty of creative BDSM bedroom play. That is also where the object mentioned in the title comes into play.Can a jaded rake find love with a woman who inflicts pain as a career? To find out, remember to grab the free intro before diving into the longer story.

Reviewed by Amy W.Book provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookWhether you believe in ghosts or not, some secrets are simply not meant to remain hidden.Author Lisa Jackson delivers another nail-biting thriller in Close to Home. Sarah and her daughters are returning to their ancestral home, Blue Peacock Manor, to restore it to its former glory. Danger is lurking, though, with young women in the area disappearing.Add in plenty of secrets, voices in the night and a statue that moves by itself and you have the recipe for a suspenseful read. From beginning to end, the storyline will keep you guessing.In true Lisa Jackson form, this story actually has multiple threads that are woven together in a climatic finish. There’s also plenty of room to kindle an old romance.If things that go bump in the night unsettle you, this might be better as a daytime read. Packed with plenty of drama, as well as a renewed love connection, this is yet another book destined for the keeper shelf.

Reviewed by JoAnneBook provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookThis was a quick read at just over one hundred pages.  It was a fast paced novella with a lighthearted playfulness to it even though it is a romantic suspense with a crime and two murders.  Serenity, the owner of Mac’s Diner, walked in on a crime scene at her business and then was assaulted herself.  Enter detectives Jason and Noah and things heat up.  Jason and Serenity have instant chemistry and he knows who she is because he eats lunch at Mac’s every Wednesday with his twin sister Violet – who happens to be dating his partner and best friend, Noah.  Watching Jason try to be all business as he protects Serenity at the safe house since she’s the only witness to the crime doesn’t go as planned.  As things heat up in the kitchen and the bedroom I could only root for more.There are family, friends, a bad guy, lots of food, romance and love.  There was also an overlooked detail that caused an almost near fatal error.  There was an anticipated happily ever after with some closure but since there are two more books to the series I can only hope we’ll meet up with all of them again.Kincaid is a new to me author but her books will be added to my always growing TBR pile.  I need to go back and read book one in the series, Love on the Line as well as books three and four, Outside the Lines and Pushing the Line, respectively.  I also will read her full length novels.  At the end of the book there was a recipe for Serenity’s Apple Turnovers that sound yummy so I may just have to give them a try.Favorite Quote:  “It’s all about action and reaction, Ms. Gallagher,” he said, his breath hot as it curved into her ear.  “So what are you going to do?”

Reviewed by JulieBook provided by the author for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookI enjoyed this romantic suspense novel mostly because it was unique. Rissa is a person in a really tight position due to her parents and the kind work she has chosen. Jerah is a detective that was touched by Rissa many years ago, but has believed her to be dead up until now. The woman he knew in the past is certainly not the woman standing before him now. But, he still loves her, and Rissa loves him, but the problem Rissa has with Jerah and pursuing the relationship is one that is nearly impossible to overcome.The story has a few threads going at once as Rissa was assigned the undercover job and has been partnered with a married man who is really dedicated to his family. This makes things a little awkward as Rissa, who is now going by the name “Cindy” will have to make it look like they are having an affair. Rissa gets sucked into Jerah’s mess too. These are dangerous people , members of drug cartels,with hidden agendas and “Cindy” will have to look like a hard partying woman that likes money and sex .As each day passes the tension in the case rises as does the heat between Jerah and Rissa. But, Rissa can’t forget the past and simply can not have a future.. with Jerah or anyone else.One small complaint is that the use of Rissa’s real name and the use of her undercover name got tossed back and forth which made it confusing at times. I thought it was sort of strange that Jerah had known Rissa eight years ago and quickly began using her new name, but then he, or the 3rd person, couldn’t decide which name to use consistently. I guess maybe Jerah used the name “Cindy” so they could stay convincing in the undercover roles they had to play. That makes sense I guess. It was just a little hard to decide which name to latch onto. I finally just went with Rissa.The plot is riveting. By the half way mark I knew I would be up late to finish this one. My goodness! I didn’t know who trust and there are some really wild and crazy times for both Rissa and Jerah. At first the relationship between Rissa and Jerah is in the forefront while the crime is being laid out. There is a lot of baggage and a lot of misunderstandings that will have to be ironed out, but the romance was really great with one very memorable scene most ladies will relate too.I wasn’t sure how things would turn out and this is certainly wasn’t the traditional type of HEA. But, it fits and it worked and even though there was a really high price to pay, Rissa and Jerah are finally free.

Reviewed by Amy W.Book purchased by the reviewer for pleasureReview originally posted at Romancing the BookWhen Emily Jacobs decides to start a new life, she knows that her past won’t be far behind. Yet with a solid dose of newly-found self confidence, she moves on. In the first installment of Rachel Carrington’s Discovering Emily series, the focus is on building relationships. With Connecting Strangers, Emily gathers a support network as she fights to keep her past from becoming her future.As a story with roots in an unhealthy relationship, there is plenty of angst. Emily’s emotions, particularly the feeling of helplessness, are well portrayed without being too dramatic. Since every little girl dreams of a knight in shining armor, the fact that she catches the key of a handsome man with a badge only underscores the importance of good being able to triumph over evil.It is part of a series, which means it comes with a bit of a cliffhanger. It’s nothing too dramatic, but it’s enough to serve as an enticement for the next book. Add in the secondary characters, and there is more room for development.Although the storyline has romantic elements, the author has provided a solid sense of suspense leading up to the end of the story. While ending a story with more questions than answers isn’t my choice, the author delivers the surprise plot twist very effectively.Anyone familiar with small town life knows how powerful a family name can be. In Connecting Strangers, the characters may not share a name, but they demonstrate the power of friendship. Those friendships, coupled with the powerful chemistry between Emily and Adam, provide the basis for this interesting series.

Reviewed by Amy W.Book provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookOne of the characteristics I have come to associate with author Lily Harlem is versatility. Whether penning solo or in collaboration with author Natalie Dae, this author consistently delivers a panty-melting erotic experience.Rule Breaker is no exception.As a prison nurse, Lacey finds herself drawn to Miller, one of the inmates. He’s about to be released after paying for his crime, which means there’s a chance for her dreams to become a reality. She’s spent her life living by the rules; taking a chance with Miller would be completely unlike her.Packed with plenty of kink, Harlem delivers a raunchy read that is pure naughtiness. Her erotic scenes are well developed without any sense of following a set pattern. The unexpected becomes the expected at the hands of this author. The storyline provides a completely new twist on the “traditional” good girl/bad boy relationship. What happens when the good girl decides to be a little bit bad and the bad boy encourages it? Throw in a secondary storyline featuring Lacey and Shay, her cousin by marriage, to complicate matters.Although there were some challenging aspects of reading a story featuring UK English as opposed to the American version, I chalked it up as a cultural experience. It did take a bit for me to get used to Miller referring to Lacey as “hen.” Because of the setting in England and then in France, there is very much of an international flavor to the story that is rich in detail.Never could I have predicted the ending. The author did a phenomenal job of laying the groundwork to lead readers in a completely different direction. The end result is one that is truly representative of Harlem’s skills as a writer.

Reviewed by Nadene R.Book provided by NetGalley for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookI was first introduced to Amanda Westwood and Jake Donovan in Against the Ropes. I was not impressed with Amanda at that stage and as such when it came time for me to read her story I must admit I began this story with a preconceived notion. Initially I thought Amanda was selfish and superficial, even so, as the story moved on my initial assessment changed. It became obvious why Amanda behaved the way she did.Amanda had an independent streak that is a mile long. She had abandonment and trust issues which led her to seek love in all the wrong places. She has a phobia when it came to commitment which led to her breaking up with Jake two years ago.Due to unforeseen circumstances, Jake came back into her life and it’s quite obvious that their feelings for each other had not changed. Jake was determined to keep Amanda in his life, no matter what it takes. The only obstacle was Amanda herself.What fascinated me about Amanda is that she is a woman who did not depend on anyone to fight her battles. She knew what she wanted and was not afraid to go after it. She was not the type to back down from a conflict and she is not easily intimidated. She had a kind heart and was always willing to give a helping hand. However, because she was someone who feels she always has to in control of every situation in her life she became an emotional cripple. This contributed to her pushing away people who cared about her.Jake on the other hand is the complete opposite. He too had experienced pain in his past, but he did not allow it to determine how he lived his life. He was willing to give Amanda a second chance, hoping that she would eventually come to trust him.The interaction between these two was conflicting at times. One minute they were hot for each other and the next moment they were cold and distant. It was good to finally see them getting their act together. The love scenes were scorching hot and sweet. These two literally burnt up the pages.I loved he secondary characters. They added to the entertainment value of the story. I found their antics to be amusing and entertaining.In Your Corner is filled with enough drama, romance and totally hot sex to keep readers entertained. It’s a story of love, healing and forgiveness. This is a story that depicts how the power of love can heal the pain of the past. The story touched on several real life issues such as domestic violence and sexual harassment in the workplace.This is a very compelling read that will pull you in and have you rooting for Jake and Amanda in their quest for their happily ever after.

Reviewed by MelissaBook provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookSweet Revenge is the 185th book in the 1NightStand series by Cate Masters. The 1NightStand series is a series that is written by several authors about a mysterious woman who sets up one night stands that ends with the couple having a happily ever after. I chose this book because I have enjoyed each book in the 1NightStand series and enjoy reading Ms. Masters’ books.Zoe Golden is a yoga instructor. She made a life change from a new anchor to a yoga instructor. While she does not make a lot on money, she saved her money up to be matched by Madame Eve.  Ty Hardin the successful owner of a chain of fitness studios. Ty is very bitter about his past from high school. He is very upset at Zoe and how she treated him in high school. To the point he is looking for revenge. He comes across as a bitter obsessed man.The chemistry between Ty and Zoe is blistering however his need for revenge seems to taint everything around him. I enjoyed reading this book a lot. I found it well written with appealing and engaging characters. At 45 pages long, this book as a well-defined beginning, middle, and end. This book is a fabulous quick read. I will be on the lookout for the next book in the 1NightStand series.

Reviewed by CrystalBook provided by the publisher for reviewReview originally posted at Romancing the BookHeather has been invited to a BBQ.
